best_comment: This course is great if you want to learn a lot about African American history. Because this is an introductory course, there are a lot of names and dates thrown at you at once. If that is a style you enjoy, take this course.

This course is great if you want to learn a lot about African American history. Because this is an introductory course, there are a lot of names and dates thrown at you at once. If that is a style you enjoy, take this course.

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Understanding Race and Racism 001
best_comment: The best part about this course is Carla. She is honestly one of my favorites, if not my favorite professor that I have had at Harvard. To be frank, I was slightly worried about having a non–Black person teaching this class, but Carla is an incredible professor. She is incredibly knowledgeable, great at facilitating discussions, and creates an incredibly comfortable environment in class. There are long weekly readings (think 150–200 pages a week), but the class as a whole is very manageable, and I looked forward to it.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Black Humor: Performance, Art, and Literature 001
best_comment: Great content in this class; I've been exposed to several great novels, routines, and just cultural references in general! Little heavy on the reading but not bad, and great environment between peers and professor.

course_title: Chocolate, Culture, and the Politics of Food 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. The professor is so sweet and the TFs are amazing. Also there are a lot of tastings in this class so if you like chocolate that's a great bonus. Even though there are two quizzes, there are both take home and doable if you pay attention in section. You don't have to do all the readings to do well, but make sure to participate in section as much as you can. Honestly this is one of those courses where the TF you get determines whether it's a "gem" or not. But overall, great class, nice teaching staff and interesting topic. TAKE IT.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. The professor is so sweet and the TFs are amazing. Also there are a lot of tastings in this class so if you like chocolate that's a great bonus. Even though there are two quizzes, there are both take home and doable if you pay attention in section. You don't have to do all the readings to do well, but make sure to participate in section as much as you can. Honestly this is one of those courses where the TF you get determines whether it's a "gem" or not. But overall, great class, nice teaching staff and interesting topic. TAKE IT.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

best_comment: This was a great class! Michael was an amazing section leader, although unfortunately he will not be returning next year to TF for this course. Unger and Stauffer are clearly brilliant thinkers, and the connections and ideas expressed in the class were incredibly interesting. Because the lecture format is essentially just a discussion between the two speakers, it could at times be difficult to follow along and conversations could get a bit off track. However, section was very helpful in contextualizing and organizing all of the information given during lecture. The reading load was very heavy (100+ pages a week), but section was useful in explaining the main ideas and important details of each text. The only assignments in this class were 3 essays, however they do take quite a bit of time to plan and write. The final paper (15 pages) was definitely one of my more difficult writing assignments since I've been at Harvard, although there was a great deal of creativity in your topic selection.
worse_comment: Definitely go to lecture. It is difficult to sit through at times, but it is more difficult to watch online outside of a class environment. Without attending lecture, you will be very lost in section and assignments because you cannot simply deduce what lectures will be about based on readings.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

best_comment: This was a great class! Michael was an amazing section leader, although unfortunately he will not be returning next year to TF for this course. Unger and Stauffer are clearly brilliant thinkers, and the connections and ideas expressed in the class were incredibly interesting. subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: People as Infrastructure: The Politics of Urban Infrastructure in Africa 001
best_comment: please take this class, especially if you need a aaas requirement. the professor is amazing and he is so reasonable with course load. literally my favorite class

This course provides a rare opportunity to discuss a variety of topics and geographical contexts through a single lens, in this case mobility studies. Regardless of your own academic trajectory,  the readings and discussions in this course will be relevant to your work and complicate/enrich your approach to your own study. At times, the course felt like a survey course—taking on themes of gender, urbanism, migration, and environmental change one at a time. On a weekly basis, this course does not demand a lot of work as there are usually only a couple of short–medium journal articles/book chapters to read. Discussion posts are flexible and generative and assignments are not overly long. While I am glad I took this course, I would have a couple of reservations in recommending this class to peers. First, the Professor has a habit of jumping into discussions so frequently that students became hesitant to speak. At times, discussions felt stifled by this dynamic and seemed to drag on despite the general interest in the topics being discussed. Changes to discussion formatting could improve this and it certainly wasn't a deal breaker. Additionally, assignment feedback was pretty minimal and if you are looking for a class to dramatically improve your academic writing, this likely would not be it. That being said, this class really could be whatever you make it—ample opportunities for presentations, wide open essay prompts, and an open ended final all make it an ideal class to adapt to your own academic needs.

This course is a solid way to engage with the current state of arts and humanities across the African continent. The best way to get the most out of this course is to actively engage in these discussions and the reflections afterward. You'll learn a lot!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Black Classicisms: Adaptations of Ancient Greek & Roman Classics in Africa, the Caribbean, & the US 001
best_comment: Emily is a PHENOMENAL interpreter, interlocutor, and teacher.  She is one of the most generous professors I have ever had in terms of the time, support, and encouragement she offers. She models such a respectful relationship to her students; she learned our names at the start of the semester, thanked us for our input, and very thoughtfully addressed even the more challenging comments made in class. The subject matter was illuminating. The profound and longtime engagements of Black adapters  with the Classics brought spheres that are often presented as separate or at odds rightfully together with a richness and specificity that was absolutely dazzling to me in my first foray into Classical reception, and that was accessible. The session about theater, civic responsibility, and participation came just days after the public release of body camera footage of police violence against Tyre Nichols and was one of the most provocative and thoughtful classroom sessions I have ever had. I will be thinking about this class for a long time, and it was the highlight of my semester.

course_title: Freedom Writers: Race and Literary Form 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! you will definitely enjoy your experience! Especially if you are looking to learn more about Black history, this class is for you! Professor McCarthy is an amazing teacher who truly cares about his students and will work with you to succeed as well as get you to think more about the course materials. This class is a must take :)
Great seminar!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: African American Lives in the Law 001
best_comment: Read weekly materials on time, class will be very great!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: The Paradox of the Garden: Good and Evil in Paradise 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class for anyone who has an interest in any of the humanities, and who delve into exploring how the garden can reach into these diverse fields. If you're someone who would like to have a great professor at Harvard, this is also an excellent class to develop a connection with someone extremely knowledgeable, kind, eccentric and intelligent.
worse_comment: This course had made me more curious about almost everything in life; in a good way! It is not your average "Do the readings and we'll talk about them in class," but rather "do the readings and use them as a launchpad to more critical thinking"

best_comment: This class is great! Lynn is the best teacher ever!! The material is applicable and the learning environment is wonderful.
subject: Afrikaans

best_comment: ***TAKE THIS CLASS***. You need to take Gullah AA first which is just as good as this class. Sunn is always very accessible and willing to do whatever he needs for you to succeed. Very laid–back, low pressure atmosphere so that you almost forget about your grade and just want to learn about the Gullah language and culture. I cannot stress enough that taking Gullah was the best decision I ever made at Harvard. Please take it.
subject: Gullah

best_comment: Take this class! Especially if it is your native language, everyone who has taken this class with professor Nneka has come out truly learning and enjoying taking this class because of the environment she creates and you can tell she pushes you to be able to grow in speaking and it may be hard at first but is a great reward at the end.
subject: Igbo

best_comment: this class is a great introduction into twi. would definitely recommend if you want a chill class where you can actually apply what you're learning into your life especially if you have someone to practice with
subject: Twi

best_comment: This course is a whole vibe, combining education and fun like no other. The teaching staff is phenomenal, fueling our passion for the language with their contagious enthusiasm.What makes this class truly special is the variety of engaging learning experiences. Through interactive discussions, role–plays, and cultural presentations, we dive headfirst into the world of West African Pidgin. Trust me, you'll be grinning from ear to ear!This class is one of the easier languages to learn at Harvard. The curriculum strikes the perfect balance between challenge and accessibility, providing us with resources and interactive exercises. Learning West African Pidgin has never been so effortless.But it doesn't stop there. The class fosters a vibrant community of language enthusiasts, where friendships are formed and cultures celebrated. It's a journey of self–discovery and pure joy that will stay with you forever.So, future students, join us in the West African Pidgin class and experience the infectious energy firsthand. Get ready to embrace the language, the culture, and a lifetime of amazing memories.See you in class, ready to shout, "Pidgin for life!"
subject: West African Pidgin

best_comment: It’s a great class to take because you can really develop your language ability in writing and speaking for useful, everyday situations! And it’s a great balance of work for your most intense coursework ***

This course is great if you want to learn basics of how to speak Yoruba. I will say that this course will not get you fluent or close to being fluent, but the atmosphere that professor Taiwo creates is fun, lighthearted and relaxed. He is extremely understanding and a great teacher of language all–around. He's also very very nice, the nicest professor I've had here, and is clearly most interested in all of his students just having a great time and taking away the Yoruba lessons we learn about in class.
subject: Yoruba

best_comment: This is an awesome class where you become very close with your classmates and work together with the help of a great professor to learn about the language along with many cultural characteristics. I highly recommend this class.
worse_comment: Take this but it’s kinda hard and annoying at time.
subject: Zulu

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Anthropology as Social Theory and the Social Theory of Anthropology 001
best_comment: This course is definitely a bit labor–intensive, between reading journal entries due twice a week, long readings twice a week, and three shorter essay assignments throughout the semester, but I definitely emerged from this class with a greater understanding of foundational theories in anthropology and greater insight about how to carefully write about theory and deploy them in practice. This class is a requirement, but you'll definitely come out of it with a better direction of what you're interested in anthropologically.
worse_comment: Make sure you go to office hours to go over your writing assignment with the TF/Prof beforehand so you're not doing it last minute. Some classes can be a bit boring, especially if you didn't do the readings for that day. Overall, it wasn't my favorite course but it got the job done.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Junior Tutorial for Thesis Writers in Anthropology 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class! Even if you are a joint concentrator with Anthro as your Allied Field, this class is so valuable because it effectively gives you credit for preparation for your thesis would you have to do, regardless. Working with a graduate student mentor has been one of the most useful experiences of my academic career thus far, and it is a kind of support that is like no other –– your mentor is solely invested in to you and thinking through your project. If you want to learn how to approach your thesis in a dually methodological and theoretical way, definitely take this class!
worse_comment: This class is essential in setting up your thesis. Not quite sure how people do a thesis without this class.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year 001
best_comment: A great class and solid way to ease into the thesis writing process, without it being too overwhelming. You will ideally get into a rhythm of writing, editing, and reading that will prepare you well (hopefully) for the rest of the process.
worse_comment: Try to get them to structure this course more! It's pass fail, so whatever, but try to get more feedback about the overall structure of your thesis and not just chapter reviews, if you can.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: It was awesome. Prepare to do the readings and a 2–page paper every week, they really do prepare you for the discussions in class. The discussions are the good part! I genuinely think about the world differently now, and can’t recommend it enough. If you don’t have a photo album of archaeology memes already you definitely will after this class (an obvious gain).

course_title: Challenging Collections: Critical Reflections on Collecting Through Harvard’s History 001
best_comment: Take this!!!!! Its such a great class about such an important topic. You will learn so so much.

course_title: Religious Dimensions in Human Experience: Apocalypse, Sports, Music, Home, Sacrifice, Medicine 001
best_comment: This is one of the best classes at Harvard. Professor Carrasco is one of the best lecturers at this school, and I have never been so interested and fascinated by the readings and the themes of the course. I learned so much about myself and how I see the world through this course. I would recommend this HIGHLY to anyone who has any interest in the ways that religion is seen in the world.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: The Price of Solidarity: Value, Sacrifice, Capital 001
best_comment: This is not a class that is history–focused –– be prepared for challenging theory readings, and be prepared to participate a lot in class. You're not going to understand most of what you read. Class is really helpful when actually making sense of the readings. You can get away with not doing the readings and just listening in class, but you definitely get more out of it if you try the readings. You do learn a lot about why we give things to each other, like gifts and money. Honestly, the professor is the best thing about this class. Super friendly, enthusiastic, and great at ensuring your understanding.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: The Anthropology of Power: Sovereignty, Hegemony, and Resistance 001
best_comment: This is a great course! I learned so much and I truly want to read the books one more time and take the class again because the lectures were so interesting :D. The readings are difficult and can sometimes be a lot, and you do have to come up with good ideas that you care about or the response papers, but if the course sounds interesting to you, definitely take it!
worse_comment: heavy reading load, low on assignments
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Science from the Arctic: Histories and Futures 001
best_comment: I think I summarized the main ideas in my first answer as well as my previous answer, but: I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in not only the Arctic but also, in general, anthropology, engaged scholarship, and ethical research theories and practices. This course gave me the opportunity to engage with issues of critical contemporary concern, both in and outside the classroom, and always in community with both my peers and numerous brilliant researchers and community members. (I actively looked forward to this class every week, and each meeting ended too soon!)

I highly recommend taking this course if you have any interest in the field of medical anthropology and social medicine and global health! Dr. Kleinman is incredibly knowledgeable about the field of medical anthropology (he was pivotal in establishing its modern foundations and has significantly advanced through his decades of work) and he adds unique context to the works we read. As the primary purpose of this class is to read medical anthropology and discuss it, I highly recommend doing the readings. Paul Farmer was quite a vivid and talented writer and if you take the time to read his work, you will enjoy it. I did not come into this course pre–med but my exposure to the clinical work that Farmer conducted was quite inspiring. If you are a pre–med, I definitely recommend taking this course as it will push you to think about what it means to provide care.

course_title: Where Science Meets Society: Introduction to STS 001
best_comment: AMAZING CLASS for ANY STEM concentrator or anyone who thinks/thought they might do science as a career. This class made me think more deeply about how the natural sciences aren't at all disconnected from the "social sciences". Amazing conversations with the peers in this class, I loved that everyone was from a different concentration/background and had different perspectives and experiences with science and the social sciences. Loved Anna's small group and large group discussion structures, especially I liked the small group activities for getting better acquainted with the reading before the large group discussion! Harvard NEEDS to offer more courses like this one!!

This was an amazing class! The subject matter really offers everything for anyone, as digital methods are applicable to every discipline. Professor Joy Garza is brilliant and does such a fantastic job of encouraging everyone to bring in their own interests to the discussion table, and this also really facilitates a sense of community in the classroom. Working on a research project throughout the semester was extremely rewarding, and I felt proud of the project I could put forth at the end. Prof. Garza encourages us to pursue research ideas that we are interested in and also provides very prompt and helpful feedback.

course_title: Counseling as Colonization? Native American Encounters with the Clinical Psy-ences 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! It's one of the most well–structured, educational, inspiring, comprehensive, rewarding courses you will ever enroll in at Harvard. Professor Gone is truly an unsung hero in the field of clinical psychology, and the incredible speakers he brings into the course are only a small testament to the rich plethora of networks and accolades credited to his name. This course was exemplary of the kind of stellar educational experience I was most excited for when coming to this school. You will get so much out of this class and emerge all the better for it.
worse_comment: This class is boring. It's 2.75 hours at a time and it's dry as heck. Prof. Gone dropped the R–word multiple times the first two lectures (referencing it in the DSM  – FYI it isn't used in the DSM 5, and massive social campaigns have been done as this is a wildly inappropriate word). All the readings feel the same: unless you're so interested in the topic you want to pick apart psychological minutia, it's excruciating.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: This class is wonderful! Tina is a great professor and the class is very well organized. There’s a fair amount of reading but it’s not crazy, and all the assignments are clearly described and pretty chill. Definitely would recommend!

This class is wonderful! Tina is a great professor and the class is very well organized. There’s a fair amount of reading but it’s not crazy, and all the assignments are clearly described and pretty chill. Definitely would recommend!

course_title: Middle East Ethnography: Discourse, Politics, and Culture 001
best_comment: This course will allow you to learn more about some of the issues concerning the Middle East and also about the genre of ethnography itself.  The texts are a highlight of the course and include some of the most current ethnographies of the subfield. Professor Caton explains ethnography very clearly in class which makes the material very accessible even if you are not already familiar with it! If the subject matter interests you, know that you will be able to fully enjoy and engage in the material.
Great course overall! I really enjoyed the diversity of topics and the ability to build connections throughout the semester.
worse_comment: Helpful if you are interested in biomedical themes around life and death, as well as religious themes of life and death.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: To let some of these concepts simmer instead of being frustrated about not understanding on the first go. It helps to revise Pierce's diagrams before each class (I have a chart of sorts at my desk) just so you can keep up with the Professor's invocation of them. In this way, best to treat this like math, where practice is what helps the formulae sink in.

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: A bit harder than 209a/109a but still easy. lecture note material is very clear, lectures are great, homeworks are very practical, and exams are very easy. overall an extremely useful course with a great staff.  the final project is horrible if you have a bad group though but I guess all group projects are like that.  Usually one person ends up doing way more work than the others and its super unfair so really try to find a good final project group
worse_comment: If you simply want ‘data science’ on your resume, then this class is for you. But if you actually want to LEARN about data science, then I would suggest looking elsewhere. By far the most disappointing class I’ve taken at Harvard. Chris is fantastic, but the rest of the TFs are not very helpful and often make mistakes. Beyond this, they make condescending comments regarding how simple the mathematical computations are, but pressed to implement those computations are just as lost as the students. As a rule of thumb, if the teaching fellows cannot solve the problem, it probably should not be assigned to students. Skip the advanced section too unless you absolutely need to take it — again, an enormous amount of work for little payoff. Simply put, this class is an absurd waste of time. That’s not to say that there’s not useful insights provided in this class, but the cost is far greater than the payoff.  On top of the homework and midterms expect: pre class reading, post–class readings, post class quizzes, post class exercises (that are sometimes broken and simply do not work), labs, sections, and a final project! Overall, the teaching staff has little to no respect or consideration for enrolled students — making this class incredibly stressful when it doesn’t need to be. Reaching out to the teaching staff results in dismissive replies. Classes like this exemplify why a code of conduct/expectations for professors and TF should be a standard aspect of an academic curriculum. Finally, and perhaps most alarmingly, homework was assigned overlapping with reading week, but no TAs offered availability to help with that homework.  This is notable because that means this class violated  official guidelines from the FAS by assigning homework during reading week. If I could report a class somewhere for crossing boundaries, this class would be it.  In conclusion, take another course because this class is a waste of time & effort.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: A bit harder than 209a/109a but still easy. lecture note material is very clear, lectures are great, homeworks are very practical, and exams are very easy. overall an extremely useful course with a great staff.  the final project is horrible if you have a bad group though but I guess all group projects are like that.  Usually one person ends up doing way more work than the others and its super unfair so really try to find a good final project group

best_comment: Take this class!! It is such an amazing course and you have such good conversations in class. You really do learn a lot about the data science and tech industries and many of the ethical considerations surrounding it. Michael is also such an amazing professor. Must take course for people interested in data science.
subject: Applied Computation

best_comment: I would definitely recommend AM22 over Math 21. It's 1 reasonable homework per week (instead of 3) and the exams were super fair– easy if you studied. Dina is extremely dedicated to teaching and you can tell she really cares about making sure we all truly understand the material. Perhaps because of that, she can come across as a tough professor sometimes, but is really kind and caring as a person. Edgar, the TF this semester, was amazing as well– super laidback and funny, and definitely improved my course experience. Since our class was very small (another perk of AM22 imo), both Dina and Edgar were very responsive to any confusions or concerns we voiced (whether about the course material, homework deadlines, or even when we wanted to take the midterm exam); this level of understanding from the course staff made such a huge difference for my mental health this semester :)

Great starter class for anyone interested in mathematical modeling! You get in what you put out, and the support staff was great. Also, the final project provides an awesome opportunity for students to author their own paper (in place of a final btw). Loved the vibes here.
worse_comment: They say that knowing how to code is not a pre–requisite but DEFINITELY have a CS background before taking. I have taken an intro CS course here at Harvard and still found the homeworks and labs way out of the scope of my ability. There is also not too much support outside of classes on homeworks because of limited office hours (but also understandable because a small class means fewer TFs)
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Statistical Inference for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: Great course! Gives you a great overview of useful stats that you can apply directly to your work. Prof. Paten is great and makes it a fun time too. Exams are doable and problem sets aren't too bad.
worse_comment: Take this class! Go to section if you are struggling to understand the content, don't wait to understand right before the exam. The psets are not too difficult if you know what is going on.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: This course is like a math course, reminiscent of 1b, 21a, or 21b. It teaches you all the necessary fundamental essentials to solve ordinary differential equations analytically. It also covers a great introduction to solving partial differential equations as well. Along the way, there is a good amount of code to visualize things and some use of numerical methods for practical ways of solving ODEs. If you have any interest whatsoever in understanding how differential equations work (because you're interested in physics, modeling, or quantitative biology), then it is definitely a worthwhile class. Like calculus, it probably does not matter that much who is teaching it, and the books can always supplement if lectures are not enough.
worse_comment: tl;dr Don’t take this class if you aren’t required to. This has been the worst class experience I’ve ever had, and that’s saying a lot as an engineering student. The only thing I could count on being consistent was the extreme delay in grades and my frustration with the course.	To start things off, Robert created a new grading system that gets rid of the usual numbers and replaces them with N, L, R–, R, and R+. While this didn’t really affect me that much as a student, it was super inconvenient to understand how I was doing academically in the class. From the first day, we asked Robert to release the grade conversion table (that he claims to have had) so we could better understand if we would end up with a good grade in the end or not. Week after week, Robert wouldn’t release the conversion table even as we continued to ask him. Even as I sit here writing this on May 15th, I still don’t have a conversion table other than Robert saying that R’s would correspond to A’s. 	To add to this confusion, the grading in this class was super inconsistent. Robert told us that if we got an R on every question of a problem set except for one R– that the entire problem set would receive an overall grade of an R–. Basically, you can do really well on every problem except one and that one problem would determine your overall assignment grade. This, however, was not the case throughout the semester. There were multiple instances where I would receive the exact same subscores as one of my peers but they would receive an overall grade that was one grade lower than mine (e.g. I would get an R and they would get an R–). There were also instances where points were deducted for a question that wasn’t even asked (e.g. “didn’t answer why ____” when that question wasn’t even asked of us). Our problem sets were originally due weekly on Wednesdays, but very early in the semester this day started changing. It originally was delayed to Thursday because the previous problem set was not released on time. Then the date moved to Friday because of the same issue. There was even a time when a problem set was due on a Sunday because it wasn’t ready for release yet. Problem sets 5 and 6 were combined to help get us back on track, but it was one of the most stressful weeks for me to get it done.With these changing deadlines, the office hours schedule remained the same, however. As someone who relied heavily on office hours just to comprehend what the problem sets were asking me to solve, these changing deadlines created a lot of unneeded stress. I could only attend office hours on Tuesdays (one in the afternoon and one in the evening), so this meant that I worked on the problem sets at the end of the week and over the weekend (or whenever they were released). When problem sets were released on Sundays or Mondays, I was left cramming in the assignment on my very busy Mondays to try and make a dent before office hours. And it’s not like I was a procrastinator; the problem sets would take hours to complete because they were so long and very hard to understand most of the time. On weeks where we would only have 5 days instead of 7 to work on a problem set because of a late release, Robert would shorten the problem set by a problem or two. However, the problem sets were still extremely long and very stressful to complete with the shorter timeline.To add to this growing frustration, there were multiple instances where Gradescope assignments weren’t created until the day before the assignment was due. This meant that even if we finished our problem sets early, we had to wait around for the submission to be opened. This led to a great deal of confusion and stress since we as students maintain very meticulous schedules that shouldn’t revolve around Gradescope submissions being opened so we can finally submit homework and cross it off our to–do list. When our check–ins moved online, this same issue occurred but was more impactful since we were supposed to turn in our quizzes within 30 minutes of the Canvas quiz closing. You can’t turn in a quiz on Gradescope if no assignment exists. It’s as simple as that.Not only would Gradescope assignments not be open for submission, Robert would often release check–ins multiple days late. The way that check–ins 3–5 worked (we were supposed to have 6 check–ins total actually, but Robert was so behind by the end of the semester that we only did 5) was that they were taken asynchronously within a 5 day window. This window was usually Friday–Wednesday. However, there were multiple instances where Robert wouldn’t release the quiz until Sunday or even Monday. This led to many students blocking time out of their schedules on Fridays or Saturday mornings to take a quiz that wasn’t available to be completed. They then had to rearrange their schedule in the days that followed to accommodate this quiz that they should have been able to take when Robert said it would be released.Let’s talk about how we communicated with the teaching staff. Robert chose to use Ed as the main platform of communication, but this was such a mistake. Not only is Ed just an unnecessary platform to use when most classes already use Slack, but Robert and the rest of the teaching staff (except for our Queen Annabelle) wouldn’t answer important questions. Granted, if someone had a question about the wording on a problem set, Robert was decently quick to respond. But heaven forbid someone asked when we were going to get grades back. By the last day of the semester, there were sooooo many unanswered posts on Ed regarding revisions, grading, and end–of–semester plans. Since we couldn’t get answers on Ed, we had to resort to using class time to ask questions that Robert would refuse to answer on Ed. There was an instance in one of the last weeks of class where I asked a question that spiraled into other students asking questions and providing suggestions for 20 minutes straight. This essentially ended with Robert saying that he had made many compromises already (e.g. one less quiz, one less homework assignment, etc) and that he couldn’t just cancel the last quiz. Keep in mind that this is the same time that we all had final projects for other classes that we already budgeted time for. I have to say that a lack of planning does not constitute a compromise on Robert’s part; he made many decisions and would refuse to let go of his original vision of the class that led to us, the students, having to make many compromises just to finish the class. We had to compromise our time and sanity just to get our assignments done.Now to talk about lectures. I can’t for the life of me understand why we spent the first 20–30 minutes of class recapping what we learned the previous class. This was a waste of time and meant that I mentally checked out during class right at the beginning. I also don’t understand why lectures couldn’t be recorded or why lecture notes (or even lecture topics) weren’t posted. There were many days where I was not feeling well (both physically and mentally) but I knew I couldn’t miss class because I would end up behind in the content and would be lost on the problem set. I don’t see how this was the standard for a class where the professor called quizzes low–stake opportunities to check in with our learning.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: You learn a lot in this class. I found the professor to be great at explaining and providing examples. Some topics take a while to understand, and some pset questions are quite challenging, but it all works out in the end. You form a great community to work with due to the relatively small class size. Grading is nice and the weightings allow you to not always worry about what you will come out with in the end.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: THE MATERIAL:– It’s very cool and has many applications.– The problem sets can be really hard, but I found working through the problems to be so worthwhile. Some problems were simply astonishing, in the best way possible. – I became much more comfortable with Mathematica, algebra, and plotting. – We even got to learn about good practices in presenting and in public speaking. :)SUPPORT YOU’LL RECEIVE AS YOU LEARN THE MATERIAL:– Everyone on the course staff is fantastic.– Dr. Iams is very accessible via Ed, and posting my questions on Ed and reading her answers helped me a lot.– Office hours are very useful to attend. Dr. Iams struck the perfect balance re: giving me the gentle nudges I needed to get out of the ruts I was stuck in but still creating opportunities for me to think deeply about and internalize the intuition, steps, etc. around solving a given problem. CLASSROOM COMMUNITY, COLLABORATION, ETC.:– The classroom community was the strongest one I’ve been a part of at Harvard. I got to know a substantial number of my classmates and made some new friends. – It’s no surprise that the classroom community was strong; we all worked on problems together three days a week, and the atmosphere in office hours (where I’d encounter many of the same people every week) was quite pleasant.– The group work component of the class was effectively organized. I liked working at the whiteboards and meeting new people. (The group configurations changed fairly regularly!)OTHER REMARKS:– I learned a LOT of math.– This class and members of its teaching staff helped me become a more flexible and creative problem solver.– Dr. Iams knows a lot about how people learn. From her, I learned a lot about learning.– Taking this class is a big commitment. But it’s a useful one.
worse_comment: Great class –– learn a lot. A ton of components but each component is really low stress.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: I took this course because I wanted to learn how to explore different types of modeling and learn how to apply models to a diverse set of situations. I definitely felt like I came out of this course with this skill set. However, I felt like a lot of what I learned was self–guided. The lectures could be very difficult to follow, especially as they used slides, so steps and derivations were often rushed through. We also covered a number of different topics, which means that we didn't go into any of the models in depth except for when we had a workshop or group project on it. This is both a pro and a con as I feel like I have a good overview of the space of mathematical modeling, but I don't know how to apply the majority of the models that we went over in class besides the ones I actually used.Do note that this class is a fair amount of work. It can replace the AM thesis requirement for a reason. I enjoyed my time in the class because I had a group I really liked working with and found the models and projects interesting. I definitely felt like I learned a lot and am glad I took the class. However, if you do not find the ideas on the syllabus interesting, don't like group work, or are looking for a gem, then I would not recommend this class.
worse_comment: This course is a little chaotic. Be prepared to be lost some of the time. Also, unless changed– there are more assignments (workshops) than the syllabus dictates.
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Applied Linear Algebra and Big Data 001
best_comment: Great class! I found the content to be pretty interesting, understandable, and straightforward. It can be challenging at times, but it is overall fine. Psets are very reasonable, and the exams are too (similar to past exams + pset problems and they give you so much prep material like practice problems + past exams). Eli is an absolute sweetheart!!!! Love, love, love him. Made lectures super fun at times, and would bring in humor sometimes too. He just warmed up the classroom :) I enjoyed am120!
worse_comment: AM 120 is a required course for AM concentrators who want to take the "easy way out." For the most part, it is relatively straightforward. However, be prepared for long and tedious psets, quizzes and exams that require simply regurgitating information, and lecture that is less than interesting. It won't be the greatest class of your life, but it's relatively well–organized. The final is hard, use Matlab over Python (I did Python and regretted it), start psets early.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: See if Brenner is teaching it. After watching one of his lecture videos, I could see why this class is required for the AM masters and appreciated what we were doing a lot more. It's honestly really cool math, you'll learn how to make approximations and make progress at solving impossible equations. You'll also learn why the approximations can be useful rather than just blindly following numerics.
worse_comment: While this class is doable without the pre–recs, they really do serve to motivate the material being studied. This is a true applied math class in the sense that it combines analytical approximations with numerical solutions fully, so if you genuinely like applied math this course is for you. If you don't enjoy engaging with equations alone (e.g. without a word problem) then I'd be hesitant about this course. Overall, problem sets are very manageable so that shouldn't be a concern.

best_comment: Great course that covers many interesting topics. Melanie is well organized and clear in her teaching. The assignments were a good mix of building mathematical rigor and coding. Teaching staff were extremely nice and supportive.
subject: Applied Mathematics

best_comment: If you're interested in biophysics, or generally applying physics to natural and biological systems, this is a great course for you. The guest talks are very worthwhile, and the problem sets have left me feeling very comfortable with the kind of math that is used in this field.

Definitely take this course. It goes much more in depth into statistical modeling than many other SEAS courses so that you truly understand the math behind the models. Professor Demba is a phenomenal, knowledgeable teacher that is extremely thoughtful about what he teaches. This was a great course and I would highly recommend
worse_comment: The material is quite interesting, but I personally did not feel like I learned a ton from the second half of the course (mostly guest lectures).
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 001
best_comment: Absolutely a fantastic class! There is a decent amount of busy work so be prepared to spend time outside of class working on it, but it is not stressful at all and Eric and the teaching team are super supportive and amazing! You also become friends with many new people due to the team–based nature! Would highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Terrible class. NOT A GEM. Take it if you need the physics pre–med requirement but just know that it's terrible and you likely won't learn. Somehow got worse from fall semester because course staff grew overly strict about trivial nonsense. Grading system is still very strange. A lot of busy work that doesn't measure mastery or retention, just how well you can BS. Group work is annoying but thankfully, there were only 2 projects this semester. Some TFs were extremely rude and had terrible interpersonal skills. Overall, a waste of time (literally ~6h/week not including the time it takes to compete all the homework) and an annoying experience from which I didn't learn a thing.
best_gem_comment: This class is SO MUCH WORK! There's a lot of work and this course is extra. Do NOT be fooled thinking that this course is a GEM because it is not. Instead of one pset a week, you have 5 other assignments per week in addition to projects. Three of those five assignments are basically like a PSET just with a different name.
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part II 001
best_comment: Absolutely a fantastic class! There is a decent amount of busy work so be prepared to spend time outside of class working on it, but it is not stressful at all and Eric and the teaching team are super supportive and amazing! You also become friends with many new people due to the team–based nature! Would highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Terrible class. NOT A GEM. Take it if you need the physics pre–med requirement but just know that it's terrible and you likely won't learn. Somehow got worse from fall semester because course staff grew overly strict about trivial nonsense. Grading system is still very strange. A lot of busy work that doesn't measure mastery or retention, just how well you can BS. Group work is annoying but thankfully, there were only 2 projects this semester. Some TFs were extremely rude and had terrible interpersonal skills. Overall, a waste of time (literally ~6h/week not including the time it takes to compete all the homework) and an annoying experience from which I didn't learn a thing.
best_gem_comment: This class is SO MUCH WORK! There's a lot of work and this course is extra. Do NOT be fooled thinking that this course is a GEM because it is not. Instead of one pset a week, you have 5 other assignments per week in addition to projects. Three of those five assignments are basically like a PSET just with a different name.

You also become friends with many new people due to the team–based nature! Would highly recommend it!

Instead of one pset a week, you have 5 other assignments per week in addition to projects. Three of those five assignments are basically like a PSET just with a different name.
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Quantum and Classical Electromagnetic Interaction with Matter 001
best_comment: This class is excellent, but Donhee doesn't require that you be in class or listen and actively engage, you'll need to make that choice yourself. Some students are happy to just listen and learn well that way, some people need to actively take notes either on pen and paper or on their computer. Finding what engagement strategy works best for you will give you the best outcome!
Yes.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: I feel like this course not only helped me understand how electron microscopy works and what can be done with it, but I now have a super marketable skill which I can apply to my own research and help others in my research group. Take the class if you may use EM in any capacity–– you will learn to take publication quality images and the training will be much more comprehensive than you could get elsewhere. The staff are totally amazing. This class is honestly one of the best resources for SEAS students at Harvard. I wish every class at Harvard was like this! There is work for the class, but the fact that it will be tied to your own research makes it fine.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: This is one of the best classes I’ve ever taken at Harvard. Perfect way to start my morning and was honestly the only course I looked forward to every week. So grateful to have met Abdi and Jamieson. They were so supportive, fun, and kind overall.  The class had such a good vibe to it, and I’m now considering an AFVS secondary as opposed to CS lol. The projects were super fun and a great way to explore art overall, as opposed to only exploring one medium like painting or sketching. Perfect class if you just want to do something fun/self–care while taking your toolkit classes.

This is a fantastic course. It is very self directed, but assistance is available when needed. There is great time to work in class, and a lot of encouragement to explore your interests and boundaries.
worse_comment: I would tell them that this is a class worth taking but that feedback is vague and minimal, and there’s not a lot of enthusiasm for your art unless it seems like you know exactly what you’re doing.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This class was an AMAZING introduction to photography. I came into the class not knowing anything about photography to wanting to be a "part–time" photographer. I've gained a new appreciation for the world through this medium. I now see the world in a different perspective because I feel inclined to capture everyday things to really look at them  and see the beauty in them. I really enjoyed the freedom that Patrice gave us in having us submit 150 images of anything every two weeks. It really allowed the entire class to gain their own photography style and led to very fun critique days. I also really enjoyed the history of photography that we learned in both a hands–on and lecture setting, as we saw archives in the Harvard Fine Arts Library, had amazing in–class lectures, had guest speakers like Allen Frame, etc.  Navid was also a great TF, who was very helpful in lab and with any question that students had. This class is truly the definition of both a hands–on and traditional academic experience.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I would highly recommend taking this class if you're willing to put the time and effort into growing as an artist with your peers and be uncomfortable at times. It's hard to take pictures in spaces you're not used to having a camera in, it's hard to share those pictures with initial strangers, and it's hard to talk about them. But if you take risks and open up and buy into the class it can be an incredibly rewarding experience and bring you closer to your creative drive and other artists from various parts of Harvard and the world. I came in with no experience in photography but I had a great time and learned so much and this is a great course for people with any genuine interest in photography as an artistic medium and at any level of experience.

This class takes up so much time but is extremely rewarding. Work really hard first semester to learn the camera, sound, and editing equipment– it will make the group film go much smoother in the spring semester. Don't take the class if you aren't prepared to be editing in a small dark room for hours and aren't willing to work with other people. Otherwise, super historic and should be the go–to intro course for anyone planning on concentrating in Film Production w/n AFVS. Profs and TFs are awesome.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This is a really great class! The structure is very nice, with the first third of the semester spent mostly watching films, and moving to showing footage that students are filming in the last two thirds. It is fully conversational, giving feedback on each other’s work, and thus how class goes is partially dependent on the other students. Be ready to put in the hours, because you will be filming probably weekly, with lots of time spent in the editing lab. It is a very rewarding course, though, to get to spend so much time developing your project. Come in with ideas for your film!!! The class gets going quickly. It is a great class, and it was so fun to get to know people through the documentaries they were filming. I would recommend it to anyone who is serious about to try making a documentary! You don’t any need experience beforehand, though!

I loved this class! Not only did I get to explore different types and styles of animation, but there was just the right balance between structure and freedom so that I could grow as a student and artist. Ruth and Sarah are the best! They're truly a kind, flexible, and engaging teaching team. I found their feedback helpful and their presence reassuring among the chaos of animating. Ruth is a brilliant instructor and has fantastically strange and wonderful taste in animation. The screenings always made me think, as did the assignments. Though Ruth has a Procreate vendetta I don't agree with, I highly recommend this course to anyone interested in animating!
worse_comment: Such a fun course! Block out 5–6 hours per week outside of class to work on assignments and the final project. Final projects aren't mandatory, but I recommend thinking about what you wanna create as early as possible because it's hard to juggle working on the final amidst other classwork
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASSif you're interested in learning anything about filmmaking, you will come away from this class with so many skills — how to use film & digital cameras, how to compose and light an image (with studio or natural lighting), how to build a MODEL, how to edit, how to color correct, etc. etc. but more than that, you will learn so much about yourself and your practice. Joana is brilliant at giving individualized advice and taking students seriously for their work in the most productive ways. I've always wanted to be a filmmaker, but she was the first professor I have had that took me seriously for that — both challenging me in all of the right ways and also inspiring me to do that. In this sense, this course is inspiring. AND it gives you time to just create so much material!!! and what more could you ask for. take it!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This is the best class that I have had all year. It is incredibly engaging, the community is welcoming, and the work — although there are a lot of readings — can be really fascinating. There are three projects — and the deadlines do sneak up on you! — but they are all really fun and your TFs give fantastic feedback. The sections are wonderful and I urge you to go to them as much as possible. They are helpful with applying the readings to lecture. Professor Frahm also is one of the best lecturers that I have ever had and she really applies the readings to what it is that we talk about in class and watch during film nights.
worse_comment: This is not a film class where you watch box office hits, but rather one where you learn to see how film has and does operate as an artform. There are a lot of old films (silent, political films, foreign cinema too), so be prepared for that. I would be patient with the course material, as it can seem dull at first, but I think the lens through which it is approached in this class really animates it.

best_comment: this course is required for AFVS concentrators so there's no getting out of it, but hopefully they design a better version of this class in future years. to get the most out of the course they currently offer, its important to know that this class is completely unstructured, so its up to you to design your own project, seek out feedback,  and evaluate yourself. this class is a great opportunity to get to know people in the afvs department since you're all in the same section, but you definitely have to be proactive about it because there aren't many structured opportunities to share your work with the class and ask for feedback –– its mostly individual work time. so, definitely ask people about their projects and express interest! the one thing i got out of this class was knowing how cool and talented my peers in the afvs department are, across all our various artistic disciplines. hopefully you can make new friends out of this class, be inspired by people's work, and even find new collaborators!
worse_comment: This class is extremely frustrating. It changes year to year depending on the instructor so it's hard to say what the class will be like in the future. As for this year, the class is only designed for a small population of Studio AFVS concentrators. We had group critiques and studio time that was useless for any Film Studies or Film Production concentrators. There wasn't a syllabus and if you asked for any clarification from TFs they would get upset that you brought it up. I genuinely had no clue what we were doing the entire semester and ended up skipping a lot of class because when I did show up we would just sit there for 2 hours and "work on our projects," of which were never properly defined. I can see students who can lean into the lack of structure enjoying this course, but as someone who isn't like that, I really dreaded going to the class every week. I think the course staff was experimenting with an unconventional structure but missed the mark pretty badly.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This course is a truly amazing studio experience, and definitely worth taking if you are interested in the visual arts. The instructors are very welcoming and encouraging of everyones' ideas, and the class enforces a positive and collaborative creative community. This course is the most worthwhile if you are willing to put time into it outside of class—making art takes time and hard work, and it would be hard to make substantial works if you are not willing to go to studio out of hours. This course is a wonderful way to ensure that you are creating art on a regular basis, and gives you enough creative freedom to make whatever work is important and inspiring to you.
worse_comment: Allow room for mistakes, avoid perfectionism, set intention changes.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: really important to be self–motivated! there are only loose deadlines around having things for each of the 3 crit cycles, but you can gain a lot out of being in the studio more, taking advantage of the very knowledgeable and kind and wonderful course staff, and just making and exploring more. definitely a course where you get what you put into it, and you'll wish by the end of the semester you'd put more in
worse_comment: hopefully it will be done better next time, but this course was sort of neglected by everyone involved due to lack of studio space and lack of attention

course_title: Quilting Circles and Assembly Lines: Painting Course 001
best_comment: This class was fantastic, and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone with any form of art background. This class really pushed me out of my comfort zone as a painter, and I learned to think about how the materials and process of production can help craft an artistic message. The teaching staff is super helpful and available, and they made me feel supported as I made artistic choices that were outside of my comfort zone.

This class was a godsend for my senior year because it did not demand an insane time commitment, yet it still taught me new ways to approach and appreciate sonic art. The student group was diverse in terms of skills and artistic themes and everyone was super supportive and helpful.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: A Way of Seeing: Photography Course 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! Patrice and Navid are wonderful and if you put in the effort you'll really grow as a photographer and visual thinker. Don't take this class if you don't have the time to put in the work –– it's too good of an opportunity to waste!

Take this class!!!! I liked the creative freedom on each assignment, as well as the final project. It was very manageable and Ruth and Sarah are both so so incredible. Ruth and Sarah have made this class the best it can be by always being so willing to help and offer feedback. I loved their attitudes and their love for animation rubs off on students as well. I enjoyed the variety of topics and mediums that we explored. Animating can take a while, but if you budget your time well, it is doable! Personally, I enjoyed the process A LOT so it did not feel like I was laboring. I felt a great sense of accomplishment after my final project because brings together everything you've learned over the course. I learned so much about sound mixing, how to use Adobe Premiere, Adobe After Effects, DragonFrame, etc. I enjoyed seeing everyone's creations as well. As an upcoming senior, this class has been my favorite class so far!!

course_title: Observation and Intervention: Filmmaking as Inquiry 001
best_comment: Definitely take it! Julie is a dream, she is genuine, supportive, warm, funny, and direct––all of which make coming to each class a joy. Always looked forward to coming into this space!
worse_comment: I enjoyed this course greatly, and I leave with a new passion for filmmaking I hope to take forward. However, I did find parts of this experience very difficult: some crits during class felt very harsh and there were days that felt quite negative and hopeless. I think a bit more of a supported/kind approach may be more useful for an introductory course.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! If you want to explore a passion through story, take this class. If you want to see the world differently, take this class. If you want a teaching team and classmates who actually want to help you and care about your wellbeing, take this class. What you put in is what you get out, and you can get a ton out of this class. Come and feel fulfilled.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: Modernization in the Visual United States Environment, 1890-2035 001
best_comment: This class is so amazing  – definitely take it! Stilgoe may at first seem to have some controversial opinions, but when you listen closely, with an open mind you will find that perhaps they are not as straightforward as they originally seem. Take time to invest in this course, because what you put in is what you will get out – and if you put in effort, you will learn so much and be so grateful for some of your takeaways. This course was maybe one of my favorite courses in my time at harvard and I came away with a new appreciation for so many various things about history/advertisements/books/harvard etc.
worse_comment: I said a version of this before but I think it's worth repeating for future students. this is a really complicated course and I have difficulty marking it as net good or net bad. I learned so much in it, I will remember it forever (and for what it's worth, it's also quite gemmy). Would also flag that the more you put into it, the more you will get out of it. You don't have to show up to every lecture or read every book, but if you do, you will learn so much more. Ultimately, though, this course is its professor, not its assignments or materials. In that sense, the weaknesses of the course are also its strengths, I think. Prof Stilgoe is SO smart & provocative & at times quite headstrong in a way that really makes you challenge your thinking but also at times can feel like he is being provocative for the sake of being provocative. There's nothing wrong with this because it forces you to think more deeply, but when it intersects with questions of identity/diverse perspectives, it can feel problematic. (For example, him facetiously taking on a sexist or racist perspective in order to make a point about gender or race. He's being facetious, but to be the minority in the room bearing the brunt of that rhetorical point can feel burdensome and deeply frustrating.)At the same time, I think sometimes when I learned the most it was because I had to recognize how genuinely pissed off he was making me and then ask why. I guess bottom line is that this won't be an easy class emotionally/psychologically (especially if you're a woman, which I was) but you will learn more than you'll learn in most other Harvard classes. And it will be a fairly easy one in terms of assignments — he doesn't ask a lot.I would say take it but take it with a grain of salt!! And get out of it everything that you can — including knowledge and including connections. Prof Stilgoe WANTS to help you later in life. He wants to form personal relationships with his students. Make the most of this!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: Can't stress enough how wonderful Professor Stilgoe's courses are.  A must. Have learned so much about so many different things, including how to be curious and how to pursue that curiosity.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Dennis and Julia are the best instructors –– engaged, thought–provoking, expansive in their modes of theoretical analysis, and full of true and abiding respect for the work you do. The course is built around modern cinematic discourse, so having an eye for film criticism helps, and so does being an avid viewer of films –– you will get a sense of cinema as a universe while you take this.
Be grateful for the space and time and budget to create and experiment! It is SPECIAL! This class is a gem in AFVS and Harvard in general.
best_gem_comment: Be grateful for the space and time and budget to create and experiment! It is SPECIAL! This class is a gem in AFVS and Harvard in general.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: It is a great class to learn ideas from diverse perspectives. David and Nick are indispensable instructors. They bring invaluable knowledge and expertise to the course.

This is a great class, and I would recommend anyone to take it. The lectures have really cool physical demonstrations that drive home the concepts. Think really large balloons, ping pong ball contraptions, giant moving models, and more props. It really made lectures engaging, and it was something to look forward to. Qijia is a great TF, and labs will be very fun and helpful with her. Overall, the material is very interesting and approachable. The course does a great job at making astronomy fun!
worse_comment: This course is extremely interesting and fun but it NOT easy! Be prepared to work through difficult mathematical problems (difficult to me, maybe not to some of you Math55 kids) for the psets.
best_gem_comment: Sometimes is boring and not exactly a gem, but would still recommend if looking for an easier physics class

best_comment: This is a great class, and I would recommend anyone to take it. The lectures have really cool physical demonstrations that drive home the concepts. Think really large balloons, ping pong ball contraptions, giant moving models, and more props. It really made lectures engaging, and it was something to look forward to. Qijia is a great TF, and labs will be very fun and helpful with her. Overall, the material is very interesting and approachable. The course does a great job at making astronomy fun!
worse_comment: This course is extremely interesting and fun but it NOT easy! Be prepared to work through difficult mathematical problems (difficult to me, maybe not to some of you Math55 kids) for the psets.
best_gem_comment: Sometimes is boring and not exactly a gem, but would still recommend if looking for an easier physics class

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! A TOTAL GEM! All of the readings and discussions are super interesting, the Professor is incredibly passionate and the simulations are genuinely fun. This class is also incredibly easy: perfect for any humanities kid trying to fulfill their divisional distribution requirements! The assignments are all very interesting and are really what you make of them: they can feel like busy work, but also have the potential to be super fun if you really invest yourself (depending on what you want out of the course.) NO PSETS, NO TESTS. You literally never have to take notes or remember a single thing from this course. Professor Sonnert is crazy smart and clearly very passionate, but also incredibly kind and sentimental. What a great guy. Super chill class. 10/10 would recommend.
worse_comment: Take it even if you have no experience or interest in astronomy – you will learn so much at a low stakes level.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! A TOTAL GEM! All of the readings and discussions are super interesting, the Professor is incredibly passionate and the simulations are genuinely fun. This class is also incredibly easy: perfect for any humanities kid trying to fulfill their divisional distribution requirements! The assignments are all very interesting and are really what you make of them: they can feel like busy work, but also have the potential to be super fun if you really invest yourself (depending on what you want out of the course.) NO PSETS, NO TESTS. You literally never have to take notes or remember a single thing from this course. Professor Sonnert is crazy smart and clearly very passionate, but also incredibly kind and sentimental. What a great guy. Super chill class. 10/10 would recommend.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: This class is incredible. Professor Johnson is awesome; he's approachable, knowledgeable, and very skilled at communicating concepts. This class is primarily composed of collaborative worksheets which makes for a very enjoyable and enlightening time if you are with a group that you love. Because of this, I highly recommend taking this class with friends. The homeworks are slightly tedious (mostly just due to my inexperience with LaTeX) but very rewarding in terms of generating a strengthened understanding of concepts as well as the skill of working with LaTeX.The grading is very fair and lenient and it is certainly possible to get an A even without the most advanced background in astrophysics. I **highly** recommend this class to anybody, even those who don't plan to study astrophysics.
worse_comment: This course is not a lecture–based course. It is incredibly hands on. The majority of class time is spent working on worksheets in groups at the various chalkboards scattered around the room, and most of the learning that goes on in this course comes from working through these worksheets. The point of this is to teach you not only some of astronomy's foundational concepts, but also how to think like an astronomer. You probably don't have a lot of experience with this, so know that it is normal to struggle in the beginning, and to not know how to approach problems. You will build intuition as time goes on, you just have to buy in and stick to it.
subject: Astronomy

course_title:
The Unity of Science: From the Big Bang to the Brontosaurus
and Beyond 001
best_comment: This class is great if you want to learn more about various science phenomena. The staff are amazing and very helpful. Professor Irwin is an amazing professor and the TFs were just as amazing. take this class if you want to learn really cool stuff. ***
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: I'm super proud of my thesis, and I think it gave me a much more accurate window into what being a professional astronomer entails. However, the class itself isn't the most well structured, so it's really important to find a thesis advisor who is supportive!!
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: All astro concentrators should take this class! The content feels super useful and applicable to astronomy, and the assignments are super chill. The small size of the class made the learning feel very personalized, and Edo and Marissa (our amazing TF) were always available to help. Also there's a FREE TRIP TO ARIZONA!!!!! You literally get to observe in the mountains for 3 days –– it's so much fun! The final project is great too –– you get to analyze all the data you just collected (on the FREE trip to Arizona) using the tools you were taught and write up a report that feels like a culmination of all the work in the class. I cannot recommend this class enough!
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Definitely a great learning experience, but be prepared to set aside 20+ hours a week during midterm/reading period. There are 2 20+ papers that you'll write for each project, and they're usually due right after the final presentations so be expected to allocate a lot of time for that. This class also goes on a trip to see the Bell Horn which was pretty cool.
worse_comment: The class workload should NOT be underestimated. This class is literally insane. You write TWO twenty page research papers that often go like 10–20 pages over 20 pages, and there’s not a lot of support along the way. I think it’s definitely worth it, but be prepared for a LOT of hard work that can feel hard, directionless, and frustrating.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: If this course is offered like it was this year, know that it is AT 9 AM IN THE QUAD. Let this sink in because it is not trivial. Maybe you can do it on the first few weeks of the semester. But near the second half? That's a struggle my friend. Aside from that, Lars lectures in a fast–paced, ultra–monotonic way that puts you to sleep faster than relaxing lo–fi bedtime sounds will. And there are no lecture notes but the psets rely heavily on things said in lecture, so be prepared to write down everything mentioned in lecture in full detail. Aside from that, this class is basically the only one in the university that teaches fluids at all, and it does give an excellent, rigorous treatment of it as long as you are able to withstand the early morning and the dull lecturing. I had an excellent time in the course and am happy to recommend it to anyone who wants to learn fluids really well and is a morning person.
Good class with a wide coverage of ISM. Introduction class to astrochemistry. Assignments are heavy in this class. The lectures are friendly and not condensed.
worse_comment: You will learn a lot about the ISM in this class, but you will also likely waste a significant amount of your time on assignments that don't teach you very much.

best_comment: The course is very low stakes. The readings are not demanding. It is definitely worth taking the course to understand funding and grants, the peer review process, the ethical side of research in astronomy, and so on. Especially if you are considering a career in academia, these topics are extremely important and relevant, and this class is great way to be exposed to them.

This was a good class overall. As for the class lectures, I personally did not feel like I gained a deep understanding of tissue engineering. Lectures sometimes felt dry and only briefly covered various aspects of the field without going into depth into any of them. However, I did enjoy the weekly journal club assignments, since they forced us to not just read landmark papers in the field but also think critically about them. Professor Mooney also really cares about the class and takes student feedback into account.I will say that the lab was definitely the highlight of this class: Melissa and Avery really want you to succeed and create an environment where you feel safe asking questions and learning important/employable wet lab skills. If you have limited wet lab experience, I highly recommend doing the lab — you learn the very basics (filtering media, culturing/passaging cells) as well as more advanced techniques (3D cell culture and modeling angiogenesis). Melissa and Avery also mentor you one–on–one every week throughout the entire scientific process, from developing a good scientific question/hypothesis to running your experiments to analyzing your data. Be prepared to spend up to 10 hours in the lab each week if you really want to get the most out of this class, but it's a rewarding experience like no other!
worse_comment: Easier than other classes in SEAS if you are required to take them, but you won't learn much and will spend some time doing busywork. The slides were very out of date and not didactic. This course was incredibly disappointing, especially given how prolific in the field Dave is, it was so poorly organized and so low effort and I left this class  having learned nothing.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: Jia is one of the best professors I have. He is very direct and caring. He wants you as an undergraduate to do well.  He is very practical in the information in his lectures and the scope of what he is talking about. Phenomenal course.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: This class covers a super cool array of topics – mostly whatever Maurice Smith is interested in. Professor Smith is super smart and it's really cool to learn from him. The class is super disorganized and assignments get graded extremely late (last week of classes) months after being turned in, instructions for presentations and other assignments were released super late and were unclear, class often started 10 minutes late and ended 20 minutes late, etc. However, this class is still worth taking. It's what a freshman seminar should be – a Professor talking about all the topics he's interested in with assignments once every two weeks.
worse_comment: Stay on top of homework assignments from an early time. Attempt all problems before going to office hours.

best_comment: worth taking if you want a good survey literature class in genomics..workload is not too bad. the class is primarily composed of BIG graduate students which you should know. also, it tends to be a bit intense in terms of attendance and speaking up contributions
subject: Biophysics
