best_comment: Keep up with the material and make sure you understand each slide, try completing assignments on your own before reaching out for solutions and take advantage of office hours!
subject: Biostatistics

course_title: Introduction to Data Structures and Algorithms 001
best_comment: I love Georg! He's a super engaging instructor and his assignments are the perfect difficulty for learning. The content might be too basic if you have already taken a few undergraduate courses in algorithms and numerical analysis, but it can also be a nice refresher on how to prove correctness and runtime for various algorithms. Also, Georg asks many advanced questions in class so if you have prior experience you can flex on everyone else with your knowledge ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)
subject: Biostatistics

course_title: Principles and Advanced Topics in Clinical Trials 001
worse_comment: No comments.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: While this class focuses less on the practical implementation of survival analysis, it's a great introduction to general methods and the theory that justifies them. The theory part of the class is presented clearly so that's it's not overwhelming, even if you've never seen martingales before
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: This class was absolutely fantastic; Jeff is a great lecturer and is clearly interested in effective pedagogy and student learning. The assignments are tough and can be time consuming, but you do learn a lot by doing them.
Excellent class and primer on genomics. Highly recommend for anyone in biological sciences.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class for non–computational students. It was really difficult to complete the homework sets as the lecture content did not prepare us for doing the homework. You need to have a solid understanding of python.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: Excellent class and primer on genomics. Highly recommend for anyone in biological sciences.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class for non–computational students. It was really difficult to complete the homework sets as the lecture content did not prepare us for doing the homework. You need to have a solid understanding of python.
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: As someone concentrating in a field that has very little in common with Celtic folk/myth, I believe that this is one of the most important and worthwhile courses I've taken during my time at Harvard. I have grown so much as a writer and as a critical/analytical thinker. The class readings and discussions were some of the most fascinating and thought–provoking of my college career.Additionally, Professor Sumner is without a doubt one of most remarkable scholars and teachers I've ever worked with. She cares so deeply about her students and about the subject matter.  She is also one of (if the *the*) foremost experts in her field within Celtic Studies—learning from someone like her is one of those "only at Harvard" opportunities. This course reminded me why I love learning so much.I would recommend that you take advantage of all the resources and opportunities that come with this class. Go to office hours. Read some of the optional readings. Chat with the grad students. Participate in class. Engage deeply and critically with the course material. You will take so much away from this course (and have so much fun) if you really dive into the readings and stay curious.I truly believe every individual would be better off for taking this class and for learning from someone like Professor Sumner. I think our world would be better off if our future leaders took part in a course like this. I wholeheartedly recommend Celtic 106 to any and all prospective enrollees—you will not regret it. You will become a better student, thinker, and person. You will engage with absolutely fascinating material and learn from one of the best (in every sense of the word) professors at this institution. This class is the transformative Harvard College experience we were promised; courses like Celtic 106 are the reason I came to Harvard in the first place.

course_title: The Mabinogion: Stories from Medieval Wales 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. This is easily one of the best classes I've ever taken at Harvard! I wish I had taken more classes from the Celtic Department! Professor McKenna is fantastic. She is incredibly kind and thoughtful. She is also a great teacher. The Celtic Department is amazing! I learned so much and had a great time in this course. The material is unique and fascinating. I guarantee you'll enjoy the course and learn a lot! I cannot say enough good things about Professor McKenna, Lorena and this course!

course_title: Research for Credit in Chemical and Physical Biology 001
best_comment: It's going to be a great class! As long as you choose your lab and project wisely, and communicate with your mentor regarding each other's expectations, you should have a great time expressing your creativity and working towards tangible progress in your field. It's very rewarding to see the fruits of your labor with the hours you'll put in during this course! I encourage others to take this course (or invest similar time into their research) as early as possible. It's a huge leg–up to your research experience and, if applicable, thesis progress to get into the lab early and start optimizing your workflow and focusing your long–term goals.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: I learned so much from doing a thesis, and at the end it was very fulfilling. But you should only do a thesis if you are absolutely sure that you want to – it’s not worth it just for an honors designation on your diploma. Also, don’t save all of your writing until the end. Start as soon as you can so that you are confident your final submission is everything you want it to be.
worse_comment: I would think very hard about writing a thesis. It can be a formative scientific experience, but it is time–consuming, stressful, and downright difficult to complete.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: Overall, Chem 20 was a good class! That said, I would recommend it with reservations. Here is everything you need to know:First, what should you take, Chem 17 or Chem 20? Chem 20 is definitely a harder course based on looking at the Chem 17 problem sets and exams and talking to many people taking Chem 17. One main difference between the courses is that Chem 20 teaches organic synthesis, which is a pretty challenging skill. For context, most people I know didn’t get a single synthesis problem on the exams fully right until the way end of the semester. That said, once you get the hang of synthesis, it is much more enjoyable than arrow–pushing mechanisms, which is the focus of Chem 17/27. Another major difference is that Chem 20 has lab while Chem 17 does not. The lab was probably my least favorite part of Chem 20 just because it is so long (4 hours at night) and very tedious, but you have to do lab in Chem 27 anyway, so lab should not be a reason to avoid Chem 20. A third major difference is that the problem sets in Chem 17 are pass/fail, while the problem sets in Chem 20 are not. That said, there are so many bonus points on problem sets in Chem 20 that you can easily get 100% if you put in the work. Most people I know got 100% in the problem set portion of the grade, so don’t worry about this portion of the course. A fourth major difference is the vibe of the course. The TFs, PSLs, and lead instructor of Chem 20 are way more supportive than in Chem 17 based on what I have heard. Everyone wants you to succeed and will help you as much as you want, which makes a challenging subject like Organic Chemistry much more enjoyable. Fifth, the exams in Chem 20 are apparently much more fair than in Chem 17. Don’t get me wrong, you have to spend a LOT of time studying, but putting in the work will pay off, which is really rewarding. I have not heard the same thing about the Chem 17 exams, which are apparently are intended to trick you. Finally, the grading curve in Chem 20 is slightly better than Chem 17, but both grading curves are not particularly generous. A big difference, though, is that in Chem 20 the grading curve is fixed at the start of the semester, while the Chem 17 grading curve changes depending on how students are doing. As a result, Chem 17 is much more competitive because you are competing against your classmates. Just for reference, in spring 2023, you needed a 90 to get in A in Chem 20 and an 85 to get an A–.To succeed in Chem 20, here is my advice. First, stay on top of the content as it is taught. This class moves really fast and it is cumulative, so do the purple book practice problems for each week’s module. YOU WON’T HAVE TIME TO LEARN ALL OF THE REQUIRED MATERIAL THE WEEK BEFORE THE TEST. Each exam is cumulative, so make sure you stay on top of the previous units as well. Second, go to office hours/helproom to work on the problem set. While there, really focus not just on the answers but on learning the material. The main factor that determines your grade in chem 20 is the exams, so treat the problem sets as a learning experience, not as required assignments that matter a lot on their own. The TFs are fantastic, so don’t be afraid to ask them questions. Third, start studying for the exams a least a week in advance. Often, you will not realize just how much material has been covered until you sit down and start working through practice problems. The exams are pretty challenging, but for the most part are fair. Make sure to study the stuff you think you are not as good at, even if you don’t think it's gonna show up on the test (because it probably will). Fourth, GO TO ALL OF THE LECTURES! Unlike LS1a and other intro classes, the lectures are not required/there are no poll questions to assess participation. But, that's because the instructors know they don’t need to require people to come since the lectures are useful on their own. If you don’t come to lecture, you will be in big trouble for the exams. Fifth, don’t feel obligated to go to section every week since they are optional. Also, if other TFs are better, just go to their section instead of your own. Use section to help YOU; I often didn’t go and still got an A in the class. Finally, Orgo lab is not fun, but it won’t matter much for your grade, so just try your best and it will be fine, even if it doesn’t feel that way when going through the class. Good luck!
worse_comment: Chem 20 is an excellent introduction to organic chemistry, and it is great for anyone looking to gain some chemical intuition! The lectures are very well structured and organized, and the course flows pretty logically from one topic to another. From my perspective now after taking the course, I believe that I not only learned many common reactions in organic chemistry, but I also learned many fundamental principles underlying organic chemistry that are more broadly applicable. Do be warned – this course is very time–consuming! Between the million practice problems, problem sets, 3 exams, and lab (4 hours every other week + lab reports!), this class is quite the time sink! If you have other demanding classes in your schedule, you will definitely have to carefully manage your time so you can finish your assignments (and eat and sleep). I believe the time commitment is worth it, but you will need to make your decision based on your schedule.Course logistics/advice: in my experience, you learn about 60% of the material needed for psets/exams in the lectures, and the other 40% you learn from the Aktiv chemistry problems (quick conceptual quizzes), the practice problem book, and the psets. Although the practice problems are technically optional, it is very very highly recommended to do the problems because there are a few advanced applications or exceptions to the rules you learn in class that are covered in them (which is a little frustrating but since chemistry is very much learned through practice and pattern recognition, it is necessary to do practice problems anyway). Start early on the psets and go to office hours early in the week – it will save you the stress of being in office hours for hours the day it is due (speaking from personal experience lol). Also, start studying for the exams early and try to stick with Amy's study plan as close as you can – I crammed for the last two midterms did okay, but then I followed her plan more closely for the final and did much better!
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: I realized that CHEM 17 runs through 2 semesters worth of organic chemistry content, with CHEM 27 being biochemistry along with a few leftovers of organic chemistry (like radicals and lab techniques like spectrometry, spectroscopy, chromatography, etc.)People taking CHEM 27 either need it for the premed requirement, the concentration requirement, or both. I highly recommend the 17/27 series. It counts for 2 semesters of organic chemistry and one semester of biochem combined into only 2 semesters. CHEM 17 is where most of the heavy work is done (e.g. learning the basics of aldol, retroaldol, Claisen condensations, nucleophilicity and electrophilicity, iminium condensation, hemiacetal/ketal formation, orbitals). CHEM 27 just takes that knowledge and applies it to biology. Learning the amino acids isn't bad at all. The mechanisms are also simple to remember after enough practice.It is crucial to know the chemical reasoning behind mechanisms. Remembering key terms like eclipsed/staggered, R and S stereocenters, hyperconjugation, antiperiplanar, etc. really comes in handy. It will help understand why and how reactions happen, as well as the requirements for E1cb, decarboxylation, and more. The slides at the end of lectures with the diagrams on enzymes, what Km is, what the properties of inhibitors are, and what happens in the electron transport chain of metabolism, for instance, will show up on sets and exams.Psets are graded holistically which is amazing. I didn't have to stress about doing a mechanism perfectly (I didn't have to worry about getting a point off for forgetting a formal charge, for instance), and I would go to office hours instead to ask questions about chemical explanations behind a mechanism or for tips on how to approach a question rather than just to check my work (which is often done in other classes).Exams are alright. The real ones are not as bad as the practice exams, but the practice exams have highlighted for me before what content I should look at again. On the actual exams, there are some questions about the biological/chemical reasoning for things, and although individually they might be worth at most 5 points, they add up to make a good portion of the grade. Thus, knowing how to explain the rationale for a mechanism is needed.Lab is chill. They made it so much better this year (only 2 hours 45 minutes instead of 4 hours in previous years). I think they want to distribute the 9 labs between CHEM 17 and CHEM 27, though, so that will be interesting to see. Some TFs are stricter than others, but overall it was fun. Make sure to hydrate well before going in because there will be many smells that could be hard to take in without having drunk water before. Also be very careful as there are so many dangerous chemicals (they indicate them in the manual beforehand). GO to office hours to check your answers for the lab report because these are not holistic, but usually they are not too strict grading either.Section handouts are sooo helpful. I still think watching the lectures and going through lecture notes are the essentials to doing well, but if you missed something (maybe you didn't think it was that important) and it is in the section handouts, take note of it!
worse_comment: I can say wholeheartedly that this was the worst course I have taken in my entire academic career. Never have I seen such a potentially interesting topic be absolutely butchered by the execution of a course. So much time is spent on memorizing pathways with no underlying intuition for why chemical events happen or how we can use chemistry to our advantage. The staff is too lazy to design a curriculum that is centered around developing problem solving skills or logical reasoning and thus, your success in this class will be a pure function of your ability to memorize even the most peripheral reactions from lecture. Like most high school classes, tests are completely closed book to introduce artificial difficulty, because otherwise, anyone with an IQ above 70 could pattern match their way to an A in this class. By nature of its ridiculous design, all knowledge I have gained from this class will be gone by the start of the next fall semester,  primarily due to the faults of an apathetic and incompetent course staff, deliberately wasting the precious time of their students. Before you enroll in this course, deeply consider the amount of time and money that will be spent for the little to no reward that you will receive in knowledge or new skillsets. Be prepared for endless amounts of mindless memorization and regurgitation. Chem 27 is a truly pathetic attempt at an organic chemistry course, and all those associated should frankly be embarrassed.
subject: Chemistry

subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This course underwent such an improvement! I felt like the difficulty was adequate and I learned a lot about inorganic chem and wasn't stressed about almost failing the class. There was a syllabus and office hours this time! (A really low bar....but based off the q guide reviews from last year, a necessary one). The TFs were great this year though, super helpful, returned psets and exams very fast, and wrote the psets and exams to be of an appropriate difficulty level. It is now definitely possible to succeed in the course (especially if you've already taken chem20/30–it's definitely less time intensive than those) and I'm so glad I didn't take it P/F. You obviously have to study, it's not a gem or easy A class, but it's definitely possible to do well if you put in some work. It's a great alternative to PS11 and there's no lab. The grading on the psets was great and the exams were sometimes good, sometimes not so good, but the TFs caught on to the main issue with exams which was just time (too many problems for 75 min). This course no longer sucks!! yay!! I was genuinely scared to take this class after reading last year's q guide reviews but I am so happy to say that there have been genuine improvements in the course! Prof Mason does lecture in a bit of a monotone voice sometimes so good to know: your mind may wander to anything but inorganic chem during lecture but they're recorded and section is great review so it's not too big of a deal. Don't be scared–take this class (maybe even over PS11) work hard, and you'll be fine.
worse_comment: I would say make sure to do as many practice problems as you can and try not to fall behind. This course builds a lot on previous material as time goes on, and if you don't fully understand material at beginning of course it could hurt you in the future.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This is a great class, you definitly get independent in lab and it is a great opportunity to improve your lab skills –– you'll actually feel confident at the end. Defninitly make use of the TFs and speak to them , and go to DC!! One of my fav classes as a chem concentrator. Also it's super fun if you get along with your groupmates
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This is a great class, you definitly get independent in lab and it is a great opportunity to improve your lab skills –– you'll actually feel confident at the end. Defninitly make use of the TFs and speak to them , and go to DC!! One of my fav classes as a chem concentrator. Also it's super fun if you get along with your groupmates
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Chem 145 is so great!! If you need to take an experimental lab course, I could not recommend this class enough. Dilek is super great (she honestly feels like our lab mom most of the time) and she makes the 5 hours as painless as she can. She understands that we dedicate a lot of time to this class, so post–labs are super short and simple, and she always checks in to make sure we get sufficient breaks. The actual lab part was also really fun because we got to do a lot of these experiments on our own terms without having to worry about "messing up" in fears of grade repercussions (at least, no major mess ups). I learned a lot of new research techniques and this class made me appreciate chemistry again!

I learned so much in this class because it was quite different chemistry from standard organic chemistry. It's definitely the single class that I learned the most information in and it made me more interested in organometallic chemistry. The professor and teaching staff was so nice and willing to answer any question you have.  Really good at teaching the topics in a way that's easy to understand even if you had no knowledge of organometallic. Professor Liu is also really responsive to feedback as after the midterm evaluations, he made minor adjustments to the class to address people's feedback. The assignments for the class were really manageable and the professor is lenient and understanding if you needed extensions. This class taught me more chemistry than all of the previous chemistry courses I've taken and the way that things are taught, I'm actually retaining the information unlike some of my other courses, where I forget everything after. Definitely take the class if you can.
worse_comment: Lectures were very difficult to follow. However, I'm sure Richard would aim to improve this class for next year. There are no psets, but this made grasping the content quite difficult. My recommendation would be to give out short psets every week covering the most important concepts.

best_comment: Please take Chem 154. The exams are fair, the psets are a little hard, but the material is very interesting and you'll expand on the things learned in Chem 40.  However, maybe more importantly, Dan is an awesome professor and scientist and I think everyone should meet and learn things from him. His stories are incredible and his accomplishments in Chemistry are very inspiring. Plus, I think this has been the funniest and most enjoyable 9am so far (you will be able to explain the symptoms of being a vampire using Chem 154!). I never missed a class.
worse_comment: Most of the lectures were confusing but the notes were informative.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: If you're looking for a low–effort, low–reward class, this is the class for you. You don't learn much (there's only 19 lectures of content, and each lecture is pretty short), unlike other classes where they're trying to rush through the material so you can learn as much as possible. The homework problems are not easy, and the solutions often take statistically questionable steps. If you care about rigor at all, you'll spend quite a bit of extra time trying to make your solution make sense (unnecessarily, but maybe just for yourself). The exams are easy, which while you might like, it made me feel like I didn't really learn anything nor were any of the problems interesting enough to make me truly interested in the topic. While other chemistry classes I took, such as 20/30/40, made me really interested in the subject matter by the lecturers' passion and interesting problem sets and exams, this course inspired no such interest in me, which was greatly saddening.
worse_comment: Unfortunately, you will have to take this class as a chemistry requirement. Hopefully, you will have a different professor. The entire course is very poorly taught and the professor is extremely condescending to her students. On several occasions, the professor would call students out in front of the entire class and made everyone feel extremely uncomfortable, to the point where by the end of the class, only one student was brave enough to raise his hand to answer any questions. Never have I felt so belittled by a teacher before, and I cannot believe that this type of behavior is allowed at Harvard. Many students asked several times for the lectures to be slowed down (since we would often end early), but little was done to slow down the course to a comprehensible level. All of the slides were prewritten and were flashed through so quickly that no one could understand what was being written on them—it would have been much better understood if the professor had simply written out the equations as she went. We asked her to do this and she also refused. The problem sets were extremely difficult and had barely anything to do with the lectures or exams. I'm not sure that I actually learned or understood many of the concepts.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Please take this class!!! Best staff ever, great way to explore your skills and interests
subject: Chemistry

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective 001
best_comment: Although I took this course because it is a concentration requirement, it has by far become my favorite class at Harvard. A few things about this course: it is extremely organized and there are many ways you can learn the material (whether it be through lecture, section, the textbook, or the weekly content review lectures). There are also many opportunities to improve one's grade. After missing one of the lab days, I was very scared about my grade in the class since the maximum I could get on one of the assignments was a fifty (for missing), but the class allows you multiple ways to drop grades (extra credit assignments throughout the year, which made me feel like I had support in the class). The exams also allow ample amount of time to finish, meaning that you can take your time and enjoy taking the exams. Other opportunities this class provides include things like News of the Week on Fridays and fun opportunities of driving a Tesla. I loved the multiple office hours provided throughout the day for the course (including lab office hours and PSET office hours), especially the office hours that occurred after lecture (Lu explains things extremely clearly); the course staff are absolutely amazing at teaching and care about our success. This course could be very time consuming at times, especially during the third unit (which is like nothing I have ever learned before, revolving around quantum mechanics), but there are so many opportunities to learn and ask questions  (and succeed) that you will be prepared! Additionally, one does not need a strong chemistry background to take this course (the course makes it very clear what one should know the first week of classes and videos to prepare you on these topics).
worse_comment: This class is essentially AP Chemistry, taught in a worse manner and tying as many of the concepts covered as possible to climate change and electric vehicles. You don't learn much in lectures but rather have a lot of material packed into sections and "optional" problem solving and review videos. You will be gaslighted if you feel confused by simple concepts because of the terrible way they've been presented. And there are a bunch of components to this class to keep track of, which the people running it are aware of. But instead of consolidating things, they make you submit pictures of your Google calendar at the beginning of the semester.
subject: Physical Sciences

course_title: Foundations and Frontiers of Modern Chemistry: A Molecular and Global Perspective 001
best_comment: Although I took this course because it is a concentration requirement, it has by far become my favorite class at Harvard. A few things about this course: it is extremely organized and there are many ways you can learn the material (whether it be through lecture, section, the textbook, or the weekly content review lectures). There are also many opportunities to improve one's grade. After missing one of the lab days, I was very scared about my grade in the class since the maximum I could get on one of the assignments was a fifty (for missing), but the class allows you multiple ways to drop grades (extra credit assignments throughout the year, which made me feel like I had support in the class). The exams also allow ample amount of time to finish, meaning that you can take your time and enjoy taking the exams. Other opportunities this class provides include things like News of the Week on Fridays and fun opportunities of driving a Tesla. I loved the multiple office hours provided throughout the day for the course (including lab office hours and PSET office hours), especially the office hours that occurred after lecture (Lu explains things extremely clearly); the course staff are absolutely amazing at teaching and care about our success. This course could be very time consuming at times, especially during the third unit (which is like nothing I have ever learned before, revolving around quantum mechanics), but there are so many opportunities to learn and ask questions  (and succeed) that you will be prepared! Additionally, one does not need a strong chemistry background to take this course (the course makes it very clear what one should know the first week of classes and videos to prepare you on these topics).
worse_comment: This class is essentially AP Chemistry, taught in a worse manner and tying as many of the concepts covered as possible to climate change and electric vehicles. You don't learn much in lectures but rather have a lot of material packed into sections and "optional" problem solving and review videos. You will be gaslighted if you feel confused by simple concepts because of the terrible way they've been presented. And there are a bunch of components to this class to keep track of, which the people running it are aware of. But instead of consolidating things, they make you submit pictures of your Google calendar at the beginning of the semester.
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: Favorite course I've taken since getting to Harvard. 100% take it. The class was huge this past year because I lot of people were taking it thinking it would be really easy, and to be fair it is a pretty easy course. BUT, if you take this course, I require you to go to every lecture and listen. You will not regret it. Professor Andrews is such a good lecturer. I can't even pin down exactly why, but I always have a really easy time listening and taking notes, and the two hour lectures go by really fast. There is a LOT of material for this course, and even with weekly two hour lectures, I feel like we still had so much we could have talked about, and all of this material is very interesting.  I think everyone should take this course, but more importantly, everyone who takes this course should try to get as much out of it as possible.
worse_comment: FAKE GEM. It is not a time consuming class because it's once a week and no section, but the essays were absolutely ridiculous assignments (I suspect if that many people sign up next year it will just be two exams which I would strongly recommend staying away from). The course material is so boring. I feel bad because the TF staff was nice but this was just not a good class in any way. Looking at the layout of old roman houses was mind–numbing
best_gem_comment: Easy class and assignments, pretty good lectures, and you learn some cool stuff about Rome and archaeology. Highly recommend, huge gem.

course_title: Roman Daily Life: The Other Side of Rome 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It’s so fun and I learned so much. I came in with an interest in ancient Rome, but not a ton of background, and because of this class I’m doing a secondary in classics. Professor Andrews is wonderful and the assignments were reasonable work but rewarding. I especially enjoyed the creative assignments. Would highly recommend.
worse_comment: Take this class if you are looking for something interesting but not too involved or difficult.

best_comment: This was a very interesting class and was organized very well.
subject: Classics

course_title: Introduction to the Ancient Roman World 001
best_comment: This class was interesting, and, at the end of the day, I am glad that I now have a basic understanding of Roman history, as a Classics concentrator.  However, I felt that the course could be learned solely from reading the textbook.  The lecture generally covered content from the textbook readings, meaning that one was, at least partially, redundant.  The textbook was quite comprehensive, but there is always room for an actual professor to engage beyond the source material, and I'm not sure that I felt that that was done.  I also think that the quizzes, especially at the start, were quite punitive and difficult, although the course staff adapted well.  Dr. Philbrick is lovely and quite understanding, and the assignments that she created were interesting and engaging, beyond the weekly reading quizzes.  Connor is also a wonderful TF and did a great job at supporting students and creating discussion.  Nevertheless, the actual format of the class is not super conducive to either learning or engagement.
worse_comment: It’s a required course, but if you’re looking for something interesting, I would still take it. It was a little bland at times, but that doesn’t mean it was a bad course or the teachers were bad. In terms of required courses, this isn’t too bad at all.
subject: Classical Studies

best_comment: Being able to go to Greece on a trip for class was one of the most amazing experiences of my life!! Definitely apply to this class even if you're not a classics concentrator. Emma and Paul are outstanding professors and you will learn so much from them.
worse_comment: If you don't have much of a historical background or are more narrow in your focus, this class will be very difficult, but you will learn a lot and have a blast.
subject: Classical Studies

best_comment: Being able to go to Greece on a trip for class was one of the most amazing experiences of my life!! Definitely apply to this class even if you're not a classics concentrator. Emma and Paul are outstanding professors and you will learn so much from them.
worse_comment: If you don't have much of a historical background or are more narrow in your focus, this class will be very difficult, but you will learn a lot and have a blast.
subject: Classical Studies

best_comment: If you want to take this class, you probably are a classics concentrator—or concentrator–to–be. You need it to get a degree, so there's really not much I can say that will make you want to or not want to take this class. If I say it's hard, that doesn't change anything unless you're taking it for fun. It 100% depends of the TF you get. If you have a fun, nice TF, you will have a great time. If you don't, you won't.
subject: Greek

best_comment: The syntax and vocabulary in Plato is fairly simple, so it is a great 100–level Greek course if you're less confident or more nervous about your translation abilities.

course_title: Ancient Greek Literature: Texts and Contexts 001
best_comment: This is an incredible class –– if you can manage to take both 112A and 112B as an undergraduate, you should. You'll learn so much, but be prepared to sacrifice a fair amount of sleep for the readings. The selections of text are usually outstanding –– this is basically a greatest hits list class –– but some weeks will be much more challenging than others, so be prepared to spend anywhere from 3 to 8 hours per reading depending on difficulty and your familiarity with the material.

Latin 2 is a fantastic class! It is taught with lecture and section, and Ivy is a fantastic lecturer who truly cares for her students. However, your experience is also pretty dependent on your TF; Vivian was not a fantastic TF and she seemed distracted sometimes, but she still mostly knew her stuff and cared for her students. If you've taken 1–2 years of Latin in high school, you should be well prepared for this class. For those who know a bit more Latin, we cover grammatical concepts up until (not including) subjunctives.
subject: Latin

best_comment: There is a lot to know about Latin 2. Taking Latin 1 is incredibly helpful, and it is unlike learning any other language. Prior to this, I had no experience with anything like cases or declensions, but it is interesting to know some of the origins of English and other romance languages. Overall as far as fulfilling the language requirements go, this is a pretty good class to do so with. It really gives you an appreciation for the etymology and origins of other languages.
subject: Latin

best_comment: This is a really good class if you want to advance in Latin to be able to start reading a little more independently. It's the first move away from learning Latin as only through grammar, to just being read Latin as any other language. What I'm trying to say is that things like language comprehension and being able to "read" rather than just "translate" become a lot more important. I think my class was kind of unique in that we used tiered texts(three difficulty levels for each text, and you try to go through all three successively) rather than the normal, just get a singular passage of the original text and  attack it.  I definitely prefer the tiered texts, it made the aforementioned transition a lot easier, but there is a pretty steep learning curve in the beginning. Said learning curve is pretty standard though, and definitely more alleviated through this method.
subject: Latin

best_comment: Highly recommend this course! No knowledge of elegy required, just a background in Latin vocab and grammar. I came in with no knowledge about elegy and left loving that part of the Latin poetic tradition. It's honestly so entertaining to read about the shenanigans of young Romans two thousand years ago, I found myself laughing at times as I read and translated for homework. The assignments are very fair, often super engaging, and well–spaced throughout the semester—and Dr. Philbrick is a fantastic teacher, with whom it is an honor to learn!

This is such a good class! It's my first Latin class since high school and it definitely was rough at the start. I was spending wayyyy too much time on the reading for the first month or so, but it gets easier. Prof. Thomas is so kind and, although I was a bit intimidated at first, I really did not have to be. This class allowed me to get my Latin back so fast, and I am really glad that I got to read the book 7–12 of the Aeneid!!! It has changed my entire view of the epic and made me love it more. Prof. Thomas also cares more than what he teaches. We had quite a few discussions on the future of the Classics and Humanities, talked about campus news, and listen to Bob Dylan (of course). It has been so enriching.

course_title: Sallust and Tacitus: Virtue, Vice, and Empire 001
best_comment: It’s a pretty standard Latin class, except reading Sallust is a challenging but rewarding experience. Definitely improves sight reading.

I was originally planning on taking Classical Latin, but ended up taking Medieval – and that was a good choice. This course exposes you to a diverse range of authors, writing styles, ideas, and vocabulary that I had never previously experienced. It was a bit of a leap to leave the Classical authors I was familiar with by name, but I gained a lot by reading authors from a time period I hadn't previously thought a lot about.  Aside from simple translation, this class discussed much about broad trends/a historical overview of the medieval world . . . again, something that isn't often taught, but is very good to know (and interesting!).
subject: Medieval Latin

best_comment: I would absolutely recommend this class! Professor Dourou is incredible and the class environment is very supportive and welcoming.
subject: Modern Greek

course_title: Intermediate Modern Greek: Culture and Civilization 001
best_comment: ***TAKE THIS CLASS (with Calliopi––she is THE nicest professor you will ever meet, and while you will learn a lot and have ample opportunity to practice the language, the class is also very enjoyable)
subject: Modern Greek

course_title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature 001
best_comment: Take this class if you get the chance! A very relaxed learning environment with my favorite professor ever. Calliopi is incredibly kind, knowledgeable and eager to get students engaged with modern greek. You'll get exposure to lots of big names in Greek literature and film and feel more connected to greek culture and your greek peers at harvard!
subject: Modern Greek

best_comment: Thomas and Jacob are so wonderful and kind. You will learn so much from discussions and your classmates, and the topics are genuinely fascinating. Be prepared to read a lot, but the essay prompts are great bc there's a lot of freedom to write about things you're interested in.
subject: Comparative Literature

course_title: Introduction to German Literature, History, and Thought LEC
best_comment: YOU MUST TAKE A CLASS WITH PROFESSOR HAMILTON IN YOUR TIME HERE!!! As for this class specifically, Professor Hamilton created such a great syllabus – with a broad enough overview of German literature so as to give breadth, but also focused enough to make you feel like you were taking concrete ideas/ themes out of the class. He is an engaging and witty lecturer, and the 2 hours passed by in no time. He is also super kind, and that will come through in office hours and even during the lecture itself. The work was just a few (very, very short) papers and the reading  assignments were minimal. Professor Hamilton also knows so, so much, and fills every second of the two hours with insight. I think this was one of my favorite classes I've ever taken in my college career –– learned SO much, minimal stress, engaging lectures. I've heard this is true of all his classes.
If you are the kind to watch documentaries / do some light reading in your own time, you will enjoy this class. Not intimidating, even as a STEM concentrator.

This is a great class! Luke is a great instructor and facilitates a comfortable environment for discussion. The assignments can be really fun if you enjoy translating, and as far as I can tell, the grading is quite lenient. You will get to read lots of interesting literature and think about challenging, surprising questions related to translation.

course_title: Introduction to Modern Arabic Literature LEC
best_comment: This is a great course with a wonderful syllabus and reasonable workload! The discussions are fascinating and very thorough, so it definitely helps to take notes and come fully prepared for each meeting.

course_title: Homer and Beyond: Theory and Comparative Methods in Studying Oral Traditions SEM
best_comment: As always, Greg is a pleasure to learn from. He is potentially the most knowledgeable educator I have ever encountered, both at Harvard and beyond. Whatever your personal interests, Greg will likely know something about it or will be willing to connect you with someone who is an expert. He is so warm and open to any student with any intellectual passion, even if it is only tangentially related to the Classics. This class is a great place to expand your mind and learn from some cool people, especially if you're new to Homer and "his" crowd. Overall, I would STRONGLY recommend this course to anyone who wants to enjoy their time at college!!

course_title: Global New Media and Art SEM
best_comment: This class is fairly interesting, though generally lacks some structure. There are a good amount of thought–provoking readings and art pieces, though they can be quite dense and vague. Class time is only used to talk about these topics quite broadly, so make sure you are really interested in the material.

course_title: What's Love Got to Do With It; Love Poetry of the Middle Ages and Early Modernity SEM
best_comment: This is a great class to take! The professor is a polyglot who pushes his students to see beyond the limits of the english language and explore the endless possibilities of the portuguese, french, and arabic language. The professor and TF are very understand regarding assignment deadline. The poems read all portray love in a different light, so it's one of the most romantic classes you can take as a Harvard student. The class is a cross–registration with the Divinity school, so a lot of the students will be graduate students, but don't be scared to take it as a first year in undergrad! it is a great environment.

course_title: Post-War Confessions: Albert Camus and Günter Grass  SEM
best_comment: This class is AMAZING! The Tin Drum is an incredible novel which would usually be tough for non–German–speaking readers to properly appreciate, but this class makes it accessible, and The Fall has powerful, meaningful messages. More than all  that, however, take this course because of Professor Hamilton –– he is an unbelievable lecturer, one whose class discussions always seem to span various themes, disciplines, and moral quandries in an immensely satisfying way. There are very few classes after which I have felt genuine appreciation and gratitude for the amazing faculty members available to us at Harvard –– this is one of them. If you get the opportunity to take this course, you should do so and feel fortunate.

course_title: Literature, Diaspora, Migration, and Trauma SEM
best_comment: Read through the syllabus closely and make sure that you are able to take on the reading load, it can be quite heavy if you have other courses that have a lot of reading as well. Obviously, aside from the discussion post, there isn't a direct way to check back on if you've done it, but without reading the text I can imagine the discussion and course experience are a lot less enjoyable. Other than that, this is a really great open–armed class. Professor Thornber is incredibly knowledgeable and cares a lot about the enjoyment and learning of her students. If you are interested in migrations, diaspora, and love to read, this would be a great fit. But those must be a prerequisite.

Don't worry too much about this class. It's not nightmarish like you hear about other CS classes. It's super approachable.  This is the only STEM class I've taken at Harvard and I survived. You don't need the textbook so don't waste your money. I took it pass–fail but probably could have afforded not to. Just go to office hours with specific questions and you'll be all good. Also  Leitner really appreciates it when you show up to lecture so go!
worse_comment: This course is very manageable, there is almost no coursework outside of the psets. Going to lectures and section is all that is needed to be well–positioned for the course.

best_comment: Having never taken a discrete mathematics class, CS20's proof–based math style was really new to me and the first few PSETs were challenging in getting used to the assignments. I really enjoyed it by the end, however. I would really recommend this course to anyone interested in math that feels like puzzle–solving rather than real math. The course was really challenging but there's a super robust teaching staff with tons of opportunities for feedback and help. I would strongly encourage going to office hours for help with the PSETs, as they are graded pretty strictly.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! 100% go to office hours, do not waste your time trying to learn material without help. It's super time efficient and not super helpful for learning the material.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Having never taken a discrete mathematics class, CS20's proof–based math style was really new to me and the first few PSETs were challenging in getting used to the assignments. I really enjoyed it by the end, however. I would really recommend this course to anyone interested in math that feels like puzzle–solving rather than real math. The course was really challenging but there's a super robust teaching staff with tons of opportunities for feedback and help. I would strongly encourage going to office hours for help with the PSETs, as they are graded pretty strictly.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! 100% go to office hours, do not waste your time trying to learn material without help. It's super time efficient and not super helpful for learning the material.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class is not too challenging and has a lot of great content embedded within, but you'll have to be very proactive about really learning the topics. Lectures are essentially optional, and most of the assignments require minimal work to be submitted and have a crazy amount of late days, so you can really put in as much or as little effort as you want (which will be inversely proportional to how much you learn). However, the final project at the end is super fun, the teaching staff is excellent, and Mike is the best! Hopefully they make the course a little more mandatory, because the psets and lectures teach useful and interesting content and the class definitely has the potential to be really great.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class if you do not know CS or have very strong mathematical and problem solving thinking strategies. The staff and OH is great but it is very stressful how quickly the course moves and the sections are more so doing other problem sets rather than actually going over confusing content. Also OH can be really busy and it is hard to get the help you need sometimes, it is overall not an intro class at all.
best_gem_comment: This class is very manageable. the lectures are effective, and you learn a lot by the end! An absolute gem and Mike is an amazing professor
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class is not too challenging and has a lot of great content embedded within, but you'll have to be very proactive about really learning the topics. Lectures are essentially optional, and most of the assignments require minimal work to be submitted and have a crazy amount of late days, so you can really put in as much or as little effort as you want (which will be inversely proportional to how much you learn). However, the final project at the end is super fun, the teaching staff is excellent, and Mike is the best! Hopefully they make the course a little more mandatory, because the psets and lectures teach useful and interesting content and the class definitely has the potential to be really great.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class if you do not know CS or have very strong mathematical and problem solving thinking strategies. The staff and OH is great but it is very stressful how quickly the course moves and the sections are more so doing other problem sets rather than actually going over confusing content. Also OH can be really busy and it is hard to get the help you need sometimes, it is overall not an intro class at all.
best_gem_comment: This class is very manageable. the lectures are effective, and you learn a lot by the end! An absolute gem and Mike is an amazing professor
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: It is hard, but it is not as bad as stat110, stat111, or other courses like that. Don't be scared! It is great even if you take it just as an elective
worse_comment: Don't take this course for the name. It's extremely difficult and not a good course for beginners. This course attempts to do too much in too little time. I never felt like I gained a decent understanding of anything. The psets are difficult and I had to rely heavily on the course assistants in office hours every step of the way. Even after getting enough guidance from them to write a line or two of code, I struggled to understand what the code actually meant.Office hours are extremely crowded and you will rarely get the help you need, just due to the limited availability of course assistants. Additionally, you cannot rely on other students to help you because the collaboration policies are strict. Overall, there is not enough support considering the intense workload.My advice: If you really must take this course, TAKE IT PASS/FAIL. Additionally, don't be afraid to turn in incomplete psets...sometimes you will just not be able to get the help you need during office hours. Just turn them in (even if you can only do the first step), show up to section, and do your best on the final test. Lower your expectations, aim to pass, and consider anything you learn along the way a win.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: It is hard, but it is not as bad as stat110, stat111, or other courses like that. Don't be scared! It is great even if you take it just as an elective
worse_comment: Don't take this course for the name. It's extremely difficult and not a good course for beginners. This course attempts to do too much in too little time. I never felt like I gained a decent understanding of anything. The psets are difficult and I had to rely heavily on the course assistants in office hours every step of the way. Just turn them in (even if you can only do the first step), show up to section, and do your best on the final test. best_comment: It is hard, but it is not as bad as stat110, stat111, or other courses like that. Don't be scared! It is great even if you take it just as an elective
worse_comment: Don't take this course for the name. It's extremely difficult and not a good course for beginners. This course attempts to do too much in too little time. I never felt like I gained a decent understanding of anything. The psets are difficult and I had to rely heavily on the course assistants in office hours every step of the way. Even after getting enough guidance from them to write a line or two of code, I struggled to understand what the code actually meant.Office hours are extremely crowded and you will rarely get the help you need, just due to the limited availability of course assistants. Additionally, you cannot rely on other students to help you because the collaboration policies are strict. Overall, there is not enough support considering the intense workload.My advice: If you really must take this course, TAKE IT PASS/FAIL. Additionally, don't be afraid to turn in incomplete psets...sometimes you will just not be able to get the help you need during office hours. Just turn them in (even if you can only do the first step), show up to section, and do your best on the final test. Lower your expectations, aim to pass, and consider anything you learn along the way a win.

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Tl;dr I loved the class but I recommend you take CS61 instead. Let me explain. Yes, I loved this class but I think that its mediocre reputation is warranted. First of all, the class' name is misleading. Yes, the class does cover abstraction and design but that is not what the entire class is about. Instead, the class is a proper Programming 2 class. A more in–depth look at programming as a whole which includes abstraction and design. I would say the first 1/3 of the class is dedicated almost entirely to abstraction and design but after that, you go into topics that are certainly applicable to software engineering, but they are not solely  in the interest of teaching abstraction and design! Another thing that pains me (as well as most of my classmates) is the language that the class is taught in—Ocaml. Ocaml is seldom used in industry and the professor will spend the first lecture telling you that it does not matter what language the class is taught in because it's a class on abstraction and design and NOT a class on Ocaml. In my opinion, that claim is simply not true. Like I said, the class does cover design but it is by no means the main focus of the course. In addition, to say that the class is not a class on Ocaml feels a little disingenuous when a good chunk of the exams require knowledge of very specific and niche details about Ocaml and do not focus on design. Yeah, exams for a class that's on abstraction and design and NOT Ocaml focuses on Ocaml and not as much on abstraction and design... that's a little ridiculous. In addition, the class focuses way too much on "semantics." Semantics are basically the way the computer evaluates your code and its presence is pervasive in the final part of the course. It accounts for a considerable portion of the second midterm and is the sole focus of the final project. I mention this because while semantics can be useful in laying down the foundations for understanding how to program, I think it was overemphasized in this course and so did my classmates.Now, I have spent most of this review tearing CS51 apart and yet I claim that I loved the class. That is true, and it is because CS51 was almost exactly what I wanted—a deeper dive into programming. I only started programming last semester in CS50 and wanted to take another class dedicated solely to programming. So logically, I took CS51 and got just that, a comprehensive look at programming as a whole sprinkled in with a good chunk of abstraction and design. However, if you are looking for a class to fulfill the Programming 2 requirement, a class that will actually cover abstraction, design, and a useful language, then this is not the class for you. If those are your only motivations for taking this class then take CS61 instead. However, if you just want a class that will build off the programming knowledge from CS50, then feel free to take this class. CS51 is hard, but it is also fun if you take it for the right reasons.
worse_comment: I would not recommend taking this class if you are new to coding. The PSets are unbelievably obscure and have little to do with what you learn in class, the feedback is infrequent, and much of the class is much more difficult than it needs to be. I don't think that CS51 itself is hard, much of the concepts are reasonably simple to grasp, but the manner in which they are presented is often confusing. The course is difficult not to be challenging, but for difficulty's sake. If you want to do well in this class, you should be prepared to live CS51 rather than merely take it. This is not because it's hard, but because this class is frustrating without a cause. I ultimately think I learned very little, even as someone who had only ever coded in CS50 since most of our PSets were filled with skeleton code.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: If you were to take this course then be prepared to essentially self–teach yourself most of the material. Lectures are not useful in any way, but the videos provided are. In most cases I would argue that the videos were more helpful than the textbook itself, but I would still look back on the figures and examples provided in the textbook. While some psets may be challenging, I found the readmes to be very helpful in figuring it out in certain cases. I would skip the background information and delve straight into what they want us to do for each problem as they sometimes give useful hints in there. Overall, I would recommend this course to someone who's interested in learning ocaml and getting better at coding. I also think it was helpful as some of the concepts that they went into were pretty cool and the TFs are an amazing help.
worse_comment: course requires a lot of self–studying, office hours queues are very long so not enough support when completing problem sets, problem sets may be very difficult if you don't have much cs background
subject: Computer Science

course_title: System Design Projects: Machine Learning for Social Impact 001
best_comment: Super good way to get hands–on experience while getting class credit. Course staff is super helpful, as well. Loved my team—was a great vibe!

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: A bit harder than 209a/109a but still easy. lecture note material is very clear, lectures are great, homeworks are very practical, and exams are very easy. overall an extremely useful course with a great staff.  the final project is horrible if you have a bad group though but I guess all group projects are like that.  Usually one person ends up doing way more work than the others and its super unfair so really try to find a good final project group
worse_comment: If you simply want ‘data science’ on your resume, then this class is for you. But if you actually want to LEARN about data science, then I would suggest looking elsewhere. By far the most disappointing class I’ve taken at Harvard. Chris is fantastic, but the rest of the TFs are not very helpful and often make mistakes. Beyond this, they make condescending comments regarding how simple the mathematical computations are, but pressed to implement those computations are just as lost as the students. As a rule of thumb, if the teaching fellows cannot solve the problem, it probably should not be assigned to students. Skip the advanced section too unless you absolutely need to take it — again, an enormous amount of work for little payoff. Simply put, this class is an absurd waste of time. That’s not to say that there’s not useful insights provided in this class, but the cost is far greater than the payoff.  On top of the homework and midterms expect: pre class reading, post–class readings, post class quizzes, post class exercises (that are sometimes broken and simply do not work), labs, sections, and a final project! Overall, the teaching staff has little to no respect or consideration for enrolled students — making this class incredibly stressful when it doesn’t need to be. Reaching out to the teaching staff results in dismissive replies. Classes like this exemplify why a code of conduct/expectations for professors and TF should be a standard aspect of an academic curriculum. Finally, and perhaps most alarmingly, homework was assigned overlapping with reading week, but no TAs offered availability to help with that homework.  This is notable because that means this class violated  official guidelines from the FAS by assigning homework during reading week. If I could report a class somewhere for crossing boundaries, this class would be it.  In conclusion, take another course because this class is a waste of time & effort.

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Take it if you have to / want to, avoid it if you are just curious about theoretical CS (CS120 is so much better and more manageable!). If you are a CS major and end up taking it just like everyone else, you will be fine but I hope this review helps you prepare for what’s to come! Not everyone might agree with my review as people from very very different backgrounds and with very different skills and preferences take the class. I’m writing from the perspective of someone who is usually average in CS classes and neither wanted to sacrifice the entire semester for this class (wanted to have time for fun and other stuff) nor is passionate about theoretical CS / research / really hard stuff. I took Math 22, Stat 110, CS50 + 51, and CS 120, which I think is good preparation for this course. As dramatic as the paragraphs below might sound, it’s still a doable class and we all struggle through it together, it just requires a lot of effort and pain so it’s good to know in advance and prepare for probably one of the hardest classes you’ll ever take!While at times interesting, this class will consume you and challenge you in ways you’ve probably never experienced or imagined. With unreasonably long problem sets due every week and exams designed by a sadist, it will be a nightmare from day 0. You will learn a lot but the cost is definitely high (unless you are really smart like a good amount of the kids in the class). I was basically taking 3 gems and this class so this was pretty much my only serious commitment for most weeks and it still was A LOT. Sure, a lot of students take this class and other hard classes at the same time. I couldn’t have done that, maybe you can but don’t underestimate it.Regarding the TFs, I really couldn’t do what they do so I admire them. Shoutout to Andrew who has been extremely supportive and gone above and beyond what I could have ever expected as well as Ashley. Some of them are helpful, and some of them not as much? I wish there were more TFs, and more OH. There are a lot of OH but most of them are still crowded enough that it’s hard to get questions answered. Ed is a must although sometimes no member of the staff would respond a question which was pretty frustrating.Lectures are the driest most boring audiovisual content I’ve ever consumed. Great if you have insomnia because they would make me fall asleep every single time. No matter what time of the day or how much I had slept the night before, 5 minutes in and I was ready for a good long night's sleep. As a consequence, I stopped going to class (had to rewatch them anyways) and then started watching half of them (or as much as my mind could take). I couldn’t exactly tell you why they were so useless but they were, and lecture notes were not that much better. Section notes, however, life–saver resources that made the content a little less indigestible.Problem sets are so long that you’ll do only that for the whole week and still have to take a (few) late day(s). They are as long as they can (un)reasonably be. The fact that they give you 12 late days for less than 12 psets should tell you all you need to know (talking about late days, wouldn’t have passed the class without them; please keep them). Psets will consume you and ruin your weekends and weeks consistently from the first one to the last one. Having said that, they do give you a pretty good understanding of the material which I appreciate and was useful to keep up with the class. However, the fact that they took forever not only was incredibly stressful but also didn’t really leave more time for engaging with the course material in other meaningful ways (reviewing lecture notes, section notes, doing section exercises, looking at the supplemental textbooks, etc). When you take the first late day, you enter a cycle where you are always late for the next deadline and the last thing that ever crossed my mind (not that I had time for it anyways) was to attempt section exercises or give a closer reading to lecture notes. I do appreciate that the optional exercises are truly optional and that at least the homework does account for a pretty considerable part of your grade so it’s effort that goes somewhere at least. So, while psets made you learn, unreasonable length and difficulty made them so painful that I’d rather learn a little less, enjoy a little more and be able to engage with the course in more ways than just complete exercises that I could have never done on my own. Like I do understand the point of having challenging exercises but when ALL of the exercises are so challenging it just becomes exhausting. Programming assignments were usually okay but still took considerable time.If problem sets were hard, I can’t start talking about exams. At least in the psets it was reasonably attainable to do well if you put in the hours. Exams were sadistically designed to make you feel stupid. You are not expected to have a great score and you can still do well on the class even if you have a score that in other classes would be close to failing. However, they are so unrealistically long that it just adds up to the stressful nature of the class where it always feels like you are not smart enough to keep up. I don’t really understand the need to make an exam that half of the students can’t even get at 50% on; Maybe there is an educational argument for making exams so challenging but I for sure am not familiar with it and it is again very frustrating that it almost feels like only the kids who are genuinely smart and have an intuition for these kind of things are able to do the exams right. For the average student, the % improvement in grade per hour of study is likely to be very little. I didn’t even have time to attempt every problem. Again, I don’t understand the purpose and other CS classes (see CS120) had challenging yet manageable exams where it was easier to do well if you had a good understanding of the material.In summary, this could be a good and enjoyable class because the material is often interesting and if you like problem–solving you might enjoy some of the results and things that this class covers and teaches you. However, they made it so hard that it becomes hell for most students and, if you are a little bit like me, you might end up not wanting to take another class on algorithms ever!
worse_comment: WORST CLASS I'VE EVER TAKEN. Seriously, if you don't have to take it, DON'T TAKE IT. Otherwise, if it's a requirement for you as it was for me, be prepared to feel like a total failure throughout the entire semester. From psets to exams, nothing was more discouraging than CS124. On top of that, the lectures are super boring. The workload is ridiculous. It will not help you get internships (doing Leetcode will). Office hours are way overcrowded. The teaching staff is not flexible for extenuating life circumstances. Overall, this class will make your entire semester miserable. Harvard's CS department and curriculum needs some serious structural changes. If I knew it would be this bad I would've chosen a different major.
subject: Computer Science
