subject: Computer Science

course_title: Convex Optimization and Applications in Machine Learning 001
best_comment: This course did a good review of convex optimization and prepared us to dive more into the subject. A lot of the content is theoretical tho, so if you are not that into math and just want to learn about ML algorithms, this course might not be for you since some of the content does not have direct applications in ML. However, knowing convex optimization is quite useful in many fields such as engineering, CS, econ, and this course definitely teaches you new concepts you probably didn't learn in other classes. If you want a deeper understanding of ML (or any other area that uses optimization), this course is for you.However, I must note that the content sometimes felt unmotivated and dry. This did not affect my experience with the course, but I hope they improve on that. The psets were sometimes challenging, but not in a bad way. I feel like I gained a much deeper understanding and appreciation of the material as I did the psets (psets definitely not tedious like 124). Overall, I recommend this class!
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: I loved this class.  I came from a software background and wanted to learn about the intersection between software and hardware, which is what I learned.  Here are a few takeaways I think will be helpful:– I don't think you need a prerequisite for this class, but CS 61 is super helpful in that it provides you with a solid high–level foundation of concepts that you'll be able to dive deeper into from a hardware perspective.  Some overlap includes caches and pipelines.  I really didn't understand them to how much I do now after taking CS 61.  Understanding the hardware is SO USEFUL.– You'll have PSETS and Labs.  PSETS take max 2 hours a week, and you have one per week.  I suggest checking with a group of people, makes it feel nicer.  Labs take a little longer because you have a week or two to do them, but you have a partner.  If you're a strong coder, it won't be anything difficult.  It's not a lot of hard debugging, more so understanding how to translate the concept into code.– The readings are ESSENTIAL.  Read the book!  Takes around 1 hour per reading.  Super helpful for when you go into lecture.– Attend Dhilan's section + office hours.  He was the GOAT of this class.
worse_comment: The material in the course itself is interesting, but the class feels so unstructured that it causes unnecessary amounts of stress. I'm not sure how helpful the lectures are for learning, since it just feels like they're really disorganized. The labs and the problem sets can be helpful in grasping the concepts, but the grading can seem nitpicky and unclear. It can also take up to two months to get feedback on assignments, so it can be really challenging to know how you're doing in the course.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This course is rather light for a 100 series CS class, and thus is a nice class for the requirement, Be warned though this course is not a gem and has some vital flaws in how it is taught. Professor Kung is great but his lectures can be boring, honestly did not attend many of them despite the quizzes. The problem sets are due like every week, but be warned, the software usd on them is either outdated or realllly esoteric. Like some of the pset questions will ask for you to use a really specific function of ns3 that has little documentation. The point is start early and clear those obstacles early. Perhaps most importantly CHOOSE YOUR PSET GROUP VERY CAREFULLY I got stuck with a deadbeet pset group for one of the psets and had to do the whole thing myself, and I heard many other similar stories. Make sure you establish division of responsibility clearly. Aside from that, course is fair. Midterm and quizzes are fair. i swear for the final presentation most teams dont even really know whats going on.  GPT will be a good friend in this course!
worse_comment: Worst class I've taken at Harvard. Not necessarily the most difficult, but the worst. First, there is practically no support from the teaching staff. Office hours were not held regularly, and there were no labs and sections to support the students. Many students would agree with me that generally the teaching staff was not welcoming, many times condescending to students in the class. Second, the assignments are very unclear and have the worst turnaround. It takes several weeks to get your grade back on assignments that are significant portions of your grade. Curves and distributions are not announced either. You will have no idea how you're doing in the class throughout the entire semester. That being said, if you have interest in the material, you'll get something out of this class. Just know that a lot of it will have to be self–driven, and you will have a lot of unnecessary stress (beyond the academic portion) because of how poorly the course is run.

best_comment: As a computer science concentrator, I'm really glad I was  able to take CS145 before I graduated. The exposure to concepts in computer networking like networking protocols, sending and receiving packets, thinking through creating and setting up computer network topologies, ISPs and networking policies were all new to me and seem like very foundational ways to think about systems of computers. Additionally, there seems to be a strong analogy that could be drawn  between networks of computers and networks of humans (from social networks to networks of companies) and how information moves through these networks. While taking CS145, I continuously saw how concepts from class came up in my own life every week. And seeing that connection was a really valuable and cool process and experience. Professor Yu is very knowledgeable and very considerate professor and I'm glad I was able to take the course with her as a professor. The only thing that is tough about this course are the projects for the course that involve P4, a computer networking programming language that you'll probably be exposed to for the first time in this class. Simple ideas that were easy to understand and grok at a conceptual  level were often difficult to implement in P4 because it's not always clear how the language works. Office hours and Ed are your best friend. Ask lots of questions at both and know that lots of students in the class are encountering similar bugs and hiccups for the projects that you are.
worse_comment: Only take this course if your interest in networking surpasses the pain you will experience of parsing unclear instructions, buggy boilerplate code, and high workload. Definitely would recommend it over the other networking course, but it was quite frustrating at times.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class is pretty dang hard.... I went to every single office hours that I could, which was around 3–4 a week, each for around 2 hours, and basically required that environment with all the other students and the TFs in order to complete the psets. There aren't many, but the questions are pretty tricky. Midterm and Final were pretty tough.. Good class though, glad I took it and even more glad I survived.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! It was so much fun and you get to build some really cool stuff! I agree that a lot of the tech in this class is a bit outdated, but it really helps build the fundamentals of graphics and how we got to where we are today. There are partner psets, so going in with someone you know is helpful, but you can always try to make friends in the class or do them alone. (I would say it is more fun if you have a partner tho)It also isn't as stressful as other CS classes so you can really learn without the intense pressure some classes put on you. **
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class. Gortler is not well–prepared nor well–organized, and the class is not particularly interesting. I've taken a variety of other CS courses and have found this one to be the least interesting and least valuable so far. While it is fairly easy I wouldn't even recommend it to gem seekers, as it's just generally a waste of time.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Amazing class to practice development and build up an engineering project portfolio. Almost exclusively web/app development for projects, but the readings and discussions are broader scoped. If you feel tired of Harvard CS theoretical–ness – this course is your cure. You work on three projects over the semester that were interesting and exciting and made me remember why I ever liked coding in the first place. Please don't let any negative reviews sway you from taking this course. This was the first time this course was taught, so Elena was still figuring out the structure and organization, but I have full faith that this class will only improve. Elena feels more like a friend and partner in the class than a professor, and she cares about the students.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: CS 181 starts with simple models like regression, but quickly covers a lot of cool and useful machine learning models like neural networks, latent variable models, and RL––the latter content being typically introduced in graduate level courses. This course is more theory heavy than code heavy; I did a lot more math than coding, and we don’t implement every single model that we covered in class. ML is one of the most satisfying applications of statistics that I’ve seen, featuring a lot of creative and nice mathematical algorithms––after taking this class, you’ll be able to code machine learning models that perform very nontrivial tasks, like recognizing handwritten numbers or playing flappy–bird.The most important prerequisite for this class is Stat 110––almost everything in machine learning uses statistics uses machine learning, so make sure to have a solid foundation in probability. Math 21a/b are also important to understand the mathematical derivations; 21a is important for optimization (trying to find the “best” model), and 21b is important for efficiently manipulating data (which usually comes in the form of vectors and matrices). CS 51/61 is not a hard prereq, and the programming in this course is not particularly difficult compared to these two courses. The class is taught in python.I took Stat 111 concurrently with this class––around the first 20% of the two classes overlap, so I did sometimes feel like I was taking the same class, but the content does branch off as the semester progresses.
worse_comment: This course was not super well organized. The material was interesting, but the exams were very difficult and grades were not returned for months. I didn't know what grade I was going to get in the class until after finishing the course. This was really frustrating.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: It was amazing to meet other people in the CS department, including the incredible course staff. I was able to learn so much from them and about them during class. I feel as though the CS concentration does not necessarily cover all areas of CS. For instance, I have not taken an ML course here and had never heard about error–correction codes prior to this course. However, I now feel as though I have a general understanding of all the fundamental areas of computer science. I have also had the chance to converse with several people in my concentration who share my interests and new ones, which has felt like a personally enriching and inspiring experience. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who studies CS and would especially recommend it to people with a strong background in CS. The papers in this class and their history are very cool and worth exploring! You'll undoubtedly walk away from this class with more CS knowledge and a stronger connection to the people in the CS department.
worse_comment: Take this course ONLY if you actually want to learn more about the history and origins of CS. Course discussion circles will be painful if you don't actually want to be there. That said, don't be discouraged if you're not a CS wizard. The course intersects (briefly) with neuroscience, physics, and philosophy, and you'll spend a lot of time thinking about larger implications rather than nitty–gritty implementations. *
best_gem_comment: While this class is a gem for workload, unless you're comfortable taking it and getting an A–, don't take it. The video project is graded in a very biased and unsatisfactory way. I effectively submitted 3 times (and put a good amount of work into it) just to be told "pretty good, here's an A–". it makes no sense. good luck arguing with the course heads as well because they're very self–righteous in their grading and don't pay attention to what you have to say. Overall, very subjective grading that will most likely result in an A–. If you're okay with that, then by all means take the course, it will be the easiest one in your semester... just don't expect an A.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Designing K–12 Computer Science Learning Experiences 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! It's the best class (not just best CS class) that I've taken in my 4 years at Harvard. KB and Brian are so incredibly kind, encouraging, and supportive of your interests and personal growth. I've never been in a college classroom where I felt more safe and encouraged to fail, learn new things, and try again. I forgot how much my inner child loved learning until I took this class. Never once do you feel like you'll be penalized (with regards to your grade or anything else) if you try something for your project and it doesn't work, and that is something that I never felt before in 16 years of schooling, let alone in college.The assignments are comprised of a term–long project, which can be literally whatever you want it to be (from a board game to a curriculum to an app), and case studies + reflections. All of the case studies are super interesting and somehow always relevant to your project, and each in–class activity for each case study is a little different, so there's never a dull moment. The week–to–week workload is very much up to you. KB and Brian and super understanding that some weeks you make more progress than others. The best part about this class is that there is never any pressure to achieve perfection. The teaching staff genuinely just wants to see you thrive as a person by doing what you're passionate about. Also, there is a SNACK CART in class that KB will refill with snacks you request. KB is an absolute legend. She has so many amazing connections with people in the CS Ed space who actually come into class to provide feedback on your projects! Anyone you ask her to bring into class, she can probably get them to come because she's just an icon. Brian is a tech expert and always provides super useful feedback on your project. All of the people in this class are so, so nice. The teaching staff and this course in general helped me uncover an area that I'm really excited and passionate about. The work you do in CS 196 feels purposeful and fulfilling. As cliche as it may sound, this course may have just helped me find my purpose. If you get the chance to be in this course, please please please take it!!!
subject: Computer Science

course_title: High Performance Computing for Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: This is by far the best class I have taken at Harvard. However, I believe this is mostly because of Fabian. He is the most enthusiastic, knowledgeable and friendly professor I have met. He manages to transfer his passion to everyone in the lecture hall when talking about optimizing code and getting the most out of the resources at hand. Every lecture was carefully crafted and you can tell he knows *a lot* about anything he mentions. If you do manage to ask about something he does not know in depth, he will research it and come with an answer. His implication in this class was unrivaled – he would answer almost all edstem posts (which are *a lot*). The content is very complex and the class covers a lot of stuff, and you will learn about both hardware and software. I think 205 manages to combine multiple harvard classes (which are known to be difficult, like 61 and 141) and add more to them – the parallelization part. You will learn to think like a true performance engineer and get every millisecond you can from your code.From what I know, Fabian will no longer teach this class :( This is the one class at Harvard I would have recommended to everyone.
worse_comment: this class is very hard. be wary
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: If you are interested in learning about randomized algorithms and the many different ways to analyze them, then you will enjoy this course's content. However, it is a lot of work. The lectures move very quickly and are quite dense as well, so you will likely have to spend some time after going through them again or sitting with the textbook. The problem sets are similar as well, in that some of the questions will likely require a few hours of thinking before they can be solved. This course is also *very* math heavy, so you should be very comfortable with probability before taking this, comparable to a good understanding of everything in Stat 110. However, Professor Mitzenmacher is very accessible outside of class, and his OHs can be very helpful in relieving some of this work.Also, be aware that there is both a final exam and a final project, which is different from many other grad–level classes. Both will take a considerable amount of time, especially the final project which should be started at least a month in advance. Don't expect this class to ease out during finals period!
worse_comment: The course is more of an "advanced probability theory" course than a CS course.I feel that a student with strong fundamentals in mathematics can take the course, even if they know nothing about programming (which can be picked up along the way).On the contrary, a student with proficient CS knowledge who doesn't feel confident about mathematics will suffer brutally.

course_title: Topics in Theory for Society: Differential Privacy 001
best_comment: This class is phenomenal! Professor Dwork is absolutely amazing, incredibly passionate, and is wonderfully willing to help when you may be confused! Highly recommend taking this course if you are interested in privacy!
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Topics in the Foundations of Machine Learning 001
best_comment: This course is a good introduction to all things deep learning. Boaz selects really topical readings that are highly interesting and cutting–edge. The lectures are decent quality and you learn a lot. Despite the material being difficult, the people in the class are incredibly smart – it’s an amazing learning opportunity that you can’t miss. We cover an ambitious amount of readings, going from transformers to VAEs and diffusion models to differential privacy and fairness and to scaling laws and training dynamics to RL and AlphaFold to practical model parallelism and the history of ML. The course gave me more confidence in understanding the math and theoretical ideas underpinning the most important advances in deep learning, and it is truly the best course you can take on the state–of–the–art. The final paper was a joy to do and I felt very empowered to be able to create novel machine learning research because of what I learned in this class. It definitely pushed me to consider doing more ML research and there are just so many research ideas floating around after our class discussions.
worse_comment: This course is relatively low on theory, more on empirical observations or existing practices, and the justifications for these are often unsatisfying.

course_title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Spectral Graph Theory in CS 001
best_comment: This course was SO DIFFICULT but SO WORTH IT. Prof. Vadhan is amazing – he cares a ton for his students, breaks down complicated ideas into intuitive chunks, and gets students genuinely excited about course concepts. The biweekly psets are difficult, but much bearable if you 1) start early, 2) bounce ideas with your peers, and 3) make good use of office hours. If you enjoy theory (and enjoyed 124, 121, etc.), then definitely consider this course!

course_title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Biology and Complexity 001
best_comment: Grad CS classes at Harvard fall into two categories: (1) have a similar structure to undergrad classes but with fewer and perhaps more difficult assignments or (2) students give lectures in the form of paper reviews and the vast majority of the final grade comes from the final project. This course falls into the latter category –– after the first few lectures, Valiant doesn't play a large role in leading the course. I'd say it's a great course to practice reading research papers (and very interesting ones at that), and a good opportunity to do a cool big project at the end, but not a heavy workload at all. Background in neurobiology and CS theory are helpful but certainly not necessary.
worse_comment: Only enroll if you are willing to put in the time learning. You can breeze past with a decent grade without learning anything too, but that defeats the purpose of such a class.

course_title: Economic Analysis as a Frontier of Theoretical Computer Science 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful course to take if you want to learn CS/Econ in the future. Yannai is a great teacher and communicates the difficult ideas very well. He cares a lot about his students and puts a lot of effort into his teaching. This class is also not a lot of work (only 3 psets and a final project) and the workload is very manageable. This class introduces you to a lot of cs/econ research techniques (some of the paper we read were published in the last five years), which I thought was really cool. I would especially recommend the class to people who are good at proof–based math/have mathematical maturity, have taken ECON 1011a/CS 136 and CS 121/124, and want to do math that is more impactful/relevant to the real world. If you really like problem solving, then you'll like what we cover in this class.
worse_comment: This class will present you with a diversity of mathematical techniques and economics topics which I personally had never heard of elsewhere. Even for the CS student who is not interested in economics itself, some of the more obscure techniques that are mentioned in class in the context of econ applications are themselves worth learning.

best_comment: This course rocks. I found all of the content super interesting, Ariel is an excellent lecturer with wonderful teaching materials (slides, everything recorded with recordings from previous years too, and omg that course website, canvas could never. Google Ariel Procaccia and dig through his website to get an idea, you can see previous iterations of his courses there which is super useful. Hey even if you don't get in but are interested in a topic, you can watch one of the previous year recordings!) PSET workload isn't too much, once every two weeks is very reasonable and doable. There aren't a lot of OHs, but we didn't really need them much, and we would have had time to go to OHs more if we had needed them more. The final project was also a great experience and we ended up super invested in ours as we found a topic that really interested us.
worse_comment: This course covers a broad range of democracy–related topics from a CS perspective, and the teaching staff are very helpful, so a lack of experience in those areas ends up not mattering at all. You should TAKE THIS CLASS
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class is a great follow up to CS 141. If you liked the content of the course, this class is for you. Matt was an amazing TF and definitely helped shore up some of the classes shortcomings, such as lectures being a bit boring and at times hard to follow. The once a week meeting style left me wanting more, as I felt we could have covered more content and I did find the subject interesting, but it also made for a relatively light course load which was appreciated.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Jim is a fantastic lecturer – if you are a CS concentrator, try to take at least 1 class from Jim before you graduate.There are 3 psets in this class, which seems few, but are very time intensive – they are full scale systems you need to build. (This class has a false reputation that it's an easy, light–weight class – it is NOT.) It's a terrific class that forces you to build systems and learn how to be a great software engineer, while understanding the fundamentals behind distributed systems. The final project is very fun – lots of super interesting topics that came out of it. Would highly encourage you to take this class!
worse_comment: Good lecture, not too much work for this course. The course unfortunately was not well organized, but this might change in the future.
best_gem_comment: this class is fundamental to learn distributed systems which are crucial to know in industry. the assignments are open ended but you'll learn a LOT by working on them.  definitely very challenging, the programming assignments and very little OH to get it done, so expect to figure it out yourself over many long hours. but jim is great and a fabulous lecturer. would recommend but this isn't a 'gem' at all

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course. Stratos and the TFs are all amazing and extremely devoted to giving a hands–on, individualized experience to doing data systems research. I loved the research project and felt extremely proud of the work I was able to accomplish at the end of the semester, but I felt like the long paper reviews erred more on the side of busywork rather than actively useful assignments, and felt like that time could have been better spent on other assignments or simply as more time to work on the project. Overall, I enjoyed this course and how it was such a great facilitator for a substantial project.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! 100%. This is one of the best classes I've ever taken and it truly transformed my approach to making impactful technology. Krzysztof is an incredible professor who is extremely engaging and thoughtful and is always willing to help. I have gotten so much out of this class and I think there isn't a single person who would not benefit from it. It forces you to think critically throughout, and I think the way the material is presented makes it very easy to absorb. The most important thing I learned is that if you want to make impactful technology there is just no way to do that without involving the societal component throughout your process, and there are specific existing ways to do that that we learn in the class. I think society would be much better off if more people took this class. The group of students who take it is also wonderful and you learn a lot from your peers. The assignments are also great, especially the final project, during which you can get really deep into a sociotechnical system and learn so much! You will do yourself so many favors by taking this class, and more than any other I think what you learn will stay with you afterwards.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Topics in Machine Learning: Interpretability and Explainability 001
best_comment: This class has a lineup of interesting papers. The subject area is interesting and quickly growing, which is exciting. The class is pretty relaxed and goes at a good pace throughout the semester. The final project was fun and gives a good opportunity to explore an interesting topic. It was great for Prof. Lakkaraju to provide a lot of project ideas that would all be promising and substantial enough to find significant results. The course staff was also great in giving helpful advice/feedback along the way to guide us with our project. The presentations were fun and not a lot of pressure. Some feedback is that there were no rubrics given for participation or presentations ahead of time, so grading felt a bit arbitrary.

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: CS290 is a really great class! I'm glad it's required for all first year CS PhD students, and think other departments would benefit a lot from a similar course as well. It's great for meeting people and building community, and you definitely learn a lot of useful skills for navigating the PhD.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: CS290 is a really great class! I'm glad it's required for all first year CS PhD students, and think other departments would benefit a lot from a similar course as well. It's great for meeting people and building community, and you definitely learn a lot of useful skills for navigating the PhD.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: CS290 is a really great class! I'm glad it's required for all first year CS PhD students, and think other departments would benefit a lot from a similar course as well. It's great for meeting people and building community, and you definitely learn a lot of useful skills for navigating the PhD.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: A Brief History of the Earth 001
best_comment: Jerry is an amazing professor he always motivated his students was understanding of each of their situations always told jokes in class and I have found very few people who care about their students but Jerry is one of those rare gems. He so kind and I truly at Harvard have not found a professor who dedicated as much time and effort to his students like Jerry does. Building up to finals he had 3 days of virtual office hours each 3–4 hours, had an open door every morning before class, often provided students with snacks, and does not expect you to be passionate or care about the subject because he knows most students do it as a requirement. But truly if I had to take this course over again I would only take it with Jerry. He’s a kind man and a fantastic professor.

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: If you are interested in the history of the Earth, take this course. The first half was very much focused on geological processes and wasn't particularly focused on life, which I found a little boring because I love environmental science, but I appreciate the broad understanding I have of geology and the formation and early stages of Earth. I absolutely LOVED the second half of the course, as we spent each lecture talking about the evolutionary feats of life and extinctions during subsequent periods. I particularly love ecology, and this course does an incredible job at teaching the evolution of ecological relationships and developments throughout time. This course barely has any work outside of lecture. Lecture slides are engaging and very visually–friendly. If I could I would take this class again.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: If you are interested in the history of the Earth, take this course. The first half was very much focused on geological processes and wasn't particularly focused on life, which I found a little boring because I love environmental science, but I appreciate the broad understanding I have of geology and the formation and early stages of Earth. I absolutely LOVED the second half of the course, as we spent each lecture talking about the evolutionary feats of life and extinctions during subsequent periods. I particularly love ecology, and this course does an incredible job at teaching the evolution of ecological relationships and developments throughout time. This course barely has any work outside of lecture. Lecture slides are engaging and very visually–friendly. If I could I would take this class again.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: This class is great! It can be a bit difficult at times but there is great support and it is worth it for what you will learn. It presents information that is so interesting and important. I would recommend this course to anyone even slightly interested in climate change!
best_gem_comment: It is a decent course within EPS and good for the ESPP Secondary. If you have Python experience the class is manageable, but will require going to office hours. The TFs are very helpful and often you could complete the whole weekly coding notebook in 1 hour in office hours. You also can complete more than 50% of notebook in class, reducing homework. The 3 hour class is a little long, but the coding and breaks make it manageable. I'd take the class and recommend it, but don't expect it to be a complete gem. But, if you like coding and don't mind a longer class and can go to office hours or spend some time attempting to read the Professor's mind, this is a good class for you.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: Great class.  Lectures are interesting and informative.  Pace of the course is good with weekly homework and section.  Start preparing for the final project after spring break to ensure that you are sufficiently prepared.  Prof. Jacob is clearly very passionate about the subject and that helps a lot!
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: This class is great! Professor Tziperman is an excellent lecturer and every class is interesting and engaging. The problem sets can be difficult but manageable by attending section and asking questions. I also took this course as an undergrad and Professor Tziperman made it clear that he was available to help me through what was, at times, some of the most challenging material I have learned.  I would highly recommend this to any college senior in Physics (my background) or perhaps Applied Math who is considering climate science for graduate study. It especially went well having taken EPS 208 with Professor Kuang in the previous semester to get an introduction in geophysical fluid dynamics.

course_title: Atmospheric Evolution and Habitability of Terrestrial Planets 001
best_comment: This class is a really lovely review of the past and current literature of atmospheres of terrestrial planets, and Robin is great at facilitating conversations in this! Overall not too stressful while still learning a lot :)
This class is very useful! Take it as early as possible.

course_title: An Introduction to Computation for Contemporary Science 001
best_comment: If you need your CS requirement as an engineer, take this course over AM10 or CS50 for sure!!! Brendan is such a sweetheart and his lectures are hilarious & captivating, and the teaching staff was also very dedicated to helping out and making sure we understood the material. There were multiple times on weekends or etc. when I was struggling with some bug in my code, and the TFs responded to my email with helpful information within a couple hours!!! The psets were well–formatted (maybe a bit tedious at times) and definitely helped reinforce the Python knowledge we learned in class. My Python skills have definitely gotten stronger as a result (and for engineers, the course does give you a chance to practice using numpy, pandas, scipy, and odeint), and I really enjoyed learning in lecture as well. I would definitely recommend this course!!!

Love this class! It is definitely a pretty big time commitment in the sense that there is class everyday and quizzes twice a week, however, you really see the results of your hardwork after the first semester. Additionally, this class has a really good support group. The teachers are always willing to help you and work with you and overall, are super positive and encouraging. I love Yuan老师. She in my opinion, is one of the best at explaining concepts and always has the patience to work with you over and over again if you don't understand the concept the first time!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you're thinking about taking Chinese either to fulfill your language requirement or just because you're interested in learning the language (like I was) DEFINITELY take this course!!!  Super well–structured, the instructors are among the best I've had at Harvard (very engaged, invested in your success), and even with no prior experience (like I had) if you put in the work you will improve rapidly.  Assignments and exams are very fair and you get to apply the material from each week in a variety of ways (writing, speaking, etc.).  A plethora of resources available to help you learn the material and improve week to week.  All in all, a very fulfilling experience and if I had to go back I would choose to take this course 10/10 times.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Take this class! I knew no Chinese before the BA/BB series and am now able to write short papers, read passages, and converse with friends in Chinese. The progress that you will see in this course, especially coming out of BA is great. You will definitely feel more comfortable and confident with the language after the semester. The class is a lot of work, but finding a good study method that works for you (I really liked quizlet for the new vocab) will help with the dictations and preparing for class. Reach out to your teachers if you feel behind! The teaching staff and overall community is amazing and I have made great friends through this class.
worse_comment: – Spend the week before classes start reviewing all of semester 1. You hit the ground running in BB with no handholding or review.– You will learn a lot.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you are interested at all in the language or culture, TAKE THIS COURSE. Yes, it is a bit difficult, but the hard work will absolutely be worth it. The material is comprehensive and covers all types of learning, and the instructors are understanding and patient.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Great class. There are a decent amount of assignments (dictations, hw, speaking and reading assignments,  etc) but they aren’t usually too bad. Once you get in the rhythm of studying a little bit every day, the class becomes easier. Also, the teachers are so amazing and really love teaching. They are so nice and try their best to help everyone understand the material. There are probably easier languages to take at Harvard, but I am still very glad I took this course.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This class is the most rewarding class I’ve taken. There’s nothing like the feeling of being able to sight read and understand ancient philosophical texts, and learn from Professor Sena. Only take it if you’re willing to put the effort in because your commitment to the coursework affects the classroom environment as well. The assignments are reasonable given your growing skillset over the term, the exams are good measures of mastery, and Professor Sena is gracious in his willingness to help at office hours.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: It's a lot of work but equal amounts of fun and gratification.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Consistent practice is key to success in this course. Set aside time (especially before dictations) to review the material and practice applying it to new scenarios. It is an every day commitment, so make sure you really want to learn the language before signing up! That being said, it really is worth the commitment if you are interested. My language skills have improved dramatically, and the class is SO much fun. I've also become close friends with some of my classmates and gotten to know the instructors, who are the best!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: TAKE 120B!!!! 120A was amazing, and 120B is just as good. The course staff is just out of this world and you can clearly see how all the course components come together to really improve your Chinese skills. This is just a phenomenal course I could not recommend more highly.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This course is very enjoyable and you will learn a lot! If you have the time to devote to it and are really interested in improving your Chinese, I would strongly recommend this course!!
subject: Chinese

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 002
best_comment: Chinese 123xb is a FANTASTIC class and you should absolutely take it if you are considering it. The pace is quite fast and the homework can be a bit more work than you would anticipate, but overall it is incredibly rewarding and fun. The Chinese professors are always excellent, the course materials are great, and you cover so many topics that are deeper than anything you've likely seen before while also covering your fundamentals. My Chinese abilities have improved so much over the course of this year (Bx + 123xb) and I cannot recommend this course enough. Even though its a long walk to Vanserg everyday, it was always worth it.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Intermediate Modern Chinese for Advanced Beginners 003
best_comment: This class had the best students I have made during freshman year and I really enjoyed showing up to class. Honestly, this was my favorite class. The homework may be a bit time–consuming, but it is worth it. The teachers are all very nice and for this class, you only have to have good listening ability (parents spoke Chinese to you growing up). Even though Chinese skill level varies, as long as you know how to listen mostly, you will do fine. Learning to read and write will not be too bad, especially coming from Chinese Bx. You get into more formal writing and I loved the small class size. Take this class!!
worse_comment: Take this class if you're willing to put in 9 hours/week and you WANT TO LEARN CHINESE!! This class is VERY fulfilling, ONLY IF YOU PUT IN THE WORK! If you are too busy, you will fall behind VERY quickly and you will struggle.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: this class is awesome. be warned that it is a lot of time "in class" but honestly 9:00 am drill is a great way to start MWF. the teachers are great, the class is great, its all great. do it if you want to learn chinese.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Only take this class if you are really committed to Chinese, and you have the time to spend 10+ hours a week on it. This class is rewarding, but very fast paced with a high volume of new words and structures each week. It can be very hard to keep up in class if you do not review before, so making sure you have the time to review vocabulary before each lecture is very important. Overall, the teaching staff make this class great, but it was still one of the harder classes in my semester.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Super well constructed class! Really fun in–class dynamic with lots of activities and debates to get us to think creatively about what we were learning. All of the teachers are super impressive and clearly know how to get us to learn at our peak. This class is a joy!
worse_comment: Take the course because you're interested in developing your language skills, not because you want a nice grade. A nice grade is certainly attainable, but not a great reason for studying a language at the pre–advanced level.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class with incredibly kind, dedicated and helpful instructors. The trek to Vanserg every morning is annoying, especially in the winter, but I'd it's definitely worth it as my Chinese aptitude has improved so much over the semester and I always looked forward to attending this class. Despite not having taken 130xa and initially feeling apprehensive about taking this class, I found that the class had a really welcoming environment. There's also a big variation in skill level between people who take the class, which also helps.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: Super fun class! Teachers are awesome (supportive, encouraging, etc).  There definitely is a lot of work to keep up with, but it is very rewarding and the teachers are usually nice about giving extensions if you talk to them before hand and explain the situation. Would definitely recommend you to take this class!
subject: Chinese

course_title: Intro to Chinese in the Social Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is AMAZING!!! I highly highly recommend taking it. The course is VERY low stress, and even though the assignments may seem like a lot it is very manageable and the teachers do a very good job being flexible. It was incredibly interesting as well, and I think a great way to learn Chinese while also learning more about Chinese history!!!

I loved this class. The teachers are fantastic, and all of the assignments are super fair. This semester, there were no exams, just lots of oral presentations that you could prepare for ahead of time. It was well organized and really interesting.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Art and Violence in the Cultural Revolution 01
best_comment: This is a fantastic class! Tian Laoshi is a really engaging lecturer and a really sweet person too. The course materials are interesting – you get to read and discuss primary sources from the Cultural Revolution in the original Chinese. If you have an advanced background in Chinese, highly recommend!

course_title: Life and Death in Late Imperial China: Social History of the 10th to 19th Centuries 01
best_comment: This class is very interesting and provides you with a very solid understanding of the social fabric of pre–modern China. Prof. Szonyi is fantastic. He is extremely engaging and knowledgeable. His lectures are eye–opening and deal with many topics typically overlooked in history. His lectures draw from a wide breadth of disciplines, including historiography, archeology, visual studies, and economics. His analysis is consistently very nuanced. I strongly recommend the class to someone interested in understanding what life was actually like in pre–modern China.
worse_comment: This class is extremely disorganized: professor would always show up late, no reminders for assignments coming up, moving due dates, TF hired last minute and didn't even study Chinese history, would often not finish content in lectures, very obvious that Szonyi does not prioritize undergraduate teaching. The content was mildly interesting, but because it was social history, you learn extremely specific details (such as what violence looked like at the time) but lacked an overall understanding of Chinese political history.

course_title: Topics in Warring States History: Seminar 01
best_comment: This is an exciting class for anyone interested in pre imperial Chinese thought.

course_title: Modern History of Rural China: Proseminar 01
best_comment: Prof. Szonyi is great at leading class discussions and asks very thought–provoking discussion questions to generate a heated debate. Highly recommend this class for anyone doing Modern Chinese/East Asian history.

course_title: Strange Tales: The Supernatural in Chinese Literature 01
best_comment: This class is a great way to read fun stories in Chinese literature. I did not have any background in anything related to China, but the coursework was still very approachable and enjoyable. There are multiple readings per week, but the amount is very reasonable. The readings are very interesting, there is a lot of freedom to explore your own interests in the projects and final paper, and Professor Kelly is really great. I am definitely happy to have taken this class and recommend it to anyone that may be interested !!
subject: Chinese Literature

course_title: China's Banned Book: Reading Jin Ping Mei (Conference Course) 01
best_comment: If you are broadly interested in Chinese/Asian literature and history, this course is a must–take, as it not only immerses students in the novel itself, it also introduces us to new ways of seeing (scholarly, everyday, artistic, et cetera).  There is so much potential for personal and scholarly growth by engaging with Jinpingmei and also the class. In a way, the class really does the novel justice.

course_title: Introduction to the Study of East Asia: Issues and Methods 001
best_comment: This is an absolutely amazing course. If you are even remotely considering studying EAS, take this course and you'll be sold. It's quite a bit of work at times, as the readings aren't the shortest some weeks (some of the guest lecturers have more dense material to discuss), but it's super rewarding and a great experience. Take it take it take it!
worse_comment: A solid intro class to the EAS department. The course covers a wide array of topics and different professors are brought in each week to discuss their field of expertise. A lot of the content (not all) is historical though, so this may not be the best course if you want exposure to topics on modern East Asia.
subject: East Asian Studies

course_title: East Asian Religions: Traditions and Transformations 01
best_comment: This course was amazing!! Seriously one of my favorite courses I've taken at Harvard. Professor Robson is an amazing and engaging lecturer who clearly has a deep knowledge and understanding of the subject matter. I found all of the material interesting and engaging and this was a very good introduction to the religious landscape of Asia/East Asia.
best_gem_comment: This is a GREAT course if you want to gain an introduction to many of the major east asian religions. There is a focus on the historical concepts that formed these religions and assignments are not overly time–intensive and very reasonably graded. I had no EASTD experience prior to this and really enjoyed the course, but might be less interesting to you if you have some prior knowledge on the topic since it seemed like we covered very introductory topics. Overall a great course and a gem!

course_title: Digital Tools and Methods in East Asian Humanities: Coding Approach 01
best_comment: This has been one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Harvard. Kwok–leong is one of the funniest and most down–to–earth professors I have ever had in this college. The course is great because it teaches you how to use Chat GPT to build a lot of interesting projects. However, I do think that if you've never written a line of code before that this course will be quite difficult. I think this is an excellent introduction, however, on how to use Chat GPT and tools in the digital humanities to build really cool projects that you can use to showcase on your resume as well! Please take it!
subject: East Asian Studies

best_comment: This course was absolutely fantastic – one of my absolute favorites that I've taken during my time at Harvard. Professor Abe is a wonderful teacher who cares deeply about and tries to get to know all his students. His lectures are great, and he is clearly very knowledgeable on the subject. The content itself is extremely interesting, and forces one to grapple with/question their understanding of the world if they don't have any prior exposure to Buddhist teachings. The way in which the class explores how Buddhist ideas manifest in Japanese arts (performing arts, visual arts, etc.) is fascinating, and afterwards you will almost surely start to notice how these ideas manifest in the types of media you consume. I also liked the structure of the lectures/content, where the introduction of different Buddhist schools was introduced alongside the types of art that are characteristic of them. The assignments are very fair and flexible: Professor Abe emphasizes that the final project is meant to be an enjoyable experience for you, and is very open to different kinds of academic or creative projects. The amount of reading is reasonable, but more importantly the readings themselves are interesting!I can't recommend this class enough, even if you haven't taken classes in the EAS department before – it is very accessible, so long as you keep an open mind and follow along with the class materials.
subject: East Asian Studies

best_comment: Really enjoyed taking this course. Prof. Koss is amazing! He is super knowledgable on the topic matter, and is also very accessible. He is always willing to help and I really appreciated his guidance.  Loved this course a lot!
worse_comment: Excellent Professor, interesting but difficult assigned readings

course_title: Language, Script, and Power in East Asia 01
best_comment: professor park is really enthusiastic and nice! it's very fun taking class with her.
subject: East Asian Studies

best_comment: Japanese is such a great class, it blazes through a lot of content really fast but as long as you keep up with assignments you'll actually learn all of it pretty well by the end. The teachers are all so nice and helpful and all of the events have really good food (soba, sushi, Japanese snacks, etc) so it's just a really fun class to be in. ***
subject: Japanese

best_comment: So much fun. Kageyama sensei, Sakomura sensei, and Natakani sensei and all Fantastic. Absolutely take this course. Good food, good people, first step towards watching anime without subtitles. 10/10 course, my favorite at Harvard
subject: Japanese

best_comment: It's a great course! Kageyama sensei is great at explaining difficult points and is a really caring teacher. I took it without having taken Japan BA but felt all the necessary support for me to catch up and feel confident about speaking Japanese. The activities across the semester are also very fun.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Most fun class series (Japanese in general) that I have taken here. Is a lot of work but you are definitely rewarded.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: *I love Japanese at Harvard. I’m so sad to be done with my citation because this class is easily my favorite I’ve ever taken at Harvard. If youmre considering taking this class, do it. You will learn so much and be supported so much by the teaching Staff.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: I would be hesitant to recommend 130 to people who have just taken elementary Japanese and 120 without any other exposure to Japanese (e.g., living in Japan for some time, regular speaking practice outside of class, etc.) because the difficulty level increases a lot from 120 to 130. The work load is super high (you will be doing 2 hours of homework every day) in addition to the class meeting every day, so I felt like I was mainly completing assignments but not actually improving my language skills that much. For example, we usually had to learn 80 Kanji compounds per lesson, so I would just memorize them for the test but forget most of them afterwards. The class would really benefit from a lower workload in favor of more in–depth review and speaking practice. On the other hand, the senseis are incredibly kind, the class environment is warm and enjoyable, and the readings are really interesting. So it really depends on the skill level you come into the class with and what you want to get out of it.
worse_comment: Expect to work hard, but to learn a lot! 頑張るね！
subject: Japanese

course_title: Readings and Discussion in Japanese Social Sciences 001
best_comment: This is it –– the final frontier. This is the highest level of Japanese offered at the greatest school in the world. To be honest, if there is one thing that all 150B students know, it is that the 'real' language–learning journey starts AFTER this class. This class is merely the turnstile that you have to pass through in order to start your adventure in earnest. To truly become a sage in the field of Japanese Studies, you have to ascend to a point where you no longer have an explicit 'need' for teachers. So, if you like REALLY like learning Japanese, try making it to the point where you get to write a comment like this one!
subject: Japanese

best_comment: If you enjoyed Korean BA, definitely take BB! It's more of the same except better :)
worse_comment: always pay attention in class because you could get called on at any moment and you don't want to be embarrassed when you don't know the answer
subject: Korean

best_comment: Please take Korean! The faculty is amazing and are so helpful. I have had some really awful language teachers in high school, but I am blown away by how amazing this department is. The classes are really well organized and help is always available. Korean is definitely not an easy language, but it is very well taught and a lot of fun.
subject: Korean

best_comment: The Korean language department is always very lovely; I think Korean is one of the best languages you can take at this school. The class was a little bit smaller than the first course of this series, so I felt like our class formed a connection of some kind. 노 선생님 and 김환희 선생님 are great instructors. I really enjoyed coming to Korean each day and participating in class. You can tell they really enjoy teaching Korean, and I think that is partly why this class has been my favorite course of the semester.
subject: Korean

best_comment: This is not an easy class, but it is incredibly rewarding and definitely worth taking. Because the class size is small, you will become close friends with the people in your class and it will be a great community to lean on.  The teachers are wonderful and so supportive, and they really care about your learning. I really recommend taking this class.
worse_comment: It was hard but thorough!
subject: Korean

best_comment: This class was more work than I expected but it was a lot of fun! The instructors were great, and the other students were really kind :)
subject: Korean

best_comment: You should definitely take this class if you're interested in learning or improving your Vietnamese! The entry level to this is low–to–middle proficiency with Vietnamese alphabet, spelling, and grammar. The speaking level is not overly high, and the expectation of hours/week is very reasonable. Co Hoa is the greatest language teacher, and she made the course super fun and worthwhile 4 days a week. I have greatly improved my speaking, reading, AND writing skills through my 1 semester of BB, and I'm very happy about it.
subject: Vietnamese

best_comment: This class is very fun, but this is very dependent on who your classmates are. This year's class has been awesome in that everyone in the class wanted to learn. This type of environment will make the class go by quick. This class is a chonky class with two hours of sitting, but it's great if it's two hours spent with cool people. The instructor is also very fun and encourages learning and making mistakes. There are little penalties for making mistakes. Because of this, I think everyone continued to enjoy and practice Vietnamese freely.
subject: Vietnamese

best_comment: With the exception of the tests, this class is honestly great! Assignments are manageable...4 short essays (but you can drop one) plus weekly psets that are basically done in section. Professor Le Brun is kind and a very considerate teacher, and TFs are lovely! Literally the only downside is that the exams are a bit brutal...even if you feel like you understand the content well, the exam averages were 70s or below every time. Exam questions are frustratingly subjective, but Professor Le Brun was always willing to try to understand different perspectives and would give back points on some questions (so make sure you always ask if you feel like your interpretation was valid)! There is also a curve applied to exam grades, so don't worry too much! Overall, a great class
worse_comment: The off–cycle version of this class is no bueno. It was so hard and as someone who has never taken an Econ class before it was not an actual introductory class. Also I was just tryna take a low stress Econ class where I could learn the basics of economics. This class is not good for that. In other words do not take this class unless you need to for a concentration requirement and in that case take the fall version.
best_gem_comment: Off–cycle ec10a is much better than the regular fall class. The class is much smaller (100 people), there are fewer assignments, and Anne is super nice. The tests, including the final, are also virtual and open note.  Finally, don’t be afraid that the tests may initially seem hard: the average was ~70% for each of our tests but Anne said that they would be curved. A definite gem.
subject: Economics

best_comment: AWESOME CLASS. I have never formally studied economics before coming to Harvard, and Ec10A I took last semester and Ec10B this semester are both really good classes that makes me fall in love with economics. It is not a hard class but would give you lots of insights into how macroeconomics work (including very interesting topics at least for me like America's debt, inflation, trade deficit). This is not the main reason I like the class, but in case you love some random treats this class actually often has random cash prizes for some economic game or free books (I actually got a free book on the Fed. ). David and Jason are really nice and engaging people too. I am someone who spends my spare time reading the Financial Times or The Economist for relaxation and yet I still learn a lot from this class.
worse_comment: Even though it is an introductory course, the class is extremely fast paced and topics are brushed over. The class can be difficult if you've never taken a course like AP macro before, especially because the class is so big (enough people do well) and the grading is horrific.
subject: Economics

best_comment: AWESOME CLASS. I have never formally studied economics before coming to Harvard, and Ec10A I took last semester and Ec10B this semester are both really good classes that makes me fall in love with economics. It is not a hard class but would give you lots of insights into how macroeconomics work (including very interesting topics at least for me like America's debt, inflation, trade deficit). subject: Economics

course_title: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems 001
best_comment: As a whole, this class is really great! Professor Chetty is a great lecturer, albeit a little slow and dull, but the content is super interesting and will introduce you to all these different sectors of social policy, like racial disparity, economic disparity, healthcare, education, etc. and how we can use different research to improve on it. All the different papers and research results we cover are so fascinating and will just totally change the way you look at all these social issues and give an empirical framework to analyze them and create change, which I love. The only caveat to this course is the assessments: they test you on really specific information that isn't really relevant to the overarching themes and conceptual parts of this course. Since this course is kind of like an overview of a bunch of different research, it's kind of to be expected, but I felt it was silly to be asked questions about the methodology of a particular research experiment or whether it was replicated, instead of applying the concepts in a different way. However, content wise, this course was amazing! So fascinating and so interesting.
worse_comment: exams are difficult as they are very specific to lectures, grading on labs is very unfair as you get 2/3 if you get even one part wrong on the lab
best_gem_comment: Gem elective class and is good because it is quantitative without being extremely hard; definitely will help you see if you like the quantitative side of economics on an intro level; my advice is to take this class as an elective if you are a Stat or AM concentrator because it definitely on the better side of electives for those concentrations.
subject: Economics

course_title: Using Big Data to Solve Economic and Social Problems 001

subject: Economics

best_comment: A topic that can be at some points dry but very important and interesting! Take this if you are looking for a theoretically challenging (but not necessarily  very discussion based) seminar.
worse_comment: Don't take Baranga's class. Confusing to listen to and he frequently had 40+ slides for each class that he would never get through, and he would always end class late.
subject: Economics

best_comment: A topic that can be at some points dry but very important and interesting! Take this if you are looking for a theoretically challenging (but not necessarily  very discussion based) seminar.
worse_comment: Don't take Baranga's class. Confusing to listen to and he frequently had 40+ slides for each class that he would never get through, and he would always end class late.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I really enjoyed the 'Natural Experiments' section! Even though the instructor is changing, this section covers a myriad of interesting topics and really allows you the flexibility to explore whatever niche interests you. Super helpful if you're considering a thesis.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I really enjoyed the 'Natural Experiments' section! Even though the instructor is changing, this section covers a myriad of interesting topics and really allows you the flexibility to explore whatever niche interests you. Super helpful if you're considering a thesis.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Overall a wonderful class. The readings are super interesting & span a wide range of topics, and class discussions are interesting, especially because a lot of the readings are about topics that are super relevant today (e.g., wealth inequality, racial and gender disparities). You learn to read & think critically about economics papers
worse_comment: This is a painful experience, but you will learn from it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Overall a wonderful class. The readings are super interesting & span a wide range of topics, and class discussions are interesting, especially because a lot of the readings are about topics that are super relevant today (e.g., wealth inequality, racial and gender disparities). You learn to read & think critically about economics papers
worse_comment: This is a painful experience, but you will learn from it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I took Professor Rice’s class on Applied Health Economics. He was super laid back, which made our class a really nice environment because everyone felt comfortable asking a ton of questions that went behind the reading. He was always fair on grading.
worse_comment: Start the paper early!! Finding datasets for the final paper can be challenging – sometimes you need to request for data and that can take a while, so make sure to budget sufficient time. Also take advantage of R and Stata office hours, there are lots of those! Personally, I decided to learn Stata through the coding psets, only to realize at the very end that I do not like using Stata and reverted back to using R, which I was more comfortable with, for the final project instead. I think there could potentially be value in exposing yourself to a new coding language, especially since Stata is widely used in economics, but I would not recommend doing what I did because it made the final project slightly more painful since I had to relearn the econometric techniques in R (also the coding psets because I was raging all the time at Stata haha).
subject: Economics

best_comment: I took Professor Rice’s class on Applied Health Economics. He was super laid back, which made our class a really nice environment because everyone felt comfortable asking a ton of questions that went behind the reading. He was always fair on grading.

subject: Economics

best_comment: As an economics major, this is definitely the best course I've taken in the concentration so far.  I learned so much about development economics and the reading materials were great– there was so much variety in the readings that class was never dull. This is the course I've learned from the most in my Harvard career thus far, and Ronak is an excellent TF who is incredibly passionate about the topic, and genuinely encourages her students to learn from each other. While the class definitely requires work, it is the most rewarding economics class I've taken so far!
subject: Economics

best_comment: As an economics major, this is definitely the best course I've taken in the concentration so far.  I learned so much about development economics and the reading materials were great– there was so much variety in the readings that class was never dull. This is the course I've learned from the most in my Harvard career thus far, and Ronak is an excellent TF who is incredibly passionate about the topic, and genuinely encourages her students to learn from each other. While the class definitely requires work, it is the most rewarding economics class I've taken so far!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class. Cirrus is an amazing teacher that lets conversations develop naturally. Out of all the Econ970 options this is the best one.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class. Cirrus is an amazing teacher that lets conversations develop naturally. Out of all the Econ970 options this is the best one.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Information Economics with Molly was incredible! By far one of my favorite classes at Harvard! This class is the best sophomore tutorial I am not lying! The material is so perfectly challenging that you are learning without being overwhelmed with work! Absolutely take this course!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Information Economics with Molly was incredible! By far one of my favorite classes at Harvard! This class is the best sophomore tutorial I am not lying! The material is so perfectly challenging that you are learning without being overwhelmed with work! Absolutely take this course!
subject: Economics

best_comment: When you are picking the courses for the EC970 lottery, I would highly recommend two things: 1) selecting a topic you are interested in, as you will be spending a considerable amount of time reading research papers and 2) if you get a chance, choose Andrés as one of your top choices! Andrés is really passionate about urban economics and his enthusiasm is contagious. He genuinely cares about his students' learning process and I found him to be the most supportive professor I had during my time at Harvard. He was always available to provide guidance and support outside of class, whether it be for Stata problem sets or the final research paper.  The class discussions were engaging, and as an introverted person, I felt comfortable speaking up in class. Finally, although the course load may seem intimidating when you initially read the syllabus, Andrés makes it really manageable by spreading out assignments well and in a way that encourages you to get ahead on your research paper. All of the assignments build on the final research paper and are helpful in the whole learning process. Without a doubt, Economics of Cities was my favorite course at Harvard and I highly recommend it if you have the opportunity to take it!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Professor Felter is great teacher and really nice guy. However, this class is a lot of work, especially the readings. I enjoyed this section overall, however, be prepared to read a lot and come to class ready to speak. If you are thinking about  pre law track this is the section is for you, however,  if you are interested in other topics this class may be a lot of work for you.

subject: Economics

best_comment: Professor Felter is one of the most caring, nice, and genuine professors that I've had at my time in Harvard. Don't be mistaken, this course is definitely an incredible amount of work and normally we were doing about ~80 pages of reading a week, sometimes more, sometimes less but I'd say on average it was about that much. However, with that said, coming into this class, I was not much of a reader but coming out of it, I've genuinely improved my ability to quickly skim and pull out the most important parts from readings (which is a super great skill in my opinion to have). Professor Felter cares so incredibly much about ensuring that you succeed –– he leaves a large breadth of comments on your assignments that makes it very very clear on how you can improve for your next one. I've never had a professor be so thoughtful and engaging in our comments. He is extremely accessible outside of class, scheduling office hours 1–on–1 with you around your schedule and it was wonderful getting to know him. He is a super cool guy overall –– a lot of amazing stories from when he was a lawyer and through law school. Overall, I think this course is a pretty good introduction to what *might* be expected in a law school class and I think it genuinely helped convince me that I for sure want to go to law school because I was on the fence when I had taken this class about it. Additionally, even though professor Felter cold calls at times, what I appreciated was he never made you feel dumb or stupid or isolated if you didn't know the answer. He genuinely just wants to lead a nice and productive conversation during class and it's a much more enjoyable experience when everyone in the section has done the readings and is able to engage. I'd for sure be ready to put a good ~10 hours into the course each week, at minimum, if you want to get a good grade and really engage with the content. Normally the readings took me around ~4 hours/week (probably a little more towards the beginning of the semester) to really dig into them and understand them (especially when we had to do our assignments based on the readings) and another good ~6–8 hours each week working on the assignments which again, professor Felter spends an incredible amount of time and care with grading them so I'd for sure spend a good amount of time and care in writing them. Overall, such an incredible course and easily one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard despite the fact that it was definitely a heavier load than normal classes.
worse_comment: For me, reading is not my strong suit so this class was difficult. Dedicate some good time to focus on your readings and problem sets and writing assignments cause they pile up a ton.
subject: Economics

best_comment: chose your tutorial wisely. Some are much more difficult than others. For example, Anne Le Brun's tutorial has different sets just for the class, so you can't work with other people. for AI and innovation specifically, it's an easier class but still a good amount of work. I do wish people were held more accountable, as people would regularly come in 20 minutes late without any repercussions which hurt the learning environment, but overall it was fine. Not amazing, not the worst.

best_comment: This is a brilliant course! Professor Goldin and Professor Katz make the classes extremely enjoyable and engaging. There is a lot of feedback provided on the assignments, proposal, and draft by both professors as well as the TF, which make the process of writing the final paper and learning about research in Education a lot less overwhelming. Ethan was our TF, and he was extremely helpful for every aspect of the course; always happy to help and able to solve all problems! Professors Goldin and Professor Katz also made themselves available to speak to everyone and provided a lot of helpful feedback on each step of the course. Of course, the workload of this course cannot be undermined, but it was the most rewarding experience for me at Harvard in all of my four years. If you want to learn about education and research and engage in educational research, this is the best course to take.
subject: Economics

course_title: Readings on Market Imperfections and Implications for Government Intervention 001
best_comment: Really really enjoyed this class –– definitely one of my top 3 classes at Harvard. The topics we covered are so important and it's really cool to see how economists have been approaching the problems. This is one of the only classes where I've felt like the content actually /mattered/ in real life. The final paper is super tough and it's a good idea to get started early. I would definitely recommend this class if you're considering writing a thesis –– the class gives you some experience doing your own research if you haven't done that before and also is probably a good indicator if you'll actually enjoy the thesis process.

Great class, not too intensive to learn about economic growth. Prof Barro is incredibly knowledgable about the subject and explains material in an easily digestible way. Also provides interesting snippets/connections for the material.
worse_comment: This is basically independent research with a weekly lecture. There are no assignments, rubrics, syllabus, or grades.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is great if you are interested in Industrial organization or health policy and want to gain more familiarity with the econometrics/methods used behind crucial papers in the industry.  I think this class has also helped as I start to brainstorm thesis topics. You'll learn a lot; Professor Pakes is very knowledgable and Ed, the TF, is amazing and supportive.

Professor Stein is such an engaging lecturer and truly makes the class worth it! He's funny, kind to all his students (he very actively makes sure that people feel comfortable participating even if they don't have a lot of knowledge in the topic area), and extremely good at explaining complex topics.
