best_comment: Doesn't get much better than this for a class on microeconomic theory. If you're an EC concentrator, take this class in the spring (off cycle). If you're a secondary, take it over 1010B AND take it in the spring. Melitz is truly a sweetheart and takes student feedback very seriously. the PSETs are similar to EC10A/B mylabs but with unlimited attemptd so the focus is on actually learning the material. quizzes are very similar to PSETs. lectur4e can be a bit confusing but go to section!!! it's optional but its where you'll learn how to actually do the PSETs and stuff for exams. 2 midterms and final, not much different from the practice exams he supplies so use those wisely since you don't get a cheatsheet or calculator. the class is very fast paced and we usually had 2–3 PSETs & quizzes per week (ranging from 4–6 hours of work on those alone) so prioritize your time well and take a balanced schedule. overall, I really enjoyed Melitz and I think he's wonderful! definitely recommend this class in spring over fall (unlimited PSET attempts, HUGE exam curve, very helpful section, only 2x a week)
worse_comment: Take it in the Spring. Meets only twice a week instead of 3. Psets are online psets with unlimited attempts so you have no pressure to do them perfect and you actually learn from them. Heavily based on exams but it is curved so if you understand all the psets you should be fine. Hard content and time consuming but it is what it is.  Ec1010a can't get better than this
subject: Economics

best_comment: I absolutely loved 1010b! It's definitely my favorite required lecture course for the ec concentration. I went into the course very nervous because I had heard it was difficult, but I actually really enjoyed the course because the material was so interesting and Prof. Foote is such a great lecturer. This might just be a personal thing, but I found macro way more interesting than micro, so even though 1010a was definitely easier than 1010b, I enjoyed 1010b so much more. A couple tips: the exams are very tricky, but are very manageable if you put in enough time. Take the time to review the lecture slides (like REALLY review the lecture slides), read the textbook, do the practice tests, review the psets, and you'll be fine. It can be super easy to fall behind in this class because lectures are recorded and psets aren't required, but don't let yourself fall behind! Force yourself to go to section every week — I would usually look at the psets and not have a single clue how to start them, so section was helpful in showing me how to approach the questions and keeping me on schedule for the course.
worse_comment: I would heavily caution you if you are looking to take this course. If you are not concentrating in economics and have a choice to not take this class then do not take it! My knowledge of economics was hurt by being forced to memorize countless models that were taught in a way that was so disjointed that I lost any idea of why we were learning them. When it comes to the final, you are given no support in the preparation and are forced to review and learn content from the entirety of the course on your own. Also 90% of your grade being formed from multiple–choice tests is crazy! AVOID THIS CLASS!
subject: Economics

best_comment: If you took 1011A this is much better (**). There's basic setting up of equations, FOCs, and solving but unlike 1011A there's a lot more intuition and explaining which makes this course soo good. Ludwig is INCREDIBLE! He taught the first half of the course and it was so much fun – he is THE BEST lecturer I've ever had and an amazing person. I've never been in a more captivating lecturer with a professor who cares more about his students. Unfortunately shortly after the 1st midterm, Gabriel took over and that was tough... He's unfortunately not engaging at all and it became tough to come to class. In terms of the TFs – if Mike is teaching again you want him – he's the best, very funny, very knowledgeable and an amazing person, if Jake is still there – he's not as a good as Mike but is very sweet.In terms of the actual structure, weekly psets weren't too bad – needed more office hours on weekends though (watch out after the first half the problem sets switch from being due on Thursdays to being due on Tuesdays....). Sections are the best and really are a life saver. The exams themselves are very fair and doing the practice exam and review problems is all you need. The TFs go out of their way to do a 3 to 4h recorded zoom review session close to the exam and so lots of credit to them. All in all, AMAZING class, much better than 1011A, and one that I'm so glad I took.
worse_comment: Ludwig and Mike are awesome. Gabe and Jake are not. The first half of this course (with Ludwig) was very fun, interesting, and engaging. I felt like I was learning models but also applying those models to the real world and actually learning economics. The second half (with Gabe) is awful. Gabe is boring, doesn't appear to care much about the course, and hasn't looked at his slides since he last taught the course three years ago. He might be the worst lecturer I have ever had (and I've had Joe Blitzstein).
subject: Economics

course_title: The Psychology and Economics of Beliefs 001
best_comment: The lecture and discussion content in class is interesting, and so is the pset content, the problem is that they’re two very different things. The course generally is not super well organized, and the psets (primarily the first 2) were pretty unrelated to the material covered in class and it didn’t feel like there was adequate preparation. The pset questions also felt convoluted and difficult to interpret at times. In the weeks between psets (which can vary unpredictably) the course is very chill, but when the psets are assigned the workload spikes drastically. Overall the professor is very nice and knows a lot, and the material is interesting, I just think it could be executed better. If you have a strong statistics background you’ll be fine, otherwise I would have some reservations if the course is structured the same way it was this semester.
worse_comment: This course is very disorganized and you never really know what to expect. The professor will say one thing and do another, and the TF makes little effort to stay on track. That said, if you go to office hours to do the problem sets, the course assignments aren't terrible. But the structure and consistent lack of direction or expectations make it a little frustrating. This is a shame because, on paper, the course seems awesome, as it is taught by a very famous professor in a small setting while covering interesting subject matter.

best_comment: The course is very interesting if you are a sports lover. Cramer definitely has a passion for economics of sports, but sometimes has moments where he goes too in depth and it becomes hard to follow. However, the material covered was interesting to follow, and this is coming from a person who follows sports in depth. The assignments are challenging but they are spread out and you have plenty of time to do them. You need a knowledge of a coding language in order to do them. The midterm was very challenging but Cramer recognized this and hopefully the final (which we haven't taken yet) will be more realistic. Take this class if you need a theory elective and love sports, lectures are easy to listen to if you love sports.
worse_comment: The midterm and final were very difficult
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is a bit strange because the readings aren't helpful and the lectures are interesting but information relevant to PSET's is scattered between them. Section is amazing though and super helpful. There isn't much materials outside of the slides but the midterm was fine. The final was a lot harder but I'm hoping it will be curved. The in–class games are fun. I would recommend paying attention to lecture, don't worry about taking notes, just absorb major concepts. Section will be more helpful for PSET's but paying consistent attention to topics as they arise is important for the final because they aren't addressed in the PSET's. It's definitely a manageable class but set aside more time than you think for assessment prep.
worse_comment: It is a difficult class, but interesting. Pay attention in lecture because the psets will be based on those, and the lecture slides are not great.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This a great class to learn about the intersection of the economy and education. We examined this connection through many different lenses which was cool. The first half of the course was a lot more difficult than the second due to all the math and econometrics we had to use. The description on my.harvard does not do enough to emphasize the need for an econometrics type course background. The final project was fun but was a little unstructured and the feedback portion of the presentations was not structured the same for everyone. The memo project presentation was the same; for some groups, Professor Carlana wanted them to know a lot of information about each article, and for other groups she went very easy on them. Overall this was a great course. Just make sure you are interested in the topic, know some econometrics, work well in groups from different schools and levels of education, and want to read and participate.

I had an absolute blast in this class. It is difficult but definitely not as difficult as everyone makes it out to seem. If you go to lecture, section, and office hours, you will actually succeed in this class. This is coming from someone who found all of the micro/macro classes here very hard. Unlike some of the other professors in the department, Bruich does NOT have it out for you—in contrast, he actually wants you to succeed. I mean, look at how cute this message was after the midterm, "I try to be thoughtful in the grading of the exams, because that is what I would have wanted as a student.  To help ensure that you are assessed fairly and accurately, each question for all 180 students is graded by the same person.  We do the same for the final exam.  Overall, the class grades on a generous curve since the class is advanced and covers state of the art methods.  Typically, one can even be below the median overall and receive an A–.  We have important work ahead of us. There’s still a lot left, so there’s plenty of time to recover if you did not do as well as you would have liked.  Please keep working hard and focus on learning as much as possible together.   If you are having difficulties of any kind (health related or otherwise), please reach out to me.  I am willing and able to make accommodations.  I feel strongly that econometrics is something that you will use throughout the rest of your careers at Harvard and beyond.  Please do your very best to master metrics and let's do it together." Like hello?? I've never gotten a message like that from any other econ professor here. I'm ngl, sometimes lecture is overwhelming/hard to follow, but if you come into the class realizing that you don't need to understand everything, your life will get so much easier. For me personally, I went to lecture to broadly orient myself on the topic we were learning, and I learned everything I needed to know in section. THIS MAKES IT IMPERATIVE THAT YOU PICK A CA THAT ACTUALLY KNOWS WHAT THEY'RE DOING & HOW TO EXPLAIN THE CONTENT. I hated this course for the first 2 weeks because my CA was a grad student who just wasn't good at explaining anything. I changed my section to Gaby's and she honestly saved my econometrics experience. #queengabyIn terms of the exams, they are VERY fair. They're very similar to previous practice exams and the questions that are tested are not hard at all. The questions were majority "interpret this coefficient" and "pick an omitted variable" which we spend so much time doing. Trust, if you're on top of the class throughout the semester you will be fine 100%. The psets take a little bit of time but so long as you go to OH they're def manageable. Also, Professor Bruich is an absolute king. He should be treated as such. #harvarddoesn'tdeservehim
worse_comment: This class can be challenging and time–consuming, but I think it's 100% worth taking it. Most people don't have a choice (because it's a requirement for concentrating in Economics), but even if it wasn't, I'd still recommend it to students. There really isn't any other class (from what I know) that teaches you how to actually conduct your own research, how to properly interpret your results, how to adequately convey the uncertainty regarding those results. This class is not super focused on coding (the teaching staff gives you sample code for every problem set and the exams don't entail any coding), but it's really hard to do well on the psets without having at least some familiarity with one of three coding languages (STATA, R, or Python). Exams are not too hard, but they're really long and the midterm especially is a time–crunch.
subject: Economics

course_title: The Economics of Development and Global Health 001
best_comment: This class is AWESOME! It's genuinely a "transformative experience" type class that you expect from Harvard Honestly, if Matt teaches this you should definitely take it. Completely reshpaed my view on the world, and delves into stuff that is definitely at the forefront of new ground in economics, public health, and generally in the social sciences. There is a lot of content covered, so it does sometimes feel like a firehose of information, but that's the byproduct of really interesting course I think. Paper + final gets a bit tedious, but not unappreciative of it – it's definitely stretched me in a positive way. The TFs are very helpful and overall very approachable and supportive. Matt is the best – guy's a resident at Yale medical school, comes down twice a week (mind you he didn't need to set up the second class time slot) to teach this, and alongside that he Djs in class, did work at the World Bank, etc etc. Guy's awesome! I wish I had some more time this semester because even though I think this class really changed me, I think it would probably be life–altering if I really engaged with it more than I did. Overall, loved it, and regardless of what grade I get, I think this was incredible.
worse_comment: This class has a sort of religious fervor that seems not particularly focused on actually solving the important problems at hand and more focused on showing everyone how much the people professing the faith believe in their cause.  There were lots of cases where seemingly arbitrary numbers like 20 billion dollars to solve homelessness or 90 billion to solve all global health problems were thrown out with basically no concrete policies attached to what this money would do.  Lots of major world problems were presented, but few new or insightful ideas were presented on how to solve them.  Lectures and sections consisted of little new and concrete content and were mostly filled with people spitballing ideas about how to solve the major problems (and probably 99% of these ideas were either nonsense or were already being researched or implemented).  Matt got very sick over spring break and understandably needed some time to recover, but the course pretty much fell apart after the midterm: we learned probably 5–10 new concrete items between the midterm and the final.  The level of nonsense ideas allowed in class and section and the lack of concrete policies also contributed to a situation in which most people stopped reading the textbook because people could get 100s on all the assignments (even the midterm and final) by regurgitating a few buzzwords and writing long–winded vague opinion pieces.  This was a shame because the textbook and the associated journal articles were the only pieces of this course that actually had concrete, coherent explanations and policy proposals.All in all, if you're looking for an easy course, this is the class for you.  If you want to learn new concrete information about global health and be challenged and pushed in your thinking, this probably isn't the course for you.
best_gem_comment: If this course is taught again, because I am not sure if it will be, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! The professor, Matt, truly cares about you as a person not just as a student. Many professors talk about the fact that they care about your mental health and wellbeing, but Matt truly means it. He is always willing to talk about the class during office hours or about anything. He is also just a very interesting guy. All of the grades have not come back yet (paper and final exam) but it is definitely a GEM of a Econ elective. Everything is low stakes and they are not trying to trick you – they want to see you just engage with the content of the course and if you put effort in, you will get an A. So if this class if offered again next year – TAKE IT!!! The downside was that it was taught at night from 8 – 10 pm, but that could change and he plays EDM music and DJs a little to help keep you engaged. I cannot say enough great things about this class – so seriously take it!

best_comment: Take this class if political economy is a possible senior thesis topic for you, but only take it if you are truly passionate about political economy. You're expected to write a 25–page paper which is really non–trivial for a semester's work (finding a good topic, finding good data, finding significant results – none of these are guaranteed). I liked that Andrei made the course meeting times (once a week, 2 hours) as chill as possible, and he really gave us maximum space to pursue our research interests while making sure to meet frequently to ensure we were on track. It's hard work, but the good part of it is, if you find something good, you would already have done significant legwork for your thesis.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This is a very good class if you are interested in learning about an economic view on religion (but it's NOT about what religion has to say about economics, to be clear). The Profs. are so helpful and you can do well in this class without being an econ genius. The lectures are sometimes dry and difficult to sit through (our seminar was from 3–5 on Wednesdays, which is also a hard time slot to focus in). There are two 8–10 page papers (basically present an argument and defend it), and you will probably need to do outside research to flesh out your thoughts. There is also a 15–20 page final research paper, but it's not too bad if you start early. A key thing in this course is to go to the Professors for feedback before assignments are due: they will tell you what you need to fix/improve, and if you address their feedback you have a very good chance of getting a top grade. Finally, if you are a student with strong religious convictions, I will say that this class takes a materialistic approach to religion, and so there are some interpretations/portrayals that you will not agree with because of a difference in first principles. That's fine, and you can also register disagreement (politely of course). It's a useful way to think about religious belief and activity, but just keep in mind that how you might see religion is different from how economics sees religion.Actually finally: YOU DO NOT NEED TO BUY THE BOOK. This was not clear to me. I ended up buying it (it's like $30) but it's provided for you on Canvas through Library Reserves.
subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: Take it!! Professor Chari is fantastic. She is a phenomenal lecturer and explains things so well, and makes time to answer questions. The teaching staff returned things in a timely manner, and grading was fair and understanding. As someone who is generally uninterested in macroeconomics, I truly loved attending class and found it easy to pay attention and to stay engaged. Professor Chari is clearly an expert, fantastic at lecturing, and a wonderful teacher.
worse_comment: Pay very close attention in lecture and take detailed notes.

course_title: Economics of Climate Change and Environmental Policy 001
best_comment: Dr. Mettetal was not a good teacher, but if you’re taking this in a year with Prof. Stavins then I expect it would be much better.Here are my thoughts on Dr. Mettetal’s version of 1661:Let me preface all of this by saying first that Dr. Mettetal seems like a great person. Really kind, someone who you can easily approach after class, and who’s interested in the work she does. But she is not a very good teacher. She is not an engaging lecturer and lacks command of the classroom, and runs through such a high volume of slides that it’s hard to see what is important. Lecture often feels like you’re just having facts listed at you without any real analysis or synthesis of what you should know.Here are the pros of 1661: the workload is light, the tests are easy (if you’re not a braindead ESPP/ec major), and the lecture notes are well organized so you can read through them quickly to pattern–match the answers to the psets when you inevitably stop going to lecture.In general, I had some other qualms with 1661. The class is designed essentially as an intro–level econ/ESPP class, so the economic theory discussed is very shallow and not that interesting. The first half of the class is focused on theory, of which there is probably 45 minutes total of valuable content, and the second half of the class goes through policy examples and case studies. 1661 is very much a survey class that covers a wide range of topics in environmental and energy economics, but at the end of the day does not leave you with the satisfaction of feeling like you can confidently understand any individual topic at a deep level. It’s not a bad class (since the workload/grading is quite nice), but it will not be a world–changing or particularly fulfilling experience. Go ahead and take it, but with very tempered expectations. (Assuming you have Dr. Mettetal.)
worse_comment: I am disappointed that I took this class the only semester when Stavins was not teaching it. After one guest lecture with him, I immediately could tell the difference between what should have been my experience in this class and what I ended up getting : dry lectures that were read off the screen and tfs who seemed just as confused as we were on the economic concepts with an inability to explain in a way that helped improve our understanding.
best_gem_comment: This class has the potential to be great, I think under normal years when Professor Stavins is teaching it it would be way better than with Elizabeth Meatal. She moved way too fast and wasn't the best teacher where as the one lecture he came in for (he was on sabbatical) I felt like I learned so much more and he was way more engaging. The week to week coursework wasn't hard, and the class could've been gem–y if not for the midterm, which apparently was way harder then past years.
subject: Economics

best_comment: One of the best finance courses on Harvard's campus – not too difficult, but not too simple either. Would highly recommend if you are interested in asset pricing/understanding the underlying mechanisms of all types of asset markets.
worse_comment: Ec1723 was interesting even for me as a philosophy concentrator. The prereqs arent that important if you've had HS stats and ec10ab. Both pritzker and gabaix knew the material but were not great at teaching.My biggest qualm about the class is that upsets are never graded on time and are worth nothing and the final is worth 75%. So if you bomb it you're done...
subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: I'd for sure follow along every lecture –– it does get a bit hard to pay attention at times because so much content is covered in the 3 hours, but honestly, if you want to do the least work outside of lecture (like 2–3 hours a week), then you should really pay attention during lecture. I'd make sure that you can do every single PSET and group assignment inside and out –– they are often representative of the easier questions that you'll see on the exam so you for sure want to make sure that you can do them. The standard deviation on the exams are often quite large and this class is graded based on z–scores, so you want to make sure that you're performing pretty well and at least one standard deviation away from the mean to guarantee an A. Definitely not a gem, even for people who have done finance. I have friends who have done finance and did very poorly in this course because they did not prepare well for exams, so it's definitely a class that you have to *actually* pay attention and study for, but honestly nothing that you couldn't manage. Practice exams are very very very representative of what you will be tested on –– so make sure that you can do them inside and out and if you don't understand something, for sure go to Professor Bergstresser's office hours to have him explain.Lastly, I will say that Professor Bergstresser is a very caring and kind professor and is very accessible outside of class. I would often email him with questions and he'd take the time to set up a zoom with me 1–on–1 so that he could explain any confusing concepts ahead of the final presentation. Super great guy overall.
worse_comment: A good class, but way too long (3 hours on a Wednesday afternoon). Take it pass/fail if you have attention issues or if you're otherwise worried that you won't be great at grinding out calculations. You're only really tested on quantitative stuff and get cheat sheets for exams, but exams are still pretty hard so do your homework and study.

course_title: Financial Crises and Recessions of the 21st Century 001
best_comment: This is a really great course in the econ department! It's super relevant to learn about financial and banking crises even as they occur today. Professor Dynan did an amazing job covering events comprehensively (also added a special lecture on the fall of SVB). The lectures on the covid recession were also very interesting to learn, and it's really cool seeing the connection between current events and the 2008 recession. As someone with not much econ background (this was my first econ course at Harvard), it was really great learning about econ/finance concepts through "history" (i.e. the 21st century) and real–life events. I would recommend taking this class P/F because although the class is interesting, the homeworks and exams are not easy and graded pretty strictly.
worse_comment: This is a great class! As long as you put in work, you will do well. There is nothing super theoretical about the class – is more a macroeconomics history class. You should of course know basic macro but it is not super based on complex macro theory.
subject: Economics

course_title: The Financial System and the Central Bank 001
best_comment: Can be very helpful to be comfortable with econometrics, otherwise you won't really understand the papers that you are expected to read and critique. The kids who had experience interning in finance and investment banking were at a significant advantage. Same with the kids who had taken some other sort of financial economics class. I also think that you would significantly benefit from the class if you were considering an Econ PhD down the road. The class definitely expects that you know a decent amount beforehand, like acronyms of random financial concepts, but you could always look these up or just ask the professor what they are. The class also has no textbook, so if you don't really understand lecture but want to grind the material at home, you'll really only have the lecture slides, which are kind of confusing when not paired with the lecture (and office hours, of course).That being said, if you're somewhat of an outsider to the field, you can still do well –– just expect an uphill battle and the frequent feeling that everyone somehow knows more than you. Professor Stein goes out of his way to make sure that you feel comfortable approaching the topic. He really likes it when you ask questions and in fact encourages it. He's a very kind and brilliant professor –– he memorized all of our first names –– and this course is one of a kind at Harvard. Even if you don't understand everything he says at first, the mere fact that you're hearing  from someone who served on the Fed Board of Governors has a great impact on your thinking in the long run. You'll get great insight into the decisions that policymakers and bankers face, and you'll get great exposure to contrasting economic ideas. Rather than just learning how to compute rote financial metrics,  you'll learn how to critically think about financial concepts and dynamics. I think that the type of thinking Stein teaches is not only valuable for those aiming to be leaders in the world of finance, but for anyone seeking to use analytical skills in decision–making roles.
worse_comment: I learned a shit ton from this course. After this class, I feel like I really actually for the first time understand how the financial system works and why it fails. It was also a crazy experience that I took this class while the regional banking crisis was happening and CS, SVB, FR and others failed. It felt like a textbook example of exactly what we had been talking about in class. Lectures were super interesting, but Stein prioritizes participation a lot, and I felt like often the same kids kept asking questions to the point where they were asking questions just to get participation points, and it made lectures annoying. Still, I never wanted to skip a single lecture. However, other than the lectures, the rest of the class isn't so great. Stein is hard to catch hold of. The TFs were not plugged in at all. Assignments were legit graded 2–3 months after submission and most of them were just binge graded during finals period. This means no feedback on lengthy papers that you had to write regularly. Overall, the resources were just terrible. Office hours were scarce and badly timed. However, I'd still recommend taking this class because you really learn a lot and I think it's worth it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is a tank of a class. Not the easiest Senior Spring class per say, but you truly learn an incredible amount of material and the profs are rockstars. If you are interested at all in cities or especially the politics of cities, this class is a perfect entry point for learning about those things. We've have awesome guest speakers ranging from the head of the MBTA to the Mayor of Boston. There are plenty of assignments to keep you busy but they're doable with a good group and sometimes pretty interesting. A slightly difficult yet very rewarding elective to take.
worse_comment: Don't take this class if you 1) are not ready to commit to a very high level or engagement and attentiveness — a very wide range of material is covered very quickly, 2) do not feel comfortable with difficult economic concepts being covered very quickly or 3) anticipate yourself ever needing an extension on an assignment.

best_comment: Even though it's not required, going to lecture and generally keeping a good understanding of the concepts discussed is super helpful for the midterm and final exams.  You don't need to know the nitty gritty and the class is pretty chill and relaxed but don't totally run off from it mentally.
subject: Economics

best_comment: learn whatever you're interested in and don't worry about the rest

best_comment: learn whatever you're interested in and don't worry about the rest

best_comment: Great instructors make this course interesting even for people with no interest in macro.

best_comment: Great instructors make this course interesting even for people with no interest in macro.
subject: Economics

best_comment: It's a great second half of the course. All focused on game theory, so if you don't love puzzles or theory games this may not be great for you. The professors do a great job of incorporating valid real–world applications of some of the most foundational economic game theory models which makes for an interesting course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: It's a great second half of the course. All focused on game theory, so if you don't love puzzles or theory games this may not be great for you. The professors do a great job of incorporating valid real–world applications of some of the most foundational economic game theory models which makes for an interesting course.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This course is amazing! You get a great overview of the history and current state of behavioral economics. Andrei's portion is substantially better than David's, mainly because his models are more innovative and he assumes the students are more capable, so the lectures are more interesting. You will really get a sense of how behavioral econ is remedying the flaws of traditional economics.In terms of prereqs, I would say Econ 1011a and Stat 110 are both necessary and sufficient. The workload is also pretty light: only six problem sets (which were easier than 1011a/1126) and a final. The final is difficult to study for, due to the lack of study materials, but it was not difficult itself (although tbd how strictly it is graded). In summary I would highly recommend. Treat it as a more chill version of a quantitative class and also a great way to get to know David and Andrei and get acquainted with grad–level econ.

This is a fantastic class — great preparation for students interested in theory.
A great introduction to the foundational models of contract theory, and a great option to learn more about organizational economics.
subject: Economics

course_title: A Computer Science Toolbox for Modern Economic Theory 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful course to take if you want to learn CS/Econ in the future. Yannai is a great teacher and communicates the difficult ideas very well. He cares a lot about his students and puts a lot of effort into his teaching. This class is also not a lot of work (only 3 psets and a final project) and the workload is very manageable. This class introduces you to a lot of cs/econ research techniques (some of the paper we read were published in the last five years), which I thought was really cool. I would especially recommend the class to people who are good at proof–based math/have mathematical maturity, have taken ECON 1011a/CS 136 and CS 121/124, and want to do math that is more impactful/relevant to the real world. If you really like problem solving, then you'll like what we cover in this class.
worse_comment: This class will present you with a diversity of mathematical techniques and economics topics which I personally had never heard of elsewhere. Even for the CS student who is not interested in economics itself, some of the more obscure techniques that are mentioned in class in the context of econ applications are themselves worth learning.

best_comment: The class is pretty useful. Very applied (and not very theoretical) and not super quantitative / rigorous. Professor Dobbie is good. Up to date and appropriate for the changing econometric literature.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Causal inference opens up new ways of thinking about social science through rigorous quantitive data analysis. Everyone who wishes to conduct high–quality quantitative research should learn causal inference to get used to thinking and researching in this way. My life has been changed forever by learning the perspectives taught in the class and opened up new ways about thinking about my research.
subject: Economics

best_comment: You should absolutely take this course (especially if Professor Andrews and Chris are on the teaching team!). Econ 2140 covers a lot of important material and is extremely helpful for thinking through applied problems in the future. The work is intellectually stimulating but not impossible, and lectures are really interesting!
worse_comment: sadly the same course will never be offered again in the foreseeable future :–(
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is phenomenal and you should absolutely take it. Professor Sanchez de la Sierra is brilliant and kind, and this class pushed me to think about topics and aspects of development and decisionmaking that I would never have thought of otherwise. It's a low–stakes class with an emphasis on exploring other conceptions of societal development and organization that the mainstream, and there was a lot of focus on how to be good researchers and academics along the way, which was much appreciated. Could not recommend more!

You get a good sense of the human capital literature, and Professors Goldin and Katz are very generous with their time and want to engage with you. Get started on the research paper soon into the semester, and keep up with readings and come with questions to ask in class. Lectures are fun and humorous, and while it is a rigorous class, they do a good job of explaining the models and concepts in the assigned papers.

best_comment: Melissa is just the BEST. She is insanely––INSANELY––smart but also incredibly humble about her academic prowess. She makes complicated matters in deep learning seem so easy. It is so enjoyable to be in her class and learn from her. Take this class, it is absolutely essential for people to learn about NLP and CV and other novel methods in deep learning. Easy to say it is the best class i've taken at Harvard.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Very helpful course for students interested in behavioral or macro.

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy II 001
worse_comment: Very very difficult math, you will be lost most of the time but so is everyone else.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Great survey course on health economics topics taught by a giant in the field. Covers a range of topics from health and development to insurance markets and competition. Requires a good amount of reading but assignments are interesting, fair, and overall the course was not as much work as I was expecting. Dr. Cutler is very available to students and obviously puts a lot of effort into teaching the course. The course does not require you to be an expert in economics already, but familiarity with microeconomic theory and econometrics will provide a good foundation to understand the topics discussed. Definitely recommend if you work or do research in health economics/health policy/health systems.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this course if you are at all interested in trade or spatial work. The course was a great overview of recent seminal papers in trade. Marc and Pol are both super accessible and helpful.

best_comment: Take this course if you are at all interested in trade or spatial work. The course was a great overview of recent seminal papers in trade. Marc and Pol are both super accessible and helpful.

best_comment: Please take this class even if you aren't a graduate student in Econ. This class is bridging the gap between econometric theory and field applications that is so often missed in coursework. You will learn about the state of the art in causal identification and become much better at research in the process.

best_comment: ECON 2925 is a worthwhile course with wonderful professors that have engaged in cutting edge research on the subject of health equity. They generously share their wealth of knowledge with the students each week during the research presentations. The course equips you with skills that will enhance your ability to deliver professional talks and write your research for future presentations.

course_title: The Politics of Education in the Developing World 001
best_comment: Please please just take it. Professor is really great and friendly, and teaches in a very organized manner. Teaching fellows help a lot really. Talk to all of them. Go to office hours. Send emails. Learn from them.A fantastic introduction to education and education politics. Sparked my interest. I am now even considering to take a master degree in education. Also, a class that considers both practical and theoretical aspects. You will be required to write an op–ed which you have the opportunity to publish, to contribute. Moreover, professor and teaching fellows are really helpful in the process. They talked me hand by hand about what I should do. It is actually the first time that I have learned about publication. Overall, fantastic experience please just take the course and enjoy it!

This class is amazing! Beth is such a sweet and wonderful person that has so many valuable and insightful stories to share. No matter what you study, take this course! It teaches you such valuable skills that no other Harvard class teaches you. This is one of the first classes at Harvard that I enjoyed and looked forward to. I never dreaded going to lecture or doing the readings because the community that Beth creates is amazing!! Truly one of the most transformative classes I have ever took in my life. Take this class!!!
subject: Education Studies

course_title: Children with Learning and Developmental Differences 001
best_comment: As an undergraduate, don't be intimidated by the fact that this is a graduate class! In fact, I would HIGHLY recommend you take it as an undergraduate student no matter what year you're in. The content is extremely accessible, and you will learn so so so much from your peers, especially those who entered graduate school from the workforce and have a wealth of experience to share. Dr Gaab and Eily made this course so welcoming and fulfilling, and I've feel like I've learned so much from this course that I genuinely could not have gotten elsewhere. It truly changed the way I view disability and ableism as a whole. If you have an interest in how individuals with learning disabilities see the world and how they go through daily life at all, this is one of the best possible introductory classes you can take on the topic. The assignments are also super fun!
worse_comment: This is an amazing class! Professor Gaab is one of the best professors I've had, and the class itself is really engaging. The assignments were not difficult but they really made me think more deeply about what we were learning about. I took this class as an undergrad but I didn't feel like it was too intimidating to be in a class with mostly grad students. I can't recommend this class enough!!!
subject: Education Studies

course_title: Flavor Molecules of Food Fermentation: Exploration and Inquiry 001
best_comment: Take this course. It is amazing. Pia is so excited about the topics, shares information in an easy and understandable way, and creates amazing hands–on class experiments and projects. The focus is not on creating a difficult environment, but rather actually learning. She cares for her students and is extremely supportive as a whole. If you are interested in food and cooking, but haven't had a science background, consider taking this class. You will love the blend of the two! Get ahead on your project early, and talk to students in the class about their interests—everyone has a different reason for being interested in fermentation and you can learn a lot!
worse_comment: This course was probably the best course I've taken at Harvard. Learning to ferment things with Pia is not only super fun, but can also be applied immediately to your life outside of class as you will learn how to make foods that you didn't know you could make. This course really opens up a world of culinary possibilities for you. Take it!!
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! One of the most fun electives I've ever taken at Harvard. The course staff (Pia <3) is INCREDIBLE and are so dedicated to the class–their excitement about fermentation is infectious. This is the gem of gems–expect minimal work outside of class (10 minutes every other week on average tops to answer a discussion question). The final group project is super open–you get to choose what fermentation you want to investigate and other folks in the class are super bought–in, so it's fun to do it together. Truly when else do you get to brew mead and make yogurt and take field trips to cheese caves for a class?
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This course is awesome. It is not too bad compared to other engineering courses. The workload is not too bad , 1 pset a week is pretty sweet. I spent maybe 7 hours per week on psets and I consider myself a slow worker.  Quizzes were really fair. Please note that I did take 15b before taking ES50 though, and the knowledge from there helped with much of the content in ES50. The teaching staff is awesome, Lombardo and Marko are really helpful. The labs were a bit of a free for all, the TAs are not the most helpful so you have to rely on other peers for guidance sometimes. The psets are most difficult toward the first half and get easier after finite state machines.  If you have doubts throughout the semester, the final project will surely make you love this course. They give alot of freedom, so you can do whatever you want. MAKE SURE YOU START EARLY ON THE FINAL PROJECT!
worse_comment: READ THIS – if you’re unfamiliar with EE this is for you. There is a poor lecturer. It is obvious who. The better lecturer sits and watches the entire class in confusion. Take the class, primarily because it’s the only option to be introduced to EE. The poor lecturer assumes way too much. Things are written in horrible handwriting and impossible to read in order to follow. Points are made with little to no explanation. Any explanation that is made is overdone and overly complicated for no reason.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This course is awesome. It is not too bad compared to other engineering courses. The workload is not too bad , 1 pset a week is pretty sweet. I spent maybe 7 hours per week on psets and I consider myself a slow worker.  Quizzes were really fair. Please note that I did take 15b before taking ES50 though, and the knowledge from there helped with much of the content in ES50. The teaching staff is awesome, Lombardo and Marko are really helpful. The labs were a bit of a free for all, the TAs are not the most helpful so you have to rely on other peers for guidance sometimes. The psets are most difficult toward the first half and get easier after finite state machines.  If you have doubts throughout the semester, the final project will surely make you love this course. They give alot of freedom, so you can do whatever you want. MAKE SURE YOU START EARLY ON THE FINAL PROJECT!
worse_comment: READ THIS – if you’re unfamiliar with EE this is for you. There is a poor lecturer. It is obvious who. The better lecturer sits and watches the entire class in confusion. Take the class, primarily because it’s the only option to be introduced to EE. The poor lecturer assumes way too much. Things are written in horrible handwriting and impossible to read in order to follow. Points are made with little to no explanation. Any explanation that is made is overdone and overly complicated for no reason.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: ES 51 made me much more excited to pursue mechanical engineering. Lectures could be a little more engaging and have better flow but the class is super well–structured and is great at giving you a hands–on dive into mechanical engineering. Labs are super fun (unless you mess up and have to make–up the lab, happened to me once, wasn't too bad) and always felt extremely applicable to your project and the real–world. You'll end up doing a good amount of work, but the work is relatively easy. P–sets are pretty solidworks based, it would be useful to have some background in CAD but not necessary. Seymur and the TFs respond super quickly on slack and have always been super accessible. You can tell Seymur genuinely wants you to succeed and is a super sweet guy. I love how the class is very connected. The parts you make in your p–sets end up being used in lab which end up being used in your final project. Definitely take the time to bond with your project members (they're randomized) and set up time outside of class to work on your final project. As long as you turn everything you need to in, you'll get a good grade in the class. I learned how to use so much equipment in the makerspace and machining room and started using them for my own personal projects. Made me feel much more competent in engineering (:
worse_comment: This is 100% the worst structured course I've ever taken in my life. It is an embarrassment to every other course at Harvard which have all been some of the best courses in that subject that I've ever taken. It is extremely clear how much of a problem that the engineering department is overseen by FAS and can't make its own decisions to cut the course into multiple classes. This course doesn't have enough office hours which is where all the learning is done and absolutely too much was thrown at Seymur Hasanov. Seymur is an absolute gem of an instructor that gave everything he had to this course after being set up to fail by not being able to structure the course to his liking after not being given enough time to remake the course in only 10 days. My only hope for this course is that Seymur will be here to stay and he'll have time to improve the course. This is not on him. This course needs a lot more TFs, it needs to be chopped down or separated into separate courses, and Seymur needs to be given time to set up the class. Right now it is so disorganized. It was extremely clear which assignments, problems, or lecture slides were layovers from previous years and which Seymur had the time to make his own. The quality difference was striking. The course he inherited is extremely poor. There are too many disjointed concepts, not enough support, and too much work. I thought of this class as 3 separate classes: the PSETs (mostly about solidworks that you had to teach yourself or live in Office Hours), the lab section (which was the best structured of the 3 but just a ton of work), and the lecture (which had nothing to do with the other too but had extremely tough concepts that the midterms would be about). Each of those 3 took more time than the rest of my classes combined. Also  the second half of the class takes a lot of physics that they expect you to know even though it's an intro class. If you haven't taken physics like me, it is a lot more time.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights 001
best_comment: Professor Lerner is an endearing, wonderful professor who will generate interest for the subject matter if you go to class. This class is great for an easy 5th class, but you get to decide how much you get out of it based on how many times you actually do the reading beforehand. It's a very forgiving workload, and you won't get cold–called or otherwise exposed for not doing the work. But you have a dedicated HBS professor who is ready to teach you, so don't let that go to waste. This is a really fun class to take with friends to get a taste of what HBS is like and feel like you're doing something a little more practical than a pset! You've really got nothing to lose from signing up. And I honestly had a lot of 'intellectual fun' with the assignments, even as someone who came in with a lot of background experience before the class.
worse_comment: good: josh's lectures, the casesbad: section is quite useless ngl & the grading's really unclear––i quite literally got all of my papers back and have no sense of what grade i have.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Entrepreneurship and Innovation: Practical and Academic Insights 002
best_comment: This class is a great class if you're interested in attending business school and want to get a taste of what HBS's famous "case method" looks like. This course is taught by HBS professors and frequently has in–person and Zoomed–in guest speakers from the cases you read/discuss. I would warn that it can be easy to fall off the rails in this class and begin to not put in as much effort, especially in discussions, but I would discourage you strongly from doing this. 90% of this class is discussions and 10% is lectures. If you slack off, you're not getting anything out of this class and are wasting your $10000 worth of tuition money! Use this time to engage in the discussions, ask the guest speakers questions, and get to know Professor Josh Lerner –– he is such a jolly, sweet professor; very much worth getting to know better! Good luck!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This is a great class to work on your startup! Paul is super awesome and supportive.
worse_comment: It is not time for working on your startup and you're going to be worried about your grade the whole time.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: This is a great class if you put in effort and time! I personally had a wonderful experience with the class, and I truly learned a lot about the topic at hand! Rob is also such a wonderful person!
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: This is a great class if you put in effort and time! I personally had a wonderful experience with the class, and I truly learned a lot about the topic at hand! Rob is also such a wonderful person!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Since a thesis is a very self led endeavor, this course is more of how much you make of the material than how well it's is as a class itself. Some things that were a plus was the project based sections, those were definitely helpful and a highlight for many students. Some of the lectures that taught core concepts like defining technical specifications, understanding testing and analysis, as well as technical writing were all very helpful. I kind of wish we had these topics covered much earlier, like almost during sophomore forum, or ES 96. It also would have been much more helpful if more skill based trainings from the active learning labs were available, such as pcb making, machining for cnc, solidworks, comsol, etc instead of some of the lectures, and these workshops would have been very useful for people who do not have these skills, or need a refresher to use on their own senior thesis. Overall though, the section leaders are incredible, Ben and Elaine, thank you for making this such an incredible year, our thesis would not have been as fun and as much of a learning experience without you all. All of the active learning lab staff are incredible and should be given so much more credit for the time they spend as section leaders and as support for all the es 100 projects.
worse_comment: Seriously try to think about defining your project during junior year. So many people waste the first third of the course trying to refine their problem statement. It seems silly, but just try to start the course with a solid problem statement and stakeholders in mind and you'll be way ahead of the curve.

subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Would recommend this class! Sometimes the work seems a little boring but for the most part, it is very rewarding knowing that the work we are doing all semester contributes to something bigger in a real community. You don't have to be an engineer to take this class!! All you need is a positive attitude and willingness to learn/ ask questions!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is a bit tedious, but that is the nature of an intro thermo class. Scot really cares about the subject so if you are also engaged he is a really great resource. The emphasis on practical applications and student presentations makes it more interesting. If you have the choice of this over 181 then def take this . The workload is very manageable and overall it feels more like a highschool type course than a college lecture.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to the Mechanics of Solids 001
best_comment: This class is fast–paced and challenging but also very doable. Definitely go to section and office hours to make sure you really understand the content, especially as you prepare for the exams. This class is ideal for people who enjoyed ENG–SCI 51 and want to continue on the mechanical engineering track. I also really enjoyed the labs and the bridge competition!
worse_comment: This class is ridiculously hard. It is so conceptually fast paced and confusing and the tests ask very hard questions, and are graded very cut–throat.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics and Transport Processes 001
best_comment: You've probably heard horror stories about this course from past years, and there's a good chance you'll have to take this course for a degree requirement anyway, so I first want to say that the course has improved substantially from last year. The lectures have improved somewhat, even with the many tangents Petros goes down, and the TFs are really quite helpful in making sure the concepts are clear. Most importantly, the grading policies have become much more lenient, with the course staff giving everyone a free 1–week extension on a problem set, one exam drop and one problem set drop, and all of these made the course a relatively low–stress experience. The content is also some of the most interesting in any engineering or physics course I've ever taken here and is super useful for a variety of disciplines (yes, even for bioengineers), and if you put in the time to pore over the lecture slides, stare at the equations until they make sense, and read over textbook examples to understand how to use the equations, you'll get a good feeling for just how elegant and conceptually simple yet powerful fluid mechanics is. The labs and final project in particular genuinely made me want to incorporate fluid mechanics into my future research because of how cool they were. That being said, most of this understanding came from me investing my own time to understand the material outside of class. The lectures move too quickly and have too many digressions to get a good grasp of the concepts in 75 minutes, and it certainly doesn't help that they're at 9am. Sections are often left to pick up the pieces and try to cover both concepts and problem–solving instead of just problem–solving as they should. While the problem sets were mostly painless, I really wished they covered more real–world situations so I felt better prepared for future work. Exams were of reasonable difficulty but far too long for anyone to complete in one class period. And while I appreciate them reducing the weekly labs down to 2 labs, I was left wanting much more computational fluid dynamics (CFD) experience to feel better prepared for industry and research, for which CFD experience is often critical.This is all to say that there's no need to worry much about doing well in the course anymore, and if you're willing to put in the extra time to really learn the material on your own it's intensely rewarding, but this course could be much better if the course staff took some time to organize the lectures more strictly and include more CFD practice.
worse_comment: I would not recommend this class if it is taught by Petros Koumoutsakos. He is a well meaning person, but a poor lecturer. You will not learn practical knowledge about fluid mechanics that you couldn't learn from videos online. The lectures are not engaging or easy to follow. I would recommend taking fluid or aerodynamic courses at a different institution.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Hardest class I've taken and probably hardest class I will take. It will challenge you so much! Be prepared to have this class take up most of the time you dedicate to classes. That being said, it is such a great course!! Psets are hard, but really fun and you will learn a lot from them. Very relevant and useful content so definitely worth the struggle. And plus, Katia and the whole teaching staff are amazing so you will have tons of support.
worse_comment: If you're looking at the average time commitment for this class and thinking "that's not going to me me" yes it is. The only way I can explain this class is unrelentless. Not only is this class an incredible time commitment, but it is also incredibly difficult. You can spend twenty hours straight on a PSET, go to every set of office hours, and still not get a perfect score. If you don't feel confident in your MATLAB skills proceed with caution– it's doable, you'll just struggle quite a bit more than your peers in the beginning. You will learn a ton from this class, but it will be an emotional journey of lots of failed Abaqus simulations and struggling on PSETS.  Finally, I cannot emphasize enough that you should not take this class at the same time as ES227.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I am so glad that I chose to take this class instead of Stat 110. I feel like I learned the underlying concepts of probability much better because it was a smaller class size and I got to have way more interaction with the amazing teaching staff, particularly the two legendary TFs Zhaolin and Xiaomin. I have never felt more supported in a class before at Harvard, and the teaching staff is always responding to Ed posts in like 10 minutes and answering our often very late emails as soon as they can. They also go out of their way to make time to meet with us to explain the concepts, and make sure we fully understand the material. While the lectures may be a bit dry, the teaching staff are the saving grace of the course. I highly recommend this course to everyone.
worse_comment: Take AM101, you won't regret it. So many things are bad in this course. There is no coding component, and the problems feel very trivial and not at all applicable to an engineering education or anything used outside of class, the assignments drag on and you only have all the information to complete just two days before it is due, this class just feels awful. The lecture content is incredibly confusing if you've never taken stats and probability before, like its expected you know this stuff. Course head is great, but this course just isn't.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This is a great follow up to ES 152 for those who were interested in further studying analog or mixed circuits, and is really your only option at Harvard. While I personally found the overview part of the course more engaging than the in depth amplifier design, both were good experiences that helped further my understanding of circuits and their applications. This course is not for everybody, but if you enjoyed ES 152 and want more circuits in you life that don't think of transistors as just switches, this one is for you. Gu is a great professor and, with time, I hope some of this year's inconveniences with grading and pacing can be resolved. This is not an easy class, but it is a rewarding one.
Very organized course. Very fair HWs. Very fair HWs. Very clear lectures. Very good resources (book). Amazing Prof! AMAZING! So so so nice! And a super good teacher! A+++++++++++++
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!This is quite possibly the coolest class offered at Harvard. It is really a one–of–a–kind experience. The structure consists of one 2–hour lecture and one 4–hour lab each week. This lab time may sound long, but it is well worth it.  No background in microfabrication is assumed. I came in with some background in electrical engineering, which I think allowed me to better appreciate some of the topics we discussed, but this is still a VERY worthwhile class without such background.The amount you learn in this class is incredible, while still being a very reasonable choice workload–wise. You gain access to the cleanroom facilities at the Center for Nanoscale Systems (CNS), and will be trained extensively. Beginning with safety training and basic cleanroom orientation/wet bench training, you then do specialized training in a variety of techniques. As part of a 5–person lab group, everyone will specialize in different areas for training, but you will work together in very cool labs, gaining exposure and experience on all sorts of techniques. We focus on photolithography, chemical & physical vapor deposition, sputtering, reactive ion etching, test & measurement. This gives you a very solid foundation for future microfabrication work.The labs are super interesting. First, you fabricate a PN junction from scratch (a diode). This is one of the most basic semiconductor devices. The second lab is when you make LEDs – it's very satisfying to see them light up! Next is a photodetector (basically a solar cell), and finally, you will fabricate transistors. The focus of this course is on fabrication techniques, not the theory behind semiconductor devices. Some of these may seem like simple devices, but working through this course you really gain an appreciation for all of the care and attention to detail that goes into microfabrication – it's almost an art. You won't be making computer chips with thousands of transistors, but you will be fabricating as advanced devices as one possibly can with only one semester of training. This training is much more accelerated than typical for getting started with microfabrication. As the course progresses, you as students take more and more agency in the fabrication process. I really like this form of structure. It allows you to dive into fabricating cool devices from the beginning, but makes it more of a thoughtful exercise than simply following a pre–determined recipe to the t. It helps prepare you to be more independent and capable in the cleanroom. The teaching staff for this course have been terrific. Professor Evelyn Hu is an incredible lecturer – she is so knowledgeable, but very skilled at explaining things in an engaging and effective way. It is clear that she has mastered her art. She puts a lot of care into her lectures, and makes sure to engage with the students, forcing us to think critically about important questions and discuss as a group. She is also very accessible to talk with, and a very kind person. Professor Kiyoul Yang is also terrific. I believe he is teaching this course next year, and if so, you are in for a treat! He is very smart, kind, and thoughtful. The teaching fellows were wonderful as well. You will work with one TF during your labs, and I have found them to be very knowledgeable, supportive, helpful, and kind. This course has an extensive teaching staff: three instructors, eight support staff, and two TFs, for an ~20 student class. You will be well supported.This course comes in two versions: the undergraduate version (ES177), and the graduate version (ES277). The only difference is that ES277 requires a final project. I really enjoyed this aspect of the course, and so if you are interested in doing microfabrication beyond this one–semester course, I would highly recommend enrolling in the graduate version. The project is to propose a process sequence for a device you would like to make – basically, you pick something interesting that you could use microfabrication for, and describe how you'd make it. People picked a lot of interesting things, from microelectromechanical devices (MEMs) to hardware for neuromorphic computers. After the course, they pick a few projects to fund with $1000 for fabrication, so this is a great chance to get some funding for a project in the cleanroom.All in all, this course is WONDERFUL, and I HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!This is quite possibly the coolest class offered at Harvard. It is really a one–of–a–kind experience. The structure consists of one 2–hour lecture and one 4–hour lab each week. This lab time may sound long, but it is well worth it.  No background in microfabrication is assumed. I came in with some background in electrical engineering, which I think allowed me to better appreciate some of the topics we discussed, but this is still a VERY worthwhile class without such background.The amount you learn in this class is incredible, while still being a very reasonable choice workload–wise. You gain access to the cleanroom facilities at the Center for Nanoscale Systems (CNS), and will be trained extensively. Beginning with safety training and basic cleanroom orientation/wet bench training, you then do specialized training in a variety of techniques. As part of a 5–person lab group, everyone will specialize in different areas for training, but you will work together in very cool labs, gaining exposure and experience on all sorts of techniques. This gives you a very solid foundation for future microfabrication work.The labs are super interesting. First, you fabricate a PN junction from scratch (a diode). This is one of the most basic semiconductor devices. The second lab is when you make LEDs – it's very satisfying to see them light up! Next is a photodetector (basically a solar cell), and finally, you will fabricate transistors. The focus of this course is on fabrication techniques, not the theory behind semiconductor devices. Some of these may seem like simple devices, but working through this course you really gain an appreciation for all of the care and attention to detail that goes into microfabrication – it's almost an art. You won't be making computer chips with thousands of transistors, but you will be fabricating as advanced devices as one possibly can with only one semester of training. The project is to propose a process sequence for a device you would like to make – basically, you pick something interesting that you could use microfabrication for, and describe how you'd make it. People picked a lot of interesting things, from microelectromechanical devices (MEMs) to hardware for neuromorphic computers. After the course, they pick a few projects to fund with $1000 for fabrication, so this is a great chance to get some funding for a project in the cleanroom.All in all, this course is WONDERFUL, and I HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Materials Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: Very enjoyable, chill experience with a super nice professor who cares a lot about his students.  He is clearly very knowledgable and passionate about the subject, and you learn a lot about material science in a relatively low–stress environment.  Highly recommend.
worse_comment: Asking the TFs and Professor about the problem sets and assignments is essential, especially because they can often be confusingly worded.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Definitely take this course. It goes much more in depth into statistical modeling than many other SEAS courses so that you truly understand the math behind the models. Professor Demba is a phenomenal, knowledgeable teacher that is extremely thoughtful about what he teaches. This was a great course and I would highly recommend
worse_comment: The material is quite interesting, but I personally did not feel like I learned a ton from the second half of the course (mostly guest lectures).
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is great! Dr. Mitragotri is super knowledgeable about the course material, and the course format is really laid–back and low–stress to allow you to engage with it as you want. The assignments are actually quite helpful in stimulating the creation of research ideas. Would recommend if you're looking for a chill engineering elective or 5th class.

If you are looking at this class you are possibly a junior trying to find an alternative to ES96. Thats what I was. This course will give you everything that 96 might lack – you will become very familiar with the problem solving process, you will have the opportunity to make something tangible to fill a niche in an industry, you will learn how to consult with your client during the problem solving process, it can be very fulfilling!However. If you have any concerns about time management, or are looking for a lighter/somewhat easy class, I do not recommend 227. Looking at you, engineers taking hard classes, student athletes, people who want space to devote more time to things outside of school. This class is a huge undertaking – there is always something that can be worked on, a process that needs to be optimized, better diagrams that should be made, meetings with stakeholders that should be scheduled. I spent so much time working on this project outside of class, and it was exhausting. We started early and definitely tried to stay on top of things, but eventually it landslides. All of this to say, it is a huge time commitment! And it isn't just busy work – a lot of times since you are trying to develop a new product, you have no references for how to do something so you need to be meeting with teaching staff, grad students, other professors, ect to figure out how to make something.And be prepared to feel like crap! You have one semester to build a whole project, and it will not be perfect or even possibly functional at the end of the semester. This will feel crappy. Basically, it gives you a really awesome opportunity to do something really cool, but it is also a HUGE time drain.
worse_comment: This course is crazy crazy crazy difficult and time consuming, but you will be working on something that is actually a real no–joke engineering project. Don't take this class with any other tough ones.
subject: Engineering Sciences

subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This was a good class overall. As for the class lectures, I personally did not feel like I gained a deep understanding of tissue engineering. Lectures sometimes felt dry and only briefly covered various aspects of the field without going into depth into any of them. However, I did enjoy the weekly journal club assignments, since they forced us to not just read landmark papers in the field but also think critically about them. Professor Mooney also really cares about the class and takes student feedback into account.I will say that the lab was definitely the highlight of this class: Melissa and Avery really want you to succeed and create an environment where you feel safe asking questions and learning important/employable wet lab skills. If you have limited wet lab experience, I highly recommend doing the lab — you learn the very basics (filtering media, culturing/passaging cells) as well as more advanced techniques (3D cell culture and modeling angiogenesis). Melissa and Avery also mentor you one–on–one every week throughout the entire scientific process, from developing a good scientific question/hypothesis to running your experiments to analyzing your data. Be prepared to spend up to 10 hours in the lab each week if you really want to get the most out of this class, but it's a rewarding experience like no other!
worse_comment: Easier than other classes in SEAS if you are required to take them, but you won't learn much and will spend some time doing busywork. The slides were very out of date and not didactic. This course was incredibly disappointing, especially given how prolific in the field Dave is, it was so poorly organized and so low effort and I left this class  having learned nothing.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I LOVED this course. Easily my favorite class at Harvard. Professor Aziz is writing his textbook over the next year which is why it isn't available in 2024. I spent a lot of time reading the textbook because it was so so interesting and applicable to my interest in energy and climate. This class is very STEM–focused and is great at applying physics, thermodynamics, chemistry, engineering, economics, and more to the energy sector. You don't need experience in all of these fields but it will make the course easier. The final project is a great way to explore something that caught your interest. It was my first real research paper and I really enjoyed it.  I would 10/10 recommend this class. The p–sets are bi–weekly. You can put in as much time as you want and will get out of it as much as you put in.

The class is challenging. There are a lot of readings to do every week, and you will invest a lot of time engaging with the material to prepare for weekly discussions. The final project is also extremely time consuming and requires a lot of commitment.That being said, this was a VERY rewarding class. I learned more applicable concepts from this class than I have from any other class I've taken at Harvard. If you are willing to engage in discussions, read every week, and ask questions, I think you will feel the same. I think the time commitment is worth it.
worse_comment: Come with an open mind. You will be exposed to lot of readings. If you invest on it, you will learn. Class discussions are major component and participate in it. If you don't do that, then you won't learn much.

best_comment: This class covers a super cool array of topics – mostly whatever Maurice Smith is interested in. Professor Smith is super smart and it's really cool to learn from him. The class is super disorganized and assignments get graded extremely late (last week of classes) months after being turned in, instructions for presentations and other assignments were released super late and were unclear, class often started 10 minutes late and ended 20 minutes late, etc. However, this class is still worth taking. It's what a freshman seminar should be – a Professor talking about all the topics he's interested in with assignments once every two weeks.
worse_comment: Stay on top of homework assignments from an early time. Attempt all problems before going to office hours.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: It is good to have some basic knoweldge about this field because it is an advanced class. If you have more insights and thoughts about this field, you can get more from this class.

Jia is one of the best professors I have. He is very direct and caring. He wants you as an undergraduate to do well.  He is very practical in the information in his lectures and the scope of what he is talking about. Phenomenal course.
subject: Engineering Sciences
