subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is amazing! It is just the right balance of useful content and free time to actually work on your startup idea.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is amazing! It is just the right balance of useful content and free time to actually work on your startup idea.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This course is extremely helpful if you have a project in mind that you wish to complete this term. The final term assignment is due earlier in the semester than usual, which helps tremendously in getting the project squared away early and not interfering with the busy end of term assignments. The guest speakers were phenomenal. I highly recommend this course to anyone with a desire to improve their writing or challenge existing norms surrounding scientific writing (mainly, that it is painfully dull). Feedback received on assignments is particularly strong and instructive, assisting in the revision process tremendously.
worse_comment: Take this class as soon as possible – it will pay off in the later years of your PhD
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: This course is extremely helpful if you have a project in mind that you wish to complete this term. The final term assignment is due earlier in the semester than usual, which helps tremendously in getting the project squared away early and not interfering with the busy end of term assignments. The guest speakers were phenomenal. Feedback received on assignments is particularly strong and instructive, assisting in the revision process tremendously.
worse_comment: Take this class as soon as possible – it will pay off in the later years of your PhD
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I strongly recommend taking the course for the following reasons: 1) The skills you learn are transferable to other areas of academic life, such as interviews and conference presentations. It is worth the investment 2) Some of the skills, such as learning to organize your thoughts in a way that is easier to process for others, are helpful in your personal life as well. You explicitly practice it in the form of whiteboard organization, etc. 3) The course workload is very low 4) If you are an international student, it might improve your speaking confidence as well. The class atmosphere is healthy, and you will not feel judged but only get honest feedback.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Incredible workshop — best I’ve taken (of 4) at Harvard. The kind of learning you can’t do from reading a how to book on writing, and the community is so lovely and supportive. Adored this class and really enjoyed how each piece was treated with such care and ambition, challenged through conversation, and reimagined. Not a lot of classes teach revision skills, and this one does.

course_title: CAFR: Advanced Fiction Workshop: Writing this Present Life 001
best_comment: This is definitely an advanced fiction workshop, and you should be prepared to dedicate a very large chunk of your week to this class, but if you love writing you'll love every moment of it. Reading other students' work and responding to it is also a large time commitment, but there's so much to learn from them too. You have to be very passionate about writing to thrive in this kind of environment, but everyone else will be as well, and so it's an insanely rewarding experience. Professor Messud is absolutely brilliant, and she's so thoughtful and purposeful about her feedback to you. It's an amazing and inspiring experience to get to write with her guidance. This was by far the highlight of my semester—I wish I could take it forever.
subject: English

best_comment: Absolutely take this class!! Sam is a great professor and it is so useful to have a class that makes you do the writing. Writing a longer piece and doing the Harvard Playwrights Festival is scary, but it is so so fun and so useful. You learn so much from the workshops. I fell off of reading the plays at some point during the semester, but they are so worth reading – it's only like an hour a week of readings and you really do learn a lot from them.tl;dr TAKE THIS CLASS

Life changing. Take it. Just do it. I was a bit hesitant to rank this workshop first in my application because I didn't know if I could sit through a three–hour zoom class, but I'm glad I did. Class passes by fast and is really energetic, especially when Jorie is talking (also Jorie is the most incredible instructor ever). One of the best classes, if not the best, I've taken at Harvard. You will probably spend more time on this class than you anticipate. And, you will grow so much as a poet and a person.
subject: English

best_comment: Do it! Put all your heart and soul into it. But take the course during a semester that is not too busy, because this is very challenging and all–consuming. It will  take a huge amount of time and energy, but it will be a labor of love.
subject: English

best_comment: Josh is maybe one of the best teachers I've ever had and I feel so lucky that he lead my first experience writing poetry in a classroom setting. He set an amazingly encouraging precedent early on, asking for "only positive feedback" in the beginning of the semester to get folks out of their shells.  Each week, he provides a thick packet of poems that are examples of the weekly poem assignment (you write a poem a week). These poems are awesome –– I've read, reread, and will continue to reread them. Reading a lot of poetry with intentionality is a cheat code to writing better poetry, and these packets really hone the skill of pinpointing when an author utilizes a certain technique. The pace of writing a poem a week is challenging, but soon the expectation of writing polished poetry sloughs off to reveal authentic poetry. Seeing everyone come into their own styles was a joy and each class felt almost spiritual. I trusted that my classmates would leave no stone unturned as much as I trusted them to turn them gently and articulately.As someone who was embarrassed to show anyone my poetry, this class couldn't have been better for me. I almost didn't take it as I read some of Josh's poems online and wasn't certain my style aligned with his. Thank god I did. Josh is scary good at articulating what a poem is doing and even more scary–good at pinpointing what an author is trying to do. He writes paragraphs, no PAGES, for every person in the class every week in response to the weekly assignments. And the stuff is pretty much pure gold every time. He'll write something about you that you didn't even know was there and the effort he puts in to his comments is heroic (I would get some of these emails at 2 or 3am).  TAKE THIS CLASS. APPLY NOW.
worse_comment: This class changed my life. Josh Bell changes, and touches, lives. If you're a poet, take this class. If. you're not a poet but want to become one, take this class.

course_title: Scene Work, Dream Work: Fiction Workshop on Design and Structure of Narrative Scenes 001
best_comment: This was my first workshop ever and it was such an amazing experience! I was pretty nervous to take a workshop class or share my writing, which I've only ever viewed as a casual hobby, but I would 100% recommend applying to a workshop even if you are feeling this way –– not only did I learn a lot about the more technical elements of writing, the class was genuinely such a warm and encouraging community that I really, truly looked forward to it every week. Nick gives incredibly kind and specific feedback, as well as top–notch book and story recommendations. Probably the most fun course I've ever taken at Harvard. If you have the chance to take a workshop, don't think twice!

course_title: Interiority & Experience: Writing Character-Driven Fiction: Workshop 001
best_comment: WONDERFUL. Claire is an amazing professor and gives such helpful feedback on your writing. All of the creative writing workshop style classes at Harvard have been so welcoming and wonderful in my experience, this class especially so. Recommend with so much enthusiasm! People from all concentrations/experience levels, take this!

This was such a wonderful class! Being in community with other people that care about engaging with your work and expressing their most honest and sincere feedback in a caring and effective way significantly improved my writing. Josh also does such an incredible job of reading through my poetry and finding specific aspects of my writing (such as theme, structure, tone, composition, etc.) that I'm not even fully aware of until he shares them with me and helps me bring them out more in future poems. I'm so glad I got the opportunity to write poetry in this class and workshop it with Josh and my classmates. I also learned so so much about engaging with different texts and voices simply by reading and discussing other students' poems. If you've ever felt hesitant about sharing your poetry with other people but still love to write, then please take this class. You will learn so much and grow abundantly

Take this class. It will change how you read about people and how you portray them! Louisa is a fantastic teacher who is able to see your writing and your goals even better than you are. She is constantly understanding and compassionate while still effectively driving progress and learning goals throughout the semester. I genuinely loved showing up to class, even at 9am! I looked forward to every week and every reading. Truly a treat of a class, and the first time I think a class at Harvard made me a genuinely better writer in such little time. I wouldn't hesitate to take the seminar again if I could!

I had so, so much fun in this course and learned a ton about sports journalism, journalism as a whole, and writing in general. Louisa is such a wonderful instructor! She clearly cares so deeply about all of her students — she provided immense amounts of feedback on my assignments and was always willing to chat or email with me whenever I had any questions. She made the class a super fun, supportive learning environment. She also brought in all sorts of wonderful guest speakers. As an avid sports fan myself, I found the readings super fun. I also enjoyed doing the assignments, especially since they were so different from most of my other work (and about topics I found more interesting).
subject: English

best_comment: Take this class!!! Musa Syeed is one of the most dedicated, experienced, and knowledgeable professors in his field out there. He's kind and funny, and really engages students well. This class was just so much fun! I felt alive as an artist and really enjoyed exploring different genres in my writing. He teaches technique and style well, while leaving lots of room for creativity and spontaneity. He even taught some production stuff and just gave a really great overview/insight into the film industry. And your classmates are going to make this worth it too –– the small setting allows for you to get to know people well (including the professor) and people's personalities just come out in an entertaining and exciting way! Musa will point you to great resources/events outside the classroom and cares deeply about integrity in our work, so you're in for a great time! Definitely going to keep writing and making films after this :)
subject: English

best_comment: This was life–changing. This course made me a better writer, a better reader, and genuinely so much more passionate about my writing and the experience of writing in general. The course materials expose you to a variety of different styles and Darcy is the most wonderful professor. He genuinely encourages and takes an interest in your writing, which creates an amazingly supportive environment. Being in a classroom with other equally passionate writers also gives you such energy to write and want to think about writing. I would say take this course if your schedule allows you to, it made every week so much more fun amidst the other classes I was taking.
subject: English

best_comment: LOVED THIS COURSE! For anybody who wants to write about themselves, their lives, or things happening in the world around them. Darcy is a great teacher, and he does a great job of fostering a welcoming environment in which everyone can be honest and vulnerable. The readings are so useful and a pleasure to leave, with great variation in style and content. You learn so much about narrative techniques, and emerge from the class as a better and more confident writer.
subject: English

best_comment: Meng is a great instructor, both in helping to create a very constructive and creative learning and writing environment as well as genuinely helping in the writing of a particular piece. You don't need to be daunted coming in, as long as you're willing to take writing and the class seriously. Some things may seem funny or unusual, but if you embrace the weird–ness then you get the most out of the class. Be ready to spend a lot of time on your final piece. I think the greatest benefit to this class truly is Meng's feedback, and the more prepared you are going into her meetings as well as into workshop, the more you'll get out of learning to be a better writer.

course_title: The Novel Lab: Studying Long-Form Narratives in Fiction 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! IT WAS DEFINITELY THE BEST CLASS I'VE TAKEN HERE!!! Paul is an *AMAZING* teacher –– super knowledgeable, friendly, and great at fostering a friendly class environment. He's also super easy to talk to re: writing advice. This class changed how I see writing and my own life, and I HIGHLY recommend you consider applying if you have any interest in what makes a book enjoyable/powerful/confusing/frustrating/innovative. Also, super reasonable (and dare I say enjoyable) workload! TAKE THIS CLASS!! YOU WON'T REGRET IT!!
subject: English

best_comment: This was one of the most fulfilling courses I've taken at Harvard. Maggie was great. My peers were great. Discussions were so thoughtful and insightful. The vibes were so good. If you're looking for a creative nonfic class, take this one. I've taken a number of poetry and fiction workshops and this class was different in ways that really made me grow.

course_title: “Queer Stories, Queer Lives”: A Fiction Workshop on Queer Narratives 001
best_comment: Loved this class! It really meets you where you are at in creative writing. Nick facilitates discussion really well too and often brought snacks which was a plus. Overall great class and I feel like a much better writer now

course_title: Plundering the Americas: Histories of Extractive Violence and Creative Resistance in the Americas 001
best_comment: I'll definitely recommend taking a class with Professor Luiselli! She's a great person and clearly a really insightful and accomplished writer, but she makes the workshop setting seem so unintimidating and encourages discussions and sharing.
worse_comment: Unless it's structured much better next time, I unfortunately wouldn't recommend it.

best_comment: This class is so lovely! Basically an opportunity to workshop your writing and receive feedback from Professor Kincaid and your peers. Was one of my favorite sections of the week. Be warned  – if you are looking for structured instruction/guidance on how to write creatively, this is not the course for you. You really have to just dive in and see what you write, and then you receive feedback in class after you read aloud. It's a great exercise in bravery and taught me to be more comfortable putting myself out there and sharing my writing—accepting imperfections and being open to constructive feedback.
subject: English

best_comment: Although this class is required for all english concentrators and secondary students, it is a great class. I was a bit wary heading into the class because I saw a lot of unknown texts on the syllabus but they were all super interesting and super fun. Plus, it's great that there's a lot of variety because on the off–chance that you don't like one of them, you'll only spend a week talking about that specific text and you can choose not to write about it on your essays. Professor Watson's lectures are interesting and offer a lot of good, formal context for the work you're analyzing, but section is really the place where the class shines, as you get to do some close readings with the class and your TF. The grading I thought was very fair and considerate, and there were a lot of opportunities to get more points. This is a great class and you'll have lots of fun; just make sure you do the readings and participate actively in class to get the most out of it.
subject: English

best_comment: Take this class!!! You have to be prepared to do the readings or else you'll be kind of lost in class, but if you come prepared and ready to engage, it's a really really great class. Prof. Kim is AMAZING and a super sweet, understanding professor. I also know that this class is a first try and will be tweaked in the future which will make the class even more exciting!!
worse_comment: This is a fantastic class even if you are not super interested in theater!

best_comment: To anyone with as much as a passing interest in theater, I'd strongly recommend this class. The workload is manageable—a few plays a week, discussion posts, well–designed presentations/assignments with clear expectations—and I found myself looking forward to class each week. It is rare to take a course that feels so natural, both in terms of flow and progression and in terms of the ease with which class discussion is led. Most weeks felt like a book club in which individual's viewpoints were taken seriously and developed and everyone was equally bought in. Professor Miller combines rigour with a relaxed approach, adding fruitful insight into the conversation without dominating it, maintaining a serious environment while also fostering a classroom in which people feel comfortable speaking their mind. The syllabus was thoughtfully designed and dynamic and there was frequent opportunities for feedback and self reflection. Assignments were extremely well designed with clear rubrics. While Professor Miller's feedback on assignments was not extensive, there was always the sense that he was available outside of class should that be desired. Couldn't recommend more, no reservations whatsoever.
worse_comment: Seminars are hit or miss, and this was a miss. The workload was light, but I also felt very unengaged during class. I didn't feel like this class was a priority to the instructor and often felt frustrated leaving lecture. Overall I would not recommend this course.

best_comment: I really enjoy Professor Ravinthiran! He does a great job connecting with students in a way that makes the poems feel relevant to our own lives. I learned so much about Elizabeth Bishop's complicated life and her poetry. I'm very happy I took this class. You get what you put into the class. The reading is manageable, but you can make it far more meaningful if you really invest in the material and try to draw some conclusions about the poems before you come to class. My only complaint is the structure of the class. A final paper worth 50% of a final grade is simply too much. However, Professor Ravinthiran is super accessible for office hours and is readily available for help. I wish I had had the opportunity to take more classes from him!
worse_comment: If you enjoy poetry and can write and you're looking for a relatively light–weight class to take, this is for you. If you aren't interested in poetry and aren't confident in your writing skills, this class may be painful for you.

course_title: Consciousness in Fiction from Austen to Woolf 001
best_comment: It is rare to find a course so rich in substance and with such little flab. Professor Wood is an outstanding teacher–––he is patient, encouraging, and down–to–earth. One thing that Harvard students instinctively do when asked their thoughts on a book is to try to make "subtle" points and delve into esoteric analysis. But Professor Wood simply desired to hear our true, unfiltered impressions of the novels we were reading; at one point, he told a silent classroom, "you don't feel you have to be literary in your answers–––just what did you think?" Professor Wood also has an infectious enthusiasm for literature that made intimidating or difficult novels so much more fascinating. As a class, we avoided the common tendency to jump straight to "smart" insights; rather, we went through passages we found beautiful, ironic, or particularly amusing.  Notably, Professor Wood spent a decent portion of our classes reading out loud. But far from being a pitfall, his reading passages helped me (and other students, I am sure) to better appreciate the various details and colors in the texts. Professor Wood also has a wonderful reading voice! I strongly recommend all students who want to read good novels take this course.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Super generous for non English concentrators, James is a gem, speaking to him has helped shift my perspective on reading and books as an English major. The class can only be described as a lovely time, and low commitment if you're looking for a gem, although you can also get tremendous value out of it.

best_comment: This course is really special and I highly recommend taking it. This may be the only course I've ever taken that really could only be taught at Harvard because it makes such extensive use of Harvard's collections and examines their history in depth. I learned to think much more critically about museums and other academic institutions and the debts they owe to indigenous people.  Professor Klassen is amazing. She is so kind and welcoming while also being such a brilliant scholar and facilitating such thought–provoking discussions.
worse_comment: Take this class! Getting to visit Harvard's museums and contemplate how to remediate insensitive or inadequate portrayals of Indigenous cultures was an invaluable experience.

best_comment: This class was extremely beneficial to me both as a citizen and as a student of the humanities and the law. This course is grounded in analysis of the world and our society in the past, present, and future. We were able to learn so much about Supreme Court precedent, the Reconstruction Amendments, and contemporary civil rights litigation surrounding affirmative action. As someone who has spent a lot of time thinking about affirmative action, I especially enjoyed the opportunity to learn from William Lee in class when he watched us perform oral arguments for the UNC and Harvard cases. The application of this course in real life is what makes it so magnificent. This has been the most rewarding class I have taken at Harvard with the most phenomenal group of students and a very dedicated teacher.
worse_comment: there will be a lot of students in the class who know an insane amount about the law. don't be intimidated by them. ask questions or wait for clarifications and you will get just as much out of the course as anyone else.

best_comment: This is a great class! You are able to pursue parts of the Tudor period that interest you the most. For instance, if you are more inclined to history versus literature, you are able to tailor your assignments to that. I love the flexibility of this class. Professor Niles is a great teacher, and I have really enjoyed the readings. I definitely recommend this class!  You'll learn a lot and it's a relatively low stress, which makes the course even more enjoyable!

Make sure you take a class with Professor Sacks before you graduate. This was a great one, but honestly any class by him would work. His enthusiasm for the subject is contagious and you'll come out with a much stronger understanding of poetry.

This class is excellent, I definitely recommend it. There is not too much material to get through and the course is really well paced so that you never feel overwhelmed. Also, Professor Blum is lovely, she is super enthusiastic and encouraging and she really knows how to approach each student in a way that best facilitates learning.
subject: English

best_comment: While English 97 may be a required course, it is truly a joy of a requirement. Professor Wilson introduces you to some of the most remarkable chapters in the history of literary theory, and each of her lessons equips you with a tool of literary criticism and interpretation that is exciting to behold and powerful to wield. Every class was a wonder to look forward to––I highly recommend this course! And do the readings: they're fun, interesting, and might just set you on the path that leads to an eventual thesis (if you're thinking of writing one).
subject: English

course_title: Advanced Old English: Scribes and Manuscripts 001
best_comment: WELCOME TO THE THUNDERDOME!!In all seriousness, I enjoyed this class a great deal. If you liked high school Latin, you'll love this. Prof. D. and Seif are both really smart, and have plentiful office hours such that you can really access them whenever you need.This is a hard class; learning a language is never easy, and the translations pick up this semester, both in terms of length and quality. Definitely work hard, because the final project is tough (fair, but tough). There are lots of resources to help you in this class, and (perhaps I'm biased based off of this year's experience) the students in it are super nice.Overall, recommend!
worse_comment: This course is quite disorganized. Only take it if Seif is NOT the TF.

best_comment: I enjoyed this class! I never would've thought medieval literature and fanfiction could mix, but this class showed me that not only do they mix, they also mix to create some pretty great and hilarious products. Professor Wilson is super funny and very responsive to students. She always brings such great energy to class and gets everyone excited (and laughing) about whatever it is she is teaching that day. Take this class even if you're not an English concentrator and just enjoy the fun!
worse_comment: Took this as an English requirement, but this class BLEW me away and ended up being one of my favorite classes ever in my four years at Harvard. Professor Wilson is exceptionally knowledgeable about medieval literature AND fanfiction theory – what a killer combo. I never enjoyed studying medieval literature before this class. Take it!!! You won't regret it!!

best_comment: Take this class! Super fun, Professor Niles is so engaging, and you really do get a whistle stop tour through so many great works.

This course is AMAZING! Professor Greenblatt is so passionate about the material and he shows it. So many of the lectures were absolutely incredible, and made you think deeply about the plays, as he opened them up in new and unexpected ways, which gripped me and astounded me! And Sam is a really wonderful TF who made section a great experience every week! Would 100% recommend this course.

This class is a really awesome class. It's tough, but it's a good tough. This is one of the classes that most made me feel like a real Harvard student. Professor Teskey is a super kind and approachable person, and the class can really be for anyone.
subject: English

course_title: The American Novel: Dreiser to the Present 001
best_comment: this class is great!!! first and foremost, the lectures (for the most part) are absolutely fantastic. professor fisher is just so energetic about the material, and that makes lectures really fun to sit in on. aside from that, although the readings are not interesting upon first glance, being able to dive into them during section and lectures gives them a lot of fresh light, which i enjoyed a lot, especially considering a lot of the novels are not ones that i would pick up on my own. however, some of the novels are a bit dude–heavy, as in it's a lot of war and dudes in war and dudes walking around town and dudes and their relationship with a woman (TM), so it got a little heavy by the time we neared the end of the course. with that, it's quite easy to get behind on readings, especially if you're taking a couple of heavy classes, but being able to sit down and read for two hours or whatever is also a really nice break from those heavier classes, so if you're looking at this class alongside super stemmy classes, keep that in mind! it's okay to stop working on your cs pset and read, and your brain will feel a lot better because of that.i had shalisa for my section leader and she was absolutely wonderful. she is so kind and led our section through discussions with ease and grace, and i loved having her as my section leader. discussions are generally super fun and intriguing. tl;dr take this class!!!
best_gem_comment: Professor Fisher's lectures are spun gold. Pearls fall out of his mouth. I took this class as a senior who just wanted to read books again and this hit the spot. The assignments are reasonable in terms of volume and intensity and feedback is fair. You could get by if you really wanted to if you didn't read the books, but this is a class where you get out what you put in–the syllabus is incredible. Take this class if you like reading but also want a gem!
subject: English

best_comment: I took this course to fulfill the premed writing requirement and because I love poetry and this was perfect! We get to read so many poems (do know that you will not find all of them interesting or engaging by any means but you will be excited by at least one poem) and I discovered so many poets that I can now call my favorites that I never would have known about before! This class meets once a week for two hours (or at least it did for Spring 2023) and it is on Zoom, which means that you have a bit of flexibility for where you take the course. That does mean it can get boring at times when the professor is lecturing but generally it is entirely interesting what Professor Sacks is saying. He encourages students to meet with him and I highly recommend doing so! Adam is also a phenomenal TF. Literally, the best teacher.

I cannot recommend this class enough! I'm so grateful to have had the opportunity to take it. Vidyan is, without a doubt, the most engaging and fascinating lecturer I have ever had the pleasure of listening to. He truly cares about the class and his students, and his passion for teaching the course shines through in every lecture. Every part of the course, from the lectures and sections to the assignments, is highly engaging and enjoyable. In terms of out–of–class workload, it includes weekly games (you can choose to play yourself or watch a walkthrough), two papers on a video game mechanic, and a final project on a game of your choice. Regardless of whether you've been playing games all your life or you haven't even played Candy Crush, this class is an excellent addition to your schedule!!
best_gem_comment: GEM! Very friendly Arts and Humanities course for STEM majors who like video games. Relaxed assignments although you obviously have to put effort in it to get a good grade. if you try and skip class, you WILL have a hard time with the final presentation/paper. Go to lecture, it is interesting and teaches you a lot about non–conventional ways of story telling.
subject: English

course_title: The Dark Side of Big Data 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Professor Dikcis is an amazing lecturer who cares so much about her students and is clearly passionate about these topics––I walked away from this class with so many new ways to view the relationship between science, technology, and society, and it was really rewarding to explore data as a construct with history and politics. The readings were carefully chosen and very manageable, as well as the other art pieces we discussed in this course. Topics were fun and engaging, and I actually looked forward to completing the assignments––this is definitely not a busy work class, and it covers themes that everyone should be thinking about.
subject: English

best_comment: Don't be scared by the 276LR of it all––there's certainly a fair deal of reading but it's nothing too dramatic and the texts are wonderful and very interesting. Prof. Gates is kind, generous, and approachable.

course_title: Queer and Trans Literature and Criticism 001
best_comment: I would 100% recommend this course! One of my favorites ever! You don't need to have any familiarity with queer lit to take it—Stephanie definitely makes the content accessible. That said, I would recommend a serious interest in studying literature. Stephanie is super supportive to undergrads, but its pretty faced paced and the expectation for quality of writing is high. Be willing to put in effort and get a lot out of it.

If you are at all interested in the role that the humanities and art can play in the global field of migration, this is the course for you. Homi and Mariano are such great professors who lead you through a staggering range of fascinating materials. Some of the reading is quite challenging (stylistically, thematically, or emotionally) but the resulting discussions are always edifying and so much fun.
subject: English

best_comment: If you are at all interested in the role that the humanities and art can play in the global field of migration, this is the course for you. Homi and Mariano are such great professors who lead you through a staggering range of fascinating materials. Some of the reading is quite challenging (stylistically, thematically, or emotionally) but the resulting discussions are always edifying and so much fun.
subject: English

best_comment: I absolutely recommend this course! Professor Scarry is absolutely lovely and the class brought together students from an array of backgrounds which generated fantastic and thought–provoking discussions. The readings were carefully chosen and varied, and the class had just the right amount of structure and organization.  There really is no one better to learn from about beauty!

A thoughtfully designed introduction to methods in DH. No coding experience necessary, though it can be helpful to situate some of the readings, which are far–ranging and interesting. The programming assignments provide a helpful opportunity to improve your coding skills.
This is a course whose success depends heavily on engaged participation. It is at is best when everyone is actively involved.
subject: English

course_title: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: It's a good course! Frank and Bryan are great instructors. The courseload isn't too much for a pset/lab class, and the material is manageable if you pay attention, ask questions, go to some office hours, etc. It's a good complement to PS11 (which is a bit too much work in my opinion). If you don't have any coding background you should know that you'll probably struggle with that component of it (either Python or R), but I encourage students to make friends in the course and work through the coding with someone who has more experience – people are happy to help out and work together. The labs are pretty fun! If you're interested in ESE or EPS or ESPP it's a great intro class to expose you to a bunch of topics so you can get a feel for what you actually care most about / what you want to study more in the future.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

course_title: Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: It's a good course! Frank and Bryan are great instructors. The courseload isn't too much for a pset/lab class, and the material is manageable if you pay attention, ask questions, go to some office hours, etc. It's a good complement to PS11 (which is a bit too much work in my opinion). If you don't have any coding background you should know that you'll probably struggle with that component of it (either Python or R), but I encourage students to make friends in the course and work through the coding with someone who has more experience – people are happy to help out and work together. The labs are pretty fun! If you're interested in ESE or EPS or ESPP it's a great intro class to expose you to a bunch of topics so you can get a feel for what you actually care most about / what you want to study more in the future.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

best_comment: This class is great! It can be a bit difficult at times but there is great support and it is worth it for what you will learn. It presents information that is so interesting and important. I would recommend this course to anyone even slightly interested in climate change!
best_gem_comment: It is a decent course within EPS and good for the ESPP Secondary. If you have Python experience the class is manageable, but will require going to office hours. The TFs are very helpful and often you could complete the whole weekly coding notebook in 1 hour in office hours. You also can complete more than 50% of notebook in class, reducing homework. The 3 hour class is a little long, but the coding and breaks make it manageable. I'd take the class and recommend it, but don't expect it to be a complete gem. But, if you like coding and don't mind a longer class and can go to office hours or spend some time attempting to read the Professor's mind, this is a good class for you.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

best_comment: I really, really highly recommend this class to anyone interested in energy or climate. It taught me a TON about the technical aspects of coal and oil/gas production in the first half of the course, much more than I've learned in the many other climate–related classes I've taken (which tend to just reiterate facts about the negative effects of carbon emissions and the importance of policy). The second half comprehensively covered different kinds of renewable energy systems and helped me understand the technical, not just political, steps necessary to achieve decarbonization. The field trip is fantastically fun and a very rare opportunity to see i.e. a shale gas drilling rig or a coal mine, things which are almost impossible to see on your own. John is deeply knowledgeable and very interesting to talk to, and both TFs were absolutely fantastic (Robert was easily the best TF I've had in my time at Harvard) – encouraging, patient, and clearly super enthusiastic about the subject. Fantastic class overall and very worth taking!

Great class.  Lectures are interesting and informative.  Pace of the course is good with weekly homework and section.  Start preparing for the final project after spring break to ensure that you are sufficiently prepared.  Prof. Jacob is clearly very passionate about the subject and that helps a lot!
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

best_comment: I highly recommend taking this class! It was very interesting learning about freshwater resources on Earth and learning more about the intricate workings of the water cycle. Kaighin is an excellent professor and the TFs were also really great at explaining difficult concepts in an understandable manner. The teaching team was definitely a huge strength of the class! There is a decent amount of math and physics involved, so I'd recommend having some understanding of basic mechanics and differential equations. The workload is not bad at all (one pset every two weeks) and there are two midterms and a final (which you're allowed to bring a sheet of notes to). The exams were not too long but they were definitely harder than the problem sets, so I'd recommend studying in advance for those. On the whole, I thought this class was super interesting and definitely one I'm glad I took!

This is a great class and I definitely recommend taking it! Patrick is a great professor and you will learn so much from taking this course! There is a good deal of math involved, which I did not think I would like, but you can see the reasoning and practical application for everything you do in the class; I can genuinely see myself using anything I learned in this class frequently. Because of this, I actually really enjoyed learning the math behind aquatic pollution. This course covers a wide variety of things related to aquatic pollution in great depth, so you come away feeling that you know much more about the course material and can see your progress with every problem set. Patrick gives great feedback and is a big help on assignments, so go to him with your questions about the material!

This class is a great introduction to the influence of climate change on food security. Papers were generally very interesting and the presentation and paper allowed us the opportunity to explore a topic in great depth. Discussions were very engaged and I emerged from the course with a newfound interest in the topic and greater appreciation for food security and climate science in general.

course_title: Natural Climate Solutions: Feasible or Fantasy? 001
best_comment: I would say the overall discourse of NCS being "feasible or a fantasy" was definitely on the fantasy side of things. I rarely left the class feeling hopeful about future climate mitigation strategies incorporating NCS. I would not consider this course to be intersectional; when students attempted to bring up intersectional topics, the conversations were almost always shifted or blatantly ignored. If you are looking for a class to better your critical analysis of scientific research papers, I would softly recommend this seminar. Otherwise, another seminar might be best. The class has a very light workload and doesn't require any background. I would recommend taking any class taught by Dr. Holbrook, though!

course_title: Natural Climate Solutions: Feasible or Fantasy? 001
best_comment: I would say the overall discourse of NCS being "feasible or a fantasy" was definitely on the fantasy side of things. I rarely left the class feeling hopeful about future climate mitigation strategies incorporating NCS. I would not consider this course to be intersectional; when students attempted to bring up intersectional topics, the conversations were almost always shifted or blatantly ignored. If you are looking for a class to better your critical analysis of scientific research papers, I would softly recommend this seminar. Otherwise, another seminar might be best. The class has a very light workload and doesn't require any background. I would recommend taking any class taught by Dr. Holbrook, though!

course_title: The Technology, Economics, and Public Policy of Renewable Energy SEM
best_comment: This course was what I hoped for, an overview of the tech, econ, a bit of public policy of the major renewables (hydro, wind, solar, geothermal, biomass) and comparing them to fossil fuels. (Public policy was covered less than tech and econ, but that was fine with me because there was plenty to talk about with tech and econ. It was useful to learn the advantages that fossil fuels have, mainly being energy–dense, because that's important to know when building up renewables.) Some topics were covered more than once in class, which I think could have been replaced with lectures on nuclear, hydrogen, and a final half–lecture comparing and contrasting all the renewables discussed throughout the course. This was the first time I learned about the electric grid, storage, and subsidies, which are important!Concepts were communicated clearly. Course feedback was a little slow at the beginning; it would've been nice to get it before the 5th Monday, which is students' deadline to change grading status. The weekly response papers were helpful to think about the course topics and were manageable. The course did a great job of covering the important information, so I'm glad there was no section (made my schedule more manageable).
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: Take this class! It may be a lot of work, and it may be difficult at times, but it is honestly the class that has had the greatest impact on me. the professor cares about the material and the students, first class I had the professor not only knew everyones name but different details and things that they liked as well.  fantastic professor with great material. The term project may be a lot of work, but it is really fulfilling to be able to work with a developing country and interview different people in the country as well! 10/10 and would definitely recommend it!
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: I would only take this class if you are ready to dedicate a lot of time to writing and researching. This class can be a lot of work at times (the final project is a cumulation of 5 separate 10 page assignments), however it is rewarding once you see your final paper come together and receive feedback from local NGOs and academics on your hard work. The small class size also allows you to get to know everyone, and Ken makes an effort to make it a fun and friendly environment. Go on the spring break trip if you can, it definitely made the course and workload worthwhile and allowed me to better understand what we had learned in lecture and section.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: Absolutely take this class! It has probably been one of the best, if not the best, course I've taken at Harvard so far. Professor Rivera is incredible –– so kind and so smart. I loved just sitting in class and listening to her speak. I even enjoyed listening to all of my classmates speak. Because it's technically a grad school class, the people in the class came from all over –– div school, various other grad schools, Nieman fellows, other college students. Everyone had such different backgrounds and perspectives, which contributed to fascinating course discussions. Also, it was clear that pretty much everyone consistently did the reading, which I can't say is true in undergrad seminars. It was really refreshing to sit in class and have truly productive and impactful conversations. Sometimes, I didn't even want to say anything at all –– I just wanted to listen to the wonderful things everyone else had to say.  The readings are chosen intentionally, and they are all super interesting. If you have an interest in environment, catastrophe/revelation, and coloniality, I absolutely recommend taking this course. The research project was definitely a daunting assignment. It's a long paper, and it requires work throughout the semester, something I struggle with, especially when taking pset classes concurrently. But, Steve, the TF, was so supportive throughout the entire process. And, if you put some work in, you will create something that you are proud of, which is very rewarding. I'm actually really glad that I had the opportunity to write such a long research paper. At the end of the semester, we did a symposium where everyone presented for a few minutes on their projects. It was incredible to hear the rich variety of topics and styles, and I'm really grateful that I got to learn from so many people in this course. I truly can't recommend this class enough –– if you are thinking of taking it, do it!!
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights

best_comment: Definitely take this class if you would like more of an intimate and personal learning environment. Open conversation is a huge component of the class, and it helps make the class more rewarding in my opinion. Readings for this class are also very eye–opening and, while long, they are very thoughfully selected.

course_title: Latinx Representation in Media, Films, and Pop Culture 001
best_comment: Take advantage of all this course has to offer! The discussion materials are super interesting and discussion is always really engaging!
worse_comment: What I took away from this course was that no matter what, any attempt to convey, portray, or exemplify Latinidad in the media is always going to be problematic. I'm only half joking. All we did in this class was analyze something with Latines (get used to this word because you hear it every 5 seconds in this class) and find ways that it was "wrong" or "harmful." For example, we were indoctrinated to believe that DORA is DANGEROUS. Dora the explorer.

best_comment: The content was absolutely incredible. The most brilliant class I have ever taken at Harvard. Its authenticity, the way it provokes questions, the interdisciplinary nature of the course were all amazing. The group work, meeting with peers/getting to know students well –– and seeing my professor so often in/outside the classroom were all great. Professor Vega–Durán gave so much of her time and knowledge and support to us and I've never had such a dedicated professor before as she is. I loved engaging with a range of disciplines about migration and I learned more in this class than any other class I've taken –– and I have covered many departments here. The assignments were challenging yet fun, interesting, and personal at the same time –– and assignments rarely do that! And they were varied –– essays (descriptive, argumentative, traditional research), art projects, journal entries and reflections, group work, interviews that had us go outside the Harvard bubble to interact with other people, etc.. Just wonderful! I've never been more excited about and fascinated by a class before. Every lecture, every homework assignment was worth it. I was overwhelmed in a very good way by how big and complex the world of migration studies –– and Ethnicity, Migration, and Rights as a field –– is. I am left wanting more, and our professor provided many, many resources and recommendations about how to keep learning after class ended (and throughout the semester). I have even been inspired to pursue graduate school and further research in this field because of this enriching class. Thank you for a unique and awesome experience. So grateful to have had the opportunity participate!

course_title: Topics in Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) Studies 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT! As an Asian American, I came into this class with some understanding of my identity and Asian American history, but I've honestly learned so much—not only about myself but about other Asian communities and Pacific Islanders. Eleanor and Seokweon are incredible, extremely knowledgeable,  and empathetic people who truly want the best for you. They put an emphasis on learning and vulnerability that I haven't seen anywhere else at Harvard. I wish that every class was like this. Honestly, I feel like everyone needs to take a class like this both because of the incredible learning environment that Eleanor and Seokweon provide but also because of simply how much we learn in this class.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights

best_comment: As a required and bothersome course full of excruciating writing and reading assignments, there's not much to redeem EXPOS overall. But if you choose a course that looks interesting and has a caring and thoughtful instructor, it can be a much more mild experience, as is the case with City Living. Even as someone who wasn't especially interested in the topic of cities, I got a lot out of the course and found new ways to think about the physical world around me and how people function in a space, as well as philosophical concepts and psychological ideas to discuss and think about. Personally, the Unit 1 essay analyzing Maier's photographs was particularly enjoyable for me as a photographer and allowed me to stand on a topic I knew strongly in order to explore the unfamiliar topic of city living. Michael was a thoughtful, understanding, and fun instructor who facilitated really engaging and perspective–shifting discussions with the class. He is helpful and generous with extensions as long as you are upfront and communicative! I recommend choosing an EXPOS course with at least one essay you are excited to write from the get–go.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Of the expos classes you could take, this is one of the best! The course readings are shorter but very interesting/varied compared to other classes, and the discussions in class are always really good. Unit 2 (research paper) is probably the most work you'll do in the course for a couple of weeks, but as long as you're on top of it you'll do well as the third unit is a capstone project instead. There's only a short assignment each week to turn in, and classes feel very fun to be in. There's also a meditation to start each class which is super fun and useful for daily life. Sheza is very kind and gives a lot of feedback on papers, so there is a lot to work with when revising. She also bases your deadline of the final draft off when you receive your paper, so you'll definitely have a fair amount of time to revise. Sections were probably my favorite compared to my other courses. Definitely take this expos if you're interested in self improvement, reflection, the mind, or sports!! You'll have a great time.
best_gem_comment: Take this class! A gem of an expos class with a brilliant instructor. The course material is universally engaging and applicable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS EXPOS SECTION. This without a doubt is one of the best expos sections possible with one of the most passionate preceptors. I know expos is a requirement, and at times yes, this class and writing assignments are a requirement I would rather not have when I have so many psets to complete––but the topic of this course made each exploration in every paper so worth it. I thoroughly enjoyed going to class each day. Sometimes when I was having a stressful day, I would look forward to going to expos because I knew it would be relaxing with our daily meditation. At the end of the semester we did a group yoga activity, and it was so fun. Group yoga and daily meditations are such a rare activity to have in a college class, why would you have any reason not to take this expos? I genuinely explored so much about myself, the human experience, other experiences, meditation, mindfulness, peace, intention, psychology, and of course writing and presentation.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Religious Pluralism is a great Expos section. You grow a lot as a writer, and you also have space to dig into the fascinating issue at hand: religion in a diverse nation like America. The workload of the course is reasonable, and it's exciting to engage with a variety of sources from a play to legal journal articles to the sources you choose for your research paper. Jacob is a really supportive preceptor who clearly explains new concepts and makes time in office hours for 1–on–1 feedback.
worse_comment: This is a great expos! Unfortunately Jacob is leaving… but it was very organised and not a huge amount of work. I did have some crunch time nights when the drafts were due though
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Although it probably won't be offered again, Wastelands was one of the best classes I've taken. The documentaries we watch are very interesting and inspiring, the readings of the short stories are interesting, and Dr. Brown is extremely supportive and encourages discussion in classes. The essays are very reasonable and allow for a lot of freedom to what we want to write, and the office hours and conference times are amazing. Dr. Brown is truly a joy and I would love to take more of his classes in the future!***
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Light reading, but really good discussion. Professor Cole is super accessible and gives very helpful feedback. the research paper is really open ended, so choose something you're actually interested in learning about and it becomes a lot more fun
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Professor Cole is an understanding Professor who will give you honest feedback that will help you identify what you need to work on. I found the smaller assignments leading up to the larger papers to be quite helpful because they will give you the foundation you need to tackle those. With that being said, don't slack off on those first few response papers because putting in genuine effort and time will give him the opportunity to communicate with you and help you do your best.
worse_comment: The workload is easy, but the repetitiveness may become boring.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you enjoy visiting museums or examining artefacts at all and want to learn and discuss about the history and meaning of an object and how that fits into (very) current debates about their repatriation (and more!), pick this class! The field trips to museums and discussions with curators are absolutely amazing, the essay topics are diverse and there is a good amount of freedom especially for the final research essay. I also appreciated Dr. Given reading complete drafts and giving extensive feedback both via in–line comments and more general thoughts at the end. Overall it was lots of fun and I loved going to class despite skipping lunch every time. For me, the topic provided a fun theme through which to improve my writing!
worse_comment: No matter what expos class you are in, the writing will be painful. Choose a topic that is interesting and engaging, and you will at least have something to write in those painful papers.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! Not only is it a great introduction to feminist theory and the mindset behind social movements but it will actually help you improve as a writer. Dr. Gold is one of the best professors I have ever had and she provides empathetic feedback with the goal of aiding your progressive improvement as a writer. The class discussions are delightful and the readings are actually interesting, unique, and engaging. Perhaps the best expos course available **
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! I know literally everyone in this Q Guide is probably saying the same thing but LISTEN!! This is literally the best expos ever. I have never understood why anyone else complains about their expos (and people complain a lot) because this is literally my favorite class (AND THIS IS COMING FROM A MATH MAJOR WHO HATED HIGH SCHOOL WRITING).  Every expos class will teach you how to write but most classes have you read a text or two in order to have something to write about and then you are just stressed about the writing (from what I hear :) ). In this course, you get to read SUCH INTERESTING texts (really cool short stories that make you feel seen in a way I never have before and feminist theory that isn't actually that hard to read because Dr. Gold will take you through the important parts and you can literally apply to everything ever). It feels like you are reading things BECAUSE THEY ARE ACTUALLY IMPORTANT and then just writing as another way to think about these ideas more deeply. It takes all the stress out of the class and just makes it fun and worth–while. And you are SURROUNDED BY PEOPLE WHO ARE ACTUALLY PASSIONATE. Everyone in the class most likely put it first choice (that's why there are two sections) and really really care about the issues at hand. You aren't just in a room with people who are taking the class because it is required. This doesn't feel like a required class. Despite my rant about the content of the course, I also think Dr Gold is incredibly good at teaching you to write. She breaks everything down into steps and gives lots of examples and even has a "Gold Guide" that she wrote that tells you everything you need to know about writing. I don't think she is the easiest grader in all of expos (if you want an easy A gem this may not be the course for you) but when you actually care about what you are writing it literally doesn't matter. And she will give you so so much feedback (20 minute videos going in depth about her thoughts on your essays) and always be willing to meet and talk about it, that you will truly learn a lot. She will also listen to you all the time and is so easy to come talk to. I sometimes mention to other people (upperclassmen!) that I am in the class and they will light up and start talking about how awesome Dr. Gold is. In conclusion, I took this class because my friend took it last semester and told me to take and I will be forever grateful to him :)))
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! I know literally everyone in this Q Guide is probably saying the same thing but LISTEN!! This is literally the best expos ever. I have never understood why anyone else complains about their expos (and people complain a lot) because this is literally my favorite class (AND THIS IS COMING FROM A MATH MAJOR WHO HATED HIGH SCHOOL WRITING).  Every expos class will teach you how to write but most classes have you read a text or two in order to have something to write about and then you are just stressed about the writing (from what I hear :) ). In this course, you get to read SUCH INTERESTING texts (really cool short stories that make you feel seen in a way I never have before and feminist theory that isn't actually that hard to read because Dr. Gold will take you through the important parts and you can literally apply to everything ever). It feels like you are reading things BECAUSE THEY ARE ACTUALLY IMPORTANT and then just writing as another way to think about these ideas more deeply. It takes all the stress out of the class and just makes it fun and worth–while. And you are SURROUNDED BY PEOPLE WHO ARE ACTUALLY PASSIONATE. Everyone in the class most likely put it first choice (that's why there are two sections) and really really care about the issues at hand. You aren't just in a room with people who are taking the class because it is required. This doesn't feel like a required class. Despite my rant about the content of the course, I also think Dr Gold is incredibly good at teaching you to write. She breaks everything down into steps and gives lots of examples and even has a "Gold Guide" that she wrote that tells you everything you need to know about writing. I don't think she is the easiest grader in all of expos (if you want an easy A gem this may not be the course for you) but when you actually care about what you are writing it literally doesn't matter. And she will give you so so much feedback (20 minute videos going in depth about her thoughts on your essays) and always be willing to meet and talk about it, that you will truly learn a lot. She will also listen to you all the time and is so easy to come talk to. I sometimes mention to other people (upperclassmen!) that I am in the class and they will light up and start talking about how awesome Dr. Gold is. In conclusion, I took this class because my friend took it last semester and told me to take and I will be forever grateful to him :)))
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos is definitely not as intimidating as I thought it would be. I don't like writing in general and I am a CS major so I felt it wouldn't be super necessary to me, but I think this course proved me wrong. Even if I don't end up needing to write in my future profession, I will still need to be able to articulate an argument and be able to support it which is something this class has taught me to do a lot. Martin is leaving but he was a sweetheart. He can be a little particular (as all of expos is) and it was a little jarring at first but once you got used to it he's a lovely preceptor who I enjoyed very greatly and was very generous with his Dunkin Donuts. Definitely try to pick a topic for Expos that you care about and want to write about because it makes the assignments so much better to do and so much easier to devote your time to.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is an absolutely amazing class. Martin is a great instructor who really takes the time with the material and provides detailed feedback on assignments! In terms of content, although the readings can get a bit philosophical and research–heavy, they are very interesting and really help you understand the problem at hand in each unit. Overall would highly suggest taking this course if you are interested in environment ethics/climate change/animal rights :)
worse_comment: I was not impressed by this class. I did not feel like I was able to exceptionally grow through this course. Part of that is likely because my writing style was not quite in line with the preceptor's. Martin also did not really put much effort into connecting our readings back to the broader theme of humans, nature, and the environment, which I was hoping to get more insight on. Overall, this class was not the bane of my existence, but I did not really enjoy it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this Expos. Based on everyone else I have asked, Expos seemed like a hard requirement that people were glad to be done with, but this Expos was genuinely such an amazing class and I am sad to leave it behind. Yes, you have to put in the work in terms of the readings and applying feedback to your papers, but the topics for each unit are extremely interesting and I guarantee you will have a fun time writing your papers. Plus, Prof Herron is such an amazing professor and will help you with whatever you need in your paper.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take Climate Fictions!! Eliza is wonderful, kind, and provides really helpful feedback on your drafts so I always knew how to improve my final draft. Especially if you're interested in environmentalism and climate change, the readings are so interesting and widened my understanding of climate art a lot. I think the professor can make a huge difference in your Expos experience, and I would totally recommend taking Climate Fictions with Eliza. It was my favorite class this semester.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course was fun! I did not actually rank it in my expos ranking, so the subject matter isn’t anything I’m super passionate about, but I still had a good time. Eliza is supe helpful and understanding when it comes to deadlines and she really prioritizes progress, so it doesn’t matter if your first paper isn’t good! Also, the reading is mostly interesting and not too heavy.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: One (unsolicited) piece of advice is to make sure that you’re using Dr. Lane as a resource! She’s extremely helpful and was always happy to answer my questions on Slack outside of scheduled classes and office hours. Especially with the first drafts, it’s often really easy to not really figure out how to structure your essays but after talking to her my next steps in setting up my papers became much more clear.That being said, definitely take this Expos. The grading definitely feels a bit harsh at times, but the reading list is honestly really cool. Pretty much every time I was reading something for this class, my friends who were taking Expos simultaneously (in other sections) would always be like “I can’t believe you’re reading that, I have to read [insert boring text name] instead.” So, you’ll never be bored at least. Definitely only recommend if you’re into science fiction though — if you are, you’ll love it and if you’re not, you probably won’t.
worse_comment: If you're looking for an easy expos, this one is it. Not super learn y though.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This was a very good expos section! I definitely recommend taking this course, as its discussions are applicable to a wide variety of subjects and its readings are fairly interesting. Additionally, I found Dr. Lane to be a supportive instructor who provided very good feedback. Based on my discussions with friends, this seemed like a much better expos section than many others and one that highly encouraged learning and growth.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I kind of liked it, but a lot of other people didn't. It's Expos – it's not going to be fun or particularly interesting – but I found the conversations surrounding scholarly literature in this course to be lacking, and our readings to be useless. Professor Martin is a pretty fair grader, though, and you'll probably learn a good bit about researxh.
worse_comment: Unless the curriculum and professor are completely changed for this course, choose another expos. I was extremely disappointed with this course and will honestly say that it was the worst academic experience I had all year.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I LOVE THIS CLASS! I LOVE ROSS! The class might be a little challenging, but it is very, very rewarding. Though the essays you are writing and cases you are reading might seem intimidating at first, Ross is so so willing to help at any point of your learning and this makes all the difference. I also think reading and analyzing cases is just a great way to learn how to write, because the cases themselves are very heavily based on logic just like expos essays and good essays in general are. The course was such a good training for my writing and helped me so much in bridging from high school writing to college writing. It is valuable to my learning in all logic–based and/or writing–based courses and topics. It does require time and will to think hard, but I think this is what a good class should be like. PLEASE TAKE THE COURSE. IT'S SO PRECIOUS. I LOVE IT.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos is a class that you're required to take, so you should definitely make the most of it! I know it can be tempting to take expos classes that have reputations for being "easy" expos classes, but I highly encourage you to select a topic that you'll enjoy and that will push you. Taking Ross' Personhood in U.S. Constitutional Law expos was one of the best decisions I made my first–year and I say this with full confidence. Ross is the best and he makes this course what it is. He's simply just an incredible educator. I feel like I had really outstanding teachers in high school,  so it was so amazing getting to connect with a college instructor who I felt cared for me like my high school teachers did. He is genuinely invested in seeing you grow and thrive as a student and this is something that you will come to see and appreciate more clearly as the semester progresses. He will constantly check–in with you and he's always happy to chat with you (one of the highlights of my semester was talking with Ross after our expos section ended). Besides the fact that Ross is just an incredible human and terrific preceptor, the course content is super interesting. A variety of really important Supreme Court cases make up the core of the reading for this class which is really cool. The discussions you'll have in class are nuanced, engaging, and really meaningful. You'll feel closer to all the people in your section because you collectively take on talking about very difficult topics. This is certainly a class that pushes you, but I think that was one of my favorite parts of the course. The rigor never feels arbitrary or unnecessary; it feels deliberate and productive. Ross has spent a lot of time fine–tuning this course and that comes across when you're a student in the course who can see how well–run it is. In short, take Ross' Personhood in U.S. Constitutional Law expos—it might be one of the most rewarding opportunities you have in your entire time at Harvard.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: As someone who loves sports and the nitty–gritty political sides within it, it was definitely a great expos experience. The course materials are definitely more garnered towards football/basketball, but you have your chance to shine on the research paper on the sport of your choosing. Super fun, loved the course and the course instructor!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: ***More than a Game is the Expos you want to take. The material taught in this class is truly amazing. I found myself completing all the readings and watching the documentaries not out of necessity, but out of genuine interest, I learned so much about so many different sports and truly feel like an accomplished writer. Professor McKeon does a great job of teaching the course and makes a dull requirement fun.
worse_comment: Take this class, it is without a doubt the best expos ever!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: this class is super well taught! professor meyer is super passionate about sociology and a wonderful resource both in and outside of the classroom. you'll learn a lot about how to write as well as some interesting sociology :)
worse_comment: This class was very hard for me even as a social studies person. The class always felt really rushed especially when talking to other students in different EXPOS classes. There is also very little flexibility in terms of extensions which is very ironic considering the class is all about how workers are exploited and capitalism, etc. There are no extensions whatsoever and just an overall pessimistic attitude towards giving extra time to complete an assignment since the dates are given in advance. Other expos classes were much more flexible so this excuse didn't make sense to me. The material is interesting though, but you have to have some background in sociology/Marx. Unit 2 was so hard, I really did not like going to class because even though I would pay attention to everything Professor Meyer was throwing at us I could never follow along. She is very enthusiastic and knowledgeable, I bet her other class is much more captivating, but I don't think this topic is suitable for an Expos class. She does give good feedback but I would increase office hours and appointment times. 15 mins is not enough for a conference. I would be cautious in ranking this class. I did learn a lot but at times it was frustrating as a student of color because I felt like the discussions lacked a racial/income angle.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course is relatively standard for an expos course. Dr. Monaghan is very knowledgable, helpful, and generally a great writing instructor. However, this course may prove to be more work than the average expos course: there is slightly more reading, deadlines come at you fast and are not flexible. Grading seems generally fair, but it's probably stricter than other options.I wouldn't recommend taking this course if you do not have at least a slight interest in military history and warfare generally. If you do, this course will be interesting though at certain points may stray more towards a home front perspective than you may like. Overall, this is a good way to get the expos requirement done. It is as engaging as possible for expos, very well taught, but may be slightly harder than other options.
worse_comment: Hard if you're not all that interested in the very very specific aspects of war that this class covers. Read the syllabus very closely before putting this on your preference list. Teacher is hard, says that deadlines are inflexible and that there are specific Expos requirements she has to abide by that are blatantly false (given that no other Expos class has the same requirements).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This isn't an "easy" Expos, but it's a class that you will absolutely learn from and grow from. To be completely honest, this was my last–choice Expos, but at the end of it I could not be more happy that I was placed into it. This class requires hard work and dedication, but if you are willing to put effort in, you will get a lot out of this class. Dr. Monaghan is amazing, and she gives very valuable feedback that will help you grow as a writer. If you're looking for the kind of transformative writing experience that Expos advertises itself to be, I would highly recommend taking this class!
best_gem_comment: This class was, in my opinion, a great example of what an expos class should be. We had many lessons, any many peer assignments, that worked to teach us the fundamental parts of writing. We had timely schedules to do work which forced the class to stay on our game. Dr. M grades harshly but fairly, and this forced all of us to put in lots of work into the class. We got interesting and valuable comments from Dr. M and our peers, and I personally improved my writing over the class by a reasonable amount. Yes, there is dark subject matter, and this isn't a gem, but it is informative and valuable.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. So many people were complaining about their expos, but I loved mine and the environment David fostered. I looked forward to every class. Discussions are so interesting, even if you're never forced to participate. I'm generally such a quiet student, but I felt comfortable and interested enough to talk regularly, and David always gives honest, constructive feedback without ever making you feel bad. You find yourself wanting to take the course seriously and succeed and grow. I went into expos planning to coast and not thinking my writing would actually improve throughout, but David makes you actually care, and now I know how to write essays I care about and I'm actually genuinely strongly convinced of the arguments I'm making. There isn't any more work than any other class; it's extremely manageable, and it is so totally worth it. There is absolutely no reason not to rank Family Trees first and there is every reason to do so. Take it! Take it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: you NEEd David NEEBut seriously I think if David is continuing to teach this next year and beyond, you should definitely check it out! The course material might not be perfect for you, but David really makes everything worth it. He's extremely kind and welcoming and as long as you have a valid reason, is very generous with extensions and is overall a very caring and understanding instructor for all students in the course.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class!! Jen is absolutely amazing. She cares about helping you become a better writing, and gives you great feedback to help you improve after each draft. She also grades fairly. The class itself is very interesting, especially if you have any interest at all in philosophy. I enjoyed the readings, and the essays and assignments are spaced out so that it never feels like we have too much work. I feel like my writing has improved significantly since I started this class, both because of learning about structure and style in the class, and also because of Jen's feedback. I would highly recommend this class!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Now, you only take one Expos 20 class, so I can't directly compare this one to any of the others, but even so I feel confident in stating that this is one of the best (if not the best) Expos class. Coming from someone who could only be described as a very STEM person who went into this with no philosophy background, Philosophy of Friendship ended up being incredibly interesting and fun, partly because what you learn here can be applied to pretty much anyone. You learn to write, sure, but also end up getting to see your relationships with other people through different perspectives, and that's pretty cool when you're first coming to college where there's a bunch of new and interesting people to get to know and make friends with. As for the course load/difficulty, what you put in to this class is absolutely what you get out of it. You could theoretically get away with doing the bare minimum, but I highly recommend putting in the effort, since you WILL be rewarded for it, and like I said the topic is also just really cool to engage with. The weekly schedule is a philosophy paper to read before each class, which doesn't take too long, and then a class that's divided between discussing philosophical ideas as a group + going over writing skills.
