Jen is a fair grader but also super nice, she gives really good feedback on essay drafts so be sure to read those if you end up taking this expos. Seriously though, great class, definitely one to put in your expos lottery list if you think the topic is even a little interesting.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Q is an amazing professor who is very understanding of her student's circumstances on a case–by–case basis. She is very enthusiastic about the subject matter and makes entering the classroom feel very welcoming. She always makes sure that her students are doing well mentally and that there's anything that she can do to help outside the academic area. While this expos does require a decent amount of time investment to reap a good outcome, I highly recommend this course if you want an Expos that is rewarding yet doesn't feel challenging.
worse_comment: You probably won't get an A. You'll get A– at most. But, it's not very demanding. The only demanding work is the essays. But you need to try really hard to get an A, and I don't think it's worth trying that hard.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS EXPOS!!! Dr. Quigley is a brilliant professor who perfectly balances teaching the engaging content of the course and workshopping our writing skills. Compared to other EXPOS classes, I found that this section was the ideal balance of challenging and fair. I think the greatest strength of this course is Dr. Quigley herself. She is a deeply empathetic and understanding teacher who prioritizes the growth and success of her students. You will grow as a writer, have great discussions, and have fun! This is the perfect EXPOS for people interested in both science and humanities as we read a wide range of sources, including both journal articles and narratives. Also a great option for premed!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: One of the best expos classes out there. Keep in mind that the expos classes are ones that really line up with your interests. But if biomedicine is even slightly of interest to you, most definitely take this class!! You have lots of freedom in exploring what you want to learn about within biomedicine, and Professor Raymer is so supportive and helpful. She is truly one of the best expos teachers out there and she is so kind and understanding and focused on helping you learn and succeed. There are a bit of readings, especially for the second essay, but I strongly recommend this course and would take it again if I had to!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Frontiers of Biomedicine is a genuinely enjoyable expos class! You hear a lot about how hit or miss expos can be, but this section is definitely a hit. Emilie successfully facilitates engaging, in–depth discussions about the material. Because the material is so interesting, the essays are pretty enjoyable to write. We cover so much analysis in class that finding a topic was never particularly difficult. I found the grading on the assignments pretty kind, but full of useful feedback. All in all, this expos allows you to learn about incredibly pertinent and fascinating topics in modern biomedicine as well as learn how to improve your writing. Definitely do recommend!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Do not take this class. I don't understand how my writing improved while taking this course. We had discussions about many topics and papers, but what I learned about how to write well (the purpose of this class) was mainly accrued through osmosis. By this I mean that we were exposed to texts that were written by influential people (not renowned for their writing itself but rather their ideas) such as Michael Sandel, but I can't remember a single class during which we focused on craft or style or anything of that sort. We did spend a day on citation formatting. It seems as though this class is a 'choose–your–own–adventure' in regard to how much you actually improve your writing, because that improvement would be nearly entirely self–directed. Class was dominated by people sharing their opinions about a variety of topics, but such discussions, although interesting, did not actually contribute to the missions of the expository writing class. What I will say is that I learned to use evidence for EVERYTHING, but it seems as though this course was more focused on providing warrants for every single one of your claims instead of broader learning about writing.  If you are already a 'good' writer, take this class. But don't take it for the cool name and the movie. Having the research paper be the second essay was too much work in an incredibly short period of time, and it led to half–baked papers. Further, the research assignment itself was poorly explained which caused confusion within the class. I don't understand how Hannah grades and it seems vaguely opinion–based. She is very understanding with extensions, which is a plus for this course. However this is not a reason to take it. Just take a better expos and hand your work in on time. I will say generally to first years selecting their expos: GET CLOSE WITH YOUR CLASS! My favorite memories from this class were going to berg after class and sitting around and chatting. If your expos ends around 6 pm, do an 'expos dinner' as we called it. It's a really special time and you have to do this, regardless of the class that you choose/rank. I have the fondest memories from my expos class (not academic!) because we got close as a group outside of class, just by walking out of section together. It's truly special and one of my favorite first year moments.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Overall, this Expos was fantastic! I had many friends who had terrible experiences, and they always told me they wished they took this Expos instead. Dr. Routon was fantastic, very kind and understanding, and always provided really helpful feedback on essays. Additionally, the discussions that we had i class were always thought–provoking and interesting. It's a shame that Dr. Routon is leaving after this year. As a result, I am not sure if this Expos will ever run again, or if it does, who will be the instructor in future years. My overall advice for picking a good Expos is: DO YOUR RESEARCH! Pick a course that got the best reviews on the Q guide, not which subject sounds most interesting. Everyone I know that had a good experience in this writing requirement picked their Expos very carefully based on reviews of the class and the teacher.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem if you are interested in the topic. Not the best choice for those who want to improve their writing skills – Prof. Routon doesn't give very much feedback on writing and assignments in general. She is an amazing teacher, but I wish that in–class discussions and coursework integrated more college–level theory and information. Overall very good course, but there are a lot of ways it could be better.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. This is hands down the best EXPOS, and I truly never expected EXPOS to be my favorite class of the semester. The readings are all so interesting and relevant, and you are exposed to a wide range of media: podcasts, graphic novels, journals, etc. The class discussions are always intellectually stimulating and make you want to contribute your opinion. Erin is a highlight: she is so friendly, and you can really tell she cares for you as a person. She is always accommodating, understanding with extensions, and approachable at all times. You will learn so much as a writer and a student, and there is no unnecessary busy work. Hearing from my peers, top–tier EXPOS class is possibly the best one out there.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! Adam is a wonderful preceptor who does a great job at generating interest in the subject. The discussions and texts are super interesting. I didn't know that there was so much to learn about Hell, but I can truly say this class was a very transformative experience. The final essay may seem daunting at first, but it's actually a really great way to get creative with a subject you're passionate about.
worse_comment: You have to take expos. I don't have any experience in other expos courses, but I would not recommend this one with flying colors or anything.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Adam is such a good professor! The content is interesting and the class really helped me improve my writing skills! The reading is super manageable and Adam provides amazing feedback and advice when on your drafts. He's super sweet and facilitates a great classroom environment where students really get to appreciate the content, and he encourages participation from students and we have great conversations! Never laughed so much in a class before :)
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an interesting class for sure, but I have a few reservations. The content is all cool and if are into con artistry, you will definitely enjoy this class. You can tell Ian really enjoys teaching and cares about the students. There are daily icebreakers at the beginning of class, which definitely break the tension at the beginning of the semester. The first essay is a bit tough, especially if you were never really taught proper academic writing. I also think you have to do a lot of work yourself, as feedback on drafts is not always super specific. However, if you do put in the work, you will get a good grade for sure.No matter what grade you receive, I think you will enjoy this class if you even remotely enjoy this topic.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I honestly think this is one of the best EXPOS classes to take (I have heard horror stories from my other friends). Ian especially is very chill, and the vibes are very much there. There is a decent amount of peer collaboration and discussion. Ian always opens with really funny questions that help you get to know the people in your section which just makes it a more comfortable environment for exploring this style of writing. As for the actual work, it honestly makes it SO much easier to do the reading. Otherwise you kinda develop an inferiority complex when everyone else has really good and thoughtful comments about the text...But, Ian gives great feedback and I do honestly feel that I have developed past the five paragraph structure, which I guess is a success. The content of the course is also super interesting –– we literally only read one book. I found cons to be very fascinating, and it is honestly such an interesting idea to touch on cons as extensions of extreme societal pressure. We approach the same text through multiple lenses, and is a very cool way to see how an author's background can drastically change the interpretation of the same facts. Take the course, tbh
worse_comment: I used to HATE writing and was dreading expos. And Ian totally changed that. He is incredible. This class is so fun and interesting
best_gem_comment: Ian is a gem! He is incredible and his passion for teaching is palpable in every encounter you have with him.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Even before I arrived at Harvard, I had the impression that Expos was notoriously difficult. Furthermore, I felt that I had done my fare share of writing in high school, and I was dreading having to take yet another writing class. My spirits rose slightly when I realized that there were different topics from which to choose, and I conceded that I could always use a bit more feedback on my writing, but it wasn't until I started taking this class that I realized that my dread of Expos was out of proportion. The assignments could certainly be challenging, but they were by no means impossible or unreasonable, and our preceptor was always there to support us when we needed any sort of assistance. Even when the course was most difficult, the readings and class discussions always kept me engaged. I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is remotely interested in privacy and surveillance and who is looking for a truly beneficial Expos experience.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an amazing expos!!!! I was a bit scared going into the course because of things I've heard, but I loved, loved, loved it!!!! If you are interested in issues of privacy, surveillance (duh) and conversations related to data privacy, AI, etc., this is a great course to take!! The course is centered around a lot of theoretical and law–based discussion, which I thought was really interesting. It's not a gimme A  course, but I thought grading was fair and Dr. Sinnott is a great preceptor!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Julia is absolutely AMAZING. She guides the class discussion in a way that so that it doesn't feel forced, and everyone is encouraged to participate however they'd like to. The assignments are manageable even with a busy schedule, and Julia's feedback on writing is super helpful and reasonable. This was probably my favorite class semester because of how interesting and open–ended the material is, as well as how comfortable the class atmosphere felt. TAKE THIS EXPOS
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This definitely the most rewarding and powerful class I have taken this year.  The readings are pretty interesting and the capstone project is as creative and powerful as you make it. No one comes into this course as great writer but you will definitely leave a better one. Hudson is a great professor that facilitated great discussions and lessons. The only thing I will say is that it is somewhat graded harshly and you may not get the grade you want on your first essay but he does prepare you to do better on the rest of the assignments so as long as you put in the effort you will succeed.
worse_comment: This course will not only allow you to grow so much as a writer and critical thinker but will engage you with an issue that is the most pressing problem society faces. The readings and speakers will provide you with crucial knowledge to become very educated on mass incarceration and its complexities.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class!!!! It is not the easiest expos, but definitely the most rewarding. If you genuinely want to be engaged and develop as a writer, this class is perfect. I love it so much and don't know anyone who doesn't love it as much as me. Hudson is the best professor at the college and he deserves all the praise in the world. There's only two papers in the semester so you have plenty of time to revise.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is truly an AMAZING Expos! If you know you like Jane Austen  (or think there's a chance you'll like her novels), TAKE IT! (That is, give yourself the best chance of taking it and rank it first. Pro tip: if there are two sections, rank them both first and second if you can – that's what I did – to increase your chances of getting in.)This class was absolutely wonderful, I honestly can't praise it enough! I was a little scared of Expos before taking it, and thought Expos might just be something I have to endure on my way to a STEM major, but from the very first class, this course quickly became one of the most enjoyable and instructive ones I have ever taken. (Although, admittedly, I might have been slightly biased as I was already getting excited ahead  of the first class for analyzing Jane Austen :)) Dr. Napier is a fantastic instructor, he will provide you with plenty of examples and sample essays and clearly explain every step of the writing process to you.  What stood out to me the most, perhaps, was how much time he was willing to devote to our learning, always agreeing to set up additional office hours to provide individual help. Also, his comments are incredibly helpful (and I know others share my opinion). Whenever I felt stuck with my essay, I knew that talking to Dr. Napier would guide me in the right direction. I was honestly always amazed how quickly he understood the gist of what my issue was and how helpful the solutions he offered were.In short, unless you know you absolutely do not want to read anything by Austen or Austen–related (but then you probably wouldn't be reading the Q–guide for this class), I sincerely, absolutely recommend this course! (Keep in mind, this is coming from a STEM major – this class is not just for English concentrators! Our group was a good mix of prospective STEM and Humanities/Social Sciences majors.) If you're hesitating between this class and another Expos, pick this one (or another one that Dr. Napier teaches if things change at some point –  perhaps you're reading this a few years after I wrote this!) – it will be one of the best decisions you'll make in your first year at Harvard!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: if you are into Jane austen, literature, feminism, etc, take this expos!! I have so much more appreciation for Emma, Clueless, and Jane Austen after this course. Dr. Napier is really supportive and helpful with the writing process, and I like that he is really passionate about the subject. I mostly enjoyed the peer review process of the class because I made friends, improved as a writer, and got to see how creative people were (people’s topics for the research paper were so cool!). One thing I wish was done differently in this course is understanding perspective. I felt there was a level of depth, especially regarding the relation of Austen’s work to feminism and women in general, that we just didn’t get to dive into because we didn’t hear from female voices on the subject.
worse_comment: Don't beat yourself up if you're not the best at this , it's a process and supposed to make you stronger, not the best.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Zecca's section is great. She always encourages open discussions during class and welcomes your ideas. Dr. Zecca offers excellent support if you are ever in need of help during your writing process. She is very understanding when it comes to turning in assignments. If you are ever having a rough week with lots of assignments in your other classes, she is open to granting extensions. This really made my experience in Expos manageable. If you are a fan of the horror genre, this class is perfect for you. Even if you are not, this course still makes the topic very interesting. Don't worry–––the scary stories aren't that extreme. :)
worse_comment: I would say that this class was very interesting but if you do not enjoy reading and watching horror then this is not the class for you.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Mande is a very kind professor, who is enthusiastic about the subject matter and excited to get to know her students. The uses of horror is a pretty cool expos, especially if you are into film. I do not recommend this course if you dislike analyzing film. Otherwise, Mande was the best instructor I could've hoped for.
worse_comment: This was a really good expos class, especially if you enjoy horror! I have friends who hated their expos classes because the readings were so boring, but this was extremely engaging and the space Mande created in lectures made it feel very easy to exchange ideas. The readings weren't too heavy at all, and die down after the first unit especially to make the class much more manageable. In general, when you're picking expos courses, focus on the topics because at the end of the day, if you don't like the topic being taught you will hate the readings regardless of how short or long they were, and thus hate the class for an entire semester.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are looking to develop your writing skills and receive consistent feedback, "The Successful Life" class is an excellent option. Throughout the course, you will have the opportunity to write and receive feedback on a variety of assignments, from personal essays to research papers. This feedback will help you improve your writing skills and gain a better understanding of what makes a strong argument.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Firstly, Statistics: I spent a total of 61:37 hours across 11–12 weeks on the class. This figure includes everything from writing, researching, lectures and more done for this class. I kept a strict time tracking schedule and these were my results for each week: (The data starts from Monday of each week and the first recorded week is the week of Feb 13. 5:29h means 5 hours and 29 minutes were spent during that week on this class.  )6 h, 4:25h, 8:53h, 2:30h, 8:20h, 0h (school break), 5:29h,  1:53h, 12:06h, 7:49h, 4:09h. I haven't finished the revision of my final paper yet, which will add another 8 hours or more probably. As you can see, some weeks are tough, others are a breeze. Be prepared for this. 28:29 hours were spent on writing, 19:13 spent on lectures, 5:21 on readings, 2:35 on the job cover letters, 3:35 spent on reviewing, preparing for class, and annotations, 0:28 on conferences. More time was spent on some miscellaneous tasks.  My data on the conference times is incorrect, im not sure where I made a mistake. Review: I feel like this was this class was a disappointment. I believe we should have focused less on the content of the readings we did and more on the writing technique of the readings. Although I had a fun time in class and discussion, I didn't learn much about _writing_! I expected more workshops and writing analysis instead of reading comprehension! For a majority of readings, our focus was on WHAT the author(s) were saying. I feel that we should have been focusing on HOW authors were conveying their thoughts. Am I mistaken here? Why didn't we analyze the O'Connoll piece (a piece about a doctor dedicating their life to helping the homeless) as an example of, say, journalistic writing instead of focusing on the content. Don't get me wrong, I cried during that reading, but now that I look back at my semester, I feel as though these were missed opportunities. How did that author manage to make me cry? Give me answers to THAT instead of making me write a random response and write some dumb thing on another classmate's post (That classmate, of course, also couldn't care less about reading my response).  I would have loved to discuss how Crawford, an author we read for unit 1 on the value of manual labor, goes from discussing separation of thinking and doing in modern jobs  to slickly including some Marx in there. I was the wide–eyed freshman who wanted to improve their non–existant writing by taking BOTH of the Studio sequence classes. Boy was I wrong! I believe you should treat the expos class as a College requirement and just take one expos class and be done with it. You will not learn significant writing from this class. My complaint with expos 10 was that I didn't learn much and that we just hung out in class with nothing done. So, I thought maybe salvation lay in studio 20. I thought maybe they wanted to make a very gentle intro and that studio 20 would actually pick up the pace and teach actual writing. Nope. The sad thing is this review will be buried with all of the SEPARATE reviews of the other sections of expos studio 20. Moreover, if you are looking through this review, that mean you probably have taken expos 10 already, so tough luck. You have to take another expos class. If so, then be a realist and take this class anyways. You paid the price of taking expos 10 by having to take two semesters of it. Now, at least benefit from that and make your second semester workload lighter.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would definitely take the Expos 10 and 20 series instead of just standard 20 if you are feeling a little shaky about writing. It was super helpful to me to have 2 semesters of writing. I feel like I really honed my skills.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr Hanes is amazing!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The section is very fun. Workload is very heavy but useful in almost all cases. The two papers are very fun to write, especially the last one because you choose a topic you like and write a research about it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely take this course, the pacing is really good and the instructor is very understanding and flexible
worse_comment: Stay on top of the assignments. The writing process is spit into stages for a reason and it is not fun when you have to do everything once it piles up.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are someone looking to improve your writing skills, this is an awesome class! It is broken down into a manageable course load and it is not bogged down with busy work. All of the assignments in this course are beneficial to improving writing skills. You are able to practice analytical writing, how to structure papers appropriately, as well as improving clarity and conciseness in papers.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Taleen is the best. She is very passionate about teaching this class, and genuinely cares about her students improvements. She created such a great community in the class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Overall, I enjoyed the course. The two big writing tasks were fun to do, and the readings were interesting as they discussed many societal problems regarding success in life. The professor was fantastic, very accessible, and provided a lot of very useful, specific, and thorough feedback. That being said, the only downsides are that you might have to allocate more time to the course than you like to, and sometimes the readings can feel very overwhelming because of their length. However, I am sure don't this class instead of the regular Expos 20 was the right decision for me.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a great class, would highly recommend taking it over regular Expos 20 if you have the option. The smaller sections allow for great conversation and it is a very easy transition from Expos Studio 10*
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: She grades like a hard ass but overall great professor, super kind, literally had a party on the last day she's amazing would take her class 10000 times again.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Enjoy this great class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class instead of regular Expos (if you took Expos Studio 10). Professor Strauss is an amazing person and is there to support you through the writing process. Expos Studio 20 will prepare you for Harvard–level writing and will introduce you to new level of critical thinking you have never experienced before! I would totally recommend this class!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is generally easy, but just helps improve basic writing
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this course!!! Especially if your stuck in between studio or standard, studio has a great format, more support, and the topic is broad enough that you'll be able to investigate something that interests you
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is an amazing class and definitely worth taking first semester.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is worth taking if you want a slower–paced version of Expos 20. It takes less work overall than expos 20, but that is because it takes into account the work you have already done last semester in expos 10. Unless you have a expos 20 class you want to take, this is a good option as well. The topic "the successful life" is vague enough that it allows a lot of flexibility with your final research paper.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you feel that you need further assistance in refining your writing and improving your writing process, I highly recommend taking this class. The course provided a comprehensive overview of the writing process, and I learned many effective strategies and tips that have significantly enhanced my writing abilities. Additionally, the class offered ample opportunities for one–on–one feedback from the professor, which was instrumental in my writing development overall. The course allowed me to explore new ideas and refine my writing skills, while also being manageable in terms of workload, which was particularly beneficial during my first year of college. Overall, if you are seeking a supportive and helpful writing course, this one is an excellent choice.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course is amazing! I think that every student at Harvard should take this course at some point before they graduate. You'll gain enormous confidence in your public speaking skills and make a lot of friends. 10/10 recommend.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an overall great course, but it's also a "what you make of it" class.  I was a weak public speaker going into this course, so this was not a gem for me. I spent a LOT of time on it during speech weeks, like 10+ hours. I chose really personal topics for most of my speeches, which made it easier to write my speeches, but much more emotional to deliver them, but I think I got a lot out of that. While harrowing for me at times, was an overall valuable and fun time. Kate is the greatest preceptor for this course, and she is so caring and kind. She did wonders for me with her suggestions, feedback, workshopping, and general support.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You must take this course and if you can, take it with Kate. Actually one of the best classes ever. Kate is such a sweetheart and cares so much about her students.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this course!!! I was super nervous about public speaking going in and wasn't sure this course was going to be all that fun despite all the good reviews – but I LOVED IT – its really chill there isn't really any homework at all, you just work on your speeches and really practice public speaking! my class got close and it was really fun and it was super low pressure. my public speaking improved so much and I had so much fun in the process. i honestly think everyone should try to take this course if they have the chance – i learned so much and had a great time and it was not high pressure or high stakes in any way – simply a great environment to learn and grow and work on a new skill and have fun.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take. This. Class. Don't have any ways public speaking is currently relevant to you? You will either in your career or in future academic settings. This class made me engage with my other classes better (it endowed me with the confidence and capacity to talk eloquently during class discussion and not constantly stress about my participation grade). Do you have to give presentations that you hate but acknowledge as a necessary evil? Take this class and you will start to look forward to them. Taking this class has allowed me to break other people's speaking performances down into discrete parts (instead of thinking, wow they're just really good / really bad). It feels like a superpower –– like looking at a painting in a museum and knowing exactly how it was done. There's something cool about that. But perhaps most importantly this class was an amazing reprieve from giant lectures where your presence feels meaningless and tiny seminars where you have to clamor against your peers to demonstrate that you did the reading. You WILL make great friends, leave with the groundwork for a lifelong skill, and exert almost no effort outside of the classroom. One of my favorite classes I have ever taken at Harvard, a sentiment shared by the seniors in the class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you're interested in improving your public speaking (whatever level of experience you are coming from) you should definitely take expos 40.  I've had a bit of public speaking experience, and I was definitely pushed out of my comfort zone, mainly with the improv exercises, which are fun, challenging, and low stakes. The main speech assignments aren't super time consuming, and I think there are only like 5 throughout the semester. Honestly the toughest part of this course was the 9am wakeup and that it was 2 hours in class twice a week, but the workload is pretty minimal (pretty much just writing and practicing the speech the day or two before...you're supposed to work on them for longer but I procrastinate). Terry is a great instructor and very caring and supportive no matter what level of experience you have. He lowkey gives politician energy which is funny lol (he used to be a politician) but he is such a good public speaker so he's great to learn from. You get to know a cool group of people cus its a small class and its interactive which is so fun. Honestly 9.5/10 experience !
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely take this class! It was a really great opportunity to practice writing speeches and speaking in front of others, and because the class is so small I feel like I got to make new friends through this course. Terry is an excellent professor (and a great speaker) and gave really good feedback that constantly helped me improve. The workload isn't too bad and all of the assignments are really fun and interesting. Highly recommend!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Absolutely take this class if you get the chance! Overall, an unbelievably good course, without a doubt one of the best I've taken at Harvard. You will make friends, improve at public speaking, and gain a new perspective about yourself.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! Not only was it extremely enjoyable but it improved my public speaking significantly. I was able to reflect on myself and my values though speaking, and how I can communiate professionally/academically etc. Zach is incredible and provides endless support and care. He brings fun and energy to sessions alongside expertise. I cannot recommend him and this class enough.
worse_comment: essential skill and low key class – would def take!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is fantastic; I highly recommend it! Zach in particular is an incredible instructor, and the small class sizes combined with lots of personal interaction means many class sections bond very closely. In my opinion, a particularly underrated part of this class is getting to listen to 14 of your brilliant Harvard classmates give interesting speeches on topics they're passionate about. Sections typically to have a range of comfort and experience with public speaking, so you can take the class if public speaking is something you enjoy and are comfortable with or if it's something that's scary that you want to improve!
subject: Expository Writing

course_title: History of Witchcraft and Charm Magic 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class if you are interested in witchcraft, folklore, and/or history, European or otherwise. Although the focus is on Europe, you have the opportunity to make the final project very personal, engaging, and creative, and have the liberty of picking almost any topic tangentially related to magic or witchcraft.  The readings are interesting, if a bit dense at times, and some weeks have a lot to cover, so learning how to skim is a key skill you will develop during this course. Steve Mitchell is very friendly  and approachable, so if you have any questions at all or want feedback on your project ideas, don't hesitate to contact him. As of writing this comment, we have still not received our midterm grades, so I have no idea what grade I can expect from this class. However, the TF warned us the grading criteria would be quite harsh. Therefore, do not assume that you will get an A just for turning in your paper on time. Engagement is highly valued, and attendance is mandatory, unless you want to fail the class. However, the class is overall really fun, and I highly recommend it.
worse_comment: An easy class as long as you have an incompetent TF. If you didn’t, I think this class would still be fairly straightforward, but would require more brainwork.
best_gem_comment: Take this glass. Enjoyable gem.

best_comment: I adored this class!! The section time has fundamentally has altered my perspective on American history. I know we always talk about how important it is to get alternative perspectives when learning history, but I've never had the privilege to take a class that actually does so.  Lufkin is extremely knowledgeable and more than happy to share her opinions about it all. The only potential issues I had with the section component was (1) the length of the readings and (2) the section feels more like a lecture because it ends up being a lot of Lufkin talking (but that could have just been our class).The labs were amazing. I really appreciated the opportunity to get to learn how to sew, both by hand and on the machine, and working on the final project gave me a chance to solidify all the skills we learned throughout the semester.If you take this class, be prepared to have the urge to bring up quilting in far more conversations than you expected!
subject: Folklore & Mythology

course_title: Genesis of Stars and Life in the Universe 001
best_comment: Avi is an incredible teacher, and it was an honor to learn from him as an admirer of his work.  His lectures had a good mix of technicality and discussion — and he made the math material accessible for students who didn’t have as much experience before / weren’t STEM concentrators. I loved his tangents, his profession of his dream to die in space and become a historic meteorite in another world, his candid discussions of what mattered most for human progress and human’s foolish history of precluding progress through politics. He inspired me to develop a more sharp, critical view of the world and scientific advancement. This is something I will carry with me. Morgan is awesome. His lectures / activities for the second half were always illuminating, and he clearly cared about everyone in the class. He was always open to questions, no matter how small. I think he was instrumental in setting the tone for the course, and creating a community among the seven of us that was both serious about the work we were doing and compassionate. His passion for astrophysics is infectious. Courseload: more than most freshman seminars. Heavy technical reading, psets every week, and a final paper you have to write while also completing psets.

course_title: The Evolutionary Transition From Dinosaurs To Birds: Fossils, Genomes and Behavior 001
best_comment: I would definitely recommend this course for anyone who is interested in birds, dinosaurs, evolution, or even just wants to learn more about science in a more relaxed environment! It was simultaneously really fun and fascinating and also helped expand my skills and knowledge regarding scientific processes. The field trips as well as the talks with paleontologists were all really immersive and helped me understand more about the topics we were learning about, the hands–on labs were really cool, and while the prep reading was a bit dense at times, it was all really fascinating!
worse_comment: This freshman seminar was not worth it. I took it since my first freshman seminar last semester was a wonderful class, but this seminar was not enjoyable in the slightest.The pros include the fact that the material itself is fascinating (although very poorly taught) and there are guest speakers and class visits that help with conceptualizing information and are good experiences.The cons are many. The course would benefit greatly if the professor actually taught and lectured regularly, and broke down the information as an instructor should. Professor Edwards neglects to understand that although many of the students in the course may have had experience with the material already, this is still a freshman seminar and there are people with varying degrees of familiarity and experience with the field. Furthermore, the class was dull and badly taught. Frankly, I don't even know why the professor was there. All the class consisted of for most of the weeks was reading several dense scientific papers without any prior contextualizing or introduction from the professor (the papers were generally interesting). Then, we would just spend much of the next class period spitting up the papers' information in completely student–led presentations, again without any feedback or guidance from the professor. The class was lazily structured and badly organized. The class would have been exactly the same if he was not there and we just read the papers on our own without coming to class. The professor barely lectured. He did so perhaps a handful of times over the semester, and even then the lectures were short and not comprehensive. They did not help in understanding or explaining the material. The assignments were useless and were basically just busy–work that wasted time. Most of them required software downloads that we never went back to after one use, so it's not even like the assignments helped with training us how to use the new software for future reference.I came into this class with an interest in evolutionary biology I was hoping to grow. I fortunately left with the same interest, but with a hesitancy to continue studying the field in any capacity while at Harvard.

best_comment: Take this class if you're interested in learning more about memory – both how it fails and how it works in general. You don't really need any background, though having an interest in psychology and understanding some basic concepts (say from AP Psychology) can enhance your experience. Professor Schacter is a great professor, and due to his many years of experience in the field of memory research he knows a LOT about the topic. The main book we read (The Seven Sins of Memory) is a book designed for popular reading, so it's enjoyable while presenting a lot of interesting psychological results. The two papers you write are pretty open–ended and a good opportunity to deep dive into a topic in memory you're interested in learning more about. Overall, a great freshman seminar!
Amazing class, highly recommend, meets lots of people, professor is amazing, not lots of work, interesting readings.

course_title: “How Did I Get Here?”—Appreciating “Normal” Child Development 001
best_comment: This class is super chill but also super interesting. Do the readings (it's for your own good). Dr. Prager is my favorite, truly so nice. Look forward to cookies, brownies, and fruits every class!

This class was definitely the highlight of my spring semester. How often do you get to take a class where all you do is listen / watch Broadway musicals and discuss their cultural impact? Not only was it a lot of fun, but I also felt that I took so much away from every single conversation and discussion that we held in class. Professor Oja is incredible; Getting to learn from her and hearing her perspective on some pretty significant moments in Broadway history was such a pleasure. There was also something so beautiful about having such a small, intimate class setting where everyone was able to share their thoughts and participate in meaningful conversations. Getting to learn about such historically significant productions in such an interactive format – watching clips, reading analyses, exploring interviews, and sometimes even getting to experience our own staging sessions – was an incredibly rewarding experience. If you have any interest in Broadway, musical theater, or just want to step out of your comfort zone and take a new class, I 100% recommend this seminar!

This is a great class. Prof Sandler is super lovely and so passionate about the topic. Make sure you spend a little more time on the readings than you think to really get the most out of the class The trip to the museum is so fun and Prof Sandler gets some really cool people to speak which is amazing. If you aren't too sure about poetry this class is for you***

Very good seminar to take! While the class's title implies a marketing class, the material actually spans a much broader range of business concepts that work as a great preliminary business seminar if you're interested in that kind of topic/field – especially since there's no other class really like it at Harvard. Professor Ofek is also great at facilitating class discussion and creating engaging cases to analyze. The readings are also all relatively short so you're not going to find this class a burden in your schedule at all, would def recommend!

Very good seminar class! If you are interested in economics or government, this is a wonderful course to take. Professor Hart is obviously an expert and is a great discussion facilitator, and the two–hour classes are always engaging and enjoyable. Discussions may involve either understanding applications of the theory behind, or (as expected) policy discussion regarding ideas either considered or implemented in the readings or in other countries (students are always welcome to and do share their own knowledge and opinions, which is a great way to expose oneself to new ideas). Both are very fun and especially policy discussion is a good way to increase one's breadth of ideas and learn from peers and the instructor.Course content includes basic theory in econ, as well as different applications. The readings involve many papers published in economics journals, which is a good introduction to the literature in the field; also, there are many relevant real–world scenarios or ideas (e.g., the coronavirus, applications of behavioral economics, etc.). Also, we read some of Professor Hart's works in the final class (due to finishing previous class's material), a very cool conclusion to the course!

course_title: Generating Biodiversity: Hands-On Research Experience in Speciation Biology 001
best_comment: If you like plants, like lab research, like looking at stuff under a microscope, and are interested in speciation, this course is perfect for you! The topic is admittedly really specific, but if you're like me and just really, really like cutting up plants and looking at pollen and that sort of thing, then you're going to have a good time. Extra bonus if you're taking ls1b after or alongside this course for premed or a concentration or whatever else, one of the topics in there is also on the same speciation biology you learn about in this freshman seminar, so you get a head start on learning that stuff too! Robin and Grace are awesome course leads, they make the class so much more fun and it's just overall a good time if you're into what this course is about. Also, be prepared for some long weekly uber rides to the Arboretum, the course is off–campus so it can take upwards of half an hour each way to get to and from the lab where the course is.

course_title: Science and Technology Primer for Future Leaders 001
best_comment: TAKE. THIS. SEMINAR. Professor Park is an AMAZING human being and is so so kind, thoughtful, and supportive. I looked so forward to our seminar each week and the insightful conversations with my classmates about really cool science!! If you want to engage with science and talk with your friends about new super cool innovations, this course is for you. If you simply want an intellectually exciting environment to pose random questions and get answers, this course is for you. I swear even though I had the most unrelated questions during our seminar, Professor Park was always happy to provide a reflective answer. This seminar is TOP NOTCH. You will LOVE it!!!

course_title: The Grail Quest of Marcel Proust 001
best_comment: This course was excellent. I feel truly sorry that this course will likely never be offered again because of the professor's retirement. This seminar is what comes to mind when I think about unique Harvard classes. Getting the opportunity to read Proust is amazing and Virginie understands the writing deeply and provides fascinating commentary. Since we can't read the whole work, the selected excerpts are well selected and feel coherent when looked at together. Reading about the the grail with Arthurian Knights was very interesting and the workload for reading was very manageable. The coolest part about this class is the moving classroom with each class in our quest being held in different locations. This is so cool. Taking this class guarantees breaking out of the Harvard bubble with fun class trips to Boston getting whisked around by curators behind the ropes of the city's best museums. I will be leaving this class with a lifetime of memories from seeing all the nooks and crannies of memorial hall to seeing Washington's Thomas Paine signed copy of Common sense at the Athaeneum. We also had a lovely time at the Fogg Museum and looking at Monet at the Museum of Fine Arts. The assignments for this class were fun and weren't overly time consuming. This course was an amazing exploration of liberal arts at Harvard and I hope it's offered again in the future.

course_title: Religion, Neuroscience, and the Human Mind 001
best_comment: Do not underestimate the amount of reading needed for the class. You'll be devoting a lot of time toward getting through the often 100 page readings, which are the entire basis of the seminars every week. What you get out of this class is truly what you can commit and put in.

course_title: Vegetal Humanities: Paying Attention to Plants in Contemporary Art and Culture 001
best_comment: This is a really interesting class, if and only if it is something you are genuinely interested in!

course_title: Happiness and Different Ways of Life 001
best_comment: Huge, huge fan. Really interesting material. Not bad of a workload at all – which is the point of the class. It is more about sharing your ideas rather than focusing on assignments. Def a gem

I'm very glad to have taken this freshman seminar. It was a great opportunity to become more well–versed in poetry, both as a creator and enjoyer. Our weekly assignments involved reading a dozen or so poems and posting prompted responses to them, with the occasional inclusion of translating poems in different languages or writing or own. It was not a heavy courseload, but easy to procrastinate until the end of the weekend. Overall, I'd recommend taking this seminar if you're in interested in reading and discussing poems of different cultures and genres.
worse_comment: This course is dense and does not do any poems we read justice. It is interesting for sure, but we never had any engaging discussions in class. We are also reading translated poems without know the original languages, which gives ways to so many misinterpretation and over–analysis of the translation. And we never got into translation theory. So it just felt very disrespectful toward the original poem and the author. I think I learned more about a similar set of poems in AP Lit in  high school

best_comment: I would tell future students to take the class! You will love the course materials and the assignments. Professor Johnson–King is an excellent, enthusiastic, and knowledgeable teacher, so you will definitely learn a lot, and learn well!
worse_comment: This is a must–take course. The readings will change your life because they are so applicable to every part of your life. The assignments are very reasonable. If you have never taken a philosophy class, you should 100% take this one. You will learn how to properly write a paper with step–by–step instructions. I could not recommend this class enough!

best_comment: If this taught by Prof Reinert, this is a must take. Easily the most engaging class I took all year, not only is the workload very manageable, but the content gets you thinking about the state/history of the world in a whole new way. Great, great class, high praise for Prof Reinert.

course_title: The Heart of Medicine: Patients & Physicians & Experience of Serious Illness in the Age of COVID-19 001
best_comment: The Heart of Medicine is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Harvard; it has helped me get to know a wonderful professor, a close group of intellectually interesting friends, and enjoy deep discussions about something meaningful to me. This is a special type of Harvard class that I think everyone should try to experience. Susan is one of the wisest and kindest human beings I have ever met. I am beyond grateful to get to know her at a personal level through this class and listen to all her deep meditations on the nature of death and suffering and what it takes to live a meaningful life. As a renowned palliative care doctor, Susan was able to bring in speakers who touched us deeply, spoke from personal experience, and left us with memories to think about. Finally, Susan brings really delicious chocolate cookies to every class, brings her golden retriever Dante to class sometimes, and invites us to her house for chats. I also want to thank you to all my classmates who are incredibly encouraging, courageous, thoughtful, challenging, and loving. The diversity in the class was able to Because this is a freshman seminar, and Susan said she passes everyone, we get to fully explore this deeply human topic without having to worry about doing anything purely for a good grade. This is a class to wrestle with some important questions on the good life and many existential musings that all of us yearn for to some degree. For example, we watched about 3 documentaries during the semester, and each time the class cried together and bonded through a shared emotion of sorrow, vulnerability, and empathy. The readings are interesting enough and the short writing assignments each week serve as a good reminder to jot down our thoughts.Overall The Heart of Medicine is an absolutely fantastic class, and I would highly recommend anyone interested in the topics of death, suffering, and meaning to apply, you will not regret it. Good luck!

course_title: Radical Actors: The Role of Public Education in American Social Movements 001
best_comment: this is a GREAT CLASS. Nicole is so helpful in connecting students with opportunities related to education and just in general. She's super receptive to student feedback with weekly exit tickets and really cares. the readings are worthwhile every time and super informative. the assignments are really helpful in the creation of the final project, and she's so great about finding times to meet and helping guide the process of the final project. Love love love love love. Recommend to anyone even remotely interested in activism or education.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I am a STEM person and I was not even particularly interested in the topic (I took the class mainly because of the good feedback and the low time commitment) but ended up REALLY REALLY enjoying what we did in the class! The professor made all lectures extremely interesting, fun, and very entertaining! I am also an international student, and this course introduced me to many interesting and important social phenomena, which people from the US tend to generally know about (or at least heard of), which was a very useful and interesting experience. The class is also, indeed, not much work and I really enjoyed the format of the two exams (midterm essay and oral final) – they were creative and not stressful.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. It absolutely sucks. Professor is an idiot who just wants you to hear him rant for 75 minutes and forces attendance because otherwise he knows nobody could put up with him and would still be able to learn all the material because its so god damn stupid.
best_gem_comment: The strength of this course is that its subject matter is very, very relevant to the current state of the world, and learning what the philosophers discussed in class say will only make you a more informed individual. Professor Robichaud is enthusiastic, though his energy somewhat dies halfway through the class, and his lectures then become class–wide Q–&–A sessions. Brian, the head TF, is a stickler, but he is approachable and knowledgeable. This is not the gem of a GenEd that many thought it would be (though it is certainly not extremely difficult), as the midterm and final projects are time–intensive, but the tradeoff is worth it.
subject: General Education

best_comment: I am so glad I took this course! This course did a great job of introducing us to a variety of philosophical traditions and ideas in a way that felt very accessible and applicable. I had never taken a philosophy course before, and I am glad this was my first! I felt that I was truly able to engage with a diverse set of ideas and think critically about my own views, both of which I found very engaging and fulfilling. Furthermore, I found myself discussing a lot of the topics we were covering frequently throughout the semester, which I think is a great sign that the ideas were interesting and important. The focus on the application also meant that I immediately started using some of the ideas from class in my daily life (usually without thinking about it first).The courseload was pretty manageable. Many small regular assignments (reading quizzes every class, weekly reflections) were added this year. I thought they were reasonable, and I actually found the reflections to be pretty interesting and useful to me in developing my personal opinions. (By the way, I felt like we were really encouraged to have our own opinions on the content and discuss what we did and didn't agree with in the readings, which I really appreciated.)I came into this class interested in learning, and like most classes, I think you will get out of it what you put into it. If you are interested in learning about the philosophy of happiness (from ancient to modern texts) and reflecting on your own personal philosophy and lifestyle then I would definitely recommend this course.
worse_comment: This class will make you jump through more hoops than a dog in a circus. The readings are quite long and there are way too many of them, but you have to do them because there is a graded quiz at the beginning of each lecture about the readings. However, all that Rinard does in lecture is talk through the readings, so there is basically no point in being there, but you have to because there's a chance she'll say something else important, and there are no resources or notes distributed, so if you miss it you'll just lose points on the exam. (The class also has two exams and two papers, which is somewhat ridiculous for a gened.) The papers are not too long, but the prompts are very dull, and they do this thing where they won't give good grades on your first submission, but then offer you a chance to rewrite the paper, so you essentially have to do each one twice. You also have to do a one page reflection piece every week, even when not very much material has been covered.In short, this class makes you do a ridiculous amount of work for a very small amount of learning.
best_gem_comment: I'd still recommend, but the course is slightly different than previous years that raved about it being a gem. They added quizzes every class to make sure you do the readings, and sometimes they are hard or obscure so that even if you did the reading you still get things wrong. Nevertheless, it is a good course! Exams are easy, and the only big assignments are 2 papers throughout the year. If you put the time into doing the readings and engaging in lecture discussions, you can also leave with some great ideas about Happiness and the purpose of life. While the course sounds like a little more work than previous years, I'd still call it a pseudo–gem and a great course to check off a GenEd requirement!

best_comment: Extremely informative course. One of my favorites I have ever taken. If you are interested in human evolution and human health, you should consider it.However, the grading is an understandable reason to not take the course. In this version of the class, the midterm/final make up I think 65% of your grade, which is kind of absurd, especially for a GenEd. The rest of your grade is determined by eight 10pt homework assignments for which the TFs nitpick and take points off very easily. It is common to get scores like 6/10, 7/10 on these assignments, of which there are, again, only eight. What else can you do to raise your grade? Nothing — except pray that the exams are not graded as harshly as the homework (they are). And no, there's no curve. The fact that the midterm was take–home helped a lot, but it still took me and many other students I spoke to about 6 hours.I took the class P/F which I highly recommend. It allowed me to enjoy the material and Professor Lieberman's incredible lectures. Basically if you want to take the course, it's a tradeoff — you will learn some awesome things from some super smart people, but there is a wacked out grading system in place that will cause you much unnecessary stress for no reason. Hopefully they take this feedback and modify the course, then I would say take it for sure!
worse_comment: This class is very interesting, but be aware that there is a lot of annoying, busy work in this class. It is not a gened where you can slack off. The midterm and final are difficult, and they grade quite harshly.
subject: General Education

best_comment: Extremely informative course. One of my favorites I have ever taken. If you are interested in human evolution and human health, you should consider it.However, the grading is an understandable reason to not take the course. In this version of the class, the midterm/final make up I think 65% of your grade, which is kind of absurd, especially for a GenEd. The rest of your grade is determined by eight 10pt homework assignments for which the TFs nitpick and take points off very easily. It is common to get scores like 6/10, 7/10 on these assignments, of which there are, again, only eight. What else can you do to raise your grade? Nothing — except pray that the exams are not graded as harshly as the homework (they are). And no, there's no curve. The fact that the midterm was take–home helped a lot, but it still took me and many other students I spoke to about 6 hours.I took the class P/F which I highly recommend. It allowed me to enjoy the material and Professor Lieberman's incredible lectures. Basically if you want to take the course, it's a tradeoff — you will learn some awesome things from some super smart people, but there is a wacked out grading system in place that will cause you much unnecessary stress for no reason. Hopefully they take this feedback and modify the course, then I would say take it for sure!
worse_comment: This class is very interesting, but be aware that there is a lot of annoying, busy work in this class. It is not a gened where you can slack off. The midterm and final are difficult, and they grade quite harshly.
subject: General Education

course_title: Work, Life and Purpose in an Uncertain World 001
best_comment: This class is amazing! Professor Hsieh is such a great conversation facilitator that time flew by every class. Professor Hsieh and my TF (Kaum) were so nice and approachable. Each week, we discuss a really interesting HBS case that pertains to finding a career, avoiding ethical pitfalls at work, and shaping the world of work for others. There is not much work but a really good opportunity to think deeply about what you value in your work and personal life. In addition, Professor Hsieh opts for real–life cases instead of dense philosophical readings, which I think is a positive. In the current form of the class, we didn't spend too much time explicitly mapping out our own career choices. So, definitely do not expect to have figured out your career by the end. Rather, the cases more liberally talk about the meaning of work in our own lives and others. I would say definitely take this course if you think a fair amount about your own career and want to experience a really engaging case study–styled course!
worse_comment: This is not a gem. I did not like this course. The midterm ruined it.
best_gem_comment: this is one of the best classes that I've taken at Harvard. truly a GEM. The teaching staff are great and even though this is a business school course that focuses on cases studies, Nien–he is such a great speaker and always ends class on a more philosophical note about priorities not just in business but in life.

best_comment: I was a premed taking this class. I was little anxious coming into the class (actually I was shaking in my boots), but I stuck with it and got an incredibly enriching experience in addition to free finger puppets. To future students, don’t be intimidated at all by the texts, the course is very doable if you put some earnest effort and time towards it. Lecture can be a little bit of a strange experience for those more accustomed to science/math lectures; Prof Damrosch speaks a lot and much of the substance is in his words and not the slides. That all being said the lectures themselves felt to go beyond the readings in a sense; you could succeed in the class just listening to them and not taking notes. The biggest help is actively trying to make connections between the texts you read. Before enrolling in this class, I’d recommend looking at the syllabus and bearing in mind the number of readings and discussion post assignments; I took this class with Chem27 and SCRB50 so at times the readings got a little in the way. The work load is fine; just schedule time for your readings and your discussion posts you’ll breeze through them.The TFs are all bangers; help them help you especially when it comes to your final projects and exam prep.If you’re a big STEM person, I’d recommend taking this class. As a big STEM person myself, this class opened my eyes to extremely important texts and topics. Seeing the comp lit folks and how that department operates. is also quite entertaining. By far the hardest part of the course was trying not to disintegrate when one of the TFs read a selection from the Mandragola aloud in class. I’d recommend taking the class just for that one moment.
worse_comment: DO NOT take this course if you can avoid it, the reading list and course description seem pretty interesting especially if you are into history/humanities, but it ended up taking time away from my thesis, being mentally exhausting and confusing, and being an uphill battle of understanding what's being asked of of you. You will need to provide HUHS urgent care notes from the same day for any abcense, even a headache, if you would like any understanding at all you've better have intense proof of illness,   there is no logic to some of the policies (for example you get attendance zeros that you can't make up if you switch into the course, the teaching staff will not budge on it, or you can be in class for the full hour–15 but if you didn't get the quiz code in the 30 seconds it was flashed on the screen on the dot at 3pm when class starts, you don't count at attended. If you can't remember tiny details from entire books you read previous weeks, you can fail the attendance quiz and not count, the midterm and final grades can end up being nasty surprises no matter how well you think you know an author you've read in many other Harvard classes. Many times they have denied students who are taking off their coat or sitting down, coming from another class, I mean clearly THERE, right to their face. Just 0 understanding. The work itself is not that hard, but the standards around it took up so much mental space this semester at the expense of my thesis, actual department classes on similar topics, and well being. It's the worst of the GENED system flaws for sure coupled with holier than thou teachers who are welcome to make changes, mistakes, etc.. but are hardline on everything with the students in return. They will actively keep information from you, no mater how many students explained they really wanted to attend the review session, they refused to zoom it, share any of the info given in it, and basically blamed you or not attending an outside of class session during reading week. It was extremely frustrating course and that it was a requirement makes it even more upsetting. Avoid if you can.

course_title: Res Publica: A History of Representative Government 001
best_comment: I highly suggest taking this Gen Ed if you're doing anything relating to social studies, Gov, etc. It's basically a primer in liberal political theory, and has the most essential readings for that field, which you may otherwise skip. The class is not difficult, and you get out of it what you put it – it is probably possible to get an A and do very little of the reading, but I'm serious – you're selling yourself short if you do that. Professor Carpenter is an excellent professor, and the teaching team (Daniel and Willie) are awesome TFs, very responsive and reasonable people with a deep knowledge of the subject. Probably the single best Gen Ed I ended up taking, and one of the best Gov courses I ended up taking (did I mention it gives you Gov credit???).
worse_comment: ** The course was very easy, not a lot of difficulty, but at times the boredom was the most difficult thing. You have  to decide what matters more to you.
best_gem_comment: If you feel estranged from American politics system but ill–equipped to criticize it or discuss fixes, take this class. You will learn about the origins of republican government and how it compared to other forms of government with examples such as Rome, medieval Europe, and the American founding.  You will read and discuss arguments from all sides of history. The class delivers on these promises and neither glosses over nor fully delves deeply into the histories of slavery and subjugation that parallel the development of "small–r" republican principles. If you are looking for a class that focuses mostly on the moral failings in the history of America or other successful republics instead of their properties, evolution, and impacts on one another, this is probably not it.As a STEM concentrator, it was extremely accessible to me and you get the benefit of being heard and remembered by the head of the department. That said, if you commit to doing all of the readings, it borders on un–gem–iness. Assignments are essays and an extremely manageable midterm. Great class.

course_title: Great Experiments that Changed Our World 001
best_comment: YOU SHOULD TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is so interesting, and you will have a wonderful time while learning a lot about the experiments that led to the ways we live our lives today. The teaching staff is wonderful––they are so sweet, interesting, and funny. If you are looking for a good Science GENED, I highly recommend this class. It has been one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Harvard.
best_gem_comment: This class is an absolute gem, take it if you can!  Max and Phil are great, and I looked forward to going to class each week (even the sections!)
subject: General Education

course_title: Higher Education: Students, Institutions, and Controversies 001
best_comment: Take this class! **Through use of class debates you will learn about so many new perspectives on the most pressing issues in higher education. Before this class I seriously doubted that Harvard students have the capability of engaging in constructive disagreement, but this course changed my mind! The teaching staff are incredibly supportive and just the most wholesome human beings ever <3 I have never encountered a professor at Harvard who would care so deeply about students as Manja. She remembers the small things about every students and really makes this class a truly transformative experience! LOVE LOVE LOVE for this class <3
best_gem_comment: Wow this class is amazing. Attendance is mandatory but very manageable in terms of workload. Just 3 small essays and you learn so much. Professor Manja Klemenčič is the best professor I've ever had at Harvard – she is so knowledgable, funny, kind and supportive and as a STEM concentrator I was a little afraid of taking such a humanities heavy class but the teaching team made it so manageable and interesting. Such an interesting GEM!

best_comment: Such a fun time, and one of my favorite courses of my first three years at Harvard. Professor Li was so passionate and knowledgeable, and I learned a lot about cinema as an art form, East Asian culture/history, and above all, and all of the filmmaking assignment options  were such wonderful creative outlets throughout the semester. People say it’s a lot of work for a GenEd, but it’s really not that bad and I think totally worth it. You have 6 assignments you have to complete over the course of the semester which you can do based on your own schedule, and can choose to write a written discussion post or make a short film inspired by the films we watched that week. The weekly movie screening obviously takes a bit of time to watch, but I absolutely loved the film selection for this class and saw a bunch of films that I would have never watched but are now some of my personal favorites. There was also such a wide range of different types of films, which kept each week feeling fresh. The 6–page midterm paper and the week 12 quiz were a little annoying, but overall were fairly quick and painless. Finally, Menglan was an awesome Section TF, and struck a perfect balance balance guiding the conversation and letting us speak freely about what we were most interested in. The teaching staff in general made such an effort to make the course fun, such as staying up several nights watching all of our final projects and putting together an Oscar–esque awards show during reading period. I know professor Li is going on sabbatical, but if she ever offers the course again, I would 1000% recommend you take it to fulfill your arts and aesthetics gened requirement.
worse_comment: A great class but also not super easy
best_gem_comment: This class is an amazing GENED. It's a great class if you want to try film without the anxiety of making it into a small AFVS class. You'll have a great time doing the creative projects, and once a week lecture is truly the best. A true gem.

best_comment: Good way to fulfill the Gened requirement and super nice staff. Prof is super passionate about the subject and makes you interested in it too

course_title: Moral Inquiry in the Novels of Tolstoy and Dostoevsky 001
best_comment: This is an incredible course! As you might expect, there is a lot of reading, but making the time to actively engage with these course materials really makes the course an enriching experience. Even if you fall behind on the readings, go to lecture and take notes so you know which passages to focus on. Professor Weir is a phenomenal lecturer–––he is clearly very knowledgeable in the field of Russian literature and he organizes his lectures in a way that he covers important aspects of the readings in a genuinely enthusiastic and eloquent way so that it never feels like he's just regurgitating information. He is very clear about his expectations for students, i.e., do the readings, but is also a super friendly guy who holds regular office hours and is genuinely happy to talk to students (he went out of his way to visit all the sections roughly twice throughout the semester). I'm sure the TFs change each year, but the TFs this year were also amazing teachers and amazing human beings.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. There is WAY TOO MUCH reading for no reason, and the teachers do not care to lighten your load.

best_comment: Prof. Goldie is a queen and likely will be the professor I will have learned under in college. She is extremely dedicated to her work as a teacher, though you shouldn't expect for her to pay much individual attention to you because she literally runs GHELI and several other Public Health efforts at Harvard. She's very distinguished but grounded and real in a way that most comparable teachers don't often act.Try to be intentional with the way you take this class. All of the content is really well prepared—Prof. Goldie has a huge course staff because of GHELI and they make everything perfect for students—and you're sure to learn a lot if you pay attention during lecture. That said, my favorite times were when I actually took creative initiative over things. Prof. Goldie and my TFs are super invested into the material and loved talking about these subjects rather than students who seemed like they were unenthusiastically dredging through the content.This was my favorite course of the semester. SO so much better than a typical gen–ed.
best_gem_comment: TAKE IT!!! SUPER MEGA CHILL GEM AND YOU WILL LEARN SO MUCH JUST BY LISTENING IN LECTURE. You do not have to prepare before class and there are no exams. Just 3 easy and actually engaging assignments. One short policy brief, another 4–5 page policy brief, and final project (which you could also just do another 5 page policy brief). You do not need any prior knowledge and the professor is sooooo good and knowledgeable and she will always fully prepare you for all assignments. The rubrics are super clear so you just have to make sure to touch every point and there is so much support if you ever want to talk through your ideas. I would always look forward to going to lecture and it was one of my favorite classes this semester because it did not require a lot of time but I was constantly learning and gaining knowledge about global health. Highly recommend to anyone who needs to satisfy GenEd requirement of GHHP requirement. Sections did feel unnecessary though.
subject: General Education

best_comment: I think this is a decent class *Before I start, if you’re an HDRB concentrator, TAKE THIS CLASS. Knock out both an HDRB and GENED requirement; why wouldn’t youFor lectures, readings aren’t necessary. I’d do them to complement studying if it helped, but other than that they are too time consuming. Also, professor Hyman does a great job of reviewing the KEY concepts (what you actually need to know, although he does go off on tangents many times). Something I didn’t expect is for there to be a lecture participation grade. You don’t need to actively raise your hand and speak. Just being present so that your TF sees you should be enough (that’s what I did and got an A in the class).For sections, I do recommend the readings. They’re the most important ones needed for 1) the debates in section and 2) the papers you will write. Also the debates are chill and section is helpful, so take advantage to ask questions about content (eg. personal identity, autonomy, consequentialism versus deontology, memory, etc.)The papers are well distributed. It’s 2–3 pages, then 3–4, then 3–4 again, and the final paper is 6–8, which is considerably better than the papers for other classes. SCHEDULE OFFICE HOURS WITH YOUR TF TO TALK ABOUT THE PAPER. HAVE AN OUTLINE. This made my grade increase from paper 2 to paper 3 considerably.The midterm is not bad if you payed attention in lecture and wrote down some ideas that professor Hyman mentions. It’s also only on the first 12 lectures or so, which is very manageable.  Remember the definitions given and you’ll be fine.
worse_comment: I found it ridiculous that this class knowingly had a midterm on housing day.. Why would you do that?!? You were aware of a school wide tradition that everyone participates in and still decided to place a midterm exam that is worth 1/5 of our grade on the same day. I think that is cruel and inconsiderate. The midterm could have very much been on the Tuesday before break or offered on an alternative time to accommodate for housing day. I understand that there is a lot of content to go over and there are time restraints, but I think there needs to be consideration of how these deadlines impact students.
