If the true purpose of the midterm is to make sure we are understanding content, you wouldn’t have placed this exam on a day that is very important to people. It can also be a very sad day for people if they get quaded. I am saying this as an upperclassmen that has already gone through housing day. That day was very stressful for me and having an exam on the same day would not help me at all. Also this class was so boring. The expectations for papers were so strange and I didn't hear of anyone getting good grades on papers. Overall I wish I hadn't taken this class.

best_comment: Overall, I would highly recommend this class to anyone who wants to expand their thinking and unlock their creative potential. The class was engaging, informative, and truly life–changing. I feel that I now have a better understanding of what it means to be creative and how to apply this mindset to all aspects of my life. Professor Atherton's lectures are not only informative, but truly engaging and entertaining (he has such a good sense of humor!). He has an extraordinary talent for presenting complex concepts in a clear and concise manner that is easy for students to understand. He took the time to get to know each and every one of us, and was always available to answer questions or provide feedback. He truly cares about his students' success and goes above and beyond to ensure that we have the tools we need to excel. His passion for his subject matter is infectious, and he has a unique ability to ignite that same passion in his students. He challenged us to think critically and to push ourselves to achieve our full potential.  You'll get as much out of this class as you put into it. Definitely take it if you get the chance!!
best_gem_comment: A GEM! Creativity is such a chill class.  It's also so wholesome, and you get to make a lot of new friends. Professor Atherton is EXCELLENT! He's very well–spoken, clearly passionate about the material, and so sweet.

best_comment: Take this class when it's next offered!!! It's really engaging but the assignments are looked at in terms of completion/effort. Thursdays were definitely long with both lecture and section combined but it was nice to eliminate the transportation time that a separate section would have led to. Karthik is an awesome lecturer who cares so deeply about the subject matter and is friends with so many of the artists that we had some awesome guest speakers.
worse_comment: While the course bills itself as a video art class, it is really not good at teaching you how to apply those skills and make videos/shorts yourself. Feedback was minimal to non–existent on each assignment. You will get to see a lot of interesting video art projects as a part of this and discuss some aspects of their film techniques, but some of them could get tedious fast. The readings were also mostly unengaging.Additionally, the course takes a heavy nosedive into critical theory discussion in the second half that mostly seems disconnected from the actual techniques of filmmaking, and falls into the standard traps of talking at the students of the political premises without really evaluating or challenging their assumptions. The lectures especially became tedious with discussing the ideas in the annoying way that made them seem unchallengeable, as well as increasingly jargon–ridden (you'll grow very sick of hearing the word "space/spaces" by the end). So many of the texts grew increasingly obtuse and overly didactic that they were not engaging to read for someone not as into those ideas to begin with.Also, the end of the class had this weird group reciting of a political treatise that seemed very propagandistic.

course_title: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments 001
best_comment: This might be the best class I have taken at Harvard. I concentrate in something completely unrelated to Buddhism or architecture, yet this class was so enlightening, formative and fun that I would recommend it to everyone. I went from knowing nothing about Buddhism to having a good grasp of its basic concepts and its imagery. The professors and TFs are wonderful and I always looked forward to the lectures and sections. We went to the Harvard Art Museums very often and examined Buddhist art from up close. The classroom atmosphere was great. We went on a very fun field trip to a pagoda in Western Massachusetts; it was one of the highlights of my semester. Take this class. It is not too much work and it is very rewarding.
subject: General Education

course_title: Permanent Impermanence: Why Buddhists Build Monuments 001
best_comment: This might be the best class I have taken at Harvard. I concentrate in something completely unrelated to Buddhism or architecture, yet this class was so enlightening, formative and fun that I would recommend it to everyone. I went from knowing nothing about Buddhism to having a good grasp of its basic concepts and its imagery. The professors and TFs are wonderful and I always looked forward to the lectures and sections. We went to the Harvard Art Museums very often and examined Buddhist art from up close. The classroom atmosphere was great. We went on a very fun field trip to a pagoda in Western Massachusetts; it was one of the highlights of my semester. Take this class. It is not too much work and it is very rewarding.
subject: General Education

best_comment: I know many students don't go to class, but the lecture contents are actually interesting! I learned a lot of strange facts such as humans and chimps are genetically more similar than chimps to gorillas. The papers are also interesting to write. You basically have the whole semester to write two papers, but the content in class is pretty useful. Do some other work during class and you'll still learn some interesting knowledge. I know some of my older friends really want to take this class because they are thinking of getting married and having children etc. Moreover, the professor also lets people out 15~30 minutes early.I would say I couldn't understand some of the questions we were supposed to discuss in sections. The sections weren't that useful. I got most of my knowledge from lectures.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS unless it is completely overhauled and no longer taught by David Haig. This class honestly ruined a lot of my senior spring and my interactions with David Haig personally were extremely upsetting, triggering, and scarring. I would not recommend people take any classes with him as a professor and I would strongly urge the university to investigate his teaching practices and interactions with students further. My experience with him is not unique to me, as I spoke with many other students who had similar experiences. If you have any sense of self–preservation, do not take this class
best_gem_comment: Take this class! Only 2 papers and the topics are given early. Very nice teaching staff that can work with you if you want it. Definitely, a gem.

course_title: What Is a Book? From the Clay Tablet to the Kindle 001
best_comment: Prof. Stern is great, and the field trips in this class are super cool. The course is manageable, fairly graded, and genuinely interesting. I think it's best taken as a freshman (you'll learn about a lot of cool places at Harvard!) or as a senior (you'll have the space, after thesis deadlines, to have some arts–and–crafts fun with the capstone project).
worse_comment: You'll have like 5 assignments a week, and scheduling is definitely a pain. Also, the lectures are so boring  that if it weren't for the mandatory attendance, I would have never gone.

best_comment: This is an amazing and fairly easy GENED that fulfills the Science & Technology in Society requirement! If you have any interest in weather/environmental science, or a fascination with any type of natural disaster, this course will be pretty enthralling, as it was for me. As a primarily arts and humanities person taking this course, I was able to follow it quite well with only a little confusion around some of the equations. My best piece of advice is to complete as much of the labs as you can during section time; it's so helpful to be able to ask a classmate or TF a question as you struggle through some of the technicalities of using GIS software. Brendan is a really great and amusing teacher who lectures in an engaging way and jokes around a lot. Overall, definitely recommend!
worse_comment: Grading scale sucks.  Way too hard to get an A
subject: General Education

course_title: Pyramid Schemes: What Can Ancient Egyptian Civilization Teach Us? 001
best_comment: The first few weeks of this class are a DRAG, but it gets better, and section is the best part because you get to go to museums and see artifacts you've been discussing in class in person!! Which is pretty cool. Prof Manuelian is very sweet but lectures tend to be REALLY dry at times. Readings were also dry for me. If you TRULY love history and Ancient Egypt, then you'll be able to take a lot from this class (Prof Manuelian is literally one of the best in the world in what he studies!!!).  Classwork is very very chill, so it definitely is a gem. All in all, the class is what you put into it.
worse_comment: My tf graded very fairly, but have heard mixed things across different tfs. Lectures are not very interesting, and feel like they have no direction – basically just a slideshow of different objects going by. The only highlight I felt were the museum visits – they were interesting, but not worth taking this course for. The readings are a slog to get through. The final assignment and final exam together is not a fun combo. Generally, the course is not too hard, but it is just kind of a pain to get through and not very interesting.
best_gem_comment: The first few weeks of this class are a DRAG, but it gets better, and section is the best part because you get to go to museums and see artifacts you've been discussing in class in person!! Which is pretty cool. Prof Manuelian is very sweet but lectures tend to be REALLY dry at times. Readings were also dry for me. If you TRULY love history and Ancient Egypt, then you'll be able to take a lot from this class (Prof Manuelian is literally one of the best in the world in what he studies!!!).  Classwork is very very chill, so it definitely is a gem. All in all, the class is what you put into it.

course_title: Classical Mythology: Myth in Antiquity and Today 001
best_comment: This class is great, a total GEM and super awesome, interesting and everyone should take it. I am not a morning person and it was worth taking it as a 9am, I liked it so much I actually went and didn't even miss more than like 1 class. Professor Love is awesome and super engaging too.
worse_comment: Prepare to be bored out of your mind and constantly threatened with failing the class if you bomb a single one of the quizzes. I did the math and you can theoretically fail the class with a 93.75% raw score. So incredibly asinine.
best_gem_comment: This class is great, a total GEM and super awesome, interesting and everyone should take it. I am not a morning person and it was worth taking it as a 9am, I liked it so much I actually went and didn't even miss more than like 1 class. Professor Love is awesome and super engaging too.
subject: General Education

course_title: Prediction: The Past and Present of the Future 001
best_comment: This is a nice class to explore prediction, but you get out of it what you put into it. Lots of it is self guided, where you can choose topics to explore that interest you, which was a positive. The professor is also great and passionate about what she teaches.
best_gem_comment: This class is such a gem, especially if you have a nice TF. It's a great class to take with friends since you'll spend an hour at a time discussing things with your table or doing group activities. If you're looking to challenge yourself just know that the only challenge of this class is staying at all engaged during the 2.5 hour classes once a week.
subject: General Education

best_comment: This GenEd is truly one of a kind. I have never taken a class like this before. The professor genuinely cares not only about the class but for you as an individual. She does an amazing job at moving away from the classic lecture format and does a great job at really drawing the class in, asking for your opinions, and inviting you into the lecture. Sure, sometimes the readings may not be your favorite, but the way in which Bernstein talks about them will truly engage you and intrigue you. She really does have a way with words and easily made this class one of my favorites this semester. The work is definitely manageable and in turn helps you with engaging with your peers because of the amount of discussion you'll often have in this course. Please do to take this course!!
worse_comment: This course was not accessible for students. No lecture slides or notes were ever posted. The prompts for the essays were also given on physical pieces of paper and not posted anywhere. No typed notes are allowed. As a student that suffered with serious mental health concerns this semester, this course did not provide me with the support that I needed in order to achieve. If you missed class, you were instructed to contact your TF for the information, however, no responses were ever given. If you are going to hire TFs more concerned with their own graduate school work and who cannot be bothered to answer emails at all or in a timely fashion, you need to make the lecture slides and notes accessible.
subject: General Education

course_title: Human Trafficking, Slavery and Abolition in the Modern World 001
best_comment: There are aspects of this course that you may really dislike, and some that you may love, but this all depends on how engaged you are with the class. One thing that I think frustrated everybody, whether or not they attended lecture, was just the severe disorganization of the course, especially in the beginning. I think this partly wasn't their fault, as 3–4x times the number of people in previous years enrolled this time around, so the teaching staff wasn't prepared and hadn't hired enough TFs to have enough sections for all those students. Because of this, section started quite late in the semester, but honestly I wasn't complaining. Another point of disorganization came when it was time for the midterm. The head TF said the midterm would be posted/available at a certain date, and it wasn't. He made promises over email several times about when the grades of the midterm would be released, and failed every single one of those promises. Aside from all this, I really liked the rest of the course. It was really eye–opening in terms of recognizing the large amount of human trafficking that happens in every–day life. I also really liked how the final paper (if you're not doing an engaged section) is pretty much self–directed, because it leaves a lot of creative direction to write about something you really care about. Once section started, I really liked it, especially since my TF made sure to reemphasize important notes from lecture and had us often debate or take certain sides of an issue, to help prepare us for the argumentative nature of the exams. There were usually only 3 people participating in these rather large sections, and that's because a majority of people didn't go to lecture. Over 400 people enrolled in this class and less than 40 would show up to lecture on a regular basis. Many people treated this class like the easy 4th or 5th class they didn't have to pay attention to, and started regretting it towards the end when the grade on our 1 midterm was a bit low and they didn't participate in section. Overall, just make sure to take notes at every lecture (keep a running document or something similar), participate in section, and go over the weekly study questions in the syllabus to help prepare for exams.
worse_comment: Overall, would not recommend this course to anyone. This course has potential but very poor execution by teaching staff. My sections were very poorly planned: most of the time, we just kept discussing the same thing over the semester. For many sections, it was obvious that my TF had not put thought into what the section was about and would allocate 20 minutes for us to just sit in silence and "do the readings." TF would also just not respond to emails. Midterm grades were not handed out until a month later, and everyone got very generic comments. It was very obvious that the head TF who graded mine did not read my response, because he copy and pasted comments that were not even applicable to my midterm — the same thing happened to many others in my section. The second half of the class was planned extremely poorly: we had a final essay due and then a final exam the next day. The explanation we received for the delay in midterm grading was that there was not enough teaching support. Given that, I thought it was ridiculous that we had a final essay and a final exam — how many people are actually going to get their papers read and graded fairly? It's laughable that we are having our labor exploited in a class about labor exploitation. Overall, one of the worst classes I've taken at Harvard. I cannot believe the Gen–ed office allows this class to continue to exist.
best_gem_comment: You get what you put into the course. Professor Patterson is not a great lecturer, he usually reads off the slides and you can barely hear what he is saying. He also does not share the slides, but the class is recorded. As the semester goes on, you see less and less people in the lecture hall and to be honest,  going to lecture is not really necessary if you have a good section component. Unless you are passionate about the topic, I suggest looking into another course. If you are looking for a gem, this is definitely it. My section (fortunately) was great, the conversations, topics and discussions helped cover and summarize what was said in class. Looking back at this class, it helped me have a breathing room from harder courses but I would have liked to maybe try another class instead. Take this with a grain of salt, try it out and if you don’t like it, take another course. Again, you get what you put in.
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Histories, Societies, Individuals

best_comment: I loved this class. I study biology and was a little concerned about writing philosophical essays going in, but if you're alright at writing and take your time, you'll do fine. I really enjoyed the stepwise decreasing structure of the essays (you get more flexibility/freedom with each essay) and how you were allowed to explore topics that you enjoyed. It wasn't too much work except on essay/exam times. Professor Risse's lectures are awesome; he's so smart, such an expert, and a sweetie. He says something slightly life–changing every class. I loved this class.
worse_comment: I came into it as a leftist from a low–income household and it kind of just reinforced the pessimism I have about social mobility. Not that any of this is inaccurate, just confirming my low station in society

course_title: Islam and Politics in the Modern Middle East 001
best_comment: Take this class! Professor Zeghal is lovely, and her lectures are easy to follow and super fascinating, especially if you're interested in the content of the class. The readings can be dense, but section is a great chance to clarify any questions you have from readings/lecture, and the TFs are super nice. Outside of readings, the only work is really weekly quizzes, which help you stay on top of content from lecture but aren't challenging at all, a quiz–style exam on the last day of class, and final paper which you're given loads of time to do. This class is really the perfect GENED –– it's super engaging and I learned a lot, but also not too demanding of your time!

SO GOOD! This class was amazing –– the content was super interesting (I discovered a hidden love for neuroscience and artificial intelligence as an economics/government interested student!), the work was VERY reasonable (just four problem sets this semester, open note midterm, and final paper which was very flexible), and the teaching staff (especially my teaching fellow Leannah) was AMAZING! The workload is extremely manageable and you might just find a new interest. There is no need for previous knowledge on the topic and you're bound to find something you love about it!
worse_comment: DO NOT take this class. It was the worst one I have taken at harvard. The lectures are extremely boring, the Psets are confusing, and the midterm was bad for most people I talked to. If you have to take it, take it pass fail. The grading makes no sense and the TFs also have no clue what is going on.
best_gem_comment: Do not get scared by the some reviews, trust me. this class is easy; for sure a gem.  You don't have to listen hard in lecture or do any of the readings; its 0 stress.  The psets (every like 3 weeks or so) are extremely short and you can find all the answers to get 100% using a quick search of the lecture slides.  People will complain about the exam, but if they did badly then honestly they probably deserved it. It was an entirely open–note exam; if you just study for like 2 hours the night before and put the lecture files in a pdf beforehand, then  (even if you don't listen at all the whole semester) you can get 95+ easily.  Not sure what some of the complaining students were expecting.  This is a 0–stress gened, with easily less than 2 hours of work per week, with a passionate professor, where you can still actually learn a lot about an interesting subject if you want to .
subject: General Education

course_title: Is the U.S. Civil War Still Being Fought? 001
best_comment: Take this course it is absolutely amazing!  Professor Stauffer's lectures are very engaging and the reading list for the class is excellent.  Section for the class was also a great time for discussion and if you have any interest in the U.S. Civil War this class is a must take.  The assignments for this class are extremely manageable and allow you to work on topics that you are interested in.  There is a final project/paper at the end but you have a lot of freedom in completing it and do not let the assignments deter you from taking this course at all.  I can truly say this was one of my favorite courses and you will learn a lot if you take the course and engage with the material.
worse_comment: this is a pretty good class, but some things can be improved. the slides are long and boring. although prof. stauffer occasionally brings in different artifacts and old books, the lectures are still long and boring. black and white slides with a lot of content on each, rarely pictures. additionally, i think the title of the course should be changed. when i saw the title, "Is the U.S. Civil War Still Being Fought?" i thought it would be a course on current events and how they could link back to the civil war. i could not have been more wrong. the entire class is focused on things that happened near the civil war. we rarely talked about current events, which is surprising considering the name. it isnt a gem, but it is not that difficult. come to section prepared on the readings.

course_title: Understanding Islam and Contemporary Muslim Societies 001
best_comment: Amazing class! Definitely some busy work with the weekly lecture reviews and section responses, which takes up time, but the content is super important and interesting. Professor Asani is so sweet and his lectures are really engaging. Adnan is the best TF I have had at Harvard!!
worse_comment: The course has a lot of work involved, and the grading is not transparent or consistent which makes it a more stressful course than it needs to be.
best_gem_comment: Any Dr. Asani class is worth taking! This one in particular is incredible because it will fundamentally inform your view of religion, the world, and people. Learning the cultural studies approach genuinely changed my life. This class does not just inform you about Islam but it shapes the way you think critically about the things around you. I promise you this is a gem if you buy into the experience. You don't need to do all of the readings... I know they look lengthy for a gen ed, but it's really not that bad. Trust me, you can get by just doing the prioritized readings and watching the pre–recorded lectures carefully. TAKE THIS CLASS IF U CAN!

course_title: The Challenge of Human Induced Climate Change: Transitioning to a Post Fossil Fuel Future 001
best_comment: This class is highly rewarding and Prof. McElroy is awesome!  Definitely sit down and talk with him about any areas of interest, and really take advantage of the final paper/presentation as an opportunity to explore something you're passionate about.
worse_comment: Take this course if you're interested in renewable energy, but know that it gets somewhat repetitive and boring after the first month or so.
subject: General Education

best_comment: This course is SO EXCELLENTLY PUT TOGETHER!!! YOU MUST TAKE IT! Professor McLaughlin is not only a wonderful lecturer and educator, but is extremely helpful, witty, and puts a lot of energy into her lectures. You will walk away from this class with some really solid skills in terms of managing stress and I genuinely feel like this course has changed my perspective on stress for the better. You would benefit from for sure being engaged during lecture (it’s the least you can do given that there’s so little to do for this course overall). The teaching staff provides really helpful rubrics for all assignments that makes it extremely clear what you’re being graded on and what you should include. Overall, I would HIGHLY recommend this class!!!!!
worse_comment: Absolutely loved the section component of this course. Every week, we met on the 10th floor of William James Hall, and talked about various things––from feelings to strategies to just the little inconveniences in our week––as we watched the sun set over the Boston skyline. I don't know, it's cheesy, but genuinely an hour of my week I always looked forward to. Also, as someone who has been skeptical of various stress response strategies in the past, I was proven wrong. There is a lot of incentive to give these strategies a try (bonus points if you do enough of them), and some of them worked. It helped me get through the semester.
best_gem_comment: This course is great! Not as much of a gem as it used to be, but super interesting and helpful for everyday life.

best_comment: If you have any interest in linguistic anthropology, this is a great course to take. The content we learned in the course felt equal parts anthropology and equal parts linguistics. The course did feel lopsided at times with significant time being dedicated to the professor’s own anthropological work. While his work was fascinating on its own, other parts of the course suffered in terms of the depth of study and analysis. Professor Caton, though he is retiring, was a captivating lecturer who was always trying to engage the class.This course is  writing focused with weekly short responses, multiple fieldnotes, one midterm essay and one final essay. As someone that enjoys writing, I did not find it a bother but I understand some of my peers did not feel as equally. I think I also enjoyed writing in the class more because the requirements were very loose. Sections in this course felt absolutely useless and significant improvements could have been made. If it was not for the mandatory attendance requirement (which was not always enforced), I would not have attended the sections. Overall, it was an interesting course but I felt like there may have been other options in my GENED category that may have been better taught. I did find an interest in linguistic anthropology and the direct exposure to the subject matter in the course provided me with plenty of insight on my own academic and personal interests.
worse_comment: You are going to learn about a wide range of topics. The course is very inclusive of other cultures. Lectures did drag from time to time. ***

course_title: Mexico and the Making of Global Cuisine 001
best_comment: This course can be slow at times, but if you are looking for a low commitment niche gened and you're interested in food then it's a super great choice!
worse_comment: It was not a super hard class but could at times be more work. Class was not particularly interesting. At the end felt like some of the grading was super all over the place and didn’t make a bunch of sense. Overall good class but don’t expect to be learn a bunch
best_gem_comment: take this class! it's a gem and the prof is really nice and accommodating. You can pretty much skim the readings and should be fine, but make sure you focus in lecture because you'll be quizzed mostly on what you learned in lecture
subject: General Education

best_comment: this class is actually one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard; I absolutely loved it and would rave about it + its readings/movies every week to my friends. I highly, highly recommend. Lunbeck is actually the sweetest, most genuine, funny, caring, wise professors I've had the privilege to get to know at Harvard, and I plan on taking all of her classes with the little time I have left at this institution. She's one of the few professors that actually actively cares about her students; and I am so so SO glad I was able to take this course this year. you will not regret this!! every reading + every movie is so great, this course is actually so well designed its insane. LOVE LOVE LOVE!!
worse_comment: You should take this class no matter what your lived experience or understanding of poverty is! Especially if have never experienced poverty, you will be exposed to a lot of eye–opening knowledge.
best_gem_comment: Take this course!! This was my favorite class this semester –– the lectures are so interesting (Professor Lunbeck is a great lecturer!) and the papers are short and actually fun to do. Section discussions are engaging and fun and I looked forward to them. The ratio of learning and enjoyment to work in this class is amazing and I would probably call it a gem. The instructors and teaching staff are also so kind and understanding and overall this class is just a pleasure to be in! Definitely take if you are at all interested in psych!
subject: General Education

best_comment: By and large I thought this was a fine course, but I don't know if I'd ever recommend it (there are so many great courses to take!).Things I liked: a course like this encourages you to read a lot, which is really wonderful. The writing assignments are also smaller and often somewhat creative, which gives you a lot of room for inventiveness and experimentation. The TFs put in loads of effort to give feedback to all of these assignments. The un–grading model is actually great in my opinion and really provides a constructive experience without adding needless stressors and punishments.Things I didn't always like: the books :( ... Sarraute was incredible, Gary very entertaining, Louis and Guibert quite readable – but most of the rest inspired indifference at best. As far as I can tell, Professor Kim had two main goals in her text selection: first, to advance an anti–identitarian argument; second, to shock you with gratuitous content. The former is perfectly fine but should be noted to attune your expectations – themes of identity and associated issues of social justice are the focus of almost all discussion. The latter goal is where I more particularly object – Professor Kim makes fine arguments that we should attend less to our shock and avoid discounting texts just for covering unpleasant material; however, she does not always compellingly prove that these particular texts are worthy of this effort. For instance, just because French critics were wrong to attack Darrieussecq's All the Way for its swearing and graphic sex (notably of the underage protagonist and her crusty adult babysitter) doesn't mean it is immune to being bad for other reasons – like its oddly TERF–y tone – and certainly doesn't prove that it is good.
worse_comment: This is the horniest course offered at Harvard and not in a fun way.
best_gem_comment: Take this class no matter your background (STEM, humanities, etc.) if you are ready to put the work in and do the readings. Be warned that they can be dense and heavy (about war, incest, pedophilia – check the syllabus). If you are ready to do the readings you'll get a ton out of this gened; Prof. Kim's lectures are super impressive and I enjoyed section as well. How much you get out though is very much up to you. It can be a gem if you want it to be due to the grading system.
subject: General Education

best_comment: German is a beautiful language. The 10a and 10b series are a fun introduction into studying German, and especially if you have Herr Neusser, your class will be a lot of fun even though it's at 9 am. If possible, try to practice speaking as much as possible with people outside of class, as part of the final assessment is a speaking conversation and skit.
worse_comment: german grammar is difficult for native english speakers i think
subject: German

best_comment: This is a fantastic beginners language requirement if you're looking to learn a cool language that's not crazy difficult but also not just way too easy. It's a great class and not too much at 4x a week with an hour long class, and I really enjoyed it. Teacher (Therese) was fantastic.
worse_comment: If you haven't studied German then it will be hard initially. The class is very fast–paced but Therese is very helpful if you are falling behind/struggling. It is a lot of assignments/quizzes/tests (every 2 weeks is quiz or test), which is stressful
subject: German

best_comment: I would definitely recommend taking this class. The German department is awesome, the teaching staff are super helpful and are easily accessible. The course moves pretty quickly, especially if you have absolutely no experience, but as long as you're on top of it all then it is very manageable. The assignments and homework is tedious at times as you have to do it every day but the quizzes are a lot easier than you expect them to be. The classes are really fun and interactive because you are just talking most of the time so the hour goes by really fast!
worse_comment: I think the experience in German heavily depends on your section leader. Overall, I didn't find it to be a terribly difficult class, but consistency in doing homework every day and participating in class is KEY.
subject: German

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! The instructors are super supportive and kind and the materials are super interesting and engaging!! Would highly recommend both the class and the department!
subject: German

best_comment: Bastian is amazing and the content is super engaging. Definitely take this class!
subject: German

course_title: Advanced Conversation and Composition: Berlin Stories 1
best_comment: I would definitely recommend this class! It was never too stressful and Frau Parkes is wonderful. There is also tons of useful vocabulary to learn through this class, as well as more advanced grammatical constructs.
subject: German

course_title: Introduction to German Literature, History, and Thought 1
best_comment: YOU MUST TAKE A CLASS WITH PROFESSOR HAMILTON IN YOUR TIME HERE!!! As for this class specifically, Professor Hamilton created such a great syllabus – with a broad enough overview of German literature so as to give breadth, but also focused enough to make you feel like you were taking concrete ideas/ themes out of the class. He is an engaging and witty lecturer, and the 2 hours passed by in no time. He is also super kind, and that will come through in office hours and even during the lecture itself. The work was just a few (very, very short) papers and the reading  assignments were minimal. Professor Hamilton also knows so, so much, and fills every second of the two hours with insight. I think this was one of my favorite classes I've ever taken in my college career –– learned SO much, minimal stress, engaging lectures. I've heard this is true of all his classes.

Professor Koerner is a great storyteller. The 3 hour class passed by so quickly because the class was engaged throughout the class period. I enjoyed the eclectic readings because they all had a unique way in which they tied together different themes.

course_title: Artificial Intelligences: Body, Art, and Technology in Modern Germany 1
best_comment: This course is absolutely incredible––one of my favorites I have ever taken at Harvard. We explored so many forms of art: photography, painting, film, dance, performance art, theater, literature. Class was always engaging and welcoming and low–stress (just a group of people excitedly and happily talking about art!). I looked forward to class every time. We also took multiple trips to the Harvard Art Museums storage facility to view specific works in person, which was definitely a highlight of the class! Professor Stewart is one of the only professors who has genuinely blown my mind with his spontaneous analysis of the readings and art we looked at in class (I hope I can analyze stuff like that one day). He is also a very compassionate, caring, and understanding person. One day, before we watched a film for class, he got us all lunch and we just chatted for awhile about how we were all doing. I would take this class again if I could, and I highly recommend it (and any other class with Professor Stewart). He is a good human.

course_title: Post-War Confessions: Albert Camus and Günter Grass 1
best_comment: This class is AMAZING! The Tin Drum is an incredible novel which would usually be tough for non–German–speaking readers to properly appreciate, but this class makes it accessible, and The Fall has powerful, meaningful messages. More than all  that, however, take this course because of Professor Hamilton –– he is an unbelievable lecturer, one whose class discussions always seem to span various themes, disciplines, and moral quandries in an immensely satisfying way. There are very few classes after which I have felt genuine appreciation and gratitude for the amazing faculty members available to us at Harvard –– this is one of them. If you get the opportunity to take this course, you should do so and feel fortunate.

course_title: One Hundred Years of Scandinavian Cinema 1
best_comment: GREAT CLASS IF YOU'RE A CINEPHILE! You will watch absolutely amazing films and have a chance to discuss them! Beware that most of them are super super dark, so not for faint–hearted, but otherwise an amazing class! Thoroughly enjoyed it! Agnes is such a fun person too!
subject: Scandinavian

best_comment: Take this class! Agnes is so lovely and the class is fun, I love starting my day with it each morning. I think it was everyones favourite class because it's such a small group and time flies like no other class I've taken. It's also a casual setting so there's space for fun questions about Sweden and a bit of casual chitchat among all the learning.
subject: Swedish

course_title: The Quality of Health Care in America 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class. The teaching staff is incredible, the lectures are fun and engaging but you will also learn so much. this class provides a really unique opportunity to learn about health care, health care quality, and health policy that is otherwise hard to find at the undergrad level. Bapu is a wonderful lecturer and is also kind, easygoing, and cares a lot about students. always looked forward to go to class and couldn't recommend it more!
worse_comment: Highly recommend this class!! You learn a lot about a lot of different topics through hearing from experts in the field; I had never known I would get to learn about machine learning in healthcare or talk about malpractice lawsuits; I think this class gives you a more realistic view of the current medical field and the problems it's facing.

course_title: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises 001
best_comment: Courses like GHHP 70 are the reason why Harvard is the best university in the world. Dr. Kayden and Dr. VanRooyen are quite literally the best of the best in the humanitarian industry and it still baffles me that they take time out of their very busy schedules (just running emergency medicine departments at MGH & BWH!) to teach undergrads. And they always manage to still come in enthusiastic and ready to really work with students. I feel beyond grateful to have been able to learn from them, and if you can get the opportunity, regardless of whether you are premed, gov, global health policy, interested in humanitarian work, or not, you should absolutely take it. If that is not enough to convince you, the topics in this course are so vital for every student to know/understand. Millions around the world die every year and even more are displaced from their homes in crises like the ones we discuss in this course and everyone can have a hand in helping these people. This class will rekindle your fire to do something good with what you have learned at Harvard, and as a graduating senior this was especially true.
worse_comment: ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS CLASS. I learned so much while also never feeling too much pressure with my assignments.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy

course_title: Global Response to Disasters and Refugee Crises 001
best_comment: Courses like GHHP 70 are the reason why Harvard is the best university in the world. Dr. Kayden and Dr. VanRooyen are quite literally the best of the best in the humanitarian industry and it still baffles me that they take time out of their very busy schedules (just running emergency medicine departments at MGH & BWH!) to teach undergrads. And they always manage to still come in enthusiastic and ready to really work with students. I feel beyond grateful to have been able to learn from them, and if you can get the opportunity, regardless of whether you are premed, gov, global health policy, interested in humanitarian work, or not, you should absolutely take it. worse_comment: ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS CLASS. I learned so much while also never feeling too much pressure with my assignments.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 001
best_comment: This course is fine... definitely should not be taken senior spring – I wish it was offered sophomore year. But, its not hard. They hold your hand throughout the whole paper and it is something you just have to do for the secondary. Also, it is nice that you get to write about anything you want
worse_comment: The course isn't built to help you write your final paper in the last weeks of class. It's relatively rigorous in the first half, but if you don't plan ahead for putting the final together, you'll be disadvantaged.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy

course_title: Research in Global Health and Health Policy 002
best_comment: you will definitely have to put in some work into this course, but if you find a topic you are excited about, it is a great class. the assignments throughout the semester help you and prompt you to complete parts of research and writing so that by the time you write the final paper, you already have a large portion of the info/research you need! it's a cool opportunity to pursue a topic in–depth whether you are writing a senior thesis in another field or not.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy

best_comment: Gov 10 is a great class for anyone wanting to learn more about political theory, gov concentrator or not! The class is very interactive, beginner friendly, and encourages you to think for yourself and connect concepts rather than memorizing them. The readings consist largely of primary sources and old texts, which is fascinating but takes a while to get through – I would definitely consider this a reading heavy course. The midterm and final are strenuous, but not unreasonable, and are ultimately fun essays to write if you're interested in the topics.  Compared to other classes, I would say that it's a little difficult to know where you stand grade wise in this class until the very end. However, nothing was hard for the sake of being hard and I feel like all evaluations were very fair. I would recommend this course for anyone wanting to think philosophically or sharpen their writing skills!
subject: Government

best_comment: Take this class. Prof. Chaudoin is great and the content is equally amazing. International Relations is an interesting field that gives you a more mature and academic view of global interactions. You get to learn and understand why countries go to war, why they trade with each other, how they negotiate, and so much more. Although I took this class for concentration credit, I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is exploring and looking to learn something very useful and interesting. The workload is very manageable too since  this class has an unusual way of assigning homework that helps students a lot. The homework is usually spaced out (2–3 weeks apart) and it is short (around 2 pages), despite the conciseness, the homework is usually fun to do and it teaches a lot, same thing with the readings. Overall, this is a favorite class that is so interesting that you don't see time passing. The homework is short and well thought–out, and the professor and TF are fun and very helpful.
worse_comment: I think if students are looking for a deep dive into "international conflict and cooperation," this isn't necessarily the right class for you. It combines simple econ theories with politics and then has you apply them to some real–world events, but basically in class we talk about theories like game theory and prisoner's dilemma instead of different international conflicts around the world and the motivations behind them. Because of this very simplified way of thinking about politics, all the assignments in the class become a checklist of what you need to say, instead of really being able to apply the concepts in complex ways. I wouldn't recommend this class if you're looking for a deeper dive into the actual history and complexity behind international conflicts, but only if you want to learn about how some intro econ models apply to politics. Also, the two lectures of class were easily simplified into a few slides in section. I think the content of the course isn't enough to be a course and so it really tries to stretch at times and ends up being somewhat dull/easy to zone out in. Overall, I think the way the class was set up detracted from the actual learning of the student (focuses very harshly on minute and I would say sometimes irrelevant details), so I wouldn't recommend this class if you want a comprehensive learning experience about international conflict and cooperation.
subject: Government

best_comment: Take this course!!!! Professor Naija is such an amazing teacher, and she really really cares about her students! She is truly one of the best professors I've had at Harvard and is so welcoming and approachable! You will lean so much from this class! The beginning is definitely more difficult because it covers the most important statistical concepts, but they provide a lot of support to make sure students understand it well. The class has three PSETs, which are all very manageable. The final project was so much fun and I loved working with my group! Truly an amazing class! You will not regret taking it!

course_title: Research Design, Qualitative, and Mixed Methods 001
best_comment: If you want to write a thesis, definitely take this course. It will help you develop the starting components of a thesis and the build–up to writing a full prospectus is very gradual which is nice because you do not do it all at once. The TFs are absolutely amazing. They are super supportive and actually give great feedback on what you are working on, but also gives advice on who else to talk to when needed. Section can be a bit boring but the workshopping parts of it are great because you also get student feedback on what you have worked on so far. Lecture is also very boring. It is super long, and then just when you think you are done, there is an in–class activtiy with groups. But the information is very helpful because Professor Hagopian is very thorough. Either way, still take this class because the assignments you do through out the semester are just super useful!!
worse_comment: If you are writing a (qualitative methods) thesis in Gov, take this course.I highly recommended that you spend winter break figuring out what you want to write your thesis about. This course provides very little time for you to think about this most fundamental question.  It is very much designed for students who already have a topic of interest, if not a precise question to research.What is unfortunate about this course is that, depending on your research topic, half the lectures and readings will be COMPLETELY useless. Not doing interviews? Too bad! You will have to sit through an hour–long human subjects training presentation and a lecture on interviews (lectures are more than 2 hours!).The capstone of the course is the prospectus, which will provide you with a great starting point for your thesis writing journey.
subject: Government

course_title: #AbolishPolice: The Politics of Public Safety in the Age of Social Media 001
best_comment: This is one of the finest classes I have enrolled in at Harvard.The greatest strength of Gov 94BF was its instructor: Jennifer Halen is one of the best professors I have interacted with at this school (and trust me: I have met a lot of them). Few members of our university's faculty are able to simultaneously provide students with meaningful support and share important lessons of great significance. Through her ability to provide valuable advice to students, dedicate considerable time to office hour meetings, facilitate important discussions in the classroom,  and more, Professor Halen is a one–of–a–kind. Harvard is very lucky to have her in its ranks.Another strength of the class was its TF, Tabitha Escalante. Tabitha was very helpful at replying to students' questions expeditiously, and she was effective at providing thorough feedback. I also appreciated the course materials: as an individual with little exposure to literature on policing, abolition, and the American prison system, I felt like I learned a lot through the readings listed on the syllabus as well as the classroom conversations we had about them.In short, take this class!
subject: Government

best_comment: Great class with very interesting readings. Having some data science/coding background will help tremendously. Prof. Kelly is great!

course_title: The Authoritarian Turn in Central and Eastern Europe: What Can Be Done About It? 001
best_comment: It's an interesting seminar about democratic backsliding in Eastern and Central Europe that is focused on finding solutions and strategies to tackle this trend. I liked that the final paper was a group project, so it's not very stressful. I recommend it to people who want to learn more about this region and are interested in ways to strengthen democracy around the world. We also had a few guest speakers who were very insightful!
worse_comment: This class is on an interesting topic and the professor is extremely knowledgeable. The class this year was disorganized and that made assignments confusing. It is also hard to know how you are doing because we receive minimal feedback on the presentations and there is just one final policy memo. All the work is in groups.
subject: Government

best_comment: This course was absolutely phenomenal. It definitely solidified my decision to go to law school, so if you're a tentative pre–law student, I highly recommend taking this course. The theory lens is great for the issues you will consider –– from prostitution to polygamy to prescription drugs. You might be skeptical at first, but I highly recommend you dive headfirst into the more "philosophy–y" papers you read at the beginning of the year. Those provide a really great framework for considering the rest of the course. There were also some phenomenal readings later in the course about neuroscience, determinism, and free will –– woah, were those world–shifting! The leeway you get on the final paper is also great: you can literally write about *anything* you want, as long as you can connect it to the course material. It's awesome! Gabe is also a phenomenal (I'm using that word too much!) lecturer. He's great at guiding discussion without dominating it, and you really get to see your classmates shine. Honestly, that was my favorite part of the course – getting to know the folks in the class and seeing their thoughts. It's one of those classes where everyone in the class gets the chance to dazzle, and it's really awesome to see.Overall: Take this class! You will have a phenomenal time.
worse_comment: This class is thought–provoking. Do not be afraid to read theory texts from Locke, Mill, or Hobbes. This class takes theory and brings it into a contemporary light. You will consider several dilemmas in the class and it will cause you to view the criminal legal system differently.
subject: Government

course_title: Thinking Out of the Box - Exploring New Insights into North Korea 001
best_comment: The course will challenge you but in a way that truly excites you in the developments of your personal growth and understanding of broader foreign policy issues. North Korea is an ever–evolving, ever–present threat, and having someone like Dr. Park distill those issues into accessible lessons is an invaluable, fulfilling experience. A wonderful class and a truly exceptional professor!

Professor Malik is a great discussion leader, very helpful with developing a research topic and fleshing out your ideas and interests. The class and reading materials are super engaging and thought–provoking. The class is oriented more towards understanding research design which is very helpful for shaping your own research projects. Highly recommend taking this class!

This class is a fascinating way to learn more about governance and globalization in East Asia. The readings are manageable and interesting; the class is discussion–based and engaging; and you receive tons of feedback on written assignments. The final paper was daunting to me (personally), but it was broken down into manageable pieces. For example, we submitted and received feedback on our literature reviews before writing the rest of the paper, which was super helpful. Professor Dillon is incredibly supportive, compassionate, understanding, and flexible (which I really appreciated this semester, given some health issues). She makes herself available outside of class, so you can always get help when you need it. Highly recommend this class! And taking other classes with Professor Dillon.

course_title: The Political Theory of Social Movements 001
best_comment: This is a good class for you if you're interested in social movements. It is also extremely theory–based, which makes some of the content and readings more dense and harder to get through. As long as you can balance between that knowledge of theory and current social movements, you'll like this class.

course_title: EJ Safra Undergraduate Ethics Fellowship Seminar 001
best_comment: If you don't have much experience reading analytic philosophy, there may be a bit of a learning curve, but it is so worth it. This class tends to attract students with a variety of intellectual interests who are interested in asking and answering very difficult ethical questions. It is one of the few undergrad classes at Harvard where every single student is genuinely interested in learning for the sake of learning, so it's a unique and exciting opportunity. That said, the class is highly rewarding but also intellectually rigorous. To get the most out of it, you will need lots of time to think! Since the bulk of the assignments are due Sunday through Tuesday, be careful of frontloading other obligations that might prevent you from taking the time to seriously engage with the readings, assignments, and discussions.Although class meets for nearly three hours each week, the time will pass quickly with Arthur's dynamic teaching (which includes a suite of long–running dad jokes) and discussion facilitation. Plus, JP is an incredibly kind and knowledgeable TF who is always willing to help (and who gives feedback at an uncanny speed). Take this class for the challenge and the community, among the class itself and with the Safra Center at large.
best_gem_comment: Applying for the fellowship and taking the course has easily been one of the best decisions I've made as a Harvard student. I have never been at a seminar table with as high a concentration of incredible, thoughtful, kind students. Arthur is an absolute gem on this campus –– he makes the 3–hour class fly by in an instant and has a lot of passion for the fellowship as a whole. JP is the absolute sweetest. The readings and material are (almost) always fascinating. The food is pretty nice. I really couldn't recommend the fellowship more highly and I definitely recommend taking advantage of all the cool events you get invited to as a fellow!!
subject: Government

course_title: The Politics of Urban Inequality in the United States 001
best_comment: The course is super interesting and covers a lot of material that is super pertinent about inequality in our country and how we might be able to address it. It's super easy to reach out for help and office hours. The discussions in the course are also super interesting since you might have people from all over the country, both from rural and urban settings, so you might be able to hear from a lot of different perspectives. Especially with the Harvard bubble, this class can help make you think about what happens right outside the Harvard gates.

This is a great Gov 97 seminar, and while political theory might seem like a more difficult method of fulfilling the 97 requirements, it is really interesting and valuable if you stay on top of the readings and put in the effort.
worse_comment: Come into this class with an open mind as you will be introduced to new, difficult assignments

best_comment: This is a great Gov 97 seminar, and while political theory might seem like a more difficult method of fulfilling the 97 requirements, it is really interesting and valuable if you stay on top of the readings and put in the effort.
worse_comment: Come into this class with an open mind as you will be introduced to new, difficult assignments

best_comment: I think that this is a great class and your success depends on the time and effort that you are willing to put into the class.
I think that this is a great class and your success depends on the time and effort that you are willing to put into the class.

I loved this class! Obviously, sophomore tutorial is required, but I really enjoyed Hobbes's Leviathan even if I went super skeptical as a non–theory student. The seminars and readings were accessible without a strong political theory background and I always felt engaged even as the material got deeper and more challenging. The assignments were very fair and I loved the way they and the feedback received built on each other.

I loved this class! Obviously, sophomore tutorial is required, but I really enjoyed Hobbes's Leviathan even if I went super skeptical as a non–theory student. The seminars and readings were accessible without a strong political theory background and I always felt engaged even as the material got deeper and more challenging. The assignments were very fair and I loved the way they and the feedback received built on each other.
Noah is a great TF and this course was great overall. They help you pace your work without making you feel like you're doing busy work.
worse_comment: This will not be an easy course. Grading is rather harsh and can often be discouraging.

best_comment: Noah is a great TF and this course was great overall. They help you pace your work without making you feel like you're doing busy work.
worse_comment: This will not be an easy course. Grading is rather harsh and can often be discouraging.

best_comment: Noah is great, and you'll love it.
worse_comment: This course was awful. The section leaders mark off tons of points and don't even provide feedback as to why the points were taken. Then they mark off points again for and tell you it is for not correcting an issue even though they failed to tell you what you did wrong in their comments. You will constantly get told you will be getting grades/ feedback back by a certain time, only to be lied to. This class is the worst class I have ever taken at Harvard. It has made me rethink being a gov concentrator and I will be switching to something else.

best_comment: Noah is great, and you'll love it.
worse_comment: This course was awful. The section leaders mark off tons of points and don't even provide feedback as to why the points were taken. Then they mark off points again for and tell you it is for not correcting an issue even though they failed to tell you what you did wrong in their comments. You will constantly get told you will be getting grades/ feedback back by a certain time, only to be lied to. This class is the worst class I have ever taken at Harvard. It has made me rethink being a gov concentrator and I will be switching to something else.

best_comment: Do not stress about having quantitative skills going into the class– I had none, yet did well because I tapped into the many available resources (for example, the Harvard library offers incredibly helpful research consultations).  Make sure to choose a topic that you're interested in, at least skim the readings, and take the early assignments seriously. If you put in the work early, the end of the semester will be a breeze. Trust me. Put in the work on that pre–prospectus!

Do not stress about having quantitative skills going into the class– I had none, yet did well because I tapped into the many available resources (for example, the Harvard library offers incredibly helpful research consultations).  Make sure to choose a topic that you're interested in, at least skim the readings, and take the early assignments seriously. If you put in the work early, the end of the semester will be a breeze. Trust me. Put in the work on that pre–prospectus!

Gov97 gets a lot of mixed reviews (often depending on your section topic and interest level in research/academia). For me, it was just ok. The week to week work load is light (relatively short readings and discussion post) however, the written assignments are very time consuming, and take a lot of effort to plan effectively. The grading is very tough and unpredictable, and you may find that even your best effort only earns a B. While the rubric can act as a guide, ultimately you're grade is determined in part at the discretion of your TF. Definitely make sure you pick a topic you're really interested in, as all of the assignments in this class culminate in a final paper focused on a tangential topic. Also, all of the weekly readings are focused on this topic (which can quickly become repetitive and feel a bit redundant) The best part of Gov97 is definetly the guest speaker lectures. I learned a lot from these lectures, and the topics and perspectives very quite varied and engaging.

Also, all of the weekly readings are focused on this topic (which can quickly become repetitive and feel a bit redundant) The best part of Gov97 is definetly the guest speaker lectures. I learned a lot from these lectures, and the topics and perspectives very quite varied and engaging.

If you are taking GOV 97, definitely rank Yi Ning's section first. She ran an excellent class that hits everything you want from a gov course: genuinely interesting readings and discussion, freedom in your research with very useful and actionable feedback, and no busy work. Everything had purpose and was useful. Yi Ning is a phenomenal teacher and section leader. You will learn so much and enjoy the process!!
worse_comment: This class is a requirement for gov concentrators. It is not too bad but it is not the easiest class ever, so perhaps factor that in when balancing with other courses.

best_comment: If you are taking GOV 97, definitely rank Yi Ning's section first. She ran an excellent class that hits everything you want from a gov course: genuinely interesting readings and discussion, freedom in your research with very useful and actionable feedback, and no busy work. Everything had purpose and was useful. Yi Ning is a phenomenal teacher and section leader. You will learn so much and enjoy the process!!
worse_comment: This class is a requirement for gov concentrators. It is not too bad but it is not the easiest class ever, so perhaps factor that in when balancing with other courses.

best_comment: U.S Grand Strategy in International Relations is the BEST Gov 97 section! The professor is so understanding  and fosters a collaborative environment where you will learn so much. A very reasonable grader and willing to support you + provide feedback. He also runs a foreign policy simulation, which I found very cool. This section makes Gov 97 way less scarier than it might be described— highly recommend!

The readings are dense and sometimes complicated to get through, but ultimately incredibly rewarding if you take the time to really dissect them! Sophie is an amazing TF who leads interesting discussions.
worse_comment: Tough but you learn a lot

best_comment: The readings are dense and sometimes complicated to get through, but ultimately incredibly rewarding if you take the time to really dissect them! Sophie is an amazing TF who leads interesting discussions.
worse_comment: Tough but you learn a lot

best_comment: The difficulty with this type of course is that everyone is coming to it from a different baseline familiarity with research. GOV 97 basically assumes you have never written a research paper before or searched Hollis; we spend an hour talking about the difference between a causal and descriptive  question. So if you're new to all this, this course might be helpful. But otherwise, I'm not sure you'll learn much about research and writing in political science, beyond that the exercise of writing a research paper is always good for research skills. The surface–level depth here was especially a problem for my section on redistricting, because the material is such that it doesn't make much sense to do anything other than a quantitive paper. It would have been helpful, then, to spend time reviewing quant methods and honestly they probably should have made GOV 50 a prerequisite for my section.Anyway, you shouldn't be discouraged from concentrating in GOV by this course. All humanities/social sciences sophomore tutorials suffer from the same issues. At worst, you'll get some interesting conversations on what is hopefully a GOV topic that interests you, but don't expect this course to improve your research/writing or give you a deeper intro to poli sci methods.

It would have been helpful, then, to spend time reviewing quant methods and honestly they probably should have made GOV 50 a prerequisite for my section.Anyway, you shouldn't be discouraged from concentrating in GOV by this course. All humanities/social sciences sophomore tutorials suffer from the same issues. At worst, you'll get some interesting conversations on what is hopefully a GOV topic that interests you, but don't expect this course to improve your research/writing or give you a deeper intro to poli sci methods.

The content of Political Violence, Repression, and Civil War was so interesting and carefully integrated with the gov 97 learning objectives. I also enjoyed Kevin's teaching style as it was very engaging and helped us transition from knowledge consumption to production. I also appreciate how the lectures are only mandatory for 3/5 sessions. I think that there needs to be more consistency among TF's carefully selecting their content and required readings to align with the gov 97 learning objectives. I had a great experience but many of my peers in different sections felt differently. In conclusion, TAKE KEVIN'S SECTION!

The content of Political Violence, Repression, and Civil War was so interesting and carefully integrated with the gov 97 learning objectives. I also enjoyed Kevin's teaching style as it was very engaging and helped us transition from knowledge consumption to production. I also appreciate how the lectures are only mandatory for 3/5 sessions. I think that there needs to be more consistency among TF's carefully selecting their content and required readings to align with the gov 97 learning objectives. I had a great experience but many of my peers in different sections felt differently. In conclusion, TAKE KEVIN'S SECTION!

I took the section on Southeast Asian political theory, which I think I initially ranked outside my top four given that my interests in the Government department are international relations first and comparative government second. I was initially skeptical about taking a political theory course because I had little to no prior exposure or interest in the subject. Although I found the first couple of weeks in the course to be quite challenging in my understanding of the very dense theoretical texts, the discussions were low–stakes and were ultimately helpful in foregrounding my theoretical analysis of the Southeast Asian historical texts we read later on in the course. I think Yi Ning did a great job at making the discussion sections intimate and encouraging student participation, which I really appreciated, and it made the vast amounts of reading I did worthwhile, which I can't say for many courses. While I generally find more motivation to work on problem sets than essays, it was nice to come out of this course with a final paper I could be proud of as a culmination of my work throughout the course, especially as I got more interested in Southeast Asia as a region. Even though this course teaches a very specific type of writing that I don't see myself needing to be familiar with outside of other Harvard government courses, it's still a required course, and your experience in it will probably be very dependent on who your section leader is. If Yi Ning's section is offered in the spring, I would highly recommend it, even if political theory isn't your forte.

It is great in diving in depth about the topic of your section
It is great in diving in depth about the topic of your section
The class will walk you through the assignments and the reí rice are super clear on expectations
The class will walk you through the assignments and the reí rice are super clear on expectations

This class is great! It can vary from TF to TF but if you get a TF that understands you and your learning style, it is a fantastic course. I truly learned how to be a better writer and researcher. I gained experience in R, while engaging with complex texts on a deeper level. This course really helps build the foundation for Gov 94 courses and thesis writing in the future.
worse_comment: This course taught me applicable methodological approaches and covered a wide array of readings on protests and political violence. The skills modules were clear and informative, and Kevin was always incredibly helpful and available.

best_comment: This class is great! It can vary from TF to TF but if you get a TF that understands you and your learning style, it is a fantastic course. I truly learned how to be a better writer and researcher. I gained experience in R, while engaging with complex texts on a deeper level. This course really helps build the foundation for Gov 94 courses and thesis writing in the future.
worse_comment: This course taught me applicable methodological approaches and covered a wide array of readings on protests and political violence. The skills modules were clear and informative, and Kevin was always incredibly helpful and available.

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class to any student with an interest in international relations! In this course, you will learn a lot about the foundational theories of IR as well as develop a framework for understanding and analyzing historical events. Professor Imparato is a wonderful lecturer and he knows how to deliver the course material in an engaging and effective manner. Moreover, he gives great feedback on papers and is awesome at teaching how to write a strong political science paper. He really cares about his students and it is very evident through his teaching style.  Again, this is a class I’d highly recommend!

As with all Gov seminars, it is highly dependent on the TF section lead. Harry Oppenheimer was a great TF for this course, really chill, but also super knowledgeable. Apparently they standardize grading across the entire Gov 97 course, but grading doesn't seem to be very easy. A–, B+ seems to be the normal range of grades. If you get the Technology/Disruption in IR one, the readings are moderately interesting, a few highlight ones, but also some rather drab ones. It is focused on technology, but it isn't really cutting edge, like AI for example. Political science moves a little slower, so take that into account for your expectations of topics. The course is mostly discussion based so make sure to do most of the readings in advance to get value out of the course.
worse_comment: The course heads tried to make grading and everything else as fair as possible, but the structure of this course does not allow for it to be 100% fair. Differences between deadlines (some sections given extensions), feedback, and the timeliness of grades greatly differed. It is also very difficult to be engaged in a course in which you are not interested in the topic. One section aligned with my interests, and unfortunately, I was not placed in that section. My section was fine, but the topic was boring and made it hard for me to be passionate about my paper. My section peers were all heavily interested in the topic and had prior exposure, which made things further unengaging. I had little background in the topic, making it hard to speak in the section.

best_comment: As with all Gov seminars, it is highly dependent on the TF section lead. Harry Oppenheimer was a great TF for this course, really chill, but also super knowledgeable. Apparently they standardize grading across the entire Gov 97 course, but grading doesn't seem to be very easy. A–, B+ seems to be the normal range of grades.
