best_comment: This class did an excellent job teaching students how to write a formal research paper as prospective social scientists. I appreciated that the course empowered students to work toward a final research paper in increments over the course of the semester, as this allowed students to solicit and incorporate feedback in an effective way. Another strength of the course consisted of its guest lecturers, as each speaker presented a fascinating perspective of political science as a discipline.An important piece of advice that I will give to future students is to ATTEND OFFICE HOURS AS MUCH AS YOU CAN in advance of paper deadlines, including and especially the first one. You will do well in the course by receiving and incorporating as MUCH feedback/advice from your section head as possible. Seriously, trust me on this. You will not regret it!

You gotta take it. I beg you to turn in the stuff on time, just throw some stuff on there, it's fine. You will probably not get yeeted for being a little late, but one of the big parts of this course is that you have to learn to like, take a big project, and break it into little pieces. Like, come up with a research topic, then ask the TF, then you kinda look into it a bit, and turns out the data is screwed, so you go and dive around some more and change your inquiry a bit, etc. That process should take place over like, a number of weeks, not in one rapid mess. That's what this course will ideally teach you.

If you want to take a gov/econ class and are good at math, take this class. If you are a gov concentrator who does not like math, I don't think this is the best class. I was the latter. This class is pretty interesting, but if you are not a math or econ person, it is easy to get lost in all of the models. The p–sets have quite a bit of excessive algebra ocassionally as well. That being said, Peter is an excellent lecturer and an all around great guy, and Sung In was a great TF!
worse_comment: Overall, I think this class was portrayed as accessible for anyone but, in reality, required prior experience with economic models, high–level math, and economic concepts. As a government concentrator, I really struggled with the pace and math. This led to a lot of stress and frustration because I'm not sure if Prof. Buisseret or the TF Sung–In understood how challenging these concepts are to those who had never seen them before. They promised me help and a manageable speed but the PSETs and exams seemed to demand way more than just an understanding of the concepts. It was especially frustrating how much harder the exams were than lecture or the PSETS.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Jill is amazing and explains topics so well. She is one of the most brilliant and caring professors I've ever had. Don't be fooled by the GOV listing, you get some good science/CS skills out of this class too!
subject: Government

best_comment: This class has a fairly heavy reading load, but the readings are pretty interesting. Professor Harrisson is very kind and cares a lot about this topic! You will learn how to think about how subjective the surveys are that create a lot of the facts we recognize as true about our world, and you will definitely gain the skills to create your own! The content is not always the most interesting, but I think it could pair well with a thesis or if you know you want to do survey research, or if you are just already interested in the topic! A pretty easy way to fulfill your QRD, especially if taken pass/fail, because there are a fair amount of assignments.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a very interesting class especially to Americans who want to be exposed to a more critical view of Economics. The structure of the class allows for a great amount of autonomous study and exploration, and the topic is very fascinating. The professor's classes are very well structured.

course_title: The Political Science of American Democracy 001
best_comment: The four professors really made this course unique. Each professor gave a different perspective on the course materials they also were extremely well communicating and really clear in their ideas. I really enjoyed Professor Muirhead’s enthusiasm. The section discussions were very meaningful. Nathan was an incredible section leader he allowed for us to share our ideas, he was also extremely helpful in putting my ideas into a coherent argument. Nathan was really easy to reach out. I met with him for office hours and he really helped me better understand course materials. Nathan was very prepared to give in–depth advice. One of the best TF’s I have had.
worse_comment: Unfortunately Professor Mansfield is leaving but the course curriculum is exceptional regardless.

best_comment: Danielle Allen is an awesome teacher... she is very approachable and encouraging. Her book is fascinating and will change the way you think about democracy. The assignments are manageable in terms of time/load, but we didn't receive feedback on them so I didn't know how I was doing until the final grade came out. Be prepared for a fair amount of reading (you will read Allen's whole book plus excerpts of lots of foundational texts)––– I'm glad that I read them though because I now have a good grasp of basic theories related to political economy (Constant, Rawls, Keynes, etc.). The course sessions were long this year (2.45 hrs), so it was sometimes hard to stay focused throughout. But we got a break in the middle and Allen does her best to keep it exciting. I definitely recommend this course because the issue of democracy will be front and center in the coming years––– you will walk away feeling prepared to contribute to conversations about it.
worse_comment: Professor Allen is very interesting and so are her ideas! Even if you're not super into political theory — this was my first class in the subfield — you'll take something away from this class. It'll also incentivize you to participate, and you'll realize that you have more to offer to a discussion than you might have expected.

course_title: The History of Modern Political Philosophy 001
best_comment: This course made me rethink concepts which I previously thought were untouchable – like the validity of universal rights, constitutions, etc. You get to explore such a wide variety of political writings, and I really feel like I now have such a solid background in Western political philosophy and Western philosophy in general. This course makes you question and understand the basis for ideas which are generally accepted. Professor Tuck's lectures were fascinating and offered really interesting insights. To get the most out of this course, you should really do all the readings – the class is really what you make of it. I absolutely loved it and would highly recommend.
subject: Government

best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. It offers a great survey of some of the most important works in political theory. All the texts were very well chosen and they worked extremely well together, many building upon and responding to similar arguments. Professor Nelson is also an excellent professor, who demonstrates both passion and knowledge of the field through his well organized and engaging lectures that explain the texts and their ramifications very clearly.  I also enjoyed the discussion section component of the course. While discussion sections usually feel unnecessary, I actually gained a lot of interesting insights from them, especially because of our TF Wells and the engagement of my other classmates. I felt like the small size of the class really helped in this regard. I highly recommend to anyone interested in political theory or the question of property more specifically.

This is a phenomenal class. Prof Unger is one of a kind and it is an honor to learn from him. However, this class requires a lot to keep up. You will need to properly read the books and attempt to keep up with the argument of the class, since every lecture builds upon the last one. Prof Unger is very approachable and more than happy to answer any questions and engage with your ideas. Take this class!!

This was by far my favorite class of my first year!! Lectures were absolutely fascinating, and I learned about the law in a way that I never had before. We discussed the inequalities and shortcomings within the law, but it also never felt hopeless or overwhelming. It was great to learn about the problems of legal systems in a way that is still hopeful for future solutions. I did have some trouble understanding the readings for the class, but sections were incredibly useful in helping me with that. Overall, I loved this class, and I would highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Take this course! Professor Holland does an incredible job with lectures and building content. You will learn SO MUCH about how the law upholds and construct inequalities. Cannot recommend this course enough!
subject: Government

course_title: The Success and Failure of Protest Movements 001
best_comment: Take this class if you are looking for an introductory gov course, something to fulfill a gov requirement, a class that will help you learn a lot about the inner workings of protest, or just want a good and chill class for the semester. Professor Hummel is great and knows a lot about the subject, and genuinely cares about teaching it in a way that makes sense to everyone. There is only one reading per class and they are manageable/interesting, and there are mini–assignments along the way to prepare you for the final paper which makes it a lot quicker to finish at the end of the course. Great class, cool subject, and great professor.
subject: Government

course_title: Propaganda and Politics: Past and Present 001
best_comment: Super interesting content. I really really appreciate how much effort Prof Soroka put into this course to select interesting documentaries, readings, and materials for this class. His lectures were always like a Ted talk. I'd just walk in, keep my computer and everything else aside, and tune in to his spiel. He covers some theoretical basis for propaganda but then goes into a lot of adjacent history and real world examples. All of them together tell a very interesting story and make you realize how much propaganda there really is out there. I started asking more questions about media I consume since taking this class. It truly was a delightful experience. I didn't want to skip a single lecture and actually really looked forward to them.

course_title: Negotiating Post-Soviet Conflict: The Geopolitics of Eastern Europe and the Caucasus 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! This is hands down the best class I have ever taken at Harvard out of my entire 6 semesters. There are 3 long Saturday sessions of negotiations, and there was genuinely nothing I would rather be doing on a Saturday. I left every session and was so so happy because they made my day. I loved this class. The negotiations were so well organized and built on each other. There are not too many readings which is great because they really let you focus on your negotiation strategy. The writing assignment is a memo where they discourage the academic fluff, which is amazing for applying this to a job. The only downside was that most assignments were due on Fridays 11:59pm which ruined 6 of my Friday nights this semester due to intense procrastination, so please do your Friday assignments on Thursday nights. This class was 60:40 Undergrad: Grad ratio. But the grad students are super nice and are learning just as undergrads are. Do not be afraid to talk up during debates and really take them as an opportunity to work on your debating skills. You will see vast improvements throughout the semester.  There are negotiation debriefs that allow you to think about what you did wrong during the debate and apply this to improve your next debate; take these seriously –– they help so much. Overall, best class ever! If you have any doubts, just take it! You will love it!
subject: Government

course_title: Capitalism and Democracy in Central and Eastern Europe 001
best_comment: If you are like to grapple with history, government, social movements, central Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union, and you like reading about these topics, take this! A lot of reading, classic lecture style, and so much (interesting) information.As someone who didn’t have as strong a framework for various comparative politics and political science frameworks, this was an amazing survey of these through the lens of a fascinating region and time.  Though a lot of reading, I found it to be very engaging.
subject: Government

best_comment: Take this course for a chill, but comprehensive review of how Chinese politics and government works. Debunk many myths about China, Xi Jingping and the CCP and gain thoughtful insight into the current tensions in international relations, Chinese domestic issues and life in China. Prof. Wang gives great lectures in which he interweaves contemporary issues, history and personal experience to show students what is truly happening in China.
worse_comment: If you want a REAL understanding of China instead of just the stereotypes and misinformation that we hear all around us (even within the halls of American academia and the US government!), then take this class!

best_comment: Levitsky is such a nice guy, and he puts a lot of effort into the lectures to make them engaging. I think his knowledge + teaching style make this an amazing class. I had heard many people say it was the absolute best class they had taken at Harvard, and I don't feel this way, to be honest, but it was super interesting anyways. If you like history and political theory in an applied way, regardless of your background, this class would be a great fit. Sections were also pretty interesting, and paper grading was mostly fair (although the TF you get can make your experience either great or bland). Something to beware is that there are A LOT of readings every week, and it is mostly fine to skim some of them but I feel like engaging with them will make your final exam prep way easier (the final is not that hard, but you should feel fluent about the terms/people encountered in some readings each week). Also, if you speak good spanish and your semester has the option of doing a spanish section like mine did, go for it! i loved mine.
subject: Government

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! This is easily by far the best course I have taken at Harvard: if only all classes were as great as this one. I cannot recommend it enough. Sparsha is incredible: so knowledgable, kind, passionate, open minded, friendly, genuinely cares SO MUCH for students as people. The rest of the teaching staff is also absolutely wonderful and a joy to work with (shoutout in particular to my awesome TF, Mauro!). The structure of the class felt smooth and natural: background and stakes for the first half, then solutions in the second. It is also SUCH an important, timely, and under–discussed topic!!! The guest speakers were all so awesome to hear from, and I appreciate all the outreach Sparsha had to do in order to secure such amazing guests. I never felt like coming to class was a chore; rather, I could not help but be excited to learn. The capstone portion was also really fulfilling – it was super rewarding to become friends with my team and produce a tangible product. As a whole, the class really felt like a family and community and I felt so cared for by Sparsha and the teaching team. I typically am not impressed by many of my courses, but I truly cannot help but gush about this one. Truly a life changing class.
worse_comment: I sadly don't think this class will be offered next year, but I enjoyed this class. It was unconventional and at time unorganized. But, most of the content really stuck with me and as  an upperclassman taking this class, I was able to read through the lines of a lot of the political implications of what we were talking about.  I did not have the best time with my Capstone Project, but that was just a function of my choice.
subject: Government

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. The course features guest speakers that are super interesting. Professor Carpenter does a great job teaching this course, and this course has been one of the most fun courses I've taken. The workload is super easy and the class is structured so well. Huge fan of this course.

course_title: Tech Science to Save the World 001
best_comment: Gov 1430 did an excellent job of highlighting ways in which technological innovation can sometimes have negative effects on society (e.g., privacy loss, misinformation spread, etc.). Even more, the course was effective at drawing on very current topic areas, which was very engaging, exciting, and fascinating. For example, a major focus area this spring was ChatGPT, which was just released in November! The greatest strength of the course consisted of its teaching staff: Ms. Leonie Beyrle and Professor Latanya Sweeney did a fantastic job helping students navigate each unit, and they worked with their outstanding teaching fellows to provide very thorough, insightful, and constructive feedback on coursework. Lastly, the class assignments were very fun and engaging to work on. Because they also focused on very current/important topic areas, I felt like I was actually contributing to commentary on these subjects in a meaningful and insightful way.I would highly recommend this class to students with an interest in technology and its impact on society. Absolutely zero technical expertise or experience is needed, as there is no coding required in the course. In short, take it!Also, a HUGE SHOUTOUT to Grace Park for being one of the GREATEST teaching fellows on this campus. They are truly a legend of Harvard, and I cannot rate them highly enough!
worse_comment: class is heavily based on slides, so lectured can be a little boring sometimes. a lot of students do other work during lectures. final project and paper were my least favorite part of the semester.
subject: Government

course_title: Tech Science to Save the World 001

worse_comment: class is heavily based on slides, so lectured can be a little boring sometimes. a lot of students do other work during lectures. final project and paper were my least favorite part of the semester.
subject: Government

course_title: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change 001
best_comment: Would highly recommend if you are interested in the topic and have some background knowledge (speaking from personal experience as I am getting an ESPP secondary). My ultimate favorite parts were the content, class structure, and overall culture. They provided a good overview of the history of climate change politics and policy as well as general basis for climate change science. We also did policymaking simulations which were so fun and immersive. And finally, the culture of the class is really good. Our professors and TF staff were very kind and chill, but they encouraged us to participate and get the most out of the class. Sometimes the instruction for assignments was a bit convoluted but I think that the Professors are improving each year in how to communicate the instructions more effectively.
worse_comment: It has made me more aware on how political issues and problems may or may not be solved.
subject: Government

course_title: Politics of the Environment and Climate Change 001
best_comment: Would highly recommend if you are interested in the topic and have some background knowledge (speaking from personal experience as I am getting an ESPP secondary). My ultimate favorite parts were the content, class structure, and overall culture. They provided a good overview of the history of climate change politics and policy as well as general basis for climate change science. We also did policymaking simulations which were so fun and immersive. And finally, the culture of the class is really good. Our professors and TF staff were very kind and chill, but they encouraged us to participate and get the most out of the class. Sometimes the instruction for assignments was a bit convoluted but I think that the Professors are improving each year in how to communicate the instructions more effectively.
worse_comment: It has made me more aware on how political issues and problems may or may not be solved.
subject: Government

course_title: Evaluating the Impacts of Public Policies: How to Design and Implement Randomized Controlled Trials 001
best_comment: AMAZING CLASS! You learn about so many different experiments and randomized controlled trials and gain a really good introduction to the field of social science. Professor Hiscox tells a lot of interesting stories about his own work with his company BETA in Australia as well. Great professor and great class all together!
worse_comment: Take it for Professor Hiscox alone
subject: Government

best_comment: Any class with Professor Kertzer is incredible, and this new course was no exception. He is truly the best lecturer I've ever had – funny, conveys information clearly, talks at the perfect pace, and generates enthusiasm for the material. Katherine was a great section leader, and did so much work to ensure we all had the best experience possible (making study sheets, creating fun section activities, leading fantastic office hours, etc.).
best_gem_comment: If you took Gov1790 and liked it, or are generally interested in how psychology might interact with IR, take this class – it's another Kertzer gem and will expose you to a lot of cool literature and cutting edge research happening in the field right now. The lectures are interesting, the readings are long, and you will have learned a lot by the end – the mark of a good and fulfilling Gov class which can act as a cool elective or help fulfill IR subfield. Kertzer is also just a gem of a professor and literally made everyone pins at the end of the class – hopefully it stays small–ish in the future because it had good, informal vibes and low stress in lecture which is a nice change from 1790 or other big intro classes in the department

course_title: Behavioral Insights and Public Policy: Nudging for Good 001
best_comment: I would take this class if the same structure of the course remains the same, as the content is very interesting!!Essentially, you have one presentation that takes up a huge portion of your grade (40%). If you are good at presenting, I would for sure take this course. My TF graded relatively well but was a bit nitpicky. Ensure that you are a great presenter and you could walk out with an A in GOV 1759.Next, there are two exams — one midterm and one final. These exams were both online, open note, but the Professor had issues with the final remaining online due to new University guidance. Since the exams were open note, they were easier than if in person, due to not having to memorize ample information on the course studies or behavioral concepts. The exams are multiple choice structured, with a few additional short response and long answer questions. I scored pretty good on the first exam and am waiting for my Final exam score. However, the exams are easy enough if you study a bit. It is integral to know key information about the behavioral concepts and course studies so you are able to answer both the multiple choice and short response questions! I made sure to study for both exams and am happy about my results.The next portion of your grade is course participation, which constituted discussion board posts (presumably credit / no credit) and in person attendance at “sections” which were just watching people’s presentations. I assume that the discussion posts are graded for completion since I got no formal feedback, but my TF contacted some students to do their discussion posts better or to complete ones they didn’t. Since participation is merely showing up to the section and isn’t based on formal engagement in course, I think this will be good for students!The content of the course is very interesting, too! I enjoyed the deep dive into economics, psychology, and public policy/government. Professor Hiscox is an AMAZINGGG lecturer and I hope you have the chance to take this course.**!!!
worse_comment: This class is not a gem. The midterm is difficult. The final is difficult. The presentation is not easy. The only thing that is a gem about this course is that they don't take attendance and all the lectures are recorded.
best_gem_comment: Many people will take the class just as a GEM, but if you truly engage with the lectures, and focus on the content, this class will leave you so happy and satisfied. Hiscox is such a joy to have in class, and makes for an amazing person to know.
subject: Government

best_comment: I think this was a great class that was well–taught and I feel a lot better about my grasp of regression now. It's probably a good idea to have some basic working knowledge of statistics and R before you take this course, but otherwise it's pretty much an intro class. Matt's a wonderful and patient teacher!

If you enjoyed 2005, you should heavily consider taking this course—it was extremely rewarding to see how we used the foundation built in 2005 to read papers and tackle more nuanced models with interesting implications.  I also left the course with very concrete work to show for my effort (a referee report and research note) and with the ability to understand formal theory papers at greater depths than I ever thought I would!

course_title: Applied Bayesian Statistics for the Social Sciences 001
best_comment: it's not really applied, you'll see lots of theory and maths. though I liked Kosuke's attitude to teaching and trying to make the material accessible

I would definitely take this course as it had such a rich dive into political theory involving capitalism, with a deep focus on leftist thinkers that usually aren’t focused on in Harvard classrooms. The reading, however, is very intensive and dense! I would recommend having taken a few upper level humanities courses before taking this one. I often found myself spending 10hrs+ per week to fully comprehend and digest the deep texts that Professor Forrester gave us. This is not a slight on the course or the Professor — just ensure that your reading and writing skills are to the level that this course demands of you, especially since it is open to both undergraduate and graduate students.Professor Forrester is so insightful and I loved hearing her commentary every week on the texts and topics at hand. I also think this discussion was illuminated by the guest speakers we had. We had many guest speakers with 2 commentators — one PHD student and one professor — who applied a critique to the texts at hand. I thought this was especially interesting when analyzing the texts as we had multiple perspectives. I thought the final paper was interesting. It was an open ended ~25 page assignment that had to touch on the course themes. I have not got feedback yet, but it is 80% of our grade so make sure that you are committed to writing a longer piece. The other part of our grade (20%) is course attendance/participation. Overall, please take this course. I hope that they offer this course in other academic years as students deserve to learn the complexities of political and economic theory on this subject, especially with such an accomplished professor like Professor Forrester!

Marx was a brilliant seminar – one of the best I've ever had in my time at Harvard. Richard Tuck is one the greatest Professors in the history of Harvard, and it was a real treat to see him work in his final seminar of his career. Should the class ever be offered again, I would highly recommend the seminar for anyone interested in learning about two of the most consequential men in the history of political thought (Marx and Engels). Thank you, Richard!
worse_comment: Sadly, you all will never be able to take it with Professor Tuck. Alas!

best_comment: Excellent class. Torben and Yuhua are great discussion leaders and provide thoughtful feedback –– they're great at turning people's insights into actionable research questions.
subject: Government

best_comment: Excellent class. Torben and Yuhua are great discussion leaders and provide thoughtful feedback –– they're great at turning people's insights into actionable research questions.
subject: Government

best_comment: Pia and Torben are wonderful wonderful scholars and teachers. Torben is the very best in the field of the comparative political economy of advanced democracies. But he also knows everything about developing countries and autocracies. For anyone who has any interest in political economy, you definitely want to take a class with Torben to learn from his way of thinking about and studying political economy.Pia is the very best in the field of the political economy of development. She is the kind of scholar that you want to become ––– she is a true thinker. Like Torben, although they both work on their specialized fields, they both know a lot different contexts and topics. Thank you both so much!

Pia and Torben are wonderful wonderful scholars and teachers. Torben is the very best in the field of the comparative political economy of advanced democracies. But he also knows everything about developing countries and autocracies. For anyone who has any interest in political economy, you definitely want to take a class with Torben to learn from his way of thinking about and studying political economy.Pia is the very best in the field of the political economy of development. She is the kind of scholar that you want to become ––– she is a true thinker. Like Torben, although they both work on their specialized fields, they both know a lot different contexts and topics. Thank you both so much!

This is a great class and is definitely something you should take if you are interested in exploring contemporary Russian politics on the domestic side, with an understanding of how they tie into international relations. I recommend this course if you have a good understanding of Russian politics and Russian and regional history and are interested in applying that to modern events and affairs in Russia and beyond.

Prof. Perry is a legend for a reason; this is a fantastic course and she is an expert at leading discussions and helping students grasp the tools and power (and limitations) of political science as a discipline. She assigns one (generally relatively recent) book on China and allows students to pick from a list of other non–China classics in the field on the topic. The juxtaposition of the two books was generally thought–provoking and helpful, and also meant that I both learned more about the field and had some agency in picking my weekly readings. (It did also mean that the course was a lot of work, but I think it's absolutely worth your while to read both books .) Overall, I gained a deeper understanding of important topics in comparative politics and in the study of China.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a really fun course with a great, chill, supportive classroom environment that covered wide–ranging topics and methods in public opinion survey design and analysis.  It gives you very practical knowledge and experience in survey development and results evaluation. The survey project that you do throughout the course is a really cool way to design a real survey collaboratively with the professor and other students, problem–solve real issues, do your own analysis, and end up with findings that are relevant to you which can be written into a publishable paper. As a PhD student, it's great to walk away from a class with a project that generated interesting novel data written into an actual publishable paper that aligns with your research interests. With the readings and course topic discussions, I learned a lot about public opinion survey design and analysis as well as was able to reinforce political science knowledge relevant to my field of study. Steve is a very approachable professor who really welcomes differing viewpoints and experiences into his classroom for everyone to learn from each other. He's incredibly knowledgeable and experienced in the topics and methods and also creates a very welcoming and fun classroom environment. Previous experience with survey design and already having research questions in mind about a short survey you would want to do is very helpful to being able to dive right into the course and get the most out of it. Highly recommend this course if you have interest in public opinion research and digging into generating novel survey data for your own project!

course_title: Proseminar on Inequality and Social Policy II 001
best_comment: Building a sense of cohort community among the other students is very valuable both personally and for the insights you can gain from people in other disciplines or with other research interests. Trying to stay on top of the long–term research project throughout the semester is important, so setting some type of relatively strict schedule for yourself would be a big benefit.
subject: Government

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! The psychological theories I learnt in this class gave me a new framework to understand the messy and dynamic international system that cannot always be captured by pure rational choice theories. Professor Powers is an amazing instructor who leads classes with excellence and really cares about students and their development. The exciting discussions and new ideas developed in this class will be a highlight of my time at Harvard that I will look back upon with fondness. Don't miss it!
I highly recommend attending to see how research is produced.
subject: Government

best_comment: I highly recommend attending to see how research is produced.
subject: Government

course_title: Graduate Research Course: Mental Health Policy 001
Graduate Research Course: Mental Health Policy 001
Research in Seminar in Health Policy 001
subject: Health Policy

course_title: Research in Seminar in Health Policy 001
subject: Health Policy

course_title: The History of American Conservatism from William F. Buckley, Jr., to Donald Trump 01
best_comment: Fantastic seminar option. Topic is super engaging and Aaron is the best. Highly, highly recommend for a seminar because work load is also not as bad as other seminars. Discussions went by quickly because they were very engaging and interesting, and Aaron facilitates them excellently. The assignment structure is super effective and nice too because you build towards the final paper.
subject: History

course_title: Political Violence in the Twentieth Century 01
best_comment: This class was really interesting and if you are interested in the subject of violence and how it manifests, I would recommend this class. Prepare to do the readings and contribute to discussions, but also for a lot of writing. It would probably be useful to have some sort of background in Historical writing or analysis of sources because I feel that even though the class is scaffolded, the learning curve is still pretty steep.
subject: History

best_comment: Definitely take the class! You will learn so incredibly much and the final zine project is a great opportunity to explore a subject of your interest in depth in a way that reaches beyond the constraints of typical final papers.
worse_comment: This course has some interesting readings but I didn't get as much out of it as I hoped to. I felt that class discussion focused far too much on extrapolating sprawling, abstract ideas about racism and colonialism that weren't very grounded in the specifics of the history we were reading at any particular time—this had the effect of dulling the fruitfulness of conversations. I wish we had spent time examining early racial identity formation in the U.S. and gotten more perspectives from other historical scholars in our readings. This class also suffers from too much busy work as it stands—particularly with excessive, repetitive weekly zine journals (which were often on zines that were unrelated to course content and that we wouldn't discuss in class) and the lengthy weekly annotations, which often felt contrived/lent itself to us rehashing the same ideas each week.

course_title: US Labor and Working Class History, 1886-1967 01
best_comment: This is an excellent course that you really should take if you have even a passing interest in modern American history. You'll learn a lot, read a lot of inspiring radical texts, and gain a much more nuanced and developed for the way that power––of all different sorts––is motivated in the workplace. The readings are manageable, if a little long sometimes, the assignments are spread out through the whole semester and are thus well paced, and Prof. Lossin and Ione are both incredibly kind, passionate, and knowledgeable people who you'd be lucky to learn from.
best_gem_comment: This class is great, a rare gem of a history seminar in that it is actually interesting in what it teaches and how it's taught. You'll learn a lot about working class history that will change how you think about this time period of US history. Truly fantastic readings, though there are quite a bit of them, and the final paper can creep up on you, but is definitely worth the work you put into it.

course_title: Modern Jewish Politics: Between Power and Powerlessness 01
best_comment: This is a great class if you're interested at all in Jewish history or politics. While this class is not too difficult or time–consuming, I would recommend that students have taken at least one history class at college before taking this seminar because Professor Ury expects some proficiency in understanding historical academia and being able to write an analytical historical essay. The seminar was always a joy to attend and super interesting. Definitely do the readings before class because you can't get away with not knowing them.

course_title: U.S. History: Major Themes in the Twentieth Century 01
best_comment: This is a great class if you're interested in a survey of major themes in 20th–century American history. It's very reading–based; be prepared for lots of pages per week. But Prof. McGirr is very passionate and knowledgeable about the subject matter, and Thomas is an amazing, accessible, helpful TF. You'll get out what you give!
subject: History

course_title: The United States and China: Opium War to the Present 01
best_comment: Take this course if you're looking for a rewarding challenge. Writing a full–length history paper is something I did for the first time in this seminar, and the process was not simple but was incredibly meaningful, and I don't regret it. The readings are fascinating; you will learn a lot. And Professor Manela and James are incredibly knowledgeable and fun to converse with.
subject: History

best_comment: The course is a decent amount of work but it will help you a lot. Professor Jasanoff is an actual beast, so intelligent, classy, and kind. I want to be her when I grow up. I also want to be Shae and Kirin when I grow up. They are the realest, most helpful, kindest, and most knowledgeable TFs I've had here. If you're lucky enough to have this EPIC teaching staff, you are bound to succeed.
worse_comment: You have to take it, but it's not enjoyable, and you won't get much out of it
subject: History

best_comment: I loved this course! If you are interested in legal history or legal proceedings, take this class! You will learn about the changing landscape of legal history and what exactly is history. In the History 97 Tutorial course, most importantly, you will learn how to write as a historian, which will set the fundamentals for writing for your other concentration courses. Professor Smail is also an amazing professor! He has a plethora of knowledge on material, Medieval Europe, and legal histories ––– so if you are interested in any of these fields, definitely go to his office hours (he is very accessible). Office hours are very helpful before you start your papers! Also, don't cram your papers (don't write them on the day they are due).

This class is hard. It's the intro class for the History concentration, so there are a lot of historical reading, writing, analysis, and research skills that will be covered. It will make you a better writer, but it's a grind for a lot of the semester. Especially the second half, when you start working towards the final research paper, there's pretty much something big due every week. It's manageable to do within the given time frames, but don't underestimate how much time the assignments will take you. Best advice would be to start the assignments as early as you can, even if it is just getting some ideas down to get your thoughts going. I do think that peoples' experiences varied a lot between class sections, but that is not really something you can control. Just stay on top of the work and do your best. Overall, the difficulty of the class should not deter you from considering history as a concentration!
worse_comment: This class is demanding and hands on. Do not take this class when you are already taking other writing intensive classes. Also–*– take the final project seriously and work on it EARLY.

best_comment: This class was great. It raised really important questions about the role of history in academia as well as questions about morality and international diplomacy. Of course, there is a lot of writing but it pays off. You will see significant improvements in your quality of history writing. Be prepared to class having done the readings and wanting to engage, as it is crucial to doing well and learning. The tutorials are great and allow you to read what others are writing as well as receive great feedback. You really do get what you put in with this class.
worse_comment: The tutotial is interesting, but little guidance is actually given on how to write and improve essays. You are kind of thrown into the dark and told to figure out how to write for what your TF is looking for. The grading isn't super hard and the actual discussions can be super super interesting. Overall not a terrible class at all just needs work on the structure.

best_comment: This is an amazing course. Prof. Deloria is an AWESOME professor who is worth hanging onto every word he says –– he is such a smart historian (he is such an important scholar in Native American and Indigenous Studies and does incredible work) and an even better teacher who makes everyone feel welcomed (invites students into the conversation, is very down to earth, is not intimidating to talk to) and is infectiously passionate about what he does. The TFs in this course are great too –– I had Emma for my writing tutorial, and she was incredibly helpful. I felt like writing tutorial was actually very productive and helped me a lot on the revisions, and meeting with her 1:1 in office hours was also great. She is actually just a great person to talk to about history/history grad school and is doing really cool work herself –– all around super cool and kind person. The course is in no way easy though lol ––– there is a LOT of writing...almost a paper or revision every week, there is a lot of reading that you cannot slack on because the 3hr seminar is spent discussing the readings, and the final research paper is a lot of work. But these are reasons why the course is great –– it's a lot of content and you produce a ton of work, but you'll feel proud at the end of it for how much you've improved. There's a lotttt of help along the way, and I definitely encourage meeting with Prof. Deloria in his office hours to discuss your paper if you're ever stuck, because he gives great advice which will not only be useful for your paper but will also be those useful tidbits how to write/do history that are worth storing away as you go throughout other classes at Harvard. The 5pm Sunday deadline was brutal for me though lol so hopefully they change that. You get a 24 hr extension bank which is good but I still left almost every paper for the Saturday before and that was pretty rough. Overall really loved this course though.
worse_comment: If you have to take HIST97, take Indigenous History. Even though the topic felt overwhelming at first, Professor Deloria made us all feel comfortable. TFs were also excellent. There is much to be said about the issues with HIST97, but this course made it bearable (although it will be stressful no matter who you take it with).

best_comment: This class is required if you're a thesising senior with History as your primary concentration, so you probably don't have much choice in whether to take it, but regardless, I'd highly recommend this class! Besides giving you time and credit for your thesis work, Dr. Heelan is also a phenomenal person to check in with throughout your thesis process, and so is Kenneth (he's probably not going to be around for much longer since he's a PhD student, but all the History PhD students here are truly wonderful so whoever replaces him in Hist 99 is sure to be just as awesome). If you have History as your allied concentration and are thus not strictly required to take this class, I'd still recommend taking it because it's truly so useful, especially when your other department gives you literally no guidance :)
worse_comment: As a department, it is helpful that history has so many deadlines. While this can be stressful, it makes the workload of writing a thesis much more manageable.
subject: History

course_title: The 20th Century United States: Politics, Society, Culture 01
best_comment: While I probably got an A– in the course, awaiting the final, which, of course, never feels great, as a senior taking the class as an elective, the GPA hit seems fully worthwhile. It was my first challenging history class, and it really broadened my view of historical arguments and American history. Having taken the class, I feel prepared and inspired to read further about American history on my own, as if I have some key parts of the puzzle that I can build out myself over the years. Lecture with Professor McGirr was quite sensational: Every other sentence felt like, and often was, the conclusion to a prize–wining history book. Sometimes, I'd write my papers, and then go back and review my class notes, and realize I might not have actually said *that* much that was new. Maybe that's why I didn't do the best; however, it definitely feels worthwhile, at least in the moment, for now. We have the privilege of living in a beautiful, amazing country, and I'm grateful to have had the chance to learn about it from such a master in lecture and such a high, high calibre of teaching staff in section.

Professor Miles is an absolute genius and also one of the kindest professors you will ever have. This is such a thoughtful, empathetic course which made the experience great. However, do not expect invigorating lectures where you are taking notes as fast as you can; this is an entirely different pedagogy that takes some getting used to. This class focuses on people and identities that have been intentionally and systematically erased from institutional history. This means that rather than lectures full of "facts," this class is more concerned with stories, people, and holding space for individual accounts and emotions. Yes, this meant that class was sometimes not as exciting as professors whose every lecture is like a TED talk, but I believe it was a super valuable change of pace that requires active participation (choosing to dig deeper and be thoughtful) than passive learning through transcribing what the professor says. At any rate, this class deals with extremely challenging topics, and I think Professor Miles' approach was the most humane I could imagine. This is definitely not for everyone, but if you appreciate less traditional methods of history and the chance to produce something creative as a final project, then you should take this class!

Professor Eatmon's teaching was incredible. It never felt like she was just lecturing rather she was promoting discussions. She exhibited great intellect in the subject matter and always encouraged students to delve deeper. A great professor who I am honored to have met and learn from. Materials were carefully curated to ensure amazing discussions. It was evident that a lot of thought and consideration was placed on the materials. Professor Eatmon gave amazing feedback and even adjusted classes accordingly in accordance to the class' feedback to improve everyone's learning experience. The material and lectures were incredible. I would highly, highly recommend taking this course if you are even interested in this subject.

This is a really great course. The professor is a great lecturer and both the TF and professor were accessible if you had extra questions. I think the readings can sometimes seem overwhelming. Try to get through as many as you can, but don't sweat if you can't read all of them. Also, although the major assignments are lengthy, they're spread out very nicely so this class was never a great point of stress for me — and both the writing projects are creative which makes them more fun than traditional essays in other courses.
subject: History

best_comment: It's really good! The teaching staff is super accessible and very passionate about the course, and the tests aren't painful (just study). There is a chunky amount of reading (a few 13+ readings per class and one longer reading for section), but it supplements the very engaging lectures and section. I would definitely recommend going to the writing center or the history department writing staff for the 2 papers that you do (both of which are 2 pages, very short), or you can send outlines to the TFs (I found this very helpful, wish I used this for the first essay). If you enjoy Classical or medieval history, I would definitely recommend this course!
worse_comment: TF can be brutal and its a lot of dense readings

best_comment: This is a great class if you are interested in Southeast Asia! It is such an understudied region, especially at Harvard, but is so rich with history. It is a sweeping class that covers a diverse and complex region but I think it was fantastic at teaching not just SEA history but global history. SEA is really a crucible and a proxy for international trends. It's the seat of colonial conflict (e.g., British vs Burmese), imperial competition (e.g., French vs. British vs. Dutch scrambling for SEA), and crucial historical concepts (e.g., imperialism, anti–colonialism, militarism etc.). I wish it spent more time on contemporary era – it is mostly 1800–1950, with a big focus on the transition from pre–colonial to colonial to post–colonial states. There are so many links with South Asian and East Asian History so if you study either of those regions, I HIGHLY recommend taking this class. It'll contextualise so much of what is happening inside those regions too. Also SEA history is very helpful if you study Buddhism.It's not too difficult – I would say a regular history class. Of course, lots of readings, most of which is fairly dry textbook stuff, but once you transcend the names and dates (of which there are a ton), the concepts are pretty cool. If you do all the readings and pay attention in class, you should be good.
worse_comment: Not as "modern" of history as the course title would suggest. over 500 years are covered and no single topic is thoroughly discusses as the amount of topical subject matter is too broad across time and geographical space. Good as an introductory course, but not as valuable for deep analysis of any specific topic.

course_title: Postwar or Postcolonial Germany: The Three Germanies after 1945 01
best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. Although it was my first history class in college, I found the lectures, readings, and sections extremely interesting and engaging. Professor Spreen was an awesome lecturer. He presented post–war German history in a way that was historical mindful, but always with a unique and eye–opening lens towards current events. He was also very interactive and organized in terms of clearly laying out what information to prioritize for assessments. The readings were manageable and very applicable for the key concepts of the course. The lectures also happened to be quite small (6–10 people), allowing each student to get to know the material and professor in a way that was unique from other humanities courses. Additionally, although the quizzes seemed daunting before I enrolled in the class, they were extremely manageable as long as you payed attention to lecture. Overall, I would absolutely recommend this class for anyone with even a slight interest in modern Western history.
worse_comment: I would highly recommend this course. There is a moderate amount of reading, but the expectations are stated from the beginning and there is no effort on the teaching staff to “pull fast ones” on you.
subject: History

course_title: Reasoning from the Past: Applied History and Decision Making 01
best_comment: This class is wonderful! Lectures especially are fantastic. Professor Logevall is a fantastic teacher, and he brings in a bunch of amazing guests. I would guess there were 5–6 guest lectures throughout the semester and they were all really nice. Reading is often fun, although there's a decent amount (anywhere between 100–250 pages a week). Assignments aren't difficult, and the environment is generally laid back. For an undergrad, it can seem a bit intimidating, because the class is filled mostly with Grad students and Fellows. But Professor Logevall does a great job including undergrads in discussions and making them feel welcome. Really, if it seems even slightly interesting, I highly recommend.
worse_comment: This class is easy but pretty boring; was ill designed as it moved last minute from seminar to lecture format.
subject: History

course_title: The Great Migration: The Exodus that Transformed Black America and the United States 01
best_comment: I enjoyed this class! It's hard to generalize because this was a lecture with like eight people, but this class was a great history lecture. Of the ones I've taken this one was the right level of specificity that made it interesting while still super applicable to my other classes.

I have some mixed feelings about this class. On the one hand, Professor Gordon is truly such a great teacher. His lectures are really well organized (he has a handout every lecture with an outline of the lecture which helps you follow along) and really clear (no small feat given the difficulty of the readings). You come away from each lecture with a clear idea of what you are supposed to have learned, and you come away from the class with a clear understanding of the arc of Hegel and Marx's work and the major themes and ideas that you should take away from the class. The essays are extremely manageable, and you get good feedback on them. Section discussions can be enlightening and help you understand major questions and ideas better. If you take this class you will become a much better reader, potentially a better writer, and you will have a much much better understanding of Hegel and Marx's ideas and how they fit into a particular kind of thought. That being said, I do want to warn about a few things. For one, the readings are hard. It may take you like five minutes to read a single page of Hegel at times (if not longer). At times you might feel too stupid for this class. You will probably be very confused at times. But going through this is precisely the process that will make you learn a lot in this class. If you don't want to put in the time for that, though, this class is probably not for you. I will also say that the readings are almost exactly ordered to go from the hardest reading to the easiest reading, so do keep that in mind if the first few weeks are hard. (The Science of Logic is practically unintelligible, Phenomenology of Spirit is not much better, but after that the readings get easier and you get better at them/ get a feel for it. And Marx is not too hard to read, though you still have read attentively.) The other thing is the people in this class. The class was mostly white people and mostly white men. I don't know if that was just a quirk of this year, but my section was about 2/3 white men ––– there were only a few women/ POC. There were also some people in the class who had a lot of experience reading theory/ philosophy, and had already read these works in particular, which was kind of intimidating at first in section (some of them made smart, insightful comments and some of them just tried to show off). However, I would say that for the most part section discussions were really interesting, fulfilling, and accessible (Hegel is hard and so he is a great equalizer). So, if you feel intimidated in the first few weeks of class that is totally valid, but chances are you can handle this class! Personally I am really glad that I stuck with the course. But do be aware that at times the vibes might be bad.
worse_comment: Too hard :(

best_comment: This is a solid course if you're interested in Latin American history, need to do your distribution requirement, aren't a History concentrator, are a History concentrator etc. I took it for my History concentration international history requirement as a sophomore and liked it but it was probably my least favorite history class I've taken so far, partly because it's an intro and intros are always more broad/similar vibes to HS history courses with big overviews overtime. The course is really really broad – it is technically Modern Latin American history, but you focus a good amount on the colonial period and 19th century history, so it's really a massive overview. This means we didn't talk about some countries, talked about some a lot more than others, focused primarily on political and economic history, and were focused mostly on drawing connections across the region. It's definitely flawed for this reason, but it's an accessible intro course. Work load wise I was almost never able to do the main 50 pages of reading but the only readings you needed for sections were the primary source docs which were usually a total of 20 pages which wasn't too bad. The midterm was tough because you're really pressed for time, but the final was doable because you got a full 3 hours with a pretty similar test structure. Prof. Weld is the highlight of this course – I honestly would take it just to take a class with her if you're on the fence. She is a really cool prof and great lecturer who had me engaged almost every class and is insanely knowledgable. Lucas is honestly a pretty meh TF in my opinion (sections were just kinda bland, not a ton of discussion), but he is nice to meet one–on–one with if you need help with the paper. Overall – I don't regret my choice to take this class, but it's not totally perfect. I heard in the past it was better when it was a bit more focused (it used to be Latin American and its history with the U.S.) and with a different TF, but even if they changed nothing with the course I still think it's very valuable – I learned a TON, got to take a class with Prof. Weld, and the research paper (although its a painful 10 pg of research for those of us burnt out from writing papers) is a really cool way to learn more in depth about anything you're interested in.
worse_comment: You really learn a lot about LatAm's history, culture, and struggles — and a lot about US history too that isn't always told or said outright. The lectures contain a lot of information and sometimes you can't go super in depth into a topic, which can be frustrated, but you'll always feel like you're coming away from lecture with something. The class has a moderate amount of work (readings, a midterm) and can get a little overwhelming towards the end, but usually the focus is just on learning. (Also, section doesn't make or break the class but I would check out the TF before taking.)

course_title: East Asian Environments: China, Japan, Korea 01
best_comment: If/when it's offered again in the future, this course will likely look a good deal different than when I'm writing this review. That said, Prof. Miller and Camden were both excellent course leaders; given their skill, passion, and kindness, and the importance of the material they teach, I really could not recommend this class enough. It's not too much work, and it'll genuinely challenge you to think in new ways about history, environments, politics, and stories.

course_title: The Ottoman Empire and the World, part one: ca.1000-1550 01
best_comment: Definitely take this course if you want to learn about an empire traditionally eluded from western historical memory, which is incredibly rich in culture and history. Professor Kafadar and his expertise are inspiring!

course_title: Nationalism, Political Independence, and Economic Development in Africa 01
best_comment: This class is fantastic! Professor Akyeampong is so deeply knowledgeable about the topics that you cover, and it's a great mix of history and other relevant fields from time to time, such as economics or anthropology. You really are able to engage with material that is not often taught in other classes, and it also provided a great variety of perspectives on the same events.

Definitely take this class if you are a museum person or think about monuments and their role in society. Like any good history class, it leaves you with more questions than answers but it is really challenging intellectually and that is very important. Definitely skewed towards department people but don't have to be a history person to be successful. Also Professor Weld is one of the smartest and (lowkey) funniest instructors I've ever had. Sometimes it was hard  for me to keep pace with her, but it was definitely rewarding when I pushed myself to meet her level. One of the best in the department in my opinion.

This is one of the most incredible courses I've taken. You learn so much very quickly; I think in one week of this course I learned more than I did a semester in high school or even in my history course at Harvard I took prior. There are a lot of readings and if you don't have knowledge already on Soviet history, expect that this class will consume a lot of your life. I spent almost all of Friday–Sunday just focused on this course and really understanding the readings with a lot of annotations. The weekly one page papers are really fun to write and allow you to connect your personal interests to the topics. If you take this course, be prepared for an active discussion in the class with a lot of counter factuals and thinking on your feet. The readings are a lot––200–300 pages of very dense sources, about 7 primary sources and 7 secondary source excerpts each week. You cover a lot of material across a lot of lenses, but all of it is focused on a single policy of the Soviet government––the nationalities policy. You will thoroughly understand this policy, but it is a singular policy, so I would recommend this class if you are the person who likes to go into depth into one topic. Every reading came back to this policy. However, you will cover political, literary, cultural, linguistic, art history lenses of this policy so you will learn to speak to a lot of disciplines.There is a 5 page book report and oral presentation which gives a lot of good practice in verbal communication. Professor Martin has vey high expectations that he will hold you to. It was roughly half undergrad/grad. He reads your work very very carefully and provides specific feedback that helps you grow as a historian, writer, and presenter, but as such, be prepared to put a lot into this class, as he will expect that and demand that, but you will get a lot out. There is a roughly 15 page paper for a final which is very flexible and illustrates how you will get to pursue your interests in this class. You will speak with him 1:1 and he is very responsive to make sure that you are set up for success and have enough access to resources. but all of these require a lot of proactivity and initiative! I even emailed him about something he casually mentioned in class and he gave me databases and resources to explore on my own. This class requires you to have a genuine enthusiasm and interest to drive that proactivity!!In short, I highly recommend this class, but you have to have a strong love of the subject matter and learning. Professor Martin is my favorite professor so far and puts a lot into this class and will ensure you grow as a scholar. I am very grateful for every moment of this class which I will treasure and I expect this class to have formed some of the most special moments of my undergraduate career.

course_title: Eastern Europe: Peoples and Empires: Proseminar 01
best_comment: While this class is quite a bit of work (you have to read a book a week essentially), I would recommend it with enthusiasm! Prof. Plokhii is a wonderful professor and person, and the course content is great for getting a broad overview of Eastern European history. Given the format and structure, I was able to learn a lot in this class.

This is a graduate course. As a undergrad, you should probably only take this class if you have a requisite background (which will probably look like having taken Social studies 10a/10b and/or some Continental philosophy classes). Know that your final paper will be completely self–directed.That being said,  I loved this class. Readings were eclectic but all tied back into to each other in some way. We read philosophy/theory texts but also hybrid works of sociology, history, etc...  Hannah Arendt's Lectures on Kant's Political Philosophy changed my life. It's a good, good time.

I learned a lot about British influence on American constitutional law. This is an Atlantic course and a course focused on elites, so keep that in mind. It is a great course for what it is. But I would recommend it for people interested in how politicians and elites created constitutions and law. Also a lot of discussion on present politics, which could be interesting to some but less appealing to others.
subject: History

best_comment: I learned a lot about British influence on American constitutional law. This is an Atlantic course and a course focused on elites, so keep that in mind. It is a great course for what it is. But I would recommend it for people interested in how politicians and elites created constitutions and law. Also a lot of discussion on present politics, which could be interesting to some but less appealing to others.
subject: History

course_title: Readings in the U.S. in the 20th Century: Proseminar 01
The Constitution in American History: Seminar 01
best_comment: Prepare yourself for one of the most disappointing experiences to be had within the Faculty of Arts and Sciences thus far. In this course, it became evident that many students had developed the university’s broader penchant for embracing post–modern notions of meaningless discourse, leading to frustrating discussions that left one questioning the purpose and coherence of the subject matter (ostensibly, “the Constitution”) at hand. If this course is emblematic of what most humanities courses at Harvard are like, I am seriously worried.Throughout the course, it was not uncommon to find ourselves immersed in extended recursive conversations that seemed detached from reality, centering around abstract concepts such as the very definition of a “foundation” or the supposed distinctiveness of the “current constitutional project.” These discussions often meandered aimlessly, lacking the intellectual rigor and substantive depth one would expect from a graduate–level course. It appeared as though the professors themselves were unprepared, as they were the ones posing such abstract questions in the first place in order to start the class. This decision allowed for a disorganized and fragmented learning experience. (They alleged that this was done purposely, in order to allow them to exist as mere facilitators of student–led conversation; not only do I not buy this claim, but I also think it’s a bad idea in a course full of pompous twenty–something–year olds who each all believe that they alone can solve all of America’s problems in one fell constitutional swoop.)One memorable class session on "progressive constitutionalism today" epitomized the prevailing atmosphere of intellectual obfuscation. The typical question posed to the class, "What about this time – is this constitutional moment different?" elicited unanimous agreement, with students hastily citing examples of increasing election denialism or the shifting post–2016 political landscape. However, as the conversation unfolded, it became increasingly clear that the students' contributions lacked meaning and coherence. Sentences were uttered that seemed divorced from any discernible purpose, with individuals veering off–topic and questioning the relevance of discussing constitutions in the first place. The absurdity reached its peak when one particularly smug student, a repeat offender, proclaimed "I think we are talking about democracy, not constitutions!" followed by – I kid you not – a personal anecdote about his conservative parents from Texas. The professors responded with smiles, seemingly amused by the discordant nature of the discourse.These instances exemplify a pervasive sense of intellectual aimlessness throughout the seminar, leaving one to end the semester pondering the value and direction of the course. The students' inclination toward Foucauldian–like thought replaced any attempt or pretense at substantive legal analysis, leading to a brutal twelve weeks devoid of meaning and purpose. In retrospect, it is disheartening to consider how a course at HLS, supposedly renowned for its academic rigor, could devolve into a realm where discussions are characterized by incoherence. Your time at the various schools within the broader Harvard University umbrella is valuable; I strongly urge prospective students to invest their studies and valuable time elsewhere, and not on this course.
