Ajantha and Vince are phenomenal interlocutors! Be prepared to read a solid amount. The direction of the discussion will really depend on the students in the class and their willingness to chime in, but even listening to the professors work something out is interesting!

Ajantha and Vince are phenomenal interlocutors! Be prepared to read a solid amount. The direction of the discussion will really depend on the students in the class and their willingness to chime in, but even listening to the professors work something out is interesting!

A wonderful course led by some of the most prominent historians in the field of Global History. The opportunity to discuss readings and debates in the field alongside other students and postdocs whose specialties span every continent was truly invaluable.
subject: History

best_comment: A wonderful course led by some of the most prominent historians in the field of Global History. The opportunity to discuss readings and debates in the field alongside other students and postdocs whose specialties span every continent was truly invaluable.
subject: History

course_title: Colloquium on Teaching and Professional Practices 001
best_comment: This is a useful course that enables students to develop effective teaching strategies along with other History Ph.D. students. It provides a space in which one can reflect honestly about positive experiences that one has had while teaching and some of the difficulties that one is encountering in the classroom. Most of the assignments are really helpful and are geared toward helping one better one's teaching skills and prepare for a future career in academia.
subject: History

best_comment: The early part of the course on American Studies writing was by far my favorite/most engaging part of the course, and I feel like I really learned a lot. I really didn't like the guest lecture structure of the course –– the guests were great, but there were too many of them and the course ended up feeling a little incoherent. I understand that it was meant to be an American Studies taste–tester, but it felt like we went through too many subjects too rapidly without ever really delving deeply into any of them, and we didn't engage much with course material in sections, which exacerbated the feeling of going too fast without real coherence. I actually found the early parts of the class where we were studying American Studies historiography –– the history of the field itself –– the most interesting part of the course. I think any class should be teaching something that it is better at teaching than any other class can teach it, and a taste test of each subfield of American Studies is never gonna be as good as each subfield's full dish. This class would play better to its strengths if it really centered more around the question of defining American Studies and practicing it, rather than sitting through long lectures that offer minimal participation in a big room with a new professor each time. I think it should be smaller (and maybe have a cap of ~25) to enforce attendance and participation –– I and lots of others stopped really wanting to attend, and I never felt like I learned anything particularly new in section that I couldn't have learned in lecture; the TF didn't really guide conversation or asked questions that prompted discussion. Everyone was very kind and well intentioned but I think the class needs significant restructuring/refocusing –– mostly sad because the first two weeks were great and I was SO excited for the class (and some of the writing prompts were incredible) but we rarely received feedback on writing (in a class that was structured around writing) and so I felt pretty disengaged by the end.
worse_comment: Professor Deloria is very kind and charismatic, but the course is a mess. It is way too broad and many of the lectures seem irrelevant or disconnected from what we're learning about. We get very little guidance for the assignments and the feedback is very limited and basic.
subject: History & Literature

course_title: God Save the Queen! Ruling Women from Rome to the Renaissance 001
best_comment: Make sure to do readings to be able to participate in section discussions. This classes workload varies week to week. Some weeks there is only readings for in class discussions while other weeks we would have to prepare for in class discussions, finish a draft for a blog post and do some kind of work towards our final project. Overall the work was definitely manageable. The work was very rewarding. The class content is sooo interesting and I'm so happy I took this class. If possible I will be taking more classes with Professor Gilsdorf in the future. He was a great professor! This class is awesome and I highly recommend it.
worse_comment: I think to just be prepared to read a lot and think about historical figures in a way that is not like you do in other classes.

best_comment: Without a doubt, this course is one of the greatest I have ever enrolled in at Harvard. There are four main strengths that come to mind.The greatest strength of HL–90DR was Professor Faust herself. She is an extremely personable, thoughtful, and intelligent professor, and she guided every class conversation in a productive way. Professor Faust made herself very accessible through office hours, and was always willing to provide feedback over email as well. Plus, she has a fascinating collection of stories to share!A second strength of the course consisted of its students, who hailed from a diverse array of "Harvard backgrounds". This made student contributions interesting and eye–opening, and made the class even more enjoyable.A third strength of the course was its syllabus: we covered a very broad and interesting collection of speeches in the course. The opportunity to do so helped us discern nuances between different "genres" of speeches, and to better appreciate oratory as an art.A final strength of the course consisted of its guest speakers. We had the chance to interact with multiple individuals who have an intimate relationship with speech–writing and oratory, and this experience allowed us to learn about public speaking in a more engaging fashion.

TAKE THIS CLASS!The readings/viewings were super engaging and incredibly thought out. Dr. Hogue is an amazing preceptor and leads the classroom conversation in a super interesting and seamless way. The students in the class were extremely engaged in the subject matter which enabled incredibly interesting conversations.
Thomas is a great professor who cares a lot about the subject he is teaching. Make sure to participate in class and to go over the readings! This a great course to take.
worse_comment: If this course is done as a Mindich Engaged Scholarship class, consider avoiding it. The engaged scholarship portion was very disjointed and led to a lot of frustration and confusion. A lot of this class was also built around group work, for which we were given no guidance, no support, and no accountability. It also required sitting through several useless presentations on interviews and website building that were very impractical for the work we were doing and limited our ability to engage with other students and the very interesting course materials put together by the professor. I would highly recommend this class based on its syllabus alone, but the actual execution of the "engaged scholarship" portion of this class was troublesome.

best_comment: If your'e in the humanities at Harvard (particularly in History & Literature), you absolutely need to take a class with Tommy. He's one of the most amazing, intelligent, and kind professors I've ever had while at Harvard and I would not be the scholar I am today without his support and guidance.
worse_comment: Tommy is a gem of a professor <3 Makes you want to do the work because I would rather die than disappoint Tommy.

best_comment: If you have an interest in Native history, incarceration/carcerality/carceral logic, or both, I really recommend you take this course. This course can be a bit tough to wrap your head around at times, as you're dealing with abstract concepts frequently, like what is "carceral" or what is an "empire," but if you like to have these types of complex discussions fueled by interesting and diverse course materials (such as art pieces, books, journal articles, etc), you will love this course.

TAKE THIS CLASS. This was easily my favorite course of the semester. Lauren and Steve are amazing professors who always know exactly what to say to keep the conversation flowing. They are also super kind and understanding, and created such a stress–free environment without compromising high–quality discussion. I had never had an opportunity to learn about the 80s and 90s, so this was great, in addition to the fact that the culture wars are still currently raging around us and learning about their origins was both upsetting and fascinating. We read amazing books, watched amazing movies, and had amazing discussions, every single week without fail. Imagine 2 hours of riveting discussion with no dead space or awkward pauses. This fantasy can be yours if you take this class! Perhaps part of that was a particularly engaged group of students, but I will say that a lot of it was also definitely due to exceptional course materials and the deft guidance of our professors. As a Hist–Lit concentrator,  I can say this is some of the best Hist–Lit has to offer: the best Hist, the best Lit, and the best of both worlds. While this class is not a gem, and you should be prepared to work pretty hard, it is rewarding, interesting, and fun. I unequivocally recommend this course.

TAKE THIS CLASS. This was easily my favorite course of the semester. Lauren and Steve are amazing professors who always know exactly what to say to keep the conversation flowing. They are also super kind and understanding, and created such a stress–free environment without compromising high–quality discussion. I had never had an opportunity to learn about the 80s and 90s, so this was great, in addition to the fact that the culture wars are still currently raging around us and learning about their origins was both upsetting and fascinating. While this class is not a gem, and you should be prepared to work pretty hard, it is rewarding, interesting, and fun. I unequivocally recommend this course.

great class, especially for a senior! highly recommend!! I took it pass fail so that I wouldn't have to worry about the final, which I didn't, but looking back would have been better to take it for a grade, as it would have been an easy A if I had studied for like a day before the final! gem, definitely take it!!! also super interesting material
worse_comment: The lectures are boring. The section is particularly bad , and not just my own from what I've heard. It is not the section leader's fault, but the questions are just not engaging and the way it is structured is dreadfully boring. Also, there is an absurd amount of memorization for this class's final and midterm – it is unclear why we have to memorize over 300 specific dates, names, and definitions.
best_gem_comment: great class, especially for a senior! highly recommend!! I took it pass fail so that I wouldn't have to worry about the final, which I didn't, but looking back would have been better to take it for a grade, as it would have been an easy A if I had studied for like a day before the final! gem, definitely take it!!! also super interesting material
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: The syllabus makes this seem more like a history class, but it is definitely an art history class. Take this if you are more interested in art, ideally already with an understanding of the history, than if you want to learn the basics of late antique history.
worse_comment: The grading of the midterm is completely arbitrary. The prof told us she was disappointed with our performance on it and graded us all extremely harshly even though I know my classmates and I spent an outrageous amt of time preparing for it and were very confident even right after the test. She did not give clear instructions for the exam beforehand and then got upset when we answered questions the way we were instructed to on the sheet. Such a disappointing and cruel introductory class to HAA. Made me lose all passion for Roman art.

best_comment: I recently had the privilege of attending a course on Japanese architecture, instructed by the erudite Harvard professor Yukio Lippit. The course delved into the intricate details and historical contexts of iconic structures such as the Ise Shrine, Katsura Villa, and Himeji Castle.Professor Lippit's eloquent presentational style is both engaging and informative. He adeptly elucidates complex architectural concepts, historical underpinnings, and cultural subtleties, creating a vivid tapestry of pre–modern Japanese architecture. His evident passion for the subject matter infuses each lecture, fostering a stimulating learning environment.The course content offers a comprehensive examination of pre–modern Japanese architecture. Students probe the cultural, religious, and aesthetic foundations of these renowned structures, gaining valuable insights into their significance and the mastery of their designA distinguishing feature of the course is the thoughtful selection of field trips orchestrated by Professor Lippit. Students are afforded the opportunity to examine two local architectural gems: the Machiya at Boston Children's Museum and the Harvard teahouse. These visits serve to contextualize and reinforce the knowledge acquired in the classroom, allowing students to appreciate the craftsmanship and architectural nuances firsthand.In summation, this course presents an enlightening and enriching foray into the world of Japanese design, history, and culture. Through his refined presentational skills, well–structured content, and astute selection of field trips, this course stands as an invaluable experience for those interested in architecture and Japanese design.
worse_comment: standard art history class. focus on very old Japanese architecture, may find boring if not very interested in subject

best_comment: This is one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard. Prof. Hamburger has an encyclopedic knowledge of Gothic architecture and the passion to match. You will learn so much about Gothic architecture and the broader art–historical sweep through Modernism in an accessible and entertaining fashion. The TF, Nora, is also so sweet and a fantastic section leader. I have nothing bad to say about this class. It has been just a joy to learn from them both. They also provide ample feedback on all your assignments so you are always improving throughout the course of the semester. I would recommend this course to anyone, and I would give it my highest recommendation even if it didn't have the fantastic Paris trip at the end to boot!

I never thought I could learn so much from coins, but this was the most comprehensive history class overall that I have taken. The professor is so passionate and kind. The assignments allow you to gain a deeper understanding of the material, but in an easy way. The lectures are so interesting, and you can tell the entire teaching staff wants you to succeed.
best_gem_comment: Take this class!! It is such a gem with the most passionate teaching team I have had in all 4 years at Harvard! The work load is very light (just a discussion post due every week) and section is really cool you get to go look at old coins (and hold them!) 100% gem and it is a really interesting topic that will likely fit in nicely with many econ and history classes

best_comment: This class taught me a lot about model–making and architecture as an applied art and it was nice to be doing something hands–on with very few constraints. That being said, the expectations for me often felt kind of unclear, I felt that some criticism of my work, while helpful, was unfair given my experience and the assignment constraints, and I felt pressure to pursue creative directions my TFs were personally interested in that I wasn't so that I would receive a better grade, even if I was personally less satisfied with my work.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Highly recommend the course if you're looking for a creative outlet and want to improve as an architect, and you have the time for late night model assembly! It's quite a bit of work but as someone who enjoys working with my hands, it's really fun and fulfilling, and you'll grow a lot and get a taste for more realistic architectural design. Be upfront with the TFs if something comes up and you can't get the deliverables in; they're very willing to work with you.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: Take this class––I am not an HAA concentrator and I LOVED it, now I'm considering a joint/secondary. Rachel is an incredible TF who is really supportive and helpful and leads great discussions. She clearly cares about her students and wanted us to succeed and learn. I learned so much, and the class isn't stressful. It's so awesome to hear from so many different HAA professors and learn about what they study. Now I have a sense of more HAA classes that I want to take. I highly recommend this class! Each class was different and super cool.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: IF KAMILA IS TEACHING THIS CLASS, TAKE IT. I have NEVER had an instructor this incredibly engaging and welcoming and knowledgeable for a department tutorial. I am actually SAD to have to be done with this course, and wish I could go back. Take this class if you want to come away with a different understanding of the depth and layered complexity of art historical writing. You WILL learn in this course, and you will enjoy doing so. It was amazing

I recommend finding a great topic that you are passionate about. If not the thesis will feel like a burden. The department does a great job providing support in the fall. The thesis experience will vary a lot depending on your advisor. Some are better at providing feedback and returning emails then others.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: best class ever. i wish i could take it again next year!! the readings and lectures are super interesting (professor roxburgh is great!) and the structure of the class is such that you end up becoming good friends with ur classmates. plus, free trip!
worse_comment: To be completely honest: the excursion makes up for the lacking structural, community, and organization of the course component of the course. The excursion is highly experiential, exciting, and well–planned—and it’s during the excursion that you really get to know your classmates and professors’ thoughts and arguments. During the actual classes during semester, this class is so uninspired and long — the lecture format often is just one professor reading slides at us, and the homework assignments revolve around group presentations and short papers in which you barely have the space to really dig into material, or the time to get to work with your group members on really understanding the area you are assigned. Take this course for an incredible, unforgettable, magical excursion experience, but be warned that the semester class experience is borderline awful.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: best class ever. i wish i could take it again next year!! the readings and lectures are super interesting (professor roxburgh is great!) and the structure of the class is such that you end up becoming good friends with ur classmates. plus, free trip!
worse_comment: To be completely honest: the excursion makes up for the lacking structural, community, and organization of the course component of the course. The excursion is highly experiential, exciting, and well–planned—and it’s during the excursion that you really get to know your classmates and professors’ thoughts and arguments. Take this course for an incredible, unforgettable, magical excursion experience, but be warned that the semester class experience is borderline awful.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Beautiful and Sacred: Armenian Book Arts 001
best_comment: Professor Maranci is amazing. Her passion for the work is immediately obvious and commands engagement with the material. After shopping the class for one day I was hooked and I have zero regrets taking a higher level course as an undergrad. Definitely recommend regardless of your background!

course_title: The Birth of the Author: Pictorial Paratexts in the Middle Ages 001
best_comment: This course is incredibly interesting and can change your perspective on Medieval manuscripts. I came into the class not really sure if I had any deep interest in religious manuscripts and their illuminations. But throughout the course, Prof Hamburger really engages everyone in class discussion and the material can be applied to so many topics that are important in writing, history, religion, and art. There is a fair amount of reading in the class and it can be a bit challenging at times, but you don't discuss the readings too often during class. The Houghton Library visits are incredible ways to engage with the material and are also a lot of fun. Overall, a great course!

course_title: Artisanal Modernism & the Labor of Women 001
best_comment: A very rewarding class that gives you a good foundational understanding of many modernist, female artists that are often overlooked. Professor Gough gives you very thorough feedback and spaces out the work for the final paper in a very manageable way. I loved seeing the artworks in person each week and Professor Gough also is a wonderfully clear and articulate lecturer.
Great class, with really engaging material and a really kind professor. At times, the grading can be kind of tough but after an office hours or two you should be good to go.
Professor del Real was a fantastic instructor. He created a very collaborative environment where every student supported one another and was very engaged with the work of everybody in the class.

course_title: Architecture, Urbanism, and Design in a Global South Asia: 18th century to the present 001
best_comment: If you are ready to engage with the readings then you will not regret taking this course. The syllabus is so comprehensive and well structured and Vishal is one of the most supportive and attentive instructors I’ve had at Harvard. For the final paper, he is extremely open to a vast range of topics that his students find inspiring and will provide so much support in helping his students find a topic they are passionate about if they don’t know exactly what they want to focus on.

I would tell students this is a great class because you get to visit museums + be creative. I spent a ton of time on the final paper + presentation for this class because I was so excited to get to have a creative prompt and design a museum. It was fun to plan it out and present it. Professor Blier is super encouraging which creates a great environment for learning, discussing topics, and presenting.

course_title: Topics in Northern Renaissance and Baroque Art 001
best_comment: I would tell future students that this is a good course to take if they are looking for a measure of creative freedom with their research projects. Professor Koerner is very good at fostering creative approaches to writing.

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: this is such an incredible course an opportunity to study the harvard art museums' collections which are vast and rich. makeda and mary are the best, so knowledgable, so kind, but they are both leaving. i hope this class continues to be taught in the future and while i can vouch for the art i cannot vouch for future professors. i loved all the meetings with different museum professionals, artists, etc. we got to go to the pigment lab! the conservation lab! very good to get a view into what different museum professions are like as well, which is part of why i personally took this class. highly recommend, so glad i took it, i really hope it continues to be taught
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: The Object in the Art Museum 001
best_comment: this is such an incredible course an opportunity to study the harvard art museums' collections which are vast and rich. makeda and mary are the best, so knowledgable, so kind, but they are both leaving. i hope this class continues to be taught in the future and while i can vouch for the art i cannot vouch for future professors. i loved all the meetings with different museum professionals, artists, etc. we got to go to the pigment lab! the conservation lab! very good to get a view into what different museum professions are like as well, which is part of why i personally took this class. highly recommend, so glad i took it, i really hope it continues to be taught
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Colonial Art of Mexico and the Andes 001
best_comment: This is a great and informative course. If this is in your cart, you should definitely enroll and experience taking class with Professor Cummins. He is wise beyond conception and you will leave the class with so much knowledge.

course_title: Works of Art: Materials, Forms, Histories 001
best_comment: You will gain insight into the key issues animating the field.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: This class is overall pretty interesting. Assignments aren't bad, but they can seem overwhelming with the amount of freedom you have to choose. Overall you will learn a lot of exciting material, so try to engage with it the best you can. The course instructors, Professor Harrington and Professor Labonte, are so sweet and helpful. I'm really lucky that I got to work with them this semester.
worse_comment: This class covers a wide variety of different topics; however, there is a lack of structure and overarching frameworks that makes the class somewhat difficult to understand.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: This class is overall pretty interesting. Assignments aren't bad, but they can seem overwhelming with the amount of freedom you have to choose. Overall you will learn a lot of exciting material, so try to engage with it the best you can. The course instructors, Professor Harrington and Professor Labonte, are so sweet and helpful. I'm really lucky that I got to work with them this semester.
worse_comment: This class covers a wide variety of different topics; however, there is a lack of structure and overarching frameworks that makes the class somewhat difficult to understand.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: There is a limit to how good a sophomore tutorial can be, and this one is ok. It's not too much work or too hard, and during the working like a historian weeks you often don't have to go to class which is really nice. The sharing sessions are really chill, as are the presentations. The written assignments can be graded pretty strictly but my TF gave really good (actionable!) feedback which I felt like improved my writing/ understanding of history over the course of the semester. I do kind of wish I emerged from the tutorial understanding the major works/ ideas in hist sci better, but the course is not really trying to do that. Don't expect this course to be the highlight of your semester or anything, but it's not bad either.
worse_comment: This course is required for hist sci but can be very disorganized at times and sometimes the materials are boring
subject: History of Science

best_comment: There is a limit to how good a sophomore tutorial can be, and this one is ok. It's not too much work or too hard, and during the working like a historian weeks you often don't have to go to class which is really nice. The sharing sessions are really chill, as are the presentations. The written assignments can be graded pretty strictly but my TF gave really good (actionable!) feedback which I felt like improved my writing/ understanding of history over the course of the semester. I do kind of wish I emerged from the tutorial understanding the major works/ ideas in hist sci better, but the course is not really trying to do that. Don't expect this course to be the highlight of your semester or anything, but it's not bad either.
worse_comment: This course is required for hist sci but can be very disorganized at times and sometimes the materials are boring
subject: History of Science

best_comment: This class is required, so you'll have to take it as a History of Science student, but the instruction is great. The expectations for assignments is clear and the support available from the teaching staff is wonderful. I always felt like I was being set up for success and had the tools necessary to complete the various portions of the research and writing process. Overall, this course felt worthwhile and beneficial to my education. If you stay on top of the deadlines and ask for help when you need it, you'll be in good shape!
subject: History of Science

best_comment: Doing a thesis is hard, so make sure it’s something you’re ready for and that you invest a lot of time in, especially during winter break. That being said, Professor Baker and the department are very supportive of you, and the payoff when you finish your thesis is very satisfying, as you’ll have completed long form writing in a unique topic you’re passionate about! Best of luck with the process, I know you can do it!
subject: History of Science

best_comment: You should write a thesis if there is something in the history of science that you are passionate about researching and learning more about. It is a lot of work, so be prepared for that going into it, and make sure you are writing about something that genuinely piques your interest and you are prepared to dedicate the majority of your free time to.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: An absolutely fantastic and interesting course! Understanding how much of the basis of modern science is tied into the military–indunstrial complex of the Cold War is really interesting, and I think important to anyone trying to understand how modern science works (scientists and those on the outside looking in). Professor Wilson is an absolutely fantastic teacher, and one of the most talented moderators of conversations I've ever had the pleasure of taking a class from. He strikes the perfect balance of gently guiding and pushing conversation, while really letting students drive most class conversation.

This is a great class. The topics are fascinating, and you don't need any specific background to learn a lot. Do the readings as thoroughly as possible; it'll only make your reading responses and experience in discussions better. Prof. Wilson is super nice and enthusiastic about the material.

course_title: Water: The Politics and Uncertain Futures of Drought and Climate Change 001
best_comment: Regrettably, this course struggled to provide meaningful engagement or coherence on the subject of “water.” The enterprising nature of the literature we were provided (“Does water have a soul, or a body? Can water transcend physical properties and hold spiritual significance?” Is water truly lifeless?”) hindered the development of meaningful critical discussion and left us students feeling adrift in a sea (pun intended) of fragmented scholarship. If you’re seeking a substantive exploration of water as an undergraduate, perhaps consider alternative educational opportunities outside of the classroom, far away from Harvard, that offer a more coherent and meaningful understanding of environmental issues writ large.In fairness to the wonderful History of Science Department and to the professor, it is worth acknowledging that devoting an entire semester to the study of water poses inherent challenges. There’s only so much you can say about this topic before having to grasp at ideological straws; by the fourth or fifth week, it became increasingly evident to many of us the course was stretching thin and struggling to sustain rigorous analysis. It soon became a running joke for enrollees to figure out what we were going to say next about “the multifaceted nature of water” as we walked into the classroom.
worse_comment: This course was interesting, but it caused a lot of confusion and frustration because of improper communication and disorganization. The professor was unorganized and difficult to reach with questions or concerns, which was a big barrier for me and other students. I relied a lot on communication with my classmates to gain information because the professor was inaccessible and sometimes reacted with irritation when students reached out with questions. The readings, content, and discussion were interesting, but the disorganization made it difficult to enjoy them.

best_comment: Professor Labonte was one of the best teachers I've had at Harvard. Her course was an absolute diamond — the readings were interesting and very accessible, she was kind, and she included so many engaging activities in the lectures. Often, in addition to pair–and–shares, Professor Labonte would include activities where she'd hand out a picture of a graph from part of a crucial research paper in the field and we'd try to determine what the paper was about, or what the figure meant. She always walked around the class to listen in and ask questions to the students who were discussing the paper in groups. Furthermore, her lectures were connected to the readings, but weren't repetitive. I always felt like I was learning something new! At some point, I stopped taking notes in the class, just because I felt like it was so interesting and so engaging that I didn't need the notes to be able to remember all of it. Professor Labonte also emphasized that she was very interested in meeting with students, and meeting with her was always really interesting! During every class, she'd frequently mention that she often "debated" what to put into the lectures, just because there was so much interesting material to share! It was clear that she cared deeply about the course and was very well prepared to teach it. One of the best classes I've taken at Harvard, by far.
worse_comment: This class is INTERESTING. Seriously, I'm MCB, not even HistSci, and I loved this class's material, progression, and curriculum. At the same time, the HistSci concentrators I knew in the class were some of the most active, so it must have been very engaging on multiple fronts, even with my limited academic perspective. The class talks about major events/discoveries/observations/advances I was aware of from an MCB perspective but focuses on the historical and thereby political and/or cultural events that made the history we talk about through the course significant, connected, and relevant to the modern day. If that doesn't sound interesting to you, you're in the wrong place. If that sounds even remotely interesting to you, this should be on the top of your potential class list at the very least, if you didn't already enroll before finishing this review.

best_comment: This is the best class I've taken in the History of Science department by FAR. Joelle is a phenomenal lecturer, take this class for her honestly. The readings and class discussions will definitely push you a bit, but Prof. Abi–Rached creates a super comfortable environment for engagement, so don't feel nervous to speak up during class!

course_title: Mental Health in Crisis: From War Neurosis to Covid-19 001
best_comment: This is a wonderful course and I enjoyed it thoroughly! Each unit is delivered with a lot of care and you can tell that Dr. Abi–Rached has put a lot of effort assembling each set of readings, lecture slides, and the lectures themselves. She presents super interesting topics that you may not have been exposed to before, and the guest speaker line–up was also super fascinating.
worse_comment: The readings and weekly discussion posts are usually interesting and totally manageable. I also think the major assignments were reasonable. Section kinda sucked though. We mostly just talked in a large group for an hour, which wasn't engaging **

course_title: Open Minds, Wired Worlds: Computers and Cyberculture 001
best_comment: Gem.  Hands down.If you ever have a chance to take a course taught by Professor Hersch, do it.  He is a fantastic lecturer, and just a really cool person.The content is just fun to learn about.  People were genuinely interested in attending both lecture and section (thanks to the great discussions facilitated by the head TF, Taylor).  Workload was extremely reasonable: the short papers are indeed pretty short, and the programming assignment is a nice change of pace.  Final exam is super chill as well.
worse_comment: CS majors, if you want to satisfy the Social Sciences divisional distribution, take this course! It's heavily STEM leaning and involves 2 essays, a programming assignment, and a final exam. No weekly problem sets nor midterm.

best_comment: Overall this is a super interesting course to learn about popular science in culture. I personally liked the first half of the material more, but it's always good to have a survey of information. I did like the analytical–style essays as I think this is one of the more useful types of writing and it's fun to be pushed in it. However, grading was very reasonable too.
subject: History of Science

course_title: The Digital Age: Sources and Methods 001
best_comment: Take this course! This is one of the best taught courses I have ever taken at Harvard. Hersch has outstanding depth of knowledge and experience in the field and you can tell he wants to pass down the information as best he can to students. The course does a wonderful job at orienting students in the field to understand canon works and exploring newer issues in the field.
Both professors are really nice and the class provides a great opportunity to think about theoretical questions in sts!
Both professors are really nice and the class provides a great opportunity to think about theoretical questions in sts!

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: Such a fantastic course. Cary is an amazing professor, so knowledgeable on the topic and also facilitates great discussion in such a small class. We have 4 essays throughout the semester and while these are stressful, the grading is tough but very reasonable and the feedback on the essays is helpful, in–depth, and exactly what is needed to continuously improve the quality of the essays. The material overall is actually THE most interesting stuff I have ever learned, maybe this is just because I already liked evolutionary bio but I truly think the info we learn is applicable in a ton of different ways, I retained so much of it, and I understand fully how important it is to learn about how humans evolved in order to efficiently progress.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial in Human Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: Such a fantastic course. Cary is an amazing professor, so knowledgeable on the topic and also facilitates great discussion in such a small class. We have 4 essays throughout the semester and while these are stressful, the grading is tough but very reasonable and the feedback on the essays is helpful, in–depth, and exactly what is needed to continuously improve the quality of the essays. The material overall is actually THE most interesting stuff I have ever learned, maybe this is just because I already liked evolutionary bio but I truly think the info we learn is applicable in a ton of different ways, I retained so much of it, and I understand fully how important it is to learn about how humans evolved in order to efficiently progress.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Research in Human Biomechanics and Physiology 001
best_comment: Take this class if you are at all interested in biological research of any kind!! You get to work on a biomechanics–related project (new territory for me, a mostly–cell–biologist) as a real member of the lab, get involved in the data collection and analysis process, and present findings at the end of the semester (like a real scientist! lol). The troubleshooting process is really rewarding, and you finish the semester feeling like you've truly learned useful, applicable skills. Also a great class for building relationships with more seasoned mentors. Most of the work tends to ramp up toward the end of the semester, when data collection comes to a close and you're analyzing your data and writing up the results, but it's no more taxing than your average class during finals season. No exams, either (always a plus). Ali is amazing and super funny. 110% recommend HEB 1210.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Amazing class with an amazing teacher. Andrew has an awesome way of explaining things and is clearly super knowledgeable about the topics covered in the course. It was awesome to learn from him. He has all his students' best interests in mind and wants them all to learn in a low–stress environment.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Evolution, Anatomy and Physiology of Sleep 001
best_comment: This is a really great class! It is interesting and not too difficult. Jo is a great teacher and really cares about her students.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Please take this class! You will be doing yourself a favor. The course is very relaxed and enjoyable but also purposeful – I feel like you will start to think about human behaviors in a new light (in relation to our evolutionary history). It's very interesting content, and Professor Joyce Benenson is just amazingly sweet and caring.

course_title: The Human Brain in the Animal Kingdom 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class, one of my favorite that I've taken at Harvard! Dr. Hecht is extremely smart, explains complex concepts in clear, easy–to–understand ways, and is very kind/patient. The lectures are fascinating, and the course is very well structured. You will feel well taken care of and able to just sit back and enjoy the material/assignments.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Be warned, this is a HARD class. You absolutely MUST STUDY EVERY WEEK for multiple hours, not just before the exam. I know a lot of professors say this when it isn't really true, but it is true for this course. I did very well in this class and I loved it, which are not unrelated – if you don't actively want to study the material, you will fail the exams, as it is entirely memorization based (I think I memorized about ~800 individual facts for the second exam alone). I got A's on my exams, but I also studied 40+ hours for each, because I genuinely found the material interesting. Also be warned that this class may consume your other courses if you let it, I wouldn't take it concurrently with another high time commitment class. All that aside, this was such an incredible course. I was afraid to take it because of the warnings about the difficult exams, etc. but I am so glad I went for it. I learned so much about the human body and it piqued my interest in a possible medical career. This was easily one of my favorite courses so far at Harvard despite the time commitment. The teaching staff was also incredibly friendly and accessible – every lecture had a nice sense of levity and humor interspersed among the ~70 slides. Also!! Go to at least one cadaver lab, was a super cool experience and less scary than I thought it would be.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Joyce to Homer 001
best_comment: If you survived 10A it makes sense to take 10B. Listen, I was also very frustrated by the end of 10A, even though I came in so excited. But my few friends who dropped 10B and went on the expos track all regret their choice. I say all of them as in every single one of them. I think if you have the impulse to take Hum 10 this class will resonate better than expos. Having said that, the readings are different in the spring (some like it better, some less) but the class definitely goes by a little faster (spring semester does in general). Hum10 made my freshman year more interesting and reading 20+ books is always a plus, so I would say go for it regardless of how this class feels tailored to the top humanities students from prep schools. Teaching staff changes too, and the vibes of the class will be different. You already took 10A, you're almost there, and it gets easier (papers are lighter and you can make a fun creative project!). The final exam is not impossible, and feels the same as 10A, but they may try to make it very cryptic to the point you roll your eyes (it's mostly term identification, passage identification/relevance, and a few short essays, nothing crazy). If I was able to make some hum10 friends and become friends with pulitzer winners, then you also belong here.
worse_comment: This course is absolutely fascinating, but it can be very disheartening to be consistently behind on the readings, something which has happened to me which I know has happened to multiple of my peers.
subject: Humanities

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Joyce to Homer 001

subject: Humanities

best_comment: Please take this class and continue to show interest in the course as you move through it. It is such a great class and Anbo is such a great professor. He brings so much knowledge and personality to the class, especially since it is so early in the morning lol. ASL is such an important language to learn and Harvard needs to recognize this and continue to support the program.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This course is a great continuation of the other ASL courses. It involved more storytelling, which was sometimes difficult but became easier by the end of the year. Anbo is an incredible and encouraging professor, which made the class very enjoyable and engaging.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This course is quite easy but also quite interesting. A lot of the things you do involve analyzing things you might already know (such as sentence structure) through a linguistics perspective, so there are times when you might wonder "why are we learning this," but overall the concepts and skills and you are quite interest and the course did change the way I viewed language. You'll probably love this course if you love learning different languages. The psets are easy (they get a little harder towards the end but still not bad compared to psets in stem classes), but they are actually aligned with the course content and help you learn the material. The "midterm" and "final" are just like the practice ones posted so just do those and you'll be fine. The two projects in the class are overall pretty fun as well (especially the idiolect interview). Prof. Davidson is a super energetic lecturer, though she sometimes goes on tangents during lecture and so lectures don't feel very structured, but it's usually not a problem for your learning. Sections are very useful for learning how to do problems on the pset so you should go (other than the fact that they are mandatory). Overall, I'd strongly recommend this course, whether you're just doing it for the divisional distribution or out of interest.
worse_comment: The class requires very little work normally but PSETs and exams will require you to go to OHs. They do not release answer keys (to anything) so studying is not easy. The lectures are not interesting and everything seems rushed and poorly organized. I took this class as an easy class for my Senior spring and regret it. By far the worst class I ever took at Harvard.
best_gem_comment: Such a gem, you learn a lot, it's super interesting and not too difficult!!
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: If you're a linguistics concentrator this is a good class (you explore two topics in linguistics intensively in two six–week tutorials) but because these topics change every year it depends on how interesting you find them (I definitely liked one more than the other). The TFs are really helpful and knowledgeable about the subject matter. Assignments are usually pretty doable, and if they're unclear the TFs are great at responding to questions. I had a good time and learnt a lot :)
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Write a linguistics thesis only if you need to (essentially for continuing Linguistics postgraduate) or if there is a fascinating topic that you want to spend a year on! The process if long and often grueling, but if you are truly interested and want to learn, it will be worthwhile!
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This is a great introduction into sociolinguistics, both for concentrators and for people who are just interested in the topic from a personal or intellectual perspective. I would recommend starting the final paper early, which will allow you to keep the workload very manageable throughout the semester. Katie is a wonderful instructor who will support you in your interests, whatever they may be. I'd highly recommend anyone who is even remotely interested in linguistics or sociology to take this class!

A very good, clean class about phonology. Does what it says on the tin (which is a lot more than you can say about many classes at this college): the course material is tightly–focused around getting you the tools to understand and further inquire about phonology and phonetics. Dr. Franich is a gifted lecturer, and section is interesting (but maybe not the most useful). The material isn't hard, the workload is moderate (~5h/wk) and you definitely don't need to go to office hours to complete the PSETs or anything. Exams were okay: the midterm was a bit tight timewise but questions were fair, while the exam was a bit rougher than probably intended (Dr. Franich said we would all leave by 2hrs in, we all stayed for the full 3). Not much math at all, so also a great way to fulfill QRD (although that's not why I took it). Good mix of all four years and good opportunity to make friends. Definitely recommend!!

I loved this class so much!!!! It was so so interesting learning about PIE and how branches of Indo–European evolved, and almost every lecture I was fascinated by something new. Prof. Jasanoff's lectures are wonderful –– he is one of the experts in the field on this topic, and presents the material in such an engaging manner, sprinkled in with geography tidbits and historical/cultural information. Oisín's section was also super helpful. My perspective is so much richer now that I've taken this –– it offers so many interesting explanations for phenomena I took for granted!The class is pretty fast–paced and does build on itself, and the material is pretty dense and non–intuitive, so go to lecture and section! You can get by without it for doing the psets, but it'll help a lot for the final and lecture is great regardless so it's definitely worth putting the time in. The psets are unironically fun to do –– they're graded check+/check/check– so as not to be stressful. The final exam is an interesting but incredibly intense 24–hour takehome, and you really need to have understood the material to do a comprehensive job.Overall I think if you are interested in historical linguistics/PIE then this is a great way to learn about it! Genuinely one of the most fun classes I've taken here.
This class is excellent and well worth enrolling in. You will be challenged, but there is ample opportunity for growth.

The exact nature of this course is very instructor dependent (it will probably be a different instructor next time, if this gets taught again). Our instructor did a great job so hopefully if the same curriculum is followed it will still be very good!
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Excellent course! Go for it!Classes may be a bit fast–paced, but the handouts are really clearly written, so I think what is not fully understood in class can be made up by reading handouts after class. I also regret a bit that I initially only cared about the detailed work–out of theories and focused more on understanding handouts in class than the conceptual landscape Gennaro tried to get across. Thus, a little advice could be: either do some preview of handouts so that you don't feel the need to rush through it in class, or just be more relaxed about the handout and focus more on what Gennaro tried to get across (if you choose this, I think going through the handout after class is very important).
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Very worthwhile
subject: Linguistics

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 000
best_comment: Well–structured and great comfortable learning environment. Teachers were extremely effective, helped me pick up the material easily, and it rarely felt stressful
worse_comment: I would tell future students that this class does take a lot of effort and that it is a more difficult course than MA.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 000
best_comment: Well–structured and great comfortable learning environment. Teachers were extremely effective, helped me pick up the material easily, and it rarely felt stressful
worse_comment: I would tell future students that this class does take a lot of effort and that it is a more difficult course than MA.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 001
best_comment: The teaching team is the best. However, if you feel somehow comfortable with calculus I would just take 1a and get it out of the way
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus II 010
best_comment: The tests can sometimes get very overwhelming, especially with other STEM classes. But if you study beforehand, you should feel prepared. The majority of the TFs are very nice, so reach out to them; they are usually willing to set time aside to help you. Go to office hours and get to know other TFs; they are also very willing to help you. This class really does set your foundational math really well and makes you get familiar with the materials compared to other STEM courses.
worse_comment: Ok MA is better than MB. Nothing to do with course head Matt who is an absolute angel or the teaching staff (shoutout shanelle you’re amazing). But! I struggled in this class much more than I did in MA because they switched up the test structure and the PSETS became harder all while the course content also gets harder. But alas, you’re probably taking it because of a course requirement so I’m not gonna say don’t do this math. I think I learned a lot but I caution against not going to class or slacking

best_comment: If you are conflicted between taking this course and a different math course: without a doubt, I'd pick this course. You can always take more math courses later in the future, but this math course will help you get a really strong foundation. Also, the teaching team is AMAZING! If you're looking for more personalized attention, this course gives you a great introduction into getting used to interacting with teaching fellows and course assistants through office hours. Taking this course doesn't mean "you're behind" or you're taking "easy math." It's the smart choice for people who want to take math seriously and actually learn the concepts in–depth. A lot of math concentrators I know actually start out with taking this course.

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences II 001
best_comment: I can not recommend this course enough. Brenden is not only a gem of a professor but a gem of a human as well. He single–handedly saved the reputation of the math department at Harvard for me. I came into the class extremely discouraged because I dropped out of Math 1a beforehand, and I am now leaving the class with a love for math that I've never had before. The projects are fun AND impactful, and it is extremely clear that Brenden and the teaching team were very thoughtful when creating the class. This has been by far my favorite class at Harvard, and I am actually sad that my Math Qa/Qb journey is over.
worse_comment: Be prepared to go to office hours multiple times a week to understand the course concepts because they aren’t explicitly taught in class. You’re expected to complete assignments without having the skills to do so, and then do a series of revisions to actually understand the concepts. The projects are pretty cool, but extremely confusing and frustrating if you have a bad group.

best_comment: I took Math 1A off cycle (my freshman spring) and can't emphasize how much of a difference this made. The course is way less crowded, you get almost a personalized math question center experience (I became friends with the course assistants), office hours are productive and the professor and TF get to know you and your math weaknesses/strengths so well. I heard that Fall 1A can be packed and it is harder to use the support network, so I'd tell you to keep that in mind. Having said that, this class is not easy. It may be way easier for those who took calculus in high school (2/3 of this class tbh), but if you didn't then you might struggle like I did (it had been over a year since my last math class in HS). But struggling doesn't mean failing, and I learned so much with this class –– at certain points I was actually excited about math even though I never saw myself as a math person. Still, the amount of time you spend on this can be intense depending on your background. So make sure you find pset buddies and use the teaching staff to help you (they rotate every semester but Spring 2023 Math 1A had such a great staff). Anyways, if you need to take math you need to, and depending on how much work you're willing to put in, this class will work out even if you were placed in Ma/Mb.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I could not recommend this class enough. It is so incredible!!!PSETs: Super helpful, really focus on these. 3 PSETs can be a bit of work during the week. However, I really enjoyed doing them and I learned a lot just while working through them.Midterms: Pretty fair! Study those practice exams!Final: I like how it was structured.You get a lot of support in this class. TFs are very helpful. MQC is a MUST and is just overall amazing. Amadeus was an EXCELLENT instructor. Seriously, just super super good. As long as you understand your PSETs and work through practice material, you will be all set. I loved this class!!!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This was actually a pretty rewarding experience. Sure, three psets per week is pretty brutal, but the wonderful CAs at math question center and the instructors running office hours are always very helpful. Classes are interactive, so it is easy to stay engaged. The teaching staff is wonderful, and the exams are pretty fair. Overall, it is a grind but I would still recommend this class.

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Even having had integral calculus before, I was a bit nervous when I enrolled in Math 1b, as I had the impression that it was infamous for its difficulty. However, once I got into it, I did not find the course to be significantly more difficult than any other, and it was definitely comparable to Math 1a. Perhaps I just think this because I love math, but although the course certainly challenged me, it did so in all the right ways, and I did not feel as if I spent more time or energy on it than I should have. Even when things did get a bit more difficult, office hours and the MQC were always there. In short, there is no reason to be afraid of this course. The teaching faculty are there to help you succeed, and you will likely gain a fresh appreciation for mathematics through the course, even if you never take another math class.
worse_comment: Take this class!! I've always abhorred math, but Amadeus is such a great professor. If you're hesitant to take MA1b because you're scared by experience in MA1a (like I was), don't be! The sections are informative,  PSETS manageable, and exams actually reflective of the content you've learned.

best_comment: Do not attempt this class alone. This class can be brutal at times, but having a group of friends to work and study with is CRUCIAL, especially since there are 3 PSets a week. I found this course to be WAY BETTER than MATH 1A. The support you are given by the teaching staff is FAR better and new concepts are explained to students with the expectation that...they are actually new to students. Be sure to look over the worksheet answers as they are pretty helpful. The course is very fast–paced, so I would recommend going to EVERY class and learning as much as you can there so that you don't fall behind. I will say, however, that when it comes to tests, this class shows no mercy. They can be pretty rough. There were times when I felt I was very prepared for exams but was quickly humbled by the type of questions that were asked. Study hard for these.

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Strongly recommend! This was just an awesome course, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. It was a bit difficult, but nothing crazy. Everything we learned felt very important and worthwhile as a person in an increasingly–data–driven world. I had taken some stats before, but didn't really understand what I'd learned... This class was much more applied and helped me consolidate that knowledge, so it's actually helpful for me now in my daily life! MATLAB experience was good, too. I came in with none (but did have a tad bit of coding experience beforehand, nothing stellar...), and I still did OK. There were only a couple problems sets that were MATLAB–heavy, so you'll need to pop into office hours for those if you're weaker there, but it truly wasn't a problem. It was generally a good low–stakes environment to pick up some MATLAB skills, so could be useful if you're taking more MATLAB–intensive courses down the line. The support system was EXCELLENT when I took it– the ratio of staff to students was 1:4. I think the small size of this class is a HUGE advantage and I can't recommend enough taking this class over 21b if you're less math–inclined like I am. I think it gets less into the weeds of linear algebra than 21b, from what I've heard (?), which for me is ideal, as I just wanted enough depth to feel in–the–loop about computational methods I'll use in my work which linear algebra forms the foundation of. The pace was PERFECT for me: enough to be challenging, but never enough that I felt left behind. There are a few tougher lessons than others, but all are highly–manageable, warning is given in advance, and support is bountiful. I love, love, love linear algebra after this course! Everything just made sense!
worse_comment: If you want linear algebra, take 21 or 22. If you want statistics, go take a stats course. This course suffers from significant structural issues, course policies are unfair, and grading is harsh. It is too small of a class with graduate students, making for a terrible class environment. Students (even fellow undergrads) refuse to cooperate and collaborate because they want you to fail (competition for no reason), and there are no practice tests provided for small exams that just punish you for small mistakes. You cannot succeed in this course without having taken linear algebra. Lectures are non traditional and, in my opinion, not conducive to learning. Course materials are outdated, unreadable, and not open on Canvas when you need them for a problem set. Regardless of who is teaching this course, you should avoid this course at all costs.  Harvard should separate 19b from 18b.  It's a shame since 19a was so wonderful. If you took 19a, go take 21.

best_comment: (1) If this is your first math class at Harvard: get an iPad and download GoodNotes! This will be super convenient and helpful for studying/reviewing material later and save you so much time. (2) Do not make the mistake of studying for an exam by simply looking over worksheets/skimming solutions. TRY SOLVING THEM YOURSELF! This will allow you to realize what you're iffy about and will go so far with providing you a conceptual understanding of the topics.(3) GO TO OFFICE HOURS OR MQC––– do Psets there, it will save you so much time, or ask questions about concepts(4) There are LOTS of formulas, have formula sheet with you(5) Make concept maps or have your TFs make concept maps for you – they don't draw connections between concepts they teach, even though this is super important
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a good class to take if you know you will enjoy what is being discussed and it's relevance. As a ec major, this wasn't necessarily the most interesting class, which made studying and psets feel like a chore and I dreaded it a lot more. However, it is an excellently structured class that has really changed with feedback! I personally do like the idea of 3 psets a week, and they are pretty short(most of the time) and it's good at consolidating content before you move on as the class moves incredibly fast. I do personally regret taking the class because it was kind of a waste of time(if you're ec just take math 18 instead, some content in this class feels pretty inapplicable to the ec field and was more STEM). Take it with friends or be ready to make friends! pset buddies are an incredible resource. I also love roderic, he's one of my fav preceptor's I've ever had, super down to earth, funny, and overall truly cares about his students. We literally played a math 21a themed kahoot–style game for our last class as review and celebration. roderic if you see this shoutout to you!!!
worse_comment: If you're interested in math, DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE. Take the 22 series instead. If you're just interested in learning how to do the computations in questions, then take it. But IMO math is more about the logic behind things than busy work. This course, however, is all about busy work. Lecture is practical, they basically don't teach theory or teach it in a "simplified" way. Also, this course meets 4 times a week, the fourth meeting being an absolutely useless "workshop". At least give serious math  (22 / 25) a try before settling for this unengaging course.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I took 21a after taking 1b and 21b, it definitely is easier than both of them. The psets are doable alone, but MQC is your friend and always helps. The class really isn't bad, just make sure to put some time aside to do the psets. Midterm and final were definitely very fair, though I do think off cycle 21a is slightly easier just because the course is smaller in terms of enrollment.

I love math 21a they want you to succeed EVERYONE SHOULD TAKE MATH 21A

best_comment: This course cares way too much about its own pedagogy. It feels to need to justify the way it teaches everything; one problem on a PSET told us to explain a certain concept as if we were talking to a friend, and then included a footnote saying that "studies show teaching a concept to someone else helps you learn it better." No one cares. On the surface, this is just mildly annoying, but it speaks to a deeper issue in the course: they refuse to teach you anything upfront. During every section, the TF will talk for like 5–10 minutes max, and then you spend the rest of the class working though a worksheet that will ultimately help you figure out what the formula–of–the–day is. I get the pedagogical rationale here — by having us try to figure things out on our own, we will hopefully gain a better fundamental understanding of it. But at a certain point, I want you just to teach me! Instead of spending an hour trying to figure this out on my own, you could just tell me what the formula is — explain why it works — and we can call it a day! What's especially frustrating is that this course eschews any attempt to get at a deeper theoretical understanding of what we are doing. You learn (read: teach yourself) one, fairly straightforward concept per section, and that's it. The material is very surface–level yet is also taught very inefficiently. In general, though, aside from these frustrations, the course is pretty good. The material is just generally quite fun — doing things in 3D is cool! The 3 PSETs a week are a total drag but it does drill the material into you. And they're really not very hard most of the time.Still, I'd recommend people take the 22A/B series instead. I took 22A and really wanted to take 22B but wasn't able to because of a silly scheduling issue. Dusty isn't back, so who knows how it will be, but I think that's a much more in–depth, theory–motivated way to go.
subject: Mathematics

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is honestly amazing. It's the right amount of challenging, fun, and enriching, although I would clarify that your experience depends HEAVILY on the quality of your TF and the people in your section. I had an amazing group of people and one of the best TFs (shoutout to Jonier) so I was spoiled; I'm fairly certain the experience wasn't as good for some people in other sections. Regardless, though, the class is an amazing one. The lessons are structured very well, and MQC is built to help you. The TFs and even course heads are very accessible if needed, and the CAs were basically in your shoes a year ago so they're chill and empathetic. The two hardest parts of the class are definitely visualizing in 3 dimensions and being able to conceptualize vectors. If you're able to do both of these things well, you're set.Also, a background in physics is CLUTCH for anything to do with vectors. Didn't know this coming in but I was very blessed.Not much else to say, but if you're looking for a moderate level math but don't want to make math the focus of your semester, this is a fabulous class to take.
worse_comment: This class is so hard and the way it was taught did not agree with me at all. I took Stat 110 and this class was so much harder to learn from and do well in.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: INCREDIBLE INCREDIBLE INCREDIBLE! Math 21a was the highlight of my semester. (This is coming from someone who absolutely dreaded her Math 22a class in the fall). Math 21a has SOOOOO much support – left and right, front and back, at any corner you go. The section style of this class is what makes learning so easy. I learn better with a smaller class size, more opportunity for collaboration, and more face–to–face time with my instructor. There will be 3 Course Assistants in your section all the time, who are eager to help you out.  The CAs are also VERY smart.You only need a decent understanding of high school calculus to do well in this course. They really build you from the ground up and are with you every step of the way. Just don't be afraid to ask questions.Math 21a is so well–organized, and I truly made the best decision switching from the 22 series to the 21 series.You have to take this math series. Period.
worse_comment: This is an extremely difficult course and it is necessary to put a lot of effort and handwork into your studies.

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is very well structured and a fantastic introduction to linear algebra that does not require any prior experience. If you've taken Math 21a, then the overall structure of this course is almost identical. The instructors are enthusiastic and great at explaining concepts; they are also all very knowledgeable about each lesson. The worksheet–based course sections are engaging and can be quite fun if you get an interesting table group. The three psets each week are frequent but manageable. Individual psets typically take longer than those in 21a, so the overall workload of the class is appreciable. But there are plenty of resources from the MQC to office hours to other students to help you through everything; definitely take advantage of these if needed!As a subject, linear algebra and the underlying techniques of dealing with matrices/vectors are very different from multivariable concepts. Nonetheless, this is a very useful and applicable subject; the class does a good job of not only teaching the fundamentals of linear algebra but also introducing the diverse applications ranging from CS to statistics to physics. Overall, this class is very useful, organized, and engaging; and with some time commitment, you can be very successful in this class!
worse_comment: Don't take this unless you have to. Honestly try 22a before this class. It is horrific especially with the 3 psets a week and exams are awful. It is by far one of the worst out of all four math classes (1a–21b) and you will hate yourself and math by the end of it.

best_comment: 21b is a great class, but only if you have the time for it! It is super time consuming with three psets per week, and the exams take a LOT of time to prepare for. Linear algebra is like learning an entirely new language. However, it is a super beautiful language! This is my first time doing not–calculus math in so long, and I ended up really loving the content. While I loved 21b and think anyone can with the amount of resources provided, I think that it is SUPER easy to fall behind, which is dangerous because this class is incredibly cumulative!!!!!!! So TLDR: AMAZING class, but only if you have the time to learn and appreciate it.
worse_comment: Block out a lot of time to do the work, and don't start too late.

best_comment: if you are like me and can do stem but it isn't your 100% comfort zone then you can still take this class but you must respect it and devote a lot of time to itspecific tips: 1. do pre–reading before section, don't skip sections and really use CA's to be sure you understand concepts during class2. do psets first alone then go to office hours/MCQ every single time –– this means making it a big part of your week (devote 2–3 hours 3x/week) 3. go to quiz sessions every single time even though you're tired and have already spent enough time on the class and have better things to do (I wish I had done this)
worse_comment: This was the worst math class I have taken so far at Harvard. They make the material difficult for no reason and the way that concepts are taught is generally poor. The three problem sets a week are incredibly tedious as they make the questions extremely long. The only good thing about this class was the problem set drops.

subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is taught well (as long as you have a good section leader) and structured well. The quiz session pset drop system is great, and there is a TON of support from the course in terms of office hours and MQC. The videos and handouts that are posted are also really great, DEFINITELY WATCH THE VIDEOS IF YOU TAKE THIS CLASS!HOWEVER, this class is SO. MUCH. WORK. It takes over your life because it is 3 psets a week (I would say this class was 70% of my work). Some of the psets genuinely took me 6+ hours to complete. I got very frustrated by this class at times, and by the end, I was incredibly burnt out. When studying for the final, I genuinely started to get a headache every time I looked at a matrix. 3 psets a week really becomes very strenuous towards the end of the semester.Also, the grading is kind of harsh and you have to explain a lot more than you think you do on exams.I wish that this class would relax a little more with the psets, provide videos for every topic (instead of just for some), and just somehow make it a bit less work. If I were to redo the semester, I might take Math 22A instead just to have 1 pset a week instead of 3 (although I'm not sure, because I didn't want to do proofs).
worse_comment: Don't take this class unless you have to. It is not "fun" nor "engaging." The instruction is poor, and I found myself self–teaching the materials with very poor resources to do so. The first few weeks are enjoyable, but don't be fooled: this is a bad class.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: 21B is very organized and I would recommend! For the exams, do the practice midterms and you'll do great.
worse_comment: Get started on the psets early and go to quiz sessions to get those pset drops. My CAs were so critical and anal about grading that my pset grade was hurt often. Give yourself some leeway.

best_comment: This class is awesome! Granted, it is definitely difficult and will require a significant amount of work per week. Exams are challenging and there isn't much partial credit, so definitely be extremely careful on assessments. Despite how tough this class can be, linear algebra is a super interesting subject and sections can be a lot of fun as you and your classmates work through the worksheets. Content can be difficult especially near the end of the course with differential equations/Fourier series, but it is so rewarding to watch your comprehension and grasp of linear algebra grow over time. Have fun and stay diligent!
worse_comment: PSETS are terrible, go to MQC.

best_comment: I actually really enjoyed this class. 3 Psets a week can be much, but go to MQC to get help quick. I did Math21b, CS51, and CS20 this semester, and I still feel like the 3 Psets a week were manageable. Just manage your time well and create a pset group if needed!

best_comment: I would recommend that they put the time in section towards learning the material, since it makes the problem sets much easier. This class is really great, but easy to get left behind in if you don't follow carefully. Take it!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Math21b is a very difficult course. Some students might like this class more than Math21a but Math21a has a more solid foundation and it is easy to figure stuff out on your own, you cannot do the same for 21b. This course is taught in sections creating an uneven playing field among the students enrolled in the course. Your TF can make or break your experience in this class, and by a chain reaction, the grade you get in the class. Students in one section could feel more confident on the content compared to students in another section. I often found myself learning stuff that another TF taught their students days before a midterm or learning about a "shortcut" for a problem from a friend in another section. Overall, if you want to do well in this class you better hope to get a good TF or spend countless hours studying for the midterms for a chance at a good grade in the class. I highly recommend attending MQC the same day you are taught a lesson as less students attend and you are able to receive more personal help.
subject: Mathematics
