subject: Mathematics

best_comment: So I am a FGLI student that went into this class with a Math 1b background. The psets are heavier than 1b and the m series for sure, but they are not impossible if you start them right after class. This class has a LOT of content so there really was never time to revisit concepts from classes prior unless there was an intentional connection, so if you are lost you should spend time with it immediately (go to quiz session, watch the pre–work video, read the handout/textbook reading). I have never struggled in math and passed calculus with flying colors, and I could pass my past math exams without studying (psets and going to class were enough), BUT THIS CLASS was where I met my match. I wouldn't say it is hard in terms of being overworked but studying for this class is completely different than studying for calculus, because I'm being so serious I have studied like I never have before and I nor any of my friends really saw their effort translate into their performance on exams. I failed both midterms, and even though I studied exponentially harder for the second one, i literally did worse.  The exams are extremely different from the material you see in class, but you are not necessarily being tested on something you weren't taught. Only someone who truly understands conceptually is able to come up with the solutions. What's worse is that there is limited time on exams, so honestly there are problems that I know I would've figured out had I been given more time. I would say course staff is available for sure though and amazing (which is weird because idk most times at harvard when ur struggling its not you its the instructor). I would say that instructors, at least jill, teach you like a college student and don't necessarily say things in the most simplest terms, so you are definitely challenged with understanding jargon and notation and stuffs. Overall, I really liked this class and I would recommend linear algebra broadly because I strongly appreciate its applications. I have never appreciated math the way I have appreciate linear algebra, and even though this was a challenge, I would do it again. I would say If i could do it again I might actually watch the pre–work videos and do more readings throughout, perhaps then I would have built enough intuition to do well on exams. I would have also started going to quiz sessions earlier on ( i strongly recommend these). Go to quiz sessions because those drops add up, AND it is a super efficient way to revisit material you need help on. Trust me it is a blessing. Anyway good luck! Esp to the fyreflies <3. A note about pre–reqs: The only thing need from 1b is integration by parts,  a basic understanding of series (none of the geometric stuff ust be able to know what it means at a high level lol), and derivatives obviously. Also, know your limits! But yea good luck fyre flies!
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Linear Algebra and Differential Equations LEC
best_comment: Do not take the class if you do not need to. Do not take the class if you will not make your life surround this class. This class is VERY demanding, and it is VERY challenging. I hadn't taken math since junior year of high school and I struggled A LOT. It moves very quickly. But if you're willing to actually put in HOURS and HOURS of work to do well on psets, go to office hours, understand the content, I think it's a very good learning opportunity. But if you have a lot on your plate during the semester (like I did), then this will definitely be a struggle and at least for me, take a hit on your grades. I haven't felt more unprepared in my life to do the midterms/exams and I hadn't done worse in my life. This class is humbling as heck! There are some really smart people in this class that will make you feel dumb, but just know that it's because they probably had a different math background, something that set them up for success. But seriously, don't take this class if you don't need to, and please plan your semester so that you are given time to do well. I was doing 7 psets a week and also in two–preprofessional clubs while enrolled in this course and it was actually one of the hardest things I've ever experienced in my life. don't do that. Don't hurt yourself like I did!
worse_comment: I heard not so great stories about Jill and those stories were not fully recognized until this course. I feel like a lot of students that took this course felt this way too. The Exams were crazy difficult and graders were very harsh with the grading. For the material that we were expected to perform on the exam, I feel like there wasn't much support either.
subject: Mathematics

But seriously, don't take this class if you don't need to, and please plan your semester so that you are given time to do well. I was doing 7 psets a week and also in two–preprofessional clubs while enrolled in this course and it was actually one of the hardest things I've ever experienced in my life. don't do that. Don't hurt yourself like I did!
worse_comment: I heard not so great stories about Jill and those stories were not fully recognized until this course. I feel like a lot of students that took this course felt this way too. The Exams were crazy difficult and graders were very harsh with the grading. For the material that we were expected to perform on the exam, I feel like there wasn't much support either.

course_title: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra II 001
best_comment: TL;DR: Absolutely incredible, amazing class and rigorous treatment of multivariable calculus with a reasonable workload that will allow you to take other classes. Dusty is/was perhaps the greatest professor in the math department but he's leaving Harvard, so I definitely suggest you shop it next year, but don't commit right away bc the class might not be as good.I write this review with a bit of a bitter taste in the back of my throat.  Not because the class was bad –– it is perhaps the greatest math class I've taken here so far and has reignited a love for the subject I thought lost in the abstraction and pedantism of definitions and theorems in analysis ––  but because Dusty is leaving at the end of this semester, so he will *not* be teaching the class ever again (or any other at Harvard). This leaves me at a bit of a crossroads: I can review this semester, which has been flawless, but I also know everyone uses the Q Guide to judge subjects they haven't yet taken for future semesters, so I would like to tell you to take the following with a grain of salt, since **everything is subject to change (but hopefully will not)**.This class is great. Moderate–to–high workload (9–12hr/wk if you want to really do the PSETs well and deeply understand the material), but it creates such a good community that PSETting feels like hanging out with friends during office hours (because it kind of is). This also does not sacrifice a rigorous treatment of the material at hand, and I definitely feel prepared to take higher upper–level math classes (112,122, etc) both from a mathematical preparation and proof–writing skill point of view. PSETs are also interesting and explore cool cracks in the definition that may otherwise slip through (why does Clairaut's Theorem only hold for C^2 functions? Are there functions that are not integrable but still have a definite integral?), and office hours are spread out appropriately throughout the week (shoutout Alice and Anamaria for the GOAT conjoined office hours on Sunday afternoons).Grading is pretty chill. 60% of your grade is determined by 3 midterms, which were fair in difficulty and you were given problems to adequately practice on, so no worries there. Another 20% is homework, 5% is computational exercises, and the final 15% is the final project that we have in lieu of a final exam (and it is so much more fun and takes so much pressure off of finals week, 100% recommended) where you can explore whatever you want provided it has rigorous treatment of multivariable calculus and algebra.DEFINITELY shop this class, and I really hope the next professor is good, because they will have big, big shoes to fill.
worse_comment: Too bad dusty is leaving :(
best_gem_comment: Best freshman math course you can take. It's almost a "gem" in terms of how interesting it is vs. the amount of work you need to put in. Take this if you're considering between 21, 22, and 25
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis II 001
best_comment: Big asterisk for future students: much of the praise I have for this class revolves around the specific lecturer and CAs we had for the spring 2023 semester.  Essentially, TL;DR if Wes is teaching this class, take it basically no matter what. If he's not, still take the class, but many of these comments might not apply.General (not teaching staff related):Personal academic experience: I came in with 25a and a pretty reasonable analysis background from high school. While this made the class significantly easier, and I definitely spent less time on it than 25a, it was still a difficult course, especially at the very beginning and very end of the semester. I still thus recommend taking 25b, even if you have previous analysis experience. For me specifically, when I took analysis in high school I didn't have a great linear algebra background, and I lost a lot of the intuition and appreciation for the material that I was able to gain in 25b. The course is an incredible deep–dive into real analysis, and you come out of it with a very good understanding of the fundamentals. Notably, if you're thinking of taking 55b, that course doesn't cover real analysis in nearly as much depth––from what I heard, they spent a week on it. Additionally, at least with Wes, he made sure that we got computational practice and worked with applications quite a bit, so for a non–pure math concentrator I feel like this class might be more useful than 55b.The intensive nature of this class and the small size made the community very strong. While I feel like it was accentuated with our specific teaching staff, I think that this is probably a constant for 25. For 90% of the class, it was basically impossible to complete the problem sets without at least some (and often a lot of) collaboration. You often found at least 12–15 people of the 20 person class at Tuesday night office hours. These office hours are some of my favorite memories of my freshman year, not just because of Saint Knut, the CA for those office hours, but also due to the fervent communal energy that would often last late into Wednesday morning. It was a truly collaborative atmosphere––everyone contributed, and everyone benefited. All of these qualities made the class feel more like a seminar–style class than a classic lecture–based one in terms of the tight–knit community that formed. Adding to the fact that most of us had taken 25a and had known each other since the beginning of freshman year, I can't think of a better class in terms of community. I'm serious: especially for STEM majors, you're not gonna get better than this.Wes:A gem among gems. Potentially the best teacher I've ever had, and definitely the best math lecturer. I assume this applies to any class he teaches, so this almost certainly applies if you're considering taking 19a, 118r, or some other class that he's teaching. His lectures are sometimes transcendental experiences, Picard–Lindelof proof in particular. (I'm not joking––I was literally dreaming about how beautiful the proof was the night after the lecture.) His enthusiasm for the material, particularly 25b material, is obvious and so infectious. He made the class feel like a journey––with the Picard–Lindelof proof, for example, he hyped up that proof specifically for weeks before we got to it, and when he finally proved it in class, the way so many of the concepts we had been learning about fit together so perfectly in the proof was just beautiful. He forces us to participate in lectures, and in a very constructive way that, combined with the clarity and deliberateness of his lecturing, made if feel like I could have proved the given proposition or theorem myself if I was given enough time. He also clearly and genuinely cares about his students, hosting numerous office hours and making himself available to schedule individual appointments whenever. His (sometimes intentional, sometimes not) humor also added to the lecture experience. Yes, it's a 9am three days a week, but it was so worth it. Wes does have a few annoying principles that he sticks to very stubbornly: the worst of these is absolutely no flexibility in deadlines (like if you submit something five minutes late you might get a zero). The exams are also in person and quite difficult, although if you study from the problem sets and lecture notes they're usually doable. All in all, the 25 sequence, including 25b, was one of my favorite and most memorable experiences from freshman year. Both 25a and 25b were my favorite classes each semester, due in part to the interesting material, but much more due to the fantastic people in the class, the community and the wonderful teaching we were privileged to experience. I got a little emotional at the end of the final lecture. Take it, I implore you.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Studies in Real and Complex analysis 001
best_comment: Math 55b was an interesting experience. If you took Math 55a you are most definitely prepared to take on this class. We also had I think about 4 students from Math 25a and 2 students from Math 22.Based on my experience and other friends’ feedback it feels that Math 55b was a decent bit easier than Math 55a and that in some sense last semester was the “real Math 55 experience.” Last semester we were forced to work together on hard problems for a long time and go to office hours for help, and as a result, we formed a close community and had a deeper understanding of the materials. To some extent this semester we had the continuation of that community but personally, I felt like I understood last semester’s material better and had more interactions with the CAs and just everyone in the class.This course is titled "Studies in Real and Complex Analysis," but on the first day of class, the professor explains to you that in reality, it is more like Math 131+Math113. We roughly had three units: 3.5 weeks on point set topology, 3.5 weeks on algebraic topology, and 5 weeks on complex analysis. As a result, we don’t really dive into real analysis and students should learn this important area of mathematics on their own at some point.We followed Munkres’ Topology through the first two units. In point set topology we learned about fundamental concepts such as product and quotient topology, connectedness, compactness, and separation axioms, which is Munkres chapter 12–34. So I would recommend future students who want to do some preparation during winter break to read this portion of Munkres. This part of the course was comparably more intuitive and chill (admittedly compactness is not very intuitive).In algebraic topology, we learned about homotopy equivalences, fundamental groups, Seifert–Van Kampen, covering spaces, and briefly introduced topics like higher homotopy groups and homology. This is roughly Munkres chapters 51–57 and 79–81. This part of the course was quite difficult for me as it is harder to visualize and see the significance of these constructions. Later on, after learning complex analysis, I was finally able to see some of the motivations and applications of these concepts. Definitely try to go to office hours here, for me at least the problem sets involve a degree of hand waving and many drawings.About a week after spring break we started Complex Analysis, which according to Professor Harris is his favorite and most beautiful part of the course (as usual Joe is an absolutely fantastic and supportive lecturer). Here we followed Ahlfors’ Complex Analysis, which honestly is quite terse and hard to understand (reading lecture notes beforehand helps). We started with holomorphic functions and with the introduction of the Cauchy Integral Formula we were equipped to take on harder problems. After learning about poles, singularities, and Laurent series, we did a good amount of Residue calculus which gave us important results about holomorphic and meromorphic functions.I have to admit, I personally did not find complex analysis to be particularly enlightening as it felt like learning a ton of cool formulas and then just applying them to solve some seemingly arbitrary problems. In retrospect, I actually liked the topology portion of the course better as they introduced new ideas I have never considered before. I will likely take Math 231, a course Professor Harris highly recommended.From my perspective my classmates took the following courses alongside 55b: quite a few took CS 124, a decent amount took Stat 111, some took Math 123 or 129 or 132, and a few took CS 181.Throughout this semester I have been thinking hard on what the point of taking Math 55 is. If a student took courses that taught the materials in 55 separately they may get a deeper understanding by virtue of spending more time on them. I have come to a few humble conclusions: I think by compressing a large amount of abstract mathematics into each semester we do get a slightly more surface–level understanding of individual topics. However, at the same time, we got to see some connections between different areas of mathematics that would be otherwise hard to see, for example, algebra with topology, complex analysis with algebraic topology, abstract algebra with linear algebra; and I’m sure some of the smaller topics we did like the exposure to basic category theory will serve us well in the future. I think I got a very solid overall “feel” and overview of higher–level mathematics. Moreover, 55 is really at its core about the community. I have met some of my closest friends and some of the most interesting people through this class. The late nights at Math Lounge and Math Library will forever be a sweet piece of memory lying in the foundation of my Harvard journey and I’m sure years later my classmates and I will look back fondly on those days and laugh and shed some tears. I highly recommend anyone reading this to reach out to your classmates, schedule a lunch or a walk together and get to know them better. You will not regret this.Overall I think continuing with 55b was the right choice for me and most of my classmates from 55a. If you are considering this course, sit in on a few lectures and check it out! I wish you the best of luck!
worse_comment: You will fall behind in this course no matter what! (except if you already know most of the concepts in this class) This is because every lecture you are introduced to a handful of definitions and another handful of theorems, just to build up on those concepts two days later. Every lecture you are expected to be familiar with all the concepts taught so far in the course, which is not realistic at all, given that we meet three times a week, that the psets already take us anywhere between 10 and 20 hours, given that the lectures are already confusing and it takes time to review them and ask questions, and lastly given that you also have other courses. Harris is a very kind person in real life, but when it comes to teaching you will feel very stupid because he always says things are so obvious when they aren't. You will feel impostor syndrome because the professor acts as if the proofs are so obvious so he will skip plenty of steps, and he will never remind you of any definitions unless you ask, but then nobody asks, because it is not a very welcoming evironment. This class is just unnecessarily hard and time–consuming. Also we only got feedback for 2 psets out of 10 until the last week of classes when we learned the rest of our grades on the psets and the final, and you also never see any solution of either the psets of the final, so you just hardly ever improve from your mistakes.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Reading Course for Senior Honors Candidates 1
best_comment: A thesis is a unique experience, I won't prescriptively recommend it to everyone. That being said, if you have any interest in doing one, I would generally say you just should. It is entirely unlike any classroom experience; you can closely interact with you advisor (and see their enthusiasm for the field, which sometimes doesn't shine through in typical lectures as much as it will when you are adjacent to their research area) and may go arbitrarily deep in any subfield of your choosing.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is excellent. Sam is an incredible TF, and I enjoyed the way he organized his class. While more group activities could be added, the lectures are not bad but can become tedious sometimes with the many proofs going on. Overall, very enjoyable and nice experience.
worse_comment: The tutorials differ in material vastly, so don't trust the comments here.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I think overall math 101 is a cool course, but there are a number of things that I was frustrated with regarding how it was run in Spring 2023. I'd like to preface everything by saying I think Janet Chen is an awesome and really kind person though. At the very beginning of the course, some of the things you do will feel very strange. Writing a proof is a very particular skill and if you've never done it before, it can feel sort of unusual. My advice at the beginning would be to practice, practice, and practice more! Really work hard at the beginning to fully understand what is going on—it will serve you well for the remainder of the course. One thing you might notice early on though is that some people have stronger backgrounds in proof writing than others. I was sometimes working with people during problem sessions who knew what things like "Without loss of generality" were and it felt discouraging to be writing proofs with people who already knew all of the steps and the general formulation of the proof. I think if this course wants to fully serve as an intro to proof based math, it needs to be designed particularly for people with absolutely no proof experience. Knowing how to write a proof is essential to this course and having knowledge of that prior to the course is a huge disadvantage for other students. The anti–requisites should be more enforced in order to make sure all students have an equal background coming into the course. In terms of the grading of the course, I think that an intro course should really focus on growth and allow people the opportunity to progress as the semester goes on (some course have this built in to how the course is scored). It at times did not feel like there was this emphasis on the grading for the course. In fact, I'm of the belief that an intro to pure math course should be scored in a way that is encouraging for students to continue to take challenges and take more pure math courses, but it often did not feel like this was the case. The grading at times felt like it was very strict and nitpicky and there weren't a lot of opportunities to earn points back (on the problem sets there was, but I think on the exams there should have been). Having the opportunity for extra credit would be an awesome idea for a course like math 101 where people are so new to what is being taught. The final paper in particular felt like an illustration of the course instructors being unnecesarily strict with their expectations. Firstly, it's a lot to ask students to write a math paper and take a math final. In addition to this, the paper was graded with a really high standard which felt unfair because this put students who had knowledge of math topics outside of the course at a clear advantage. Also, the paper was the first time a lot of us ever wrote a pure math paper, so grading it so strictly without at least having multiple rounds of edits or multiple opportunities to conference or even a practice paper earlier in the semester feels like an unfair expectation. I know that grades shouldn't be the foremost concern when deciding what courses to take, but I think people should take challenges and do things like take a pure math course as a non–math concentrator. In order to incentivize people to do this, you need to create a course centered around growing and one that eliminates inequities that can exacerbate the challenges and frustrations that come along with the course. One other thing I'd note are that it's pretty frustrating to have timed exams in a course like math 101. I think proof writing takes time and I often felt like there was time pressure on the exam, and this made things more challenging. I know a lot of this has been about some of the ways this course can be improved, so I just wanted to take the opportunity to highlight some of the positives of this course. Firstly, it will likely challenge you in ways you've never been challenged. This is a good thing! It is a rewarding intellectual experience to think through a lot of the problems in the course. Secondly, the course staff is great! Janet is a great person and explains concepts very clearly. The CAs are awesome—try out all the CA's office hours and find which CAs you most vibe with / understand their teaching style. Doing this as early in the semester will definitely benefit you. Overall, I would say I definitely enjoyed learning a lot of the concepts in math 101 and am glad to have faced a challenge with the course material. My TLDR of where I think this course can improve is: make sure this is really at the intro level, eliminate inequities by being stricter about the anti–requisites, create a culture that makes people want to continue taking higher level math classes and challenge themselves. If you're really excited about this course material and willing to put in the effort this course requires, definitely don't let these concerns stop you since math 101 can be a rewarding experience.
worse_comment: don't take this class. especially not with janet. she's absolutely overhyped and not at all a great teacher. she doesn't have empathy and has policies that literally make negative sense. i don't think this class is worth the stress. the content is interesting, but you have to learn it yourself. overhyped prof and course. learned that higher level maths is cool, but class was not taught well at all.

best_comment: The material is inherently boring, but you may find parts of it (like point–set topology) interesting. Course staff were generally understanding, though having no drops on psets was not ideal, and grading was very behind (some Pset grades we got back a month after submission). I'm definitely not against this course, because if you wanna do anything in Econ/math/applied math it is a course that you kind of have to take, but it could be better done. Lecture was pretty good. OHs were also pretty good. Lecture was not recorded which is strange compared to what is standard for larger lecture–based classes like this. A 6/10 course. Not the worst I have taken but certainly not the best.
worse_comment: As a note, the professor next semester will be different so the teaching style may be different. I was very underwhelmed by this class. Lectures were very confusing and didn't seem to build understanding of the course material. Problem sets were both difficult and pretty harshly graded. The midterm was much easier than the problem sets, but the final was much more difficult. The course just felt very over the place, which was disappointing since I was looking forward to the class.

best_comment: Here are some results from complex analysis:– The trig function sin(z) can exceed 1, if z is a complex number– If a function f : C –> C is differentiable once, then it must be differentiable infinitely many times– Constant functions are the only differentiable functions f : C –> C that are bounded (i.e. |f(z)| < M for some positive real M). In other words, all non–constant differentiable functions are unbounded.– The sum of the reciprocal of perfect squares, 1 + 1/4 + 1/9 + 1/16 + 1/25 + … converges to pi^2/6 I chose these examples because I can easily write them on the q guide (no integrals are featured in the list, for example), but this is just a small list out of the many beautiful and surprising theorems that are proven with complex analysis. Math 113 is an epic voyage through these exciting theorems––I learned something interesting in literally every lecture––which will broaden your mathematical perspective and leave you with a deep appreciation for math.I recommend having taken real analysis at the level of Math 22b, Math 25b, or Math 112 before taking this course, because complex analysis borrows many techniques (epsilon–delta) and theorems from real analysis, and these techniques will not be covered as deeply in 113 as in these other courses. Real analysis is also important to appreciate the subject––complex functions behave in very surprising ways, but this won’t come as much of a surprise without learning how they “normally” behave on the real numbers. This is definitely not necessary, but I also found Math 131 as a good course to take before 113 because we rely on some topological techniques in 131 (mainly homotopies of paths). Since 131 is not assumed as a prereq, these topological concepts will be covered during lecture, but having a background in topology will let you see the “big–picture” connection between complex analysis and topology, giving you a deeper understanding and appreciation for the subject. You’ll also gain this insight by taking 113 –> 131, since 131 also references some complex analysis to illustrate certain topics (Riemann sphere as one point compactification of C, for example).
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Algebra II: Theory of Rings and Fields 001
best_comment: I think people's experiences with 123 depends largely on their interests and their background. I have some friends who have described the content in 123 as the most beautiful math they've seen so far, while others have expressed more dismal views toward the topics of the class. Personally, I took 123 solely to satisfy the algebra requirement for math joint concentrators, and while I thought some applications of topics (e.g., Galois theory for the unsolvability of the quintic or the norm in quadratic number fields to solve Diophantine equations), I found much of the course content broadly not very interesting. Nonetheless, the content in 123 feels important to know as a math concentrator, and I'm glad that I chose to take 123 to satisfy the algebra requirement. One of the main factors was probably Prof. McMullen, who is a captivating lecturer and makes the content feel tangible (e.g., through geometric explanations of algebraic topics) and clear. His exams were fair (potentially on the easier side if anything), problem sets were really helpful, and the course notes he posts provide some of the best explanations I could find. He's also just a great person, and it's really clear that he cares a lot about teaching and his students.I'd recommend spending time to really understand the course content and the problem sets. I often found myself thinking that I understood content before the next lecture really demonstrated that I indeed did not understand the content.
worse_comment: This class is the worst math class you can take at Harvard.  It has everything that a math class should not: timed in–person exams, weekend psets to be physically submitted, minimal feedback, and an instructor who does not know his students.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Math 124 is a good class to take to know number theory. This might sound like the most abstract and theoretical math course since it is literally about numbers, but there is a great deal to learn that can help with studies in other fields that are not obvious at all when you first look. But after the class, you will realize you learned an incredible amount of ideas that genuinely are different from other classes. It is almost like jumping into an entirely different area of learning, which is where the most learning can happen.

This class is definitely a grind/one of the harder undergrad math classes, but the material is quite important and fairly interesting. Note that we covered all of Daniel Marcus's Number Fields with one lecture to spare (that's eight chapters lol), so material goes by pretty quickly. Expect psets to be long and kind of computational/bashy at times; exams were a similar flavor. That being said, while he does go quite fast at times, Salim is one of the best lecturers in the department. He's so nice and really great at making the classroom feeling like a place where you can ask questions. Also, his office hours were very helpful for both psets and content questions. In summary: would definitely recommend the class, but it is a decent amount of work.
worse_comment: This is one of the most difficult classes I've taken at Harvard. Problem sets were very long and overly computational. Only take this course if you are very solid with Galois theory and are okay with very tedious problem sets.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: i would liken this course to an abusive sugardaddy that keeps you coming back for more. hopkins is an absolute mess every class and never fails to confuse everyone in the room, including himself.  he stumbles over seemingly minor details in his proofs, an issue which I think is easily solved if only he bothered to look at his course notes whenever he is confused during lecture. most of the time, he turns around in the midst of his rambling and asks the class if we're okay, to which he is always answered, without fail, with deafening silence. he knows that the majority of the class stopped following everything since 5 minutes into the lesson, but he decides to move on anyways. some of us are pretty sure that he has not presented a single, completely correct proof in class since the start of the semester. im pretty sure that if I had not seen half the material before in some other math class, I would have come out of the class understanding completely nothing. personally, I came out of the class knowing buzzwords and some vague idea of how things clicked together, but its the kind of unsettling feeling where you dont really know the details well enough to be satisfied with yourself. because he never prepares for lecture, he is a mess on the blackboard, and he constantly likes to switch notation at the drop of a hat in the middle of a proof. he himself is aware of this, but he jokes about it and tells us to go figure it out for ourselves, which is pretty hilarious in some weird way. despite all this chaos, hopkins' personality combined with his style of teaching makes for strangely addictive lectures. despite the fact that I never learn annything from class, I am extremely proud to announce that I have 100% attendance for math 132 lectures (lets just forget for a moment that this class is at 1.30 pm on mon and wed so its p hard to miss on accident). hopkins likes to present the material in a way that fits into a larger picture that was the development of modern math, and the way he briefly mentions the people and their stories behind some of the major theorems breathes a touch of humanity into an otherwise dry and technical subject. hopkins also taught cobordism, something which is unique to his take on math 132 and definitely not something you learn in a normal rendition of math 132. I barely understood the details on surgery, especially the interplay between global and local properties in cobordism and surgery, but it was pretty cool nonetheless. he also compensates for his horrible blackboard work with absolutely amazing pictures, which surely is core in any class on topology/geometry. you can always tell a good geometer/topologist by the way he draws donuts, especially 2 donuts stacked on top of each other and intertwined, which eventually turned into a picture of a meditating buddha by the time hopkins was done using the picture. finally and most importantly,  quirky is an understatement for hopkins' personality. i dont think any other professor here is as cool and in touch with young students as he is. the antics that he pulls during class are so weird that they become hilarious and endearing. highlights include his habit of trying to spin the blackboard duster while throwing it behind his back onto the blackboard at the start of every lesson, claiming that his lecture quality will drop because his thumb hurts due to playing too many console games with his daughter last night, and also his profound insight of using the famous lemma stating that 1+1 = 2 in the middle of a proof (this eventually made it onto sidechat). overall, a solid class for people who come to class to be entertained but are prepared to put in the work outside of class, because you wont learn much during lectures. his notes are amazing (full of typos though, but he likes to put his inner ramblings inside his notes so you can occasionally see him complaining some details he has to straighten out in his notes). in addition to gaining a deeper appreciation for how cool and beautiful diff top is, even though i understand close to zero of it still, i also gained an appreciation for how cool some mathematicians are. definitely a recommendation if you are insane like me. oh btw, he likes steifel manifolds and grassmanians alot for some strange reason. the psets are full of them
worse_comment: Prof. Hopkins's lectures were some of the most entertaining lectures I've heard – he often goes on long tangents that make the class more entertaining and personal. However, it sometimes seemed that he didn't prepare much for the class; proofs and definitions presented in lecture were often disorganized, and problem sets were released sporadically toward the end of the course. In total, the course was fairly light (short problem sets + no exams), though I'm hesitant to say that I learned much through the course of the semester.Part of this is also driven by the extremely wide range of backgrounds that students have heading into the course. There were some students who had no experience with analysis, abstract algebra, or topology, while others had just finished Math 231a. I think that trying to accommodate such a wide range of backgrounds occasionally got in the way of learning. Some of the topics in differential topology seem difficult to understand without at least a rudimentary understanding of some math topics, and sometimes the course awkwardly balanced between explaining content without topics with other math courses and incorporating topics from other math courses.Overall, while this course was an easy way to fulfill the topology requirement, I think that it had the potential to teach much more than it did, and I'm not sure I would have taken it knowing what I know now.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Professor Popa is a brilliant instructor. Be prepared for a very challenging course both on a conceptual level and in terms of time commitment, but the lectures were always very engaging and Professor Popa was always willing to meet and help explain things. The course assistants Hahn and Eliot are among the best the Math Department has to offer and always gave very extensive feedback on assignments and were willing to help us catch up whenever things fell behind. The material itself I believe is quite different from how the course was taught before, but which made for a very interesting learning experience. I would highly recommend any course with Professor Popa, but be prepared to put in a lot of hours and carry out some independent reading or research outside of class. In the end, though, I think it was very rewarding. It has been among, if not the, best math courses I have taken at Harvard.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I would like to tell future students that it's a valuable course with incredibly use and insight that I would happily recommend.
worse_comment: Boring lectures. Confusing material. Inaccessible teaching team. Unfair exams. Take Stat110 instead.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: It is a great class for those who are familiar with and interested in approaching various mathematical topics through the lens of problem solving. The course material is very broad, and so if you are not as interested in one area of the course it will not be dwelt on for long. Great opportunity to gain exposure and see the applicability of the pure math work you've been doing (if you are a math major). The course also includes the writing of an original math paper, which is perfect for the expository paper requirement (again for math majors). Very relaxed and fun environment, and the professor/TFs are remarkably helpful!
worse_comment: This class is pretty much a guaranteed A because the grading was very lenient, but the homework problems (75% of the grade) were so hard I could never do almost any of them without office hours. Could be pretty frustrating that the homework problems were usually nothing like class problems, so I’d always feel unprepared for homework, so definitely go to office hours, the CAs are very helpful and will walk you through problems. There were flexible homework deadlines which is really nice, but the assignments were quite difficult. Not really math puzzles like advertised. Also no course head, just a TF and CAs
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Introduction to Formal Verification of Mathematics 1
best_comment: Math 161 was without a doubt the best class I've ever taken in the math department and the best–taught class I've taken in college. It is clear that Phil really cares about the class and its students. He invests a ton of time and effort into making the class feel seamless and is just generally a really good person. This class would not have existed or been the same without him and his incredible knowledge and interest in Lean. He's a very patient and kind teacher, and he is always going out of his way to help students and advocate for them. He also stayed late during office hours consistently and made sure every student was at a good stopping point by the end of his office hours session. His lectures are really fun and engaging. You can tell that he really loves what he's teaching and loves teaching in general by the way he explains things. Also, as a math and CS concentrator, I thought that Lean was soooo cool. You get to use code to write math proofs! It was like two worlds colliding for the first time. I might have written my thesis on theorem provers if I had taken this class junior year instead of senior year. I could not recommend this class enough. It completely changed my perspective on what math could be and left me with incredible memories and friends. Phil really did a great job of cultivating a community, and connecting with the people in the class makes it so much easier to connect with the material too. Also the assignments were super instructive but also accessible. The problems on the homework were actually based off of the topics and examples we covered during lecture. Both of the projects were so fun, interesting, and personally meaningful. I felt like I learned so much from them. I also appreciated that there were no exams. It took way the sense of impeding doom I sometimes feel during a semester. It made it so much easier to focus on and invest in what we were learning as well as who we were learning the material with. Overall, I am so grateful that I was able to take Math 161 during my final semester. I would highly recommend this class and any class that Phil teaches.
best_gem_comment: For non–standard classes in the math department, this is definitely above–average. The material generally is interesting and the labs and problem sets are appropriately difficult. The class is definitely not easy – do not take if you're looking for a gem and be prepared to work, but it's not going to give you as many nightmares as something in the 130s, for instance. The projects are very open–ended – especially if you're a procrastinator or you don't have a lot of experience with programming, get started early, go to office hours, and make sure to pick something that works well in Lean. It can be easy to get stuck in a project which is not fun and also really hard to implement formally. Really, the main perk of this class is that it's super light on theoretical ideas and feels much more like CS exercises, and pairs well with a theory–intensive math class in the course schedule.

best_comment: This is a great course for people who want to begin a serious study of analysis. One should be prepared to put in hard work but the benefits justify the effort.
worse_comment: This class was hands down the worst part of my first year at Harvard.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Kronheimer's a great lecturer, so definitely take it if he's ever teaching it again! It was definitely a fair amount of work, but office hours were incredibly helpful. Plus, I feel like I actually learned so much this semester—I think we covered a good portion of Donaldson's book on Riemann surfaces. I think listening to Kronheimer explain things also just really builds so much visual intuition for a lot of stuff going on in the subject. Also his board work is endearingly wonky (plus very colorful!), which I'm a huge fan of
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: the class this year was about algebraic groups instead of lie groups, plus elden is leaving so the feedback and ratings here are going to be not useful. but just going to say that i really enjoyed this class. Elden and the course CA Wyatt are amazing. really smart, caring people. i learned a lot of useful algebraic geometry in this class, some lovely perspectives, and overally really glad i took it. so maybe what the student perusing these comments should take away is: after learning scheme theory, you should at some point learn algebraic groups
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: If you enjoyed the algebraic machinery introduced in the first course, then this course takes things to a whole new level. Many interesting ideas in this course. If Andy teaches it again, definitely take it since he is the most patient person ever and will make sure to unpack things to the point where they are easily digestible.
worse_comment: Take this class. It's pretty neat. But it can be very hard if you don't spend a good amount of time internalizing the ideas.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Algebraic geometry is hard. I have never heard of a postdoc/professor saying they felt like things truly 'clicked' in AG until at least the third time through. Chris is very good at teaching. He was always super available to talk about concepts, and to make the abstraction feel more concrete. Even for the technical things, he was very good at explaining the proofs and techniques. The CA Duc Vo was also an amazing CA. He helped all of us every Tuesday with difficult Hartshorne exercises. I think I learned a lot and still have maintained immense enthusiasm for AG despite this grueling process because of their support and encouragement. Thanks for a wonderful semester!
worse_comment: The exercises in Hartshorne are very difficult and you should work with others, but they are instructive.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a super chill class that does not have weekly homework or any exams. The only graded parts are a final project proposal due in April and a final project due in May. It is a graduate math class that is also suitable for being a fifth class. You may learn some coding skills and get to know some interesting people in grad schools like the business school and the med school in the final project.This is not a class without its downsides. I don't think I learned that much from the class nor would I retain much, but it was fun hearing some speakers talking about what makes them passionate and Nowak is an important figure in mathematical biology. If you want to take a class to learn something deeply and have a strong class community, this might not be for you; but if you want an enjoyable survey class with low stress and is a grad math class, this is a great class to take.Overall I enjoyed the class and am grateful for meeting my final project teammates that I may otherwise have not met, though I do have ambivalent feelings about this class and would not recommend it to everyone.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is a great class, and Dori's a great lecturer. I would highly recommend taking classes taught by Dori. In addition, K3 surfaces admit quite a rich theory and are really cool, and I would recommend learning about them at some point of time.

Great class – interesting the whole time and such a privilege to learn from Fabian and get his unified perspective on ideas which are scattered among a lot of papers and which would have been much less efficient to learn without this class.

Super great class with super interesting reading and discussion! One of the best, if not the best, class I've taken at Harvard so far and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who's interested in behavior and its intersection with drugs. Assignments are super light, although it's important to stay on top of weekly readings, and the final paper isn't bad as long as you pick a topic you're interested in writing about.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm

best_comment: This course requires a lot of in–class time very early in the morning and has a strict attendance policy. It provides a rigorous, helpful overview of metabolism, but definitely consider how much time you are willing to devote to it, especially if you are also balancing other coursework and research with it.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm

course_title: Principles of Drug Action in People 001
best_comment: To echo a review of the course from a previous semester: "Enjoy what the professionals can offer you." It's super cool to be lectured by people at very top of their field, although understandably not all of them are the best lecturers and left more to be desired in terms of pedagogical effectiveness. Nevertheless, feel like I learned a lot while not being stressed out with an enormous workload.
worse_comment: If you are looking for course that will give you a very comprehensive introduction to drug development, this course is what you need! It covers diverse areas of drug development, including cancer immunotherapy, pain management, gene therapy, and cardiovascular disease with fantastic invited speakers from industry. Don't miss out!

best_comment: The breadth/scope of this course is quite large, so students will definitely be more engaged/interested in some units over others. Overall, I think the workload is reasonable and does a good job assessing students' understanding of the material. The course improved throughout the semester, and lecturers were strong.
worse_comment: I would tell future students that there is no point in going to lectures, that they should not expect the homework content to be covered, prepare to be embarrassed in front of the class because you don't know everything about a field you don't study and aren't even interested in. Don't take the class if you don't have to.

course_title: Biology of the Cancer Cell: From Molecular Mechanisms to Therapeutic Implications 0001
best_comment: This class is so wonderful. It gives students an in–depth survey into the world of cancer biology and current cancer therapeutics, and brings in the leading experts on these topics. This class only has strengths. It is a great class that truly prioritizes student learning. Course heads are wonderful.
worse_comment: I would tell students that if you need a good elective that isn't super intense, gives you the freedom to explore the topics you are interested in while also pointing you in different directions, but also teaches you the important concepts and problems in cancer biology, then this is the course you should take.

best_comment: This class was wonderful. I spent time reading scientific papers deeply, and through that experience, I have come to understand genetics from a more inquiry–centered perspective, which has allowed me to appreciate the field even more. This course allows you to have deep, and sometimes existential, discussions about science and genetics, and will definitely help you improve your thinking as a scientist. This class was a very great, very wonderful, experience. I would highly recommend you take this class if you are even remotely interested, just be prepared to read the papers and be ready to have interesting discussions about them. Great, great class!

This is not an easy class to take lightly.

This class is essentially an independent research project with guest lectures. Some of the lectures were more interesting than others, and I often found that many of them went over my head. They aren't necessarily relevant for the final project, but it is a great way to get a sense of the kinds of research that is happening in the field. For the project, you really should have some coding background. I had never worked with neural networks before, and that was a learning curve enough for me even with a solid Python background. It's a great opportunity to pursue an independent project to put on your resume with the support of Professor Kreiman and the TFs. This class is really what you make of it though – it definitely can be as complicated as you'd like. And it's a nice exercise in research design and report writing. Just be prepared to be working on the project *very* independently.
worse_comment: Don't take this class under any circumstances. There is a way better use of your time than this bullshit

course_title: At Cross Purposes: The Crusades in Material Culture 001
best_comment: TAKE IT!!! Just take it!! This course is fantastic. You learn so much, and might even go on a trip to Dumbarton Oaks in DC! Georganteli is my favorite professor ever, she is a rockstar in her field and an incredible professor. She really encourages you to chase your dreams and make it a reality!!! The most encouraging professor ever.
BEST CLASS EVER. Milberg is amazing, so passionate about the subject, so funny, and the 3 hours fly each week. Never bored the entire class time, it's the best MBB seminar out there.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: Functional Neuroimaging of Psychiatric Disorders: Insights into the Human Brain-Mind 001
best_comment: Good class. There are writing assignments due every week but they are pretty quick and are graded very very generously. Don't take longer than an hour a week to do with one 10pg final paper – overall not bad at all. Class is taught in seminar style with lots of open discussions.
worse_comment: This class is honestly such a gem. Though the readings can be difficult to parse at times, each class is filled with discussion that doesn't necessitate a comprehensive understanding of the structure of the brain. The professor brings in real–world examples to contextualize the issues he presents, and has a really refreshing view on mental health and the stigma that surrounds it.
best_gem_comment: This class is a GEM! The professor is very kind and understanding. The assignments makes sense (so you are ready for discussion). Nothing is unreasonable. You learn lots about neuroimaging and the brain as well as mental illness.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: Neuroimaging and Big Data in Connectomics: Advances in Understanding the Wiring of the Brain 1
best_comment: This intro seminar is maybe more in–the–weeds and less up to interpretation than other seminars I've had. During lectures, information was clear. Prof Nickerson is very knowledgeable, and often gives very thorough follow–up on questions during class and feedback. She is very available for the students, even outside of scheduled hours. Sometimes, she is looking for something very specific with assignments, so it's good to take advantage of the small class size to get individual feedback and have your questions answered. The material covered is broad, but I feel like the class does a fairly good job covering a wide variety of interesting topics.

course_title: Translational Neuroscience: Limits of Adaptation from Extreme Environments to Clinical Practice 001
best_comment: I came into this course with a passing interest in space life sciences, and left with a passion for the field that will drive me in my future research. The material in this course, especially the focus on spaceflight and human health, is something you probably wouldn't find in most universities, let alone with 2 professors as knowledgeable and well–connected as Gary and Vlad. That alone made the class very compelling for me, and if you have even a basic interest in extreme environments and medicine, I'd absolutely recommend taking the course just for those reasons.That being said, you should know that this course focuses much more on overall physiology than just neuroscience. While this does mean that having a neuro background isn't important to understand the material, you do need a good background in anatomy/physiology to appreciate the material. The lectures, while fascinating, can seem a bit disjointed at times – perhaps this is just because of the very niche nature of extreme medicine, but sometimes I was left wanting a clearer understanding of how each specific extreme environment affects the human body instead of a combination of all environments at the same time. The variance in stress levels I experienced from this course was also really high – from very low during the weeks with just a quiz (which are quite easy), to medium during the week of my presentation, to quite high when having to write a 7000 word term paper during reading period, which was far longer than any term paper I've ever had to write. This wasn't helped by the fact that the course has no TFs or CAs to provide assistance for assignments and that Gary and Vlad provide very little feedback (or even grades!) on completed assignments.Ultimately, despite the caveats above, I'd still gladly recommend this course to anyone interested in going beyond clinical medicine to learn about environments outside the hospital, especially spaceflight – the material is just that interesting, and the unanswered research questions that compelling.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Michael is an AMAZING professor. Take whatever course he's teaching, even if it's not Virtue Science. Dr. Lazar is also extremely kind. Both Michael and Sara not only want you to succeed as a student, but they also genuinely care that you're mentally well and that you leave Harvard being a good and kind person. As for the class itself, the material is extremely interesting. There's no other class at Harvard like it. You learn so much about the science of compassion, kindness, justice, etc., and the philosophy and psychology of those virtues too. You will not regret this class AT ALL. TAKE IT.

best_comment: This class allows for a really amazing discussions with an exceptional professor. Truly was able to take an interdisciplinary approach to a very fruitful subject. You get a chance to talk about biology, philosophy, law, psychology, CS, and wide array of different topics. Really fascinating stuff. Professor Ellsworth is also an amazing professor. I cannot rave about him enough.

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution 001
best_comment: If you're looking at this class, then odds are that it's either a concentration requirement or a prerequisite for something else like the premed track. Here's the rundown, but be aware that the class is going to be taught by a different professor next year so I don't know how much of this will still apply.Lectures: Decent to good, it really depends on the lecturer so it may be different, but they weren't bad. Dr. Berry and Dr. Sabeti each had their styles of lecturing that were both more engaging than just sitting in a hall listening to someone talk for an hour, which was nice. They put up these questions which you just had to answer for attendance, but other than that, they're a good way to get the general idea of what you're going to be learning in any given week, with some examples sprinkled in. Pay attention to the examples that they give, a fair amount of this class is (kinda surprisingly) based in some math and statistics, so seeing problems being worked through will come in handy on the PIEs(more on those later).Lecture notes: There are these notes published weekly alongside the lecture slides, READ THEM. Go through, take notes, make sure you understand everything in the lecture NOTES. Anything in there is fair game, and sometimes there are details that aren't in the slides, so if you want to do well, use them. Heck, you could probably get through the class on those alone, as long as you also make sure you know how to do some simple stats calculations. Lab: So once a week, you go into a lab room, do an experiment or part of an experiment, clean up, fill out some info for a lab report, and repeat. That part's pretty fun if you're into biology, what sometimes sucked is when we had a multi–week experiment where something went wrong in the beginning and we had to use sample data for the whole thing, but yeah. If you're coming from ls1a, be warned that there are also a few lab papers you'll have to write throughout the semester, where you have to find scientific articles and then do a write–up on a specific gene or bacteria. It's very formulaic, they tell you what to include though, so it's not hard just time–consuming.Exams: Good news, ls1b doesn't have midterms. Bad news, it has these things called PIEs instead. Instead of 1–2 midterms, you have 5 min–exams that are 40 minutes each, and you get to drop the lowest one. I'm not sure what they were like in past years, but coming from someone who did pretty well on them, they did NOT calibrate the difficulty correctly. Half the class barely passed the first one, and they weren't much better moving forward. You're expected to write way too much for the time they give you, and any short–response question is graded on whether you include 1 or 2 specific details about the question topic, so you end up just writing everything you know in the box and hoping for the best. They let you take a single page of notes into each one too, but there isn't time to really use it, and some questions are oddly specific so you still have to write mostly everything on it in order to answer those questions. Be prepared if you're going to take this class. The final exam was pretty fair though, so credit where credit is due.Homework: Classic PSET course, not much different from ls1a's PSETs if you did those. Get a weekly document, answer questions, go to office hours, work with other people, etc. Definitely get a good PSET group together if you're not already planning on taking this class with other people you know. Halfway through the semester, they reduced the number of PSETs, but that just meant they took half of the remaining PSETs and merged them with the other half, so each one was twice as long instead. In terms of difficulty, very hit or miss, some would be pretty straightforward and then others would take hours to figure out.So...yeah, that's about it. The content was actually pretty interesting, there's even a little bit of disease genetics and virology if that's what you're into (I was, which made it fun), and overall it wasn't bad – though, having friends also taking it and being able to study together and all that definitely helped. And if you've gotta take this class for premed, then godspeed to ya.
worse_comment: do not take this class if absolutely not needed for your concentration. If you don’t have a good bio background please look at the AP bio page on khan academy, prepare to waste so much of your time every week on PSETS and also taking PIES. The pies are so horrible, start studying a week before, go to every OH. The Preceptors, especially Monica, she is great. These comments don’t reflect issues with any staff member specifically, but the way the course comes together is a mess. Prepare for the anxiety of the PIES. The final IS in no way similar to any of the PIES. The pies are so math based and the final wanted us to do some fact recalling that was never asked of us throughout the course (except for the pie about cancer genetics). literally no idea what this course wants from us and I regret taking it because of all the stress it’s caused me.
subject: Life Sciences

Pay attention to the examples that they give, a fair amount of this class is (kinda surprisingly) based in some math and statistics, so seeing problems being worked through will come in handy on the PIEs(more on those later).Lecture notes: There are these notes published weekly alongside the lecture slides, READ THEM. Go through, take notes, make sure you understand everything in the lecture NOTES. Anything in there is fair game, and sometimes there are details that aren't in the slides, so if you want to do well, use them. Heck, you could probably get through the class on those alone, as long as you also make sure you know how to do some simple stats calculations. Lab: So once a week, you go into a lab room, do an experiment or part of an experiment, clean up, fill out some info for a lab report, and repeat. That part's pretty fun if you're into biology, what sometimes sucked is when we had a multi–week experiment where something went wrong in the beginning and we had to use sample data for the whole thing, but yeah. If you're coming from ls1a, be warned that there are also a few lab papers you'll have to write throughout the semester, where you have to find scientific articles and then do a write–up on a specific gene or bacteria. It's very formulaic, they tell you what to include though, so it's not hard just time–consuming.Exams: Good news, ls1b doesn't have midterms. Bad news, it has these things called PIEs instead. Instead of 1–2 midterms, you have 5 min–exams that are 40 minutes each, and you get to drop the lowest one. I'm not sure what they were like in past years, but coming from someone who did pretty well on them, they did NOT calibrate the difficulty correctly. Half the class barely passed the first one, and they weren't much better moving forward. You're expected to write way too much for the time they give you, and any short–response question is graded on whether you include 1 or 2 specific details about the question topic, so you end up just writing everything you know in the box and hoping for the best. They let you take a single page of notes into each one too, but there isn't time to really use it, and some questions are oddly specific so you still have to write mostly everything on it in order to answer those questions. Be prepared if you're going to take this class. The final exam was pretty fair though, so credit where credit is due.Homework: Classic PSET course, not much different from ls1a's PSETs if you did those. Get a weekly document, answer questions, go to office hours, work with other people, etc. Definitely get a good PSET group together if you're not already planning on taking this class with other people you know. Halfway through the semester, they reduced the number of PSETs, but that just meant they took half of the remaining PSETs and merged them with the other half, so each one was twice as long instead. In terms of difficulty, very hit or miss, some would be pretty straightforward and then others would take hours to figure out.So...yeah, that's about it. The content was actually pretty interesting, there's even a little bit of disease genetics and virology if that's what you're into (I was, which made it fun), and overall it wasn't bad – though, having friends also taking it and being able to study together and all that definitely helped. And if you've gotta take this class for premed, then godspeed to ya.
worse_comment: do not take this class if absolutely not needed for your concentration. If you don’t have a good bio background please look at the AP bio page on khan academy, prepare to waste so much of your time every week on PSETS and also taking PIES. The pies are so horrible, start studying a week before, go to every OH. The Preceptors, especially Monica, she is great. These comments don’t reflect issues with any staff member specifically, but the way the course comes together is a mess. Prepare for the anxiety of the PIES. The final IS in no way similar to any of the PIES. The pies are so math based and the final wanted us to do some fact recalling that was never asked of us throughout the course (except for the pie about cancer genetics). literally no idea what this course wants from us and I regret taking it because of all the stress it’s caused me.
subject: Life Sciences

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Genetics, Genomics, and Evolution 001
best_comment: If you're looking at this class, then odds are that it's either a concentration requirement or a prerequisite for something else like the premed track. subject: Life Sciences

best_comment: LS50b is a great class! If you took LS50a and had a solid experience, I'd strongly recommend taking LS50b. The topics in the course are just as expansive and interesting as the first semester's. I felt that the knowledge you gained from LS50a makes LS50b especially insightful for connections to research; you feel much more comfortable reading papers and understanding experimental design. A couple highlights from the course topics are: linear algebra, protein structure, machine learning, and population genetics. This semester's PSets were definitely heavier on the coding portions, but I feel that you are well–prepared for them. The community is probably the course's most valuable asset. After having spent a term together already, the student community already has a strong bond, and they always bring great curiosity to each lecture. The course lecturers are wonderful, and they make time to talk to students not only about course materials and but also about their amazing research. CA's are super great to meet, and they hold plenty of office hours for all your PSet questions.I'd strongly recommend taking LS50b!
worse_comment: Could not recommend this class enough!!!

course_title: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: Depending on your sub–team, the class can be very self–led, which is good for learning how to do things on your own but hard for understanding all the concepts and next steps. Just something to keep in mind! Otherwise, it's a fantastic way to get some research experience, develop a passion or research question you're interested in, and meet incredibly learned people in an area of interest! Angie is absolutely wonderful and very accessible over email (despite being a bit busy), and Alain is incredibly knowledgeable, always available to help out if possible, and very funny!
worse_comment: This course had the potential to be great, but I often felt like I had no idea what I was doing and didn't know how to get on track. This made for a stressful semester.

best_comment: Be prepared to spend much more time than you anticipate for this course. With a MWF schedule, lab component, 3 exams, lab report, and weekly problem sets this course will take up a significant chunk of time. The course material is well thought out and comprehensive but also means you learn quite a lot of material often at quite a fast pace. Finally, this is not a course that rewards you for choosing one of the harder intermediately biology options, meaning despite all the material and components of the course, grading can be stringent at times and exams can be both too long for the allotted time and too difficult, even though the course staff tries their best to support you. If you're truly interested in physical biochemistry, feel free to take it, otherwise this class likely isn't for you.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: I really loved this course and would highly recommend it to anyone interested in learning more about life science and cellular states and interactions. The content is incredibly interesting and gives you a great foundation of understanding that allows you to form connections between information from many different classes. In section and within workshops, you learn how to read, analyze, and critique research articles (which is a skill that I struggled with a lot) in a way that I found to be, if initially quite difficult, very engaging. Teaching staff for this course is amazing and definitely the key to what makes this class so great. In the end this is a class that you get out what you put in, and if you are willing to put in the effort I think you will really like this class and gain a much better appreciation for science from it.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Research for Credit in Molecular and Cellular Biology 001
best_comment: This class is a great way to do research during the semester without overloading your schedule! I would highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to spend a significant amount of time in the lab during the semester. Don't let the 10 page final paper sneak up on you though!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: I loved doing a senior thesis! However, be sure to prep significantly in advance to get the most out of it.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: I loved doing a senior thesis! However, be sure to prep significantly in advance to get the most out of it.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Great course and very relaxed! Florian has that dawg in him (truly, the man is so funny, so knowledgable, and incredibly kind) and the lectures were awesome. Also, the Matlab assignments were sooooo chill (like 30 mins to 1 hr max) and the papers we read were super interesting. Really enjoyed my experience!
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class. It is an absolute gem and you will learn a lot! Engert makes sure that you know you are not supposed to worry about your grades in this class and that he merely wants you to focus entirely on the content. The matlab psets are pretty straight forward and there is also help for them. you DONT NEED a programming background! So please dont let that shoo you away. The final exam was a little unguided because there were no practice exams or anything like that, but they say they grade it leniently so it should be fine. Choose a fun  project for the final project, choose something you have wanted to explore, that will make the work and research you do 10 times more fun. Overall, PLEASE TAKE!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Pr. Dulac is such a gem–– she's an incredibly well–achieved professor who works very hard to put together a super diverse curriculum to cover as much material as she can. The teaching team is great as well, they truly want you to succeed and learn efficiently in the course. I had only taken MCB60 (no neuro experience) and the course was definitely doable, it serves as a good intro/broader overview to neuro material. All lecture content was really interesting, and I feel like I gained valuable paper–writing skills from section. was my favorite course this year and has probably been my favorite course at harvard–– definitely recommend!!
worse_comment: This class is very boring and tedious. I do not recommend. There are no exams, but the psets are long and unfulfilling. There is no communication on the participation grade and how that grade is calculated, so grades seem very based on how much the TF vibes with you. As a whole, I learned nothing in this class other than how to control find in a textbook and paraphrase the text. Although this is an "easier" class, it is a waste of time that is still somewhat of a time commitment with no reward. There are, however, not many great intermediate neuro classes. This is an easy class with no exams, but just know you will learn nothing and be miserable.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Pr. Dulac is such a gem–– she's an incredibly well–achieved professor who works very hard to put together a super diverse curriculum to cover as much material as she can. The teaching team is great as well, they truly want you to succeed and learn efficiently in the course.
