All lecture content was really interesting, and I feel like I gained valuable paper–writing skills from section. was my favorite course this year and has probably been my favorite course at harvard–– definitely recommend!!

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: Good course overall. The presentation in sections are fun and engaging. Reading a research paper every week improves the ability to read them. However, the feedback and grading is kept secretive. Don't really know why. Feel like transparency would make people feel more comfortable with how they are doing and the rewarding experience they feel. Like is a 2 good? is a 3 good? still don't really know what they correspond to.
worse_comment: It’s low workload but not the most interesting

course_title: Interplay between Viruses and their Hosts 001
best_comment: This is a FANTASTIC MCB course! Lecture is once a week, with the other weekly course block dedicated to a paper discussion. The paper in question you are asked to read and summarize beforehand for credit. The final was to summarize and present (in 10ish minutes) a paper of your own choosing: a very fair and doable final which is done before reading period! Overall, I found that I learned a lot in this class. Victoria (the professor) is a great lecturer and is super keyed in to the newest research happening in the field, which is super cool. Took it senior spring and did not once find it monopolizing my schedule. Would highly recommend to anyone in MCB or those on the bio side of chemistry.
worse_comment: Very light course work; but dry lectures and unclear expectations regarding lecture participation and attendance.

course_title: Foundations of Systems Biology and Biological Engineering 001
best_comment: An amazing survey of systems biology! Cluzel is a kind, compassionate and deeply knowledgeable professor who will bring you through a series of fascinating substudies, combining physics math chemistry statistics and more! Really cool connections and mind blowing revelations will be made in this class, and the small size makes it intimate and easy to participate! Get prepared for a seminar style class and be ready to be wrong and right while learning!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: If you want a relatively low–stakes but nonetheless engaging course at the intersection of physics, chemistry, biology, math, etc. that can either fulfill an upper–level MCB or a Phys credit (i.e. there are so many reasons!) then take this course! Prof. Nelson accomplishes so many things at once: he integrates knowledge from a wide range of STEM fields in a way that remains accessible to undergraduates, 2) he presents coursework that is mathematically rigorous (challenging enough to be fun) but still steps back to consider the bigger picture (large–scale, conceptual, macroscopic ideas). The material covered in this course strips back the nitty gritty of the life sciences to the basics and allows you to peer into the ways in which each field builds upon and informs the next (statistics in understanding entropy, thermodynamics in understanding mechanics, mechanics in understanding biochemical/molecular behavior, etc.). Richard is also an amazing TF; he explains everything so clearly! If you take this course, lectures and section are both optional, but highly recommended; they're super helpful, but they won't affect your grade, so no stress about that. The psets can be a slight bit challenging but rarely were they too frustrating and there's also a lot of extra credit; either way, just go to office hours and Richard will make everything make so much more sense. Midterm was a bit weird because there were only four questions — the first three were super easy but the fourth one confused everyone. Overall, a very chill course. You get what you put into it. Highly recommend.

This is a great course! It is a great way to practice your presentation skills and get useful feedback from highly experienced professionals in the field. The workload is manageable, you only have to prepare one presentation. Highly recommend!
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! You will learn presentation skills that will be CRITICAL to future scientific careers!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Current Topics in Molecular, Cellular and Organismal Biology 001
best_comment: The papers discussed all fit within the same niche so it's quite possible only a few people will be interested in the topics.

course_title: Current Topics in Molecular, Cellular and Organismal Biology 001
best_comment: The papers discussed all fit within the same niche so it's quite possible only a few people will be interested in the topics.

You may not need to read every paper until you know every detail. The 1st priority should be to understand what is being stated in these papers to a reasonable degree based on your time availability. This will help each class function at its full capacity and serve each student. Then, the next priority should be in finding something exciting or debatable about the material. We're here to learn how to be scientists, and that is tiring. However, a scientist should be familiar with science in other fields, even if they aren't particularly interested in it. It keeps the science moving forward. All that being said, take this opportunity to do what will improve you as you start your Ph.D.
worse_comment: This class is going to suck if they don't change it next year. Just show up, get your attendance points, and sit through it. If you like historical science, this is the class for you.

course_title: Introduction to Western Music, from Bach to Beyoncé 001
best_comment: I really enjoyed this class! I gained so much from it and felt like I left the class better off than when I started. I learned a ton about music history, was introduced to a lot of "classical" music  that I had never heard before, and I think this has partially changed the way I think about modern music now that I know so much context. However, this year, the teaching staff had very unrealistic expectations. Despite this literally being Music *1*, the class was so intense and rigorous. It had a lot of necessary required readings from both the textbook and supplemental Canvas readings, and we were expected to not only know the content of supplemental readings but to know, by name, which author said what about specific songs. We also had "low stakes" short essays, but they still required lots of time and effort. And then there were the listening quizzes that were difficult and required lots of studying long before the quiz because we had to know niche knowledge about songs after identifying them based on a 20 second or so snippet of the song. This class simply required too much. I've heard that it was gem–adjacent in the past, but it definitely was not this year. In fact, it was probably my hardest class. Also, Professor Callahan is super enthusiastic and super knowledgeable. He has cool stories and is very excited to hear people's thoughts. He clearly acknowledges the biases in music history and reminds us why we learn about so many white old men. By extension, he teaches general sociopolitical history well and isn't afraid to skirt around uncomfortable truths of historical problems relating to race, feminism, or treatment of children. With all that being said, however, Professor Callahan oftentimes acted snobby or pretentious and tries too hard to let the world know that he is a legitimate musicologist. Overall, I think this was a really fun class, it's way more Bach and way less Beyonce (she was mentioned literally in the class), and it's very rigorous. I still would recommend it despite all of the negatives. But definitely take this all into consideration before deciding to take it.
worse_comment: This class is sneaky hard. I spent so much time listening to songs that we were quizzed on. The exams ask random questions about the songs that are just mentioned in one line of the text book. You must do the readings. If you want an A, and don't know anything about music, don't take this class. I took it pass fail and did decent on the midterm, but the other quizzes I got C's on. Sneaky hard, you have to put in work in this class and it is so hard to follow along.

subject: Music

best_comment: This course is amazing! It is an introductory course, so if you want to learn about music and why it works, you should take it. Professor White is engaging and makes the course fun. He is energetic, humorous, and knowledgeable and incorporates examples of pop music into the class. I took this course as an elective and loved it! Super low–stress, interesting, and enjoyable. The class is fun, and Professor White is incredible! If you are just shy of being prepared for Music 51, this is a great class—even if you're just taking it as an elective.
worse_comment: First of all, during this semester the class was thought by a different profesor so the experience might be really different when the other professor comes back (or a new one). In general this is a pretty chill class if you decide to take it like that. It can be more time demanding if you are new to music and are just learning everything but if you already have some background it shouldn’t be to hard as you are just remembering the basics of music. The projects are fun and also not very demanding. Professor white is really understanding and is willing to move due dates if needed. The bad thing is that there is a final so that not great but it is also not very hard
best_gem_comment: This course was awesome! It's a gem if you have some musical experience under your belt, and it is perfect if you're looking for a class to formalize theory that you have already picked up on through playing music.
subject: Music

best_comment: Definitely take this class/join HRO, there is awesome music making and community; it is rare to find such a high caliber of music making in any other academic university around the country.
subject: Music

best_comment: Collegium is a home for me. Coming to college, Collegium was one of my first communities. Now, after singing for two years, Collegium has become a second family for me. The professors/conductors are some of the kindest folks you will ever meet, and the community is full of positive, encouraging spirit. Collegium is fun, and quirky, and provides us with the wonderful opportunity to create mixed–voice music we all love. We have weekly dinners and cool socials often! We also have our own traditions and go on an international tour every four years. Collegium is one of my biggest commitments, and I can't love it enough! If you're interested in singing in a choir, then you should come join us!!!
subject: Music

best_comment: Glee Club is a great opportunity to see friends quite often and improve on singing and general music making abilities on a consistent basis. I loved learning and growing through singing in this choir and the yearly tour is awesome and a great opportunity to learn more about the world and other people in the Glee Club. Highly Recommend.
worse_comment: Do problem 2ä only
subject: Music

best_comment: Beware RCS and HarChor in general are going through some administrative and staff changes. It’s a rough time. Still, it’s fun to sing and make music with other people, in the fall there’s a lot of variety, and Andy is going on sabbatical next year so it should be more fun and chill than this year. Don’t get discouraged – RCS is a lovely community and a good way to do music without having to be The Best at it (though many are amazing singers)
subject: Music

best_comment: This is a very very good class to take if you have room for an elective in your schedule. The content is extremely interesting and engaging, while not being too challenging. Professor Abbate has a very careful, intentional way of speaking, and everything she says during lecture feels extremely relevant and interesting. The lectures covered both the history of opera, as well as the effects of different stagings and analysis of short sections of opera. The assignments for this class come in the form of 6 listening responses and 4 portfolio essays. The listening responses were short (300 words) papers about a section of 1–2 minutes of opera music where we wrote about what we heard in the music and libretto, and how this tied to what we were covering in lecture. They were short and chill –– they had a time limit of an hour but I usually spent about half an hour on them. The portfolio essays were longer (1000 words) essays analysing a specific opera or about our personal experience writing opera. They were also nice, they usually took me 2–4 hours, and they were pretty fun to write! Other than that, there were about 30 pages of reading and 30–60 minutes of opera viewing assigned each week, but I could usually get the main ideas without doing the whole reading. I really enjoyed sections as well –– they were a good way to remember everything from lecture, discuss upcoming assignments, and have cool discussions about opera. All in all, I really enjoy this course, and I strongly recommend it to anyone with even the slightest interest in opera who has space for a chill and fun class in their schedule.
worse_comment: Be aware that there is some basic music theory and singing knowledge assumed. They will go over terms in class but very quickly. The prof only talks for an hour usually. The assignments are not super easy even though they look short. Good class but not a gem!
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! It is truly a gem... in so many ways! When else can you learn how to appreciate the different parts of opera and the history of opera? It truly is not as intimidating as it looks, and the course is designed to be very welcoming and approachable from all fields. You definitely don't have to be involved in music to any extent to take this course, but it does help to have some background if you can. This is one of the most unique courses I have taken here at Harvard... with the BEST in the field (Professor Abbate!)
subject: Music

best_comment: Not going to lie, I kind of regretted taking this course. I just don't think it's the right kind of class for me. If you took music 51a, this class is not really any more interesting or fun than that class. If you loved 51a, you will probably love this class, if you didn't I doubt you will really like this class (that was me). If you didn't take 51a and know a decent amount of music theory, I think you should take this course, just to give music theory at Harvard a try. It's not miserable, but it's not amazing. One warning is that the lectures are kind of convoluted. His teaching style isn't the most organized or clear, so I would often times have to try to relearn everything from the handouts he gave us. Another warning is that this is not a composition class. The clear focus is on analyzing music, not writing it. Many of the skills cross over, but just keep in mind that composing is not what the course is meant to teach you. I found this frustrating at times, because I don't like analyzing music, but if you enjoy analyzing music maybe you're chilling. Homework isn't that bad, maybe 2–3 hours a week, plus the two projects. The last project is a three minute composition , which I really think we should spend more time on workshopping at the end of the semester to get those pieces as good as possible, but like I said, this isn't a composition class. This semester the professor tried integrating some concepts that were not just western classical music, which was really cool and I respect the idea, but I don't think it was executed that well, but I bet next time he'll know how to teach it better.  Don't let this negative review deter you, just know that it's not for everyone. A lot of people I think really did like this class.
subject: Music

best_comment: The time commitment for HRO and the response papers for this class are very manageable, but make sure you set aside enough time for them. It's so incredibly rewarding but it definitely is a huge time commitment, so make sure you really want to participate!
subject: Music

best_comment: I would tell students that this is a flexible course but that it is most definitely what you make of it and would most serve them as a valuable experience. I would also recommend that they do Engaged Scholarship and join CCV.
subject: Music

best_comment: Doing the readings is a great way to learn about the history of jazz as you develop as an instrumentalist.
subject: Music

best_comment: A wonderful class all around. Andy and Nathan did a great job keeping the class engaging and fun. Though there is a lot of "busy" work associated with the class, the conducting assignments make up for it all. Tons of fun and overall a great experience: highly recommend it to all (including thesising seniors)!

This class has been my absolute favorite in college. Fed is so deeply invested in the growth of his students, and while he holds high standards, he knows exactly what will best help an orchestra/singer to better internalize and perform a piece of music. Fed is extremely reasonable in his assignments, and is arguably one of the most knowledgeable professors I have ever met–– the content covered in this course did not solely pertain to music, but also to history, philosophy, sociology, psychology, and much more. I learned so much about opera through this course, but also took several valuable life lessons away from this course as well.
worse_comment: Music 127R has been my favourite course at Harvard; I could not recommend it more.

course_title: Cuban Music Through The Lenses of Six Selected Composers 001
best_comment: This class is fun! It's pretty chill, but a lot of the course material is sloppy and not really well organized. If you're willing to roll with the punches and open to whatever you should have fun! Definitely not a serious class, but you will learn a lot about Cuba and its music and even get a chance to perform, which is super fun!

worse_comment: Take this class if you are serious and willing to think outside the box

best_comment: This is the best class I’ve ever taken! Hans and Elena are extremely encouraging and supportive. I’ve learned so much from them throughout this semester and would highly recommend this course to anyone who is even remotely interested in electronic music or music in general. I was scared that I didn’t know enough to take this class, but that definitely was not the case. The 2.5 hour class may seem daunting, but the time always passed so quickly and I looked forward to going to class and hearing everyone’s work each week. It was also so so cool to listen to everyone’s final pieces on the hydra system in concert and I had a lot of fun working on my own piece.

My favorite course and one of the best all–around experiences I've ever had at Harvard. It's something really very special. Professor Iyer is a legend and remarkably brilliant and kind. Samora is as well; the feedback they give together is always constructive but honest and mind–opening. The small nature of the class and the way that ensembles move around also created a musical community that I was extraordinarily grateful to be a part of, both because they're all great musicians from all different sorts of backgrounds but also because many people I met in the class have become very good friends. Would 1000% recommend if you want to grow as a musician and an artist.
subject: Music

best_comment: As a graduating senior, I can comfortably say there are few things at Harvard I will miss as much as this class. It has been one of the greatest joys to make music alongside friends and under the incisive yet always warmly encouraging tutelage of the Parker Quartet. Take advantage of the gift that this class is while you can! It's a privilege to have this structured space to take musical risks and express yourself—and it really brings out the best in everyone involved.
subject: Music

course_title: Music Since 1945: Contested Boundaries, Alternate Visions. 001
best_comment: If students love considering diverse approaches to making music and a way to learn about the ways in which culture has shifted  (since 1945) through a creative lens this is an excellent course to take
subject: Music

best_comment: I truly believe that any student interested in music theory (or, to be frank, music at a theoretical level) in general needs to take a class with Suzie Clark. She is everything a music student could want — knowledgeable in the field, well–respected the field, enthusiastic, kind, graceful, and fosters a fantastic class community. I feel so lucky to have taken this class — which connected music theory to so many things that I hadn't an inkling of before. I would drop anything to take another of Suzie's classes again, and I would recommend the same for you.

This course is excellent! Discussions with the other students and the professors were engaging and the variety of student from the music department and history department brought together different backgrounds that made the course great!

This course is excellent! Discussions with the other students and the professors were engaging and the variety of student from the music department and history department brought together different backgrounds that made the course great!

This course is excellent! Discussions with the other students and the professors were engaging and the variety of student from the music department and history department brought together different backgrounds that made the course great!

Enroll! This course is intellectually challenging in a way that doesn't negatively affect you or your performance. The teaching staff are communicative, accommodating, and really spirited about the topics of the course. No reservations about recommending at all.
worse_comment: I wouldn't recommend. I thought that the TF in this class was by far the worst I've had in all of my time here, the class was poorly structured, the readings weren't interesting, the vibes in the class were hostile because of the grad students, and overall it wasn't very fun to have taken this class.

best_comment: This class is amazing. The materisl are student–directed and the discussions are student–led but Dr. Barjamovic will happily and easily help explain concepts, historical context, whatever he feels  is needed to push the conversation. There are almost certainly going to be higher–level students auditing the class (sometimes for the 2nd time) but dont' let them intimidate you! Learn from them! Engage with them. You will learn more than you ever thought.

This is a great class! Richard Cozzens is a great teacher!! the class is very engaging and you get so much attention from the faculty!! they're really invested in your success. DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS!

This is an excellent course, and puts into practice everything you've learned from Arabic AA. Ustaadh Richard is a fantastic teacher, and takes personal care to ensure that every student masters the material.
worse_comment: 1) Professor can be rude. I get students coming in late is not ideal, but nagging them all class about it is not a welcoming learning environment anyone wants to be in. Attitude really needs to change because the behavior with students is unacceptable at times.  Throwing a marker at student, for example, was crossing a line.2) Too many assignments. Hard to keep track of all of these "smaller pieces" and easy to mess up your grade just because there are so many moving bits you can lose track of. There should be more "big assignments" that are longer term and less assignments overall.  3) Lecture is not engaging and does not review course material effectively. The disconnect between the textbook, lecture and quizzes is large. Also, does not utilize more innovative technology or resources out there.  I was really bored, it just wasn't fun. 4) Feedback not helpful sometimes.5) Hard to access office hours w/course staff sometimes––I recommend calendly or something. 6) The class felt speaking heavy over writing heavy––there was a lot more speaking practice than writing practice. 7) In–class activities did not capture different levels of learning. The amount of time given for writing practice in class was sometimes not enough for some to complete their work. Lack of in–class resources other than the professor himself to assist struggles also did not help.8) Professor hovers too much over your in–class activity, you can't take a breath without him watching you in class, it's too suffocating. You aren't really allowed an opportunity to be in charge of your own in–class learning experience.

best_comment: This class can seem daunting especially at the beginning and sometimes when it feels like you are the only one not understanding what’s going on. This is a general feeling which most students tend to have but once you understand that what matters is that you make progress then it all starts being more enjoyable. I really can’t believe how much my proficiency has been developed in just 2 semesters. It is really a great class if you want to learn but learn really seriously
worse_comment: Make sure to do the daily homework and to ask questions in class! Don't be afraid to speak even if you think that you're going to say something wrong!

best_comment: I loved this class! Ustatha Dana is an incredible teacher who will really make sure you learn, but she wants you to enjoy learning too. The class is fast–paced yet she's always willing to slow down if someone's confused, and even though there are long grammar lectures, we had interesting and fun assignments that spiced things up.
Take this class!!! Dana is amazing and you will gain a deep appreciation for the Arabic language
A good continuation, if you liked Intermediate Arabic I. Worth doing some review over the winter, even if it's just vocabulary flashcards.

Please take this class. I have really loved Intermediate Arabic at Harvard. Prof. Amr Madi is the best person that you will ever meet. First, his humor in class, and his very sweet Egyptian accent, while he is speaking, will always be in my heart. His attention to detail and willingness to assist always is sth that should draw you to this class. Also, the infusion of dialects into the class, Egyptian and Levantine, spiced up things in this class for the better and exponentially improved our Arabic.

This class is time–consuming but so rewarding. If you have the time to allot, I’d definitely encourage taking this course with Amr. He cares so much and values the process more than the grades. I learned a lot of Arabic and this was one of the most rewarding classes I’ve taken at Harvard.

This is a great course and one that I would highly recommend to anyone interested in learning Levantine Arabic.  I found it super helpful to be able to learn directly from authentic media – not only was I confident that everything I was learning was actually usable in the modern world, but it was a great way to learn more about the culture and available forms of entertainment as well.  Ustaadh Richard is a fantastic and amazingly dedicated instructor, and it's evident to me that I've made significant strides in my Arabic abilities over the course of this class, as well as that that improvement is due in large part to the patience and care that Ustaadh Richard and Alaa Aldeen, our TF, took in their lesson planning, assignments, and extensive feedback.  They both consistently went above and beyond in terms of their dedication to this class, and it was obvious that each lesson was intentionally thought out so as to be as useful as possible to our learning.  Additionally, because students start from different ability levels , the class is largely participation based, which put some of the fun back into doing my work.  Lastly, I want to note how much I appreciate that this class introduced me to several language–learning tools that I will be able to continue to turn to in the pursuit of language learning in the future.

course_title: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture II 001
best_comment: Take this course! Professor Uthman is the best professor, and will help foster deep growth in MSA proficiency in a fun and empowering classroom. For anyone looking to seriously improve their Arabic, gain a better understanding of the Arab world, and have tremendous fun in learning Arabic alongside other committed students, this course is for you!

This class requires a lot of work –– each week there is a substantial amount of reading in addition to many other assignments.Your speaking skills will definitely improve in this class, as all discussion is conducted in Arabic but just keep the workload in mind. With that being said, Prof. Habib is very flexible so he will adjust the amount of assigned work based on the students' feedback so DO NOT LET THE AMOUNT OF WORK KEEP YOU FROM TAKING THE CLASS.

course_title: Islamic Intellectual History: A Survey of the Field 001
best_comment: Do the readings and come prepared to class. With that, you are going to benefit a lot from the immense knowledge of Professor El–Rouayheb.

I LOVED this class!! I loved getting to critically think about different parts of Jewish culture each week and discuss them in a small seminar setting. The diversity of readings (including tv shows, video game playing, eating) was awesome. Josh is a great teacher and created an awesome learning environment.

The class is really great. Morah Ran is there to work with you, and he is incredible. The class does not necessarily teach all the skills (it assumes some basic Hebrew knowledge), but you will figure it out and be fine! it's really great. Parts of the course could be improved, but Ran will be teaching it again and will be improving it.
subject: Modern Hebrew

course_title: Sectarianism and Islamic Identities in the Middle East: Modern and Medieval 001
best_comment: Very interesting class especially if youre interested in Islamic studies, religion, theology, or foreign policy. The class is very unique in its discussion of the intersection between religious sectarianism and geopolitics. The readings are interesting and teach you a lot about Islamic history and the diversity of ideologies within the religion. Professor Sagha is very knowledgable about the topic so I recommend going to office hours to ask any questions.
subject: Modern Middle East

course_title: Government and Politics of the Modern Middle East and North Africa 001
best_comment: This course was excellent thanks to Professor Shahin who kept the students engaged and interested throughout the semester.
worse_comment: Do not take this course. It will be a waste of your time. Most of the course is spent doing the the case study presentations where students are asked to make general presentations with low expectations, so pretty much a waste of a course slot.

course_title: Regional Order, U.S. Wars, and the Politics of Iraq and Afghanistan 001
best_comment: Prof. Sagha is amazing! He is obviously very knowledgeable not just in the politics of Iraq/Afghanistan but the whole region . He understands the nuances of regional politics (which is very rare among other Harvard faculty). This is all in addition to the fact that he is an amazing  human being, very accessible outside of class, and very understanding!Overall, truly enjoyed this class and would 10000% take it again if I could. It helped me better understand US policy in the region (even though I thought I had some background on this, I still learned SO much). Doing the readings will definitely help you, but you will also not be completely lost if you do not do them entirely (you might be a bit for section though). Lectures are posted so it makes it very easy to go back to them if you need to reference something particular for the papers.The assignments are straightforward and  fair. The prompts that Prof. Sagha posts help you start thinking critically about the material and are very helpful in getting you started on the paper. All in all, I do not have anything negative to say about this class. Take it if you are interested in learning more about US policy in Iraq/Afghanistan (which you should be if you are thinking of going into anything related to US politics!)
worse_comment: The class material is interesting but it was not presented incredibly effectively.  Lecture was really hard to follow, which made the material difficult to understand and internalize and thus made the assignments really hard to complete. This made the class pretty stressful and not super enjoyable  If lecture was better organized the class would be great though as the material is really important.
subject: Modern Middle East

course_title: Jihad, War and Peace in Islamic Law and Practice 001
best_comment: Prof. Emad Shahin is absolutely great! I wish I had taken more classes with him. He is extremely knowledgeable not just in Islamic law but also in the politics of Muslim–majority countries. This helps a lot with the discussion. He is also very flexible and funny, so you will definitely enjoy going to his office hours / conversing with him.  The only things I would comment on regarding the class is 1) I wish the class time was a bit shorter and 2) I wish the slides were more detailed. Other than that, I definitely learned a lot.

course_title: Historical Background to the Contemporary Middle East: Religion, Literature and Politics 001
best_comment: Great and informative course overall – not a heavy or burdensome workload, and offers interesting deep dives into an array of subjects over the weeks.
subject: Near Eastern Civilizations

best_comment: I would tell them to enroll in this course because Persian is such a beautiful language and Professor Ebrahimian creates a very welcoming environment for all students to participate.
subject: Persian

best_comment: fantastic course. ** – reasonable amount of work, lectures can be boring (but aren't recorded), but the content itself is SUPER interesting. teaching team is great – I loved this course! It's pretty easy – almost too much (repetitive with neuro 80) – so probably better to take as an OEB concentrator than after neuro 80. regardless, highly recommend. slightly disorganized class so make sure you check in with the TFs about ANYTHING you're not sure about.
worse_comment: Don’t blow lectures off because the exams are tough and information comes mostly from lecture
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This class is fantastic. You really get to dive into the research process, and even take on your own project. I loved this course, and found it super helpful in my overall science experience.

best_comment: Please make sure your research topic is one that you’re genuinely interested in so that you don’t totally hate this process and a majority of your senior spring because of it! I had a great experience since I love my lab and my thesis project, so I’d highly recommend thesising if this is the case for you. The Neuro department (especially Ryan) is very helpful and supportive throughout the process as well! Definitely utilize them as a resource!

course_title: The Neurobiology of Sleep and its Role in Mental Health 001
best_comment: Take this seminar!!! So great, Ed and Tony are really passionate and really care about the students. Manageable work, its the best neuro seminar by far
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: The Neuroscience of Learning and Memory 001
best_comment: GEM! Reasonable workload for a full–year course; Vincent is super understanding and kind as a professor and makes the effort to make sure you understand the content (TLDR: meet with him for help). Really interesting course about learning and memory that you can apply to real life. One of the best courses at Harvard I ever took, would recommend this class to everyone!
best_gem_comment: GEM! Reasonable workload for a full–year course; Vincent is super understanding and kind as a professor and makes the effort to make sure you understand the content (TLDR: meet with him for help). Really interesting course about learning and memory that you can apply to real life. One of the best courses at Harvard I ever took, would recommend this class to everyone!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Neurobiology of Emotion and Mood Disorders 001
best_comment: Take this class! Its a great neuro tutorial and one of the most interesting! Alen is so passionate about his work and explaining neuro discoveries in depth. It's so interesting spending time learning about medicine in the US, his homecountry of Croatia, and what advancements are being made around the world. Ask lots of questions! Read the articles in advance, and work with the students in the class to get the assignments done and you'll be fine!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This course is phenomenal. Chloe likely won't be teaching it in future years, but if she does continue then you're incredibly lucky. She does such a wonderful job facilitating conversation and interest in the subject matter. The paper readings are very manageable – it'd be useful to come into this class knowing at least how to read a paper, but if you aren't there yet then you'll learn in a very low–stakes setting. This course has been one of the best, if not the best, courses I have taken at Harvard because it effectively taught me how to critically engage with science while simultaneously distilling a lot of knowledge on different drugs of abuse.

FANTASTIC CLASS!! Kiah is a wonderful instructor with endless insight, gives fantastic feedback, has super engaging lectures, and is truly there to help you succeed and become a better communicator of science. Also a very laid–back and inviting classroom environment, which I really appreciated coming from some of the more cutthroat, larger STEM classes here. Would highly recommend it if you're interested in computational neuroscience, want to become a better writer, read cool papers, and be involved in a really great classroom environment!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Sculpting Activity: How Inhibition Shapes the Brain in Health and Disease 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS (pt. 2)! Saad is so awesome and a great tutorial lead. You will grow so much in your knowledge of neuro in a really nice environment. Everyone is super supportive throughout the course. The assignments are also super applicable to real research work, and allowed me to grow in that way. If you are thinking about signing up even a bit, DO IT!! It’s really a great course, maybe my favorite.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: Great course and very relaxed! Florian has that dawg in him (truly, the man is so funny, so knowledgable, and incredibly kind) and the lectures were awesome. Also, the Matlab assignments were sooooo chill (like 30 mins to 1 hr max) and the papers we read were super interesting. Really enjoyed my experience!
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class. It is an absolute gem and you will learn a lot! Engert makes sure that you know you are not supposed to worry about your grades in this class and that he merely wants you to focus entirely on the content. The matlab psets are pretty straight forward and there is also help for them. you DONT NEED a programming background! So please dont let that shoo you away. The final exam was a little unguided because there were no practice exams or anything like that, but they say they grade it leniently so it should be fine. Choose a fun  project for the final project, choose something you have wanted to explore, that will make the work and research you do 10 times more fun. Overall, PLEASE TAKE!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This is a really cool class if you enjoyed the first half of neuro80 about ion channels etc. It just a deeper dive into that and the pace of the class is really good and manageable. You will have time to fully understand most of the concepts and in lab you actually get to patch clamp neurons and record from them which is very exciting. You can record action potentials and actually measure currents through K and Na channels. It's also actually collecting data and you'll learn some useful lab skills.Furthermore, the teaching staff is really nice and excited/passionate about the material. I had a really good time in this course and have a better appreciation of how plasticity and ion channel characteristic can lead to different types of action potentials and synaptic responses and how that can have impact on behavior and firing patterns. Really cool class, def recommend.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: This is a really cool class if you enjoyed the first half of neuro80 about ion channels etc. It just a deeper dive into that and the pace of the class is really good and manageable. subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Pr. Dulac is such a gem–– she's an incredibly well–achieved professor who works very hard to put together a super diverse curriculum to cover as much material as she can. The teaching team is great as well, they truly want you to succeed and learn efficiently in the course. I had only taken MCB60 (no neuro experience) and the course was definitely doable, it serves as a good intro/broader overview to neuro material. All lecture content was really interesting, and I feel like I gained valuable paper–writing skills from section. was my favorite course this year and has probably been my favorite course at harvard–– definitely recommend!!
worse_comment: This class is very boring and tedious. I do not recommend. There are no exams, but the psets are long and unfulfilling. There is no communication on the participation grade and how that grade is calculated, so grades seem very based on how much the TF vibes with you. As a whole, I learned nothing in this class other than how to control find in a textbook and paraphrase the text. Although this is an "easier" class, it is a waste of time that is still somewhat of a time commitment with no reward. There are, however, not many great intermediate neuro classes. This is an easy class with no exams, but just know you will learn nothing and be miserable.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Pr. Dulac is such a gem–– she's an incredibly well–achieved professor who works very hard to put together a super diverse curriculum to cover as much material as she can. The teaching team is great as well, they truly want you to succeed and learn efficiently in the course. All lecture content was really interesting, and I feel like I gained valuable paper–writing skills from section. was my favorite course this year and has probably been my favorite course at harvard–– definitely recommend!!

best_comment: This class is essentially an independent research project with guest lectures. Some of the lectures were more interesting than others, and I often found that many of them went over my head. They aren't necessarily relevant for the final project, but it is a great way to get a sense of the kinds of research that is happening in the field. For the project, you really should have some coding background. I had never worked with neural networks before, and that was a learning curve enough for me even with a solid Python background. It's a great opportunity to pursue an independent project to put on your resume with the support of Professor Kreiman and the TFs. This class is really what you make of it though – it definitely can be as complicated as you'd like. And it's a nice exercise in research design and report writing. Just be prepared to be working on the project *very* independently.
worse_comment: Don't take this class under any circumstances. There is a way better use of your time than this bullshit
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Experience-Based Brain Development: Causes and Consequences 001
best_comment: Good course overall. The presentation in sections are fun and engaging. Reading a research paper every week improves the ability to read them. However, the feedback and grading is kept secretive. Don't really know why. Feel like transparency would make people feel more comfortable with how they are doing and the rewarding experience they feel. Like is a 2 good? is a 3 good? still don't really know what they correspond to.
worse_comment: It’s low workload but not the most interesting

course_title: Brain Invaders: Building and Breaking Barriers in the Nervous System 001
best_comment: This class is genuinely the best course I have taken at Harvard.  I've enthusiastically recommended it to so many of my friends to take next year. The material is SO incredibly fascinating, and Laura is a truly amazing lecturer. I'm one of the few non–pre–med Neuro concentrators, and this felt like a really amazing foray into some medical microbiology that I wouldn't really get a chance to explore otherwise. Every lecture, and student–led lecture/discussion, sincerely felt like a really elevated, academic YouTube video I was watching for fun and discussing with others in my free time. Helena is such a great TF, explains the papers in a really succinct way, and really advocates for her students' learning. Every week, I was so passionately excited to come to class and learn, and I had been missing that kind of academic enjoyment for a while! I cannot stress enough how amazing of a class this is! If you're on the fence, take it!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Biology and Evolution of Invertebrate Animals 001
best_comment: Gonzalo is awesome, and a great teacher. The class is hard because there is a lot of material, but that is to be expected. The exams are tough but fairly graded: he understands that it's impossible to memorize all the anatomy of the lesser phyla and therefore they focus more on higher–level concepts.  I definitely learned a ton from this class, and the Panama trip is one that I am so thankful to have gone on and that is one of my high points at Harvard. That being said, the people in this class really make or break it. You will spend a lot of time with them (~7 hours/week in lecture + lab, plus an entire week on the fieldtrip) and by the end, I had had enough. Gonzalo is really kind to everyone and he wants everyone to succeed, but he also clearly has favoritism towards underclassmen (2 people literally joined his lab by the end of the semester), which made all the seniors in our class feel a bit left out, as though we were being discounted as not being worth investing in from the get–go. But again, the opportunity to snorkel in Panama and live out my marine biologist fantasy was one I will never forget.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: The History and Evolution of Life on Earth 001
best_comment: If you are interested in the history of the Earth, take this course. The first half was very much focused on geological processes and wasn't particularly focused on life, which I found a little boring because I love environmental science, but I appreciate the broad understanding I have of geology and the formation and early stages of Earth. I absolutely LOVED the second half of the course, as we spent each lecture talking about the evolutionary feats of life and extinctions during subsequent periods. I particularly love ecology, and this course does an incredible job at teaching the evolution of ecological relationships and developments throughout time. This course barely has any work outside of lecture. Lecture slides are engaging and very visually–friendly. If I could I would take this class again.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: OEB 60 with Prof. Hartmann is an absolute GEM in the goldmine that is OEB. he does a fantastic job of making upper–level course material accessible to non–OEB students, and focuses a lot of the class on the impacts of climate change and general marine ecology. Great way to balance out a semester with more time–consuming courses. Going to lecture is worth your while because they weren't recorded and the material is just taught in a great way with tons of guest speakers, and most of the projects and papers give you the choice to find a topic that you're really passionate about. Grading isn't harsh at all.  The chill final paper and no final exam are a HUGE bonus. TFs are also super helpful, and prof Hartmann is a genuinely kind and caring individual that cares about spreading his passion on coral reef conservation and sharing a lot of his own experiences from working in the field. Please take this course if you get the opportunity!
worse_comment: Take this class!!! OEB or not, you'll enjoy it and get a lot out of it.
best_gem_comment: If you have any interest in learning about the ocean, its inhabitants, or human impact on marine life, TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! Such an amazing course, the assignments are all super fun and not too difficult, and Professor Hartmann is so friendly and accessible. There are a lot of diverse components to the grading (participation, group quizzes, one exam, papers, video project, in–class debate, etc.) so you never have to stress about any one assignment. The class has a pretty hefty collaborative component (weekly quizzes with a group of ~5 people + peer editing, debates, and mini projects with that same group), which I found very fun and engaging but might not be for everyone if you don't like group work. Note that this class is very much "you get out what you put it" – can totally be a gem if you want to put in minimal effort, but if you engage with the material and your group members, you'll have a much more enriching (and fun) experience. Overall 10/10 you should take this course. Genuinely enjoyed going to class for every lecture.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: From Darwin to Derrida: The Evolution of Meaning and Purpose SEM
best_comment: Take OEB 128! Prof. Haig is just absolutely lovely and so knowledgable and the book is interesting. Class discussion varied wildly, which was fun. Of note: take a look at the first few chapters first (I believe you have to read Ch. 1 to petition for the course anyway) and if the book is not for you, then you may not enjoy the class. I found it interesting, and thoroughly enjoyed my experience in this course.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I loved this class! Professor Lauder is an excellent professor and the best professor I’ve had at Harvard. Even those who don’t know a lot about fish can learn so much during this class.Most of the class is straightforward and it’s relatively easy to do well, BUT the tests are memorization–heavy. I wish there had been more “application” of concepts learned instead of rote memorization, but I also get that phylogenies and anatomy are just…things you have to memorize and can’t “apply.” Labs were super fun, and viewing the specimen in the museum’s collection during class was a once–in–a–lifetime opportunity. The TFs and Professor Lauder were so nice and clearly wanted you to do well and understand the concepts. Definitely take this class if you have any open slots in your schedule!

I am a graduating senior and this is the best course I have taken at Harvard and the best class I have ever taken in my life. Jim is such a wonderful person and is an incredible lecturer. He is humorous and generates great enthusiasm for herpetology. The teaching staff was amazing. I can say with confidence that the spring break field trip to Costa Rica was the best week of my life, and I experienced many beautiful moments with amazing people. The whole structure of the course and the sequence of lectures was super engaging and made it easy to follow along. The guest lectures were super cool. Labs were incredible, as we got to work with dozens of incredible specimens. Please take this course. I am begging you.
worse_comment: Take it pass fail

best_comment: The course if very fun and chill! I really liked the organizational structure of the course, where we just read papers and then go in the class every day to present. The teaching staff is also really nice and caring towards the students!
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: For undergrads, I think this course is a lot like LS1B but with Stat 110 + more depth. They very casually will throw in distributions like the Poisson, Exponential, NBin, Binomial, Geometric, Gaussian, and kind of expect you to know and be comfortable with those + using their PMFs/CDFs right away, so for people without that exposure, it can feel a bit like using mystery formulas. I think that some of the math gets really complicated with partial differential equations + everything, but they mostly abstract it away, so you don't really have to be able to derive anything. I think the first exam was fair + very similar to the psets, and the second exam was much more difficult (at least the first question was much more difficult) as the content covered was also a bit more involved mathematically + statistically. Definitely try to understand the psets, whether before or after they are due, and pay attention in lecture!! I would always give myself a solid amount of time to really think + check + work through the exams, so even though they are take–home + open–book, definitely take them seriously because your grade is basically determined by these two exams.
worse_comment: This is a chill upper level oeb course that lets you explore more quantitative biology in a lower stress way (psets completion based). Desai is also a really interesting lecturer.  However, the pset reviews felt like a waste of time and the course is very unstructured which can make it difficult to learn/retain information.

best_comment: For undergrads, I think this course is a lot like LS1B but with Stat 110 + more depth. They very casually will throw in distributions like the Poisson, Exponential, NBin, Binomial, Geometric, Gaussian, and kind of expect you to know and be comfortable with those + using their PMFs/CDFs right away, so for people without that exposure, it can feel a bit like using mystery formulas. best_comment: As always, John is a fantastic professor to learn from and have discussions with. I really enjoyed the course and found the time I put into it each week to be time well–spent. I would recommend the course to those who are interested in diving into specific topics of evolutionary genetics and in strengthening their skills in critical reading of the literature — this course is a great space to develop those skills in a comfortable, non–judgmental setting among peers.

course_title: Microbial Sciences: Chemistry, Ecology and Evolution 001
best_comment: OEB 290 is a great course that exposes you to many different facets of evolution and ecology in microbiology. It can be extremely low effort, though the time required can scale based on how closely you read the papers (I appreciated the flexibility when certain weeks of the semester became rough). Assignments are structured to be useful for fellowship applications – I'd highly recommend this class for anyone looking to explore this field before grad school fellowship applications.
worse_comment: This class is not a ton of work but the actual material itself is very difficult to understand.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: Have fun! It’s a chill course and great to have free dinners.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

course_title: Self and World: An Introduction to Early Modern Philosophy 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE. I've only taken eight courses at Harvard so far, but this has been my favorite one, with Math 101 being a close second.Every component of this course was wonderful. Professor Simmons' lectures are engaging, exciting, clear, and I genuinely only checked my phone a couple of times during lecture across the entire semester. They were that captivating.Almost all of the readings were extremely doable, roughly 1–2 hours per reading/class (so, 2 or 3 times per week). More than doable, the readings were like the lectures—engaging and exciting. Not always clear, but that's what the lectures are for!Office hours were one of my favorite aspects of the course; I liked them so much that I ended up going to almost every one I could physically attend. I sometimes came with questions prepared, either about concepts I wanted to clarify further or curiosities that went beyond the lecture. Sometimes, though, I just showed up ready to hear what other people had to ask about/say. Because it's an intro class, office hours had people from all (prospective) concentrations—physics, neuro, math, philosophy, and more. This made them a million times better, since everyone would bring their own unique perspective (either based on their concentration or other interests) to the discussion.Finally, assignments were extremely manageable and rewarding. The courses is not too writing–intensive. You will write no more than a total of 3,000 words across the entire semester, split up into four short (250–500 word) essays and one longer (1,250 word) essay.I had always been slightly interested in philosophy, but I had never done much reading before, and I had not read a page of metaphysics. I was totally fine, and came out of the class loving metaphysics, wanting to take as many more philosophy courses as possible, and potentially concentrate.DO take this class if you:– Have no background in philosophy– Have some background in philosophy– Have a lot of background in philosophy– Are curious about philosophy– Are not curious about philosophy– Have read any/most/all of the readings in the syllabus (yes, even you! You'll get so much out of Professor Simmons lectures and office hours)– Are a first–year, sophomore, junior, senior, grad student, or any other kind of learner– Are concentrating in philosophy– Are not concentrating in philosophy– Are curious about the world around you– Are curious about what it means to be you– Haven't taken it before(Maybe) DON'T take this class if you:– Have taken it before (honestly, you could still get a bunch more out of it a second time)Disclaimer #1: this class is geared to people who are totally new to philosophy, so if you've read a bunch of metaphysical Descartes, Hume, or Kant before, some of the information might be redundant. However, this introductory–mindedness allows you to get as much out of the class as you put into it. If you just go to lecture and section without doing any of the readings or going to office hours, you'll still get a bunch out of the class. However, you will get so, so much more if you do all (or most, like me!) of the readings and go to office hours with questions or just to listen to other peoples' thoughts.Disclaimer #2: be prepared to rethink everything you thought you knew about the world around you and what it means to be you.At this point, I realize I have not given enough credit to Professor Simmons. From day 1, she was the most compassionate, understanding, funny, and smart professor I have had here so far (or ever in my life, most likely). She genuinely cares about all of her students, and entertained all of our questions no matter how silly or off–topic.I truly cannot praise this class, or Professor Simmons, enough.The ONE thing I didn't love about this course were the three lectures (Sor Juana, Poullain, and Astell) in which it was clear that Professor Simmons was not totally clear on the thinker's concepts herself. The lectures were still good, but at times she tripped over her words and admitted that she wasn't exactly sure what the thinker meant about something. The great part about this is that the next time she teaches Phil 8, she will surely be more comfortable and confident with these lectures!P.S. Shoutout to our TF, Luke Ciancarelli—he probably won't TF this course again, but he was part of what made this class special.
best_gem_comment: Excellent course. Prof Simmons is an absolute gem of a professor and the TF Luke was fantastic as well. This course was a great introduction to philosophy. It is great at teaching how to read more carefully and write with more precision and clarity. I don't think it would be an exaggeration to say that this course changed the way I think – about philosophy but also science.

best_comment: This was my first philosophy class, and it was such a wonderful introduction to philosophy reading and writing. Emilio's lecture notes are extremely clear and his lectures follow them very closely. The readings are really interesting and flow naturally throughout the class, and I really appreciated the teaching staff's efforts to figure out students' interests and tailor the readings to them.  Ryan's sections were also just so fun, and though he did a good job of keeping us on track he is also very fun and welcomed brief humorous diversions. I had a really fun time working on the assignment as well, which scale up naturally over the semester cumulating in a ~10–page paper on essentially whatever you want in the class.
worse_comment: This is not an intro class. The readings are fairly long and hard, and you need to do them as sometimes you may be quizzed randomly. The lectures are very dry and most of the time it is just the lecturer going through the reading, which is often not clear and will have to be reviewed in section.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! When people talk about how they took a class and it changed their life, I thought that was total BS. But this class truly did that for me. The readings –– if you do them, which you should, they're worth it –– make you think about your values. Why you have them, are they good values to have. Especially recommend if you feel like you're going through the motions in classes, and you are searching to actually learn something meaningful. And learn something that matters. This was the first philosophy class I've ever taken, and it was extremely accessible and easy to understand. I feel like I have a better grasp on analyzing the people around me and their values, as well as my own. Why I want to be a good person. So many important questions that we should all ask ourselves. So eternally grateful for this class <3
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!!The course staff promises that background in philosophy is not required but this is a LIE. You will not do well on the response papers if you don't have previous experience or don't write for The Crimson. In fact, I was told by the professor to approach the application papers as a good editorial piece from The Crimson. While this is great, it does not help when that is not your strength. I have never felt worse about myself as a student and writer. ALSO, there is only one correct interpretation of the philosophy and papers. If yours does not align with the TF, your grade will suffer.  While the teaching staff is readily available, they do not provide actual help. Instead, it's a lot of fluff but leaves you to figure out the rest even when you express feeling lost or not familiar with the writing. THE GRADING IS SUPER HARSH!Basically:– boring lectures– harsh grading– experience in philosophical writing REQUIRED– waste of your timeThe section discussions with other students is the only thing going for the class

best_comment: Take this course if you're a philosophy concentrator and thinking of writing a thesis. It's not a lot of work and you'll get an A, so don't worry about that stuff, but you actually learn a TON about how to write well (and how to write well in philosophy in particular).
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: The PHIL 97 tutorial on Indoctrination has so many interesting and relevant topics in philosophy, though the discussion in the course felt forced, and even when it was clear that there was not much left to talk about and the room was silent, instead of ending it there the instructor would try to force new discussion. The course also lacked instruction on how to write a philosophy research paper, although I thought that was the focus of the tutorial in philosophy.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Ian is great. The material for this class gets a little wacky, but it’s cool to say you’ve read Wittgenstein I guess. Tutorials can be tedious but Ian does a good job giving you genuine feedback about improving as a writer so you feel like you’re doing more than just fulfilling a requirment
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: I took the course with Emilio and would definitely recommend ranking his section highly. He keeps the structure of the work really flexible, so its easy to fit this class into any schedule. The course touches on some interesting ethical debates, though some of the issues do feel slightly dated. Overall though, I felt like I had a lot of freedom to focus my thinking and writing on the areas that I found most interesting.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: I took the course with Emilio and would definitely recommend ranking his section highly. He keeps the structure of the work really flexible, so its easy to fit this class into any schedule. The course touches on some interesting ethical debates, though some of the issues do feel slightly dated. Overall though, I felt like I had a lot of freedom to focus my thinking and writing on the areas that I found most interesting.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Great course! The material is very interesting, the course instructor is great, and overall I am extremely glad I chose this tutorial!
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Phil 98 is a really nice opportunity to have personalized feedback and small discussions with your peers in a conducive way to learning. Caitlin was a super organized and knowledgeable TF, if you get the opportunity to take the class with her, I’d highly recommend taking it.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Take this course!!! Professor Matherne is probably the best lecturer in the philosophy department (you can ask a question in class and she'll fully just know, off the top of her head, the page number in the book that corresponds to an answer to your question). She writes everything clearly on the blackboard and explains the thinkers in depth, so don't be intimidated by the readings if you find them complicated because she'll walk you through it. The midterms are graded not that harshly and office hours are extremely helpful so make sure to go before you turn in the midterms. Most importantly, the class is super interesting and will actually help you lead a better life (unlike most classes here) helping you think through why art might be crucial for doing so.
worse_comment: Prof Matherne is awesome! Take a class with her at all costs! This course was great, but also recognize that it is a course about aesthetics, so if you are not interested in art and its role in the meaningful life, you might get frustrated that that is always the angle. Assignments weren't too onerous.

best_comment: Professor Bernhard Nickel is one of the best Philosophy professors at Harvard. You would be hard pressed to find someone more dedicated, more welcoming, or more perspicuous. So, absolutely take this class. The philosophy of language has implications for the rest of analytic philosophy. Once you enter, you'll find that this subfield has contemporary stakes –– in domains such as pornography, Twitter, and hate speech. The material is knotty –– you'll be bewildered plenty of times –– but you have the best guide leading you through. Professor Nickel has a way of breaking down the most complex material into succinct explanations. Additionally, expect to find amazing intellectual diversity among the students. My year, we had, among the undergraduate and grad students, people from mathematics, computer science, economics, physics, biology, linguistics, engineering, history, and philosophy. That's another tip: for anyone who pooh–poohs the humanities, just enter the philosophy department and find a cognitive link between ALL disciplines. These classes are challenging but incredibly rewarding. They will ground your thinking in the fundamentals of logical rigor –– a quality indispensable to any serious academic work.
worse_comment: This is a difficult class, will grow if you engage with the material

best_comment: I highly recommend this class not just if you are interested in philosophy, but even if you're interested in psychology, neuroscience, or computer science. We discuss very interesting topics in philosophy of mind like consciousness, intentionality, and the mind–body problem. It is also really nice that we only write 3 papers throughout the whole semester with no exams and our TF even gave us 2 free extensions on our papers. Professor Chen is a great lecturer because she describes concepts in the textbook very clearly and provides many examples to solidify our understanding. This is the best philosophy class I have taken so far after taking 3! I promise you will enjoy this class if you are interested in any of these topics and you enjoy writing over exams.
worse_comment: Poster course for "interesting, but not engaging." Super cool subject matter, lots of fun conversations with other students after class, but I found it quite hard to stay mentally checked in during lecture.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Trystan is a wonderful instructor. The course has many consistent weekly assignments (blog, QFC, and milestones for the project), so there's a lot to keep track of. The final project was a great opportunity to explore an area of interest, and I'm grateful for the flexibility that Trystan gave us. Guest lecturers were helpful and informative too. Overall, a good course.

I absolutely loved this class, by far one of the best I have taken at Harvard. Professor Schouten is an amazing teacher and facilitates an effective and fruitful section. She is incredibly attentive and accessible for help. The assignments are a bit difficult, but you'll definitely be able to see yourself make progress throughout the semester, and there are many opportunities to improve your grade. Those with a philosophy background will probably be a bit better prepared, but really anyone from and background could be successful in this course as long as they put in the effort. The readings and podcasts were quite interesting (although a bit difficult to follow at first). The class group project was quite involved, but so much fun, and I greatly enjoyed by time learning about and working with my group members. I thought I knew a lot about education, but this class introduced me to a wide array of issues and really challenged by understanding and perspectives. If you are at all interested in education, definitely lottery for this class!

This course is well–structured and dives deeply into philosophical questions and applications of inequality. I appreciated how we started with Rawls's theory of justice, then considered other philosophers' critiques and extensions of Rawls. The assignments (two 3–4–page papers, two 7–8–page papers) were reasonable and challenged me to think deeper and really understand and critique the readings. Section and lecture were dynamic and really helpful for strengthening and extending my understanding. Readings were very interesting and a reasonable length.This was my first course in philosophy, and I loved it.Also, I really liked how this course used empirical (quantitative) evidence when it was relevant and did not use it when it was not relevant (i.e., data from our unideal world may not be generalizable to an ideal–world philosophical argument). I had been wondering how to relate empirical evidence with philosophy, and I think this course handled it well.I learned how to build a rigorous framework and theory for social justice, how to consider objections to a theory of justice, and how to extend and challenge a theory of justice. In essence, I learned how to think holistically about inequalities in our society and whether they are just or unjust. This was exactly what I hoped to learn from this class, and I am so grateful. In the past, I had felt unequipped to address arguments for or against inequalities in our society, which I feel strongly about. Now, I feel equipped to engage with others' ideas about inequality in a critical, understandable way by pointing out their implicit assumptions, implications, and alternatives.
worse_comment: This class will challenge you to think logically, rather than making gut decisions about what is right and wrong.

best_comment: If you are looking for a philosophy or feminism course, TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! I accidently stumbled upon this course and I LOVED IT and I am so glad that I did. The professor, Remei, is a wonderful human who wants nothing but the best for everyone. She has a true passion for the subject matter and teaches it in an engaging way. The class is very low stress and low stakes (many of the assignments are completion based) so the only true grade you receive are your papers and they are fairly straightforward. I look this as a sixth class and highly recommend it. SO TAKE THIS CLASS!!!
worse_comment: This class is interesting at times and not super difficult, but I did find sitting in class boring sometimes since the slide shows and discussions of readings were not always super engaging. However, if you do the readings carefully and participate a lot, you can change the vibe of the classroom and make it more dynamic!
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Great class—you probably wouldn't be able to read these texts many other places (if only because most of the translations are very recent) and you certainly wouldn't be able to find someone much better to guide you through them than Parimal. He's great at explaining things and very clearly cares about his students and their getting something out of the texts. The texts are definitely tough though you get more comfortable with them as the semester goes on. I'd say that you definitely need some philosophy experience and that you should be interested in the subjects of most of the texts because if you aren't, the relatively slow pace that they demand will not be enjoyable. Would definitely recommend for most philosophy concentrators, and it's an added bonus that it fulfills the ancient requirement!

course_title: Special Topics in Post-Kantian European Philosophy 001
best_comment: Take this class if you want to learn about german idealism. Professor Kelly is absolutely amazing philosopher and an even better person. He will always treat you with the proper dignity due to human beings, and Professor Matherne is an absolute delight to work with. I sincerely look forwards to taking more classes with them both in the future .
subject: Classical Philology

course_title: Special Topics in Post-Kantian European Philosophy 001
best_comment: Take this class if you want to learn about german idealism. Professor Kelly is absolutely amazing philosopher and an even better person. He will always treat you with the proper dignity due to human beings, and Professor Matherne is an absolute delight to work with. I sincerely look forwards to taking more classes with them both in the future .
subject: Classical Philology

course_title: Electromagnetism, Circuits, Waves, Optics, and Imaging 001
best_comment: This class is very challenging, but it is structured to reward you for learning later on in the semester. Even if one or two midterms go poorly, you will have the opportunity for redemption. If you are pre–med and looking to fulfill the second semester physics requirement, this is definitely a difficult course, and you'll need to set aside ample time for studying and course work. I did not take AP50B, but I have heard that it is a good alternative to this class. However, Tim (preceptor), Gabriel (head TF), Dagim and the rest of the CAs and TFs are INCREDIBLE! They are so kind and helpful and are basically willing to do whatever to help you. Next year, I hope Tim does all the lectures. He explains this much more clearly and manages time more efficiently than Prof Franklin. I think Prof Franklin cares and tries hard, but her teaching is so confusing, and we never made it through a full lecture when she taught. Tim taught the back half of the course, and it was much better. In comparison to PS2, this class is much more difficult. Be prepared to go to office hours and do much more work than last semester. This class rewards effort. The more time you put in, the better you will perform. If you do the online section, PAY ATTENTION. Don't just click through and fast forward. Your learning will suffer and I found that if I paid attention during the section videos, I was able to grasp the material much better. I also recommend trying the section problems on your own before watching the videos. If you have to take this class, you got this!! Go to Tim or Gabriel for help if you need it. They are amazing and so kind!!
worse_comment: Oh boy do I have things to say about PS3. I took this class having done well in PS2 and liking the teaching staff despite not loving the subject matter. I went into PS3 expecting it to be a continuation of PS2 which in some ways it was – useless and tedious labs, long problem sets, 2 midterms with the whole unnecessary group exam thing, etc. So format wise pretty similar. The main difference is that the teaching and teaching staff of this course is exponentially worse than for PS2. With the exception of a couple of the TFs, office hours are unreliable (TFs often just don't show up). And don't even get me started on Tim and Melissa. Melissa has got to be the worst professor I've had in my time at Harvard in terms of her ability to explain the subject matter. You will regularly leave class more confused than when you walked in. She is an extremely strange person but at least somewhat entertaining (though I don't know if she means to be). You will literally never get through the content on days when Melissa is teaching. And I mean never. You are regularly 1–2 full lectures behind schedule and they still assign problem set questions on the content you haven't ever been taught. No more than 40 people (out of ~250) go to class after the first few weeks. By the time Tim switches over to teaching, no one is even there anymore. While he is slightly more able to stick to the schedule and manage his time than Melissa, his lectures are extremely boring and bland. This class is kind of a disaster.
best_gem_comment: Hearing from other students/the Q that this class was harder than PS 2, I was apprehensive to take PS 3. However, I feel like it was not more difficult, rather the material is just different. I probably enjoyed it more and I did better on exams! I really liked the labs a lot more than PS 2 since they actually applied the content we were learning in class and allowed me to gain an intuition for them.  As cheesy as it may sound, I literally look around my environment now and I am able to observe and recognize a lot of the things we learned about in class such as constructive/destructive interference and the Doppler effect. I definitely recommend this class especially to fulfill the physics pre–med requirement! Go to office hours, they are a gem.
