course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: TAKE IT. If you're not a physics concentrator but you need physics, TAKE THIS CLASS! The course staff are so so lovely and really care about making it a great and useful experience for students. Fun demos, retests are CLUTCH, learned a lot in labs, Anna and Kathryn are amazing.
worse_comment: I, unfortunately, have to take this course for my concentration, and I have no previous physics background. I, and my peers, struggled week after week when the lecture component was insufficient in preparing us for the psets. I understand this course used to be exam–free. In my semester, we had exams and retests. This was nice at first, but by the end of the semester, I had spent more time in the lecture hall for exams than I had lectures. I still think that the retests were helpful to my understanding of concepts, but I was so tired of taking physics exams by the end of the semester.
subject: Physical Sciences

course_title: Mechanics and Statistical Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: TAKE IT. If you're not a physics concentrator but you need physics, TAKE THIS CLASS! The course staff are so so lovely and really care about making it a great and useful experience for students. Fun demos, retests are CLUTCH, learned a lot in labs, Anna and Kathryn are amazing.

subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! It is a lot of work but SOOO worth it. Even as a STEM concentrator, I feel like I learned so much and it is so cool to look back and see all the cool things you were able to build in this course. Shoutout to Nathan and Kassia for making this course phenomenal and for always being very attentive to their students. I'm so so grateful I took this course before I graduated. This course stretched me in ways I could have never imagined. This course also attracts really interesting people, many of which I hope to stay connected to for the rest of my life. Please take this course!!!
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: I took this class to fulfill Physics requirement for pre–med due to weird concentration stuff. I was very hesitant going in because I had heard this class was super challenging and I was concerned it would tank my GPA and suck up all my time. I'm SO GLAD I chose to stay in the class. With a semi–solid calculus background, this class is very doable. Psets seem challenging on first glance but going to office hours is super helpful. Studying for exams requires redoing all the homework questions (it's surprising how much more intuition you build over time) and I would also suggest doing all the multiple choice questions in the book + practice exams because very similar ones are asked on the exam and this section can be killer. Also, this class has a great office hours COMMUNITY (there's food at physics night) but people are genuinely interested in the subject and want to help each other instead of just wading through another requirement like in other courses I've taken for pre–med. If you're pre–med //and are ok with math//, take this over PS2/3 because VIBES ARE SO MUCH BETTER and you'll actually learn problem–solving skills.Also, although Professor Morin is indeed not a great lecturer as previous qguides say, he is a GREAT PROFESSOR in office hours. He is super good at giving hints without giving away the entire answer and he is super approachable and encouraging. I'm not good at sitting through lecture anyways so reading post–lecture notes and going to section, I found I could get everything I needed to do well. I prefer having more in–person 1:1 help anyways, which is super rare in intro STEM classes.
worse_comment: This was overall a pretty good class. The PSETS are difficult and usually require collaboration; however, they shouldn't take that much time. Prof. Morin is really nice but sometimes the problems he provides are very abstract and hard to understand. In general, you want to start studying early! I know everyone says this but at least save enough time to cover a topic a day in preparation for the exams. Also use the textbooks that he provides a lot of the MCQs are recycled. DO THE PROBLEMS IN THE BOOK.
subject: Physics

subject: Physics

best_comment: Physics 15b is a good course. It is not exceedingly difficult, though, with all physics classes, certain concepts can be tricky at times. If you have a strong background in mechanics, special relativity, and vector calculus, you should not have much trouble with this course. The exams and finals are very kind and the grading is forgiving. This may not be the most stimulating physics course you take at Harvard, but it is in no ways bad. Of course, it also fulfills a concentration requirement. When it comes to the actual content of the class, I really enjoyed deriving magnetism through relativity, something that is outlined in Morin and Purcell's E&M textbook (the required text for the course). Of course, E&M can start to feel repetitive since there really are only so many E&M problems out there, but 15b will certainly give you a solid introduction to the material. I chose 15b over 153 since I hadn't done much E&M going into college, and though I think I would have enjoyed the rigor of 153 a bit more, 15b still covered plenty of relevant material. All in all, an enjoyable course and Carlos is clearly passionate about the material (I really recommend talking with them one on one! They're super cool!).
worse_comment: Dr. Arguelles is very enthusiastic about physics and willing to help, but they are not a very effective lecturer. Lecturers simply rehashed the material from readings with more confusing and less clear presentation. I don't think this is the biggest issue with lectures, but filling in the fill–in–the–blank notes is not as helpful as writing new notes on the board (as Dr. Morin did in Physics 15a). Also, they were not very good at understanding or answering students' questions, which (especially toward the beginning of the course when people paid enough attention to ask questions) led to uncomfortably long and unhelpful breaks in class. You need to attend lecture because there are in–class participation quizzes. (The main question was asking us to write a question about the lecture –– I would have preferred actual questions about the concepts. They experimented with ai–based comprehension of the questions –– I found this distracting and unhelpful and would have preferred to do physics questions.) I personally learned most of the material in the course from the book and sections. The class material is difficult but graded fairly. Psets can be hard and there are not quite enough office hours (Carlos' office hours were at 10–12 AM Mondays, which was particularly unhelpful.) Also many of the CAs tended to not be prepared for office hours and they tend to be monopolized by particularly zealous students in office hours. I did not find it helpful to go to office hours and wait for hours to answer a one–minute question. I took AP Physics C so had some preparation for the course, and I do think the course is doable with less preparation, but you'll have to identify the actually helpful sources of support and ways to learn that work for you, because I do not think Carlos' lectures will do that. A few bright spots: If Gemma is TFing the class again, attend her section. She is an incredible teacher and very generous with her time to answer questions. Also Jeffery's office hours are fantastic if he is CAing the class, he is a physics legend great at explaining the intuition and physical reasoning behind physics concepts.A lot of course communication is done on slack. Carlos is generally responsive but they sometimes did not respond to important questions. Midterms generally rehashed the problem sets. Practice midterms posted did not align well with the problems on the actual midterm (or the material we learned in the class). The final practice tests were more aligned with course content and the final included several questions from the practice tests. For all tests (midterms and final) there was a group portion. This helps your grade but I honestly did not find that it particularly helped my learning –– it was mostly just an annoyance to rehash all the problems. I would suggest making a shorter test with only the bonus–type problems (these were extra problems at the end of the group test). This would be more effort but it would be more helpful for learning to work on new problems. Lab was also very good. It is participation–based so watch out if you miss a few –– you'll have to make them up at the end of the class. However the participation based system greatly decreases the stress of the lab while still allowing a lot of learning. Anna and Gregorio are really great teachers.
subject: Physics

You need to attend lecture because there are in–class participation quizzes. (The main question was asking us to write a question about the lecture –– I would have preferred actual questions about the concepts. They experimented with ai–based comprehension of the questions –– I found this distracting and unhelpful and would have preferred to do physics questions.) I personally learned most of the material in the course from the book and sections. The class material is difficult but graded fairly. Psets can be hard and there are not quite enough office hours (Carlos' office hours were at 10–12 AM Mondays, which was particularly unhelpful.) Also many of the CAs tended to not be prepared for office hours and they tend to be monopolized by particularly zealous students in office hours. I did not find it helpful to go to office hours and wait for hours to answer a one–minute question. I took AP Physics C so had some preparation for the course, and I do think the course is doable with less preparation, but you'll have to identify the actually helpful sources of support and ways to learn that work for you, because I do not think Carlos' lectures will do that. A few bright spots: If Gemma is TFing the class again, attend her section. She is an incredible teacher and very generous with her time to answer questions. Also Jeffery's office hours are fantastic if he is CAing the class, he is a physics legend great at explaining the intuition and physical reasoning behind physics concepts.A lot of course communication is done on slack. Carlos is generally responsive but they sometimes did not respond to important questions. Midterms generally rehashed the problem sets. Practice midterms posted did not align well with the problems on the actual midterm (or the material we learned in the class). The final practice tests were more aligned with course content and the final included several questions from the practice tests. For all tests (midterms and final) there was a group portion. This helps your grade but I honestly did not find that it particularly helped my learning –– it was mostly just an annoyance to rehash all the problems. I would suggest making a shorter test with only the bonus–type problems (these were extra problems at the end of the group test). This would be more effort but it would be more helpful for learning to work on new problems. Lab was also very good. It is participation–based so watch out if you miss a few –– you'll have to make them up at the end of the class. However the participation based system greatly decreases the stress of the lab while still allowing a lot of learning. Anna and Gregorio are really great teachers.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Physics 15b is a good course. It is not exceedingly difficult, though, with all physics classes, certain concepts can be tricky at times. If you have a strong background in mechanics, special relativity, and vector calculus, you should not have much trouble with this course. The exams and finals are very kind and the grading is forgiving. This may not be the most stimulating physics course you take at Harvard, but it is in no ways bad. Of course, it also fulfills a concentration requirement. When it comes to the actual content of the class, I really enjoyed deriving magnetism through relativity, something that is outlined in Morin and Purcell's E&M textbook (the required text for the course). Of course, E&M can start to feel repetitive since there really are only so many E&M problems out there, but 15b will certainly give you a solid introduction to the material. I chose 15b over 153 since I hadn't done much E&M going into college, and though I think I would have enjoyed the rigor of 153 a bit more, 15b still covered plenty of relevant material. All in all, an enjoyable course and Carlos is clearly passionate about the material (I really recommend talking with them one on one! They're super cool!).
worse_comment: Dr. Arguelles is very enthusiastic about physics and willing to help, but they are not a very effective lecturer. Lecturers simply rehashed the material from readings with more confusing and less clear presentation. I don't think this is the biggest issue with lectures, but filling in the fill–in–the–blank notes is not as helpful as writing new notes on the board (as Dr. Morin did in Physics 15a). Also, they were not very good at understanding or answering students' questions, which (especially toward the beginning of the course when people paid enough attention to ask questions) led to uncomfortably long and unhelpful breaks in class. You need to attend lecture because there are in–class participation quizzes. (The main question was asking us to write a question about the lecture –– I would have preferred actual questions about the concepts. They experimented with ai–based comprehension of the questions –– I found this distracting and unhelpful and would have preferred to do physics questions.) I personally learned most of the material in the course from the book and sections. The class material is difficult but graded fairly. Psets can be hard and there are not quite enough office hours (Carlos' office hours were at 10–12 AM Mondays, which was particularly unhelpful.) Also many of the CAs tended to not be prepared for office hours and they tend to be monopolized by particularly zealous students in office hours. I did not find it helpful to go to office hours and wait for hours to answer a one–minute question. I took AP Physics C so had some preparation for the course, and I do think the course is doable with less preparation, but you'll have to identify the actually helpful sources of support and ways to learn that work for you, because I do not think Carlos' lectures will do that. A few bright spots: If Gemma is TFing the class again, attend her section. She is an incredible teacher and very generous with her time to answer questions. Also Jeffery's office hours are fantastic if he is CAing the class, he is a physics legend great at explaining the intuition and physical reasoning behind physics concepts.A lot of course communication is done on slack. Carlos is generally responsive but they sometimes did not respond to important questions. Midterms generally rehashed the problem sets. Practice midterms posted did not align well with the problems on the actual midterm (or the material we learned in the class). The final practice tests were more aligned with course content and the final included several questions from the practice tests. For all tests (midterms and final) there was a group portion. This helps your grade but I honestly did not find that it particularly helped my learning –– it was mostly just an annoyance to rehash all the problems. I would suggest making a shorter test with only the bonus–type problems (these were extra problems at the end of the group test). This would be more effort but it would be more helpful for learning to work on new problems. Lab was also very good. It is participation–based so watch out if you miss a few –– you'll have to make them up at the end of the class. However the participation based system greatly decreases the stress of the lab while still allowing a lot of learning. Anna and Gregorio are really great teachers.

subject: Physics

best_comment: Of the 15 sequence, 15c is more interesting and useful than 15b, but less interesting and useful than 15a. It is significantly less difficult than 15b and slightly less difficult than 15a. if you treat 15c seriously, you will honestly be fine. just don't BS it, and you should do pretty well.
worse_comment: If you can avoid taking this class (or the 15 series in general), I seriously implore you to do so. Frequently, an option is between the 12 series and the 15 series for other concentration requirements, so please look into 12a,b. You do not learn anything other than which equations correspond to what buzzwords in  problem that you can then use to solve it. Most of the time, no one understands why we are doing what we are doing, but the problem sets are so long and require so much outside knowledge that no one has time to slow down and think about why. The professor is also the worst lecturer that I have ever had and only writes equations on the board for an 75 minutes, most of which include typos because he is not careful.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is amazing, but make sure you have a good partner for class. You learn way more than it feels like it and the laboratory skills are extremely useful. Take this class!
worse_comment: This class is NOT EASY! I know they tell you it is. They're liars. The tf was so so wonderful and I think the professor cared a lot, but if you don't know code and you haven't done electronics before its pretty high level and very difficult. It's really hard, its a lot of time, and the constant failure decays the soul just a tiny bit. I feel 1,000 years older after taking this course. It is really cool material but you need to be a BIG FAN of electronics.
subject: Physics

subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is SO cool, but it definitely requires a high level of comfort with abstract mathematical ideas and notation. Lecture can be a little bit hard to follow sometimes if you've never encountered the topics we discuss, so definitely try to brush up on the basics before starting the class in case you are also coming from a place with little background knowledge. Jacob is an amazing professor who will really walk you through classical and quantum theory over the course of the semester, and having a good understanding of these abstract topics will definitely make lectures more valuable. Problem sets tend to get progressively more difficult with the weeks, so office hours is a great resource to have your questions/confusion clarified (and just to discuss quantum theory more generally). I definitely found this class challenging, but it was also incredibly rewarding to watch my understanding of quantum theory improve with time. Beyond just improving understanding of the foundational components of quantum theory, this class also intermixes philosophy in a super thought–provoking way (also – make sure to go to section for more philosophical discussion!). I think this class is super unique, and if you are at all curious about quantum theory, this class is a fantastic opportunity to learn more about it and the historical/philosophical context of quantum theory's development!
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS WONDERFUL. If you are at all interested in taking it, you probably should. Definitely take it if you are interested in learning about our current best understanding about the nature of reality and how the world works. You will get to learn quantum mechanics in an understandable and digestible way. This is a gem at Harvard; not in the sense that it is easy, but in the sense that it is such an amazing and wonderful and fascinating course that you won't find anywhere else. Additionally, you'll read some of the classic papers of the field, written by the founding fathers of quantum mechanics.You will also get to learn from professor Barandes, who is the best professor I have had at Harvard, and probably objectively one of the best. In the end, you will not only have taken a great course and learned a lot, you will also have a fantastic set of lecture notes that you can turn to in the future if you ever forget anything or want to review the content.The course is not very hard if you are comfortable with math and logic (having taken calculus is probably enough). If you are more leaning towards the philosophy side, it won't be bad. Professor Barandes tries to make the class very accessible, even for people who are not in a STEM discipline. You'll just have a to work a little harder on the PSets, which are primarily composed of (relatively straightforward) math problems.

best_comment: Physics 143A was an amazing experience!! Louis + the teaching staff are all wonderful people who really care about your learning. The content, which covers the fundamentals of quantum mechanics, is mostly engaging and interesting. Although some of the problem sets in the middle are slightly long and tedious, the problem–solving process was mostly fun and enjoyable! The grading and pace of the class are pretty lenient thanks to Louis's conceptual–focused approach to Quantum Mechanics –– you get plenty of partial credit on midterms and exams, and all the exams have a group section. You will learn a lot and have a very solid understanding of the material if you pay attention in lecture and section! Also, make sure you go to office hours if you want to ask for help and talk to the super cool TFs. TLDR: Louis is AMAZING, Quantum Mechanics is cool, and take this class!
worse_comment: Delaurier is great. I think that class is very well taught and reasonable in workload. I have no complaints. The only reason you should think twice about taking this course is if you don't care that much about physics.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is a great course, and I'd recommend it! The material you cover is challenging, but it is very interesting. We aimed to cover all of Griffiths' Introduction to Electrodynamics in one semester – this was an ambitious goal. This material is often taught as a two–course sequence at other universities, and so this class operated at quite a fast pace. I enjoyed it, but would have liked to spend more time on the applications at the end (chapters 9–12). Unfortunately, there is only so much you can squeeze into a semester, and so if you can't cover all of that material in depth, I'd still recommend reviewing it, because it's just super cool.In this class you cover a lot of really interesting and cool material. It starts with electrostatics, moves to magnetostatics, then we begin the electrodynamics, looking at EM waves and Maxwell's equations. It wraps up with applications such as waveguides, reflection, dipolar radiation, relativistic electrodynamics, and more. Lectures are fast, and so reading the textbook is a helpful review activity to solidify your understanding. Problem sets are also great for developing better intuition and understanding of the material.Make sure you are solid with multivariable calculus going in. I'd recommend being familiar with E&M at the level of AP Physics C: E&M before the course. I took this without having taken 15b, and found it manageable, but I know people who were glad to have taken 15b before, so if you're debating between the two, shop them for a bit. At the beginning they both cover electrostatics, so it should be relatively easy to switch from 153 to 15b if necessary for the first few weeks.Professor Philip Kim was wonderful. He is a very sweet and thoughtful man, and incredibly smart. Lectures are great. I was very impressed, after the first exam (which was brutally hard – many considered it the hardest exam they had ever taken), he solicited feedback from the class, and adapted. As a result, the class switched over to take–home exams. It's clear he really cares about his students and their success. He is very accessible outside of class, and always happy to talk. He is very passionate, and just a great professor!This is a challenging course, but I'd recommend it! Very interesting, and I'm glad I took it!
worse_comment: Overall, well taught! The psets sometimes take a long time, but are manageable. The exams are very hard.
subject: Physics

course_title: Laser Physics and Modern Optical Physics 001
best_comment: 175 is a great class with prof. Greiner, he is a wonderful lecturer and a great professor as well. The material gets interesting in the second half of the term, so expect less "Modern Optics" than the title suggests. PSets are pretty short and well–connected to the class. I think one can take 175 without 15c if they had previous wave/ray optics experience.
worse_comment: I don't feel like I got a lot out of this class because I took it as a fourth pset class, which I DO NOT recommend. It's not an easy class by a long shot, which I thought it would be based off of the Q guides from the year before. Markus is a great guy, and if you can make his office hours he's good about answering questions and clearing things up, but his lectures are hard to follow and his psets are SO LONG. I don't think I would take this class if I could redo this semester. But if you can make the time, I think you'll get a lot more out of it. There are things in this class that deal with quantum electrodynamics, which is important in higher–level physics classes. You could do a QFT treatment of optics!!! So in summary, this class is not easy, not very well organized, but you might get something out of it?

best_comment: i had really mixed feelings about girma's stat mech class for most of the semester but now im proud to be a big fan of this class and girma himself. girma has a very unique and i would say chaotic style of lecturing, where he goes into his own world and rambles on while scribbling on the whiteboard. he doesnt really try to explain himself to people, so you have to try very very hard to keep up during lecture. by keep up i mean understand what he is even trying to say, because the math is impossible to follow since he likes to skip steps and go straight to the result ("we dont care about the math, only the physics" in his own words). he is constantly thinking during lesson so a lot of his weird mannerisms and quirks tend to take over the class very quickly. but this is precisely what makes the class so entertaining and keeps me coming back for more. although it is definitely a true struggle to keep up and understand what he says during lecture, the weird movements and sounds he makes during lecture are rather endearing and pretty hilarious, to the point that several of us sitting at the front spend most of the lesson keeping track of how many times he did this or said that. pretty fun times, and definitely a big factor in making me come to class even though i understand very little from class. another major thing is that girma's approach to teaching is definitely an acquired taste. at the beginning, many people dropped the class because girma is very messy and not very careful with his reasoning or the stuff that he writes on the board. i really empathise with these folks and understand why they would want to drop the class. however, i would argue that these people missed out big time, since girma really emphasizes conceptual understanding and physical intuition instead of mathematical derivation and interpretation, which is uncommon and very profound at times in a subject as mathematical as statistical mechanics. even though most of his class is a blur sometimes, he likes to drop little gems of physical intuition/justification for why certain things are true here and there, which truly makes his classes unique in my opinion. at some point, people get used to girma's way of teaching, and the bunch of us that soldier on and continue turning up to class eventually get a feel for how to interpret girma's words and ask him the right questions. my personal realization is that the weird stuff that girma says is usually correct (except when he is blatantly wrong, duh. youre gonna have to figure this part out by yourself unfortunately). if you dont understand something, its probably because girma skipped a million intermediate and crucial steps, so what i personally did was raise my hand and pester him like a mosquito whenever i failed to follow for too long during class. often times, it turns into an argument between me and girma in the middle of class, but i always come out learning so much. besides, I think girma really appreciated the questions as well. even though he might not appear that way, he really really cares about student learning which is awesome. sections were mostly just review and not much else outside of lecture, but i loved it and so did a lot of other people, since girma is lowkey incomprehensible during lecture and we really need recaps every week. assignments seemed kinda boring and were just convoluted calculations at the beginning, but towards the middle and the end when things got really confusing, we really appreciated the homeworks that were, even though simple and routine, showed us concretely how to apply the principles we applied in class. girma's course notes are really amazing and literally saved my life during every assignment and the midterm + final. to conclude, definitely a recommendation, especially for students who are looking to not think so much like a mathematician studying physics, but a physicist trying to understand physics with math as a walking stick. i dont think i understand stat mech at all after taking an entire semester of it, but i think its more to do with the inherently confusing nature of stat mech, rather than girma being horrible (though i do admit that his teaching has a lot to improve on. but his intentions are good, which is what really matters to me in the end)
worse_comment: This class moves fast, but you are not asked to do anything unreasonable. Lectures are not too good, but the teaching staff is INCREDIBLE!!Also, go to office hours because the hardest part of any pset is understanding how to approach a problem and where to start.

best_comment: You have to take it for honors, but I honestly recommend it for anyone who is thinking about doing experimental science in general. Really really helps with conducting experiments and writing scientific papers. Do leave your schedule empty since this class will take up a LOT of your time, with 8hrs of experiments (or more) per week, but definitely a for–sure recommendation. Instructors are super helpful and friendly so :)
worse_comment: it's a lot of work, and the physics is really hard

best_comment: If you want a relatively low–stakes but nonetheless engaging course at the intersection of physics, chemistry, biology, math, etc. that can either fulfill an upper–level MCB or a Phys credit (i.e. there are so many reasons!) then take this course! Prof. Nelson accomplishes so many things at once: he integrates knowledge from a wide range of STEM fields in a way that remains accessible to undergraduates, 2) he presents coursework that is mathematically rigorous (challenging enough to be fun) but still steps back to consider the bigger picture (large–scale, conceptual, macroscopic ideas). The material covered in this course strips back the nitty gritty of the life sciences to the basics and allows you to peer into the ways in which each field builds upon and informs the next (statistics in understanding entropy, thermodynamics in understanding mechanics, mechanics in understanding biochemical/molecular behavior, etc.). Richard is also an amazing TF; he explains everything so clearly! If you take this course, lectures and section are both optional, but highly recommended; they're super helpful, but they won't affect your grade, so no stress about that. The psets can be a slight bit challenging but rarely were they too frustrating and there's also a lot of extra credit; either way, just go to office hours and Richard will make everything make so much more sense. Midterm was a bit weird because there were only four questions — the first three were super easy but the fourth one confused everyone. Overall, a very chill course. You get what you put into it. Highly recommend.

I took this course because so many people recommended it to me, and I'm very happy to pass on that recommendation. It's rare to find a class that has had this much care, time, and effort put into it from the instructor and TF. You will be able to leave this class feeling like you leveled up as a scientist in a way that is immediately applicable.

This course was great. The homeworks definitely took a lot of time, but I had so much fun bonding with students in my cohort while doing the psets. The take home exam felt fair, and the content of the course was amazing. I always wanted to understand general relativity after having heard so much about it in popular science, and this course did a great job of exposing me to it. GR is really beautiful, and it's not just for cosmology or high energy theory; I really feel like I have a better understanding of gauge theories in general now, and the way I look at E&M, quantum geometry, and QFT in general is totally different than before I took this course. 10/10 would recommend.

course_title: Holography and the infrared structure of gravity 001
best_comment: You can learn many fascinating topics from the course! For example, I learned an alternative interpretation of the soft theorems, which supplements my understanding of what I learned from 253B. The psets are very helpful for understanding the materials, and even though they are not always easy, they are manageable. Some knowledge of conformal field theories may be helpful.

Cora is a decent lecturer but a very kind person. She clearly cared a lot about all of the students in the course. There were 5 problem sets and then after that a final project, pretty reasonable workload.

If you're interested in biophysics, or generally applying physics to natural and biological systems, this is a great course for you. The guest talks are very worthwhile, and the problem sets have left me feeling very comfortable with the kind of math that is used in this field.
I love how enthusiastic the professor is about the material. That alone is a really good sell for the class.
It is a great class. Weekly psets can consume quite a bit of your time during the semester if you don't plan properly.
worse_comment: If you want more mathematical rigor, then this course would not satisfy you.

best_comment: This course is great! Professor Yin is very knowledgeable about the subject and he explains things very clearly, and he cares a lot about the students. The final project is a great opportunity to explore something you are interested in, and Professor Yin gives helpful feedback. Some familiarity with complex analysis is helpful for some of the early topics of the course. You will learn a lot!
If you have the opportunity to take it, take it!
subject: Physics

best_comment: This course doesn't seem to spend enough time on fundamentals and the foundations of quantum information/computing. Though the topics and scope are wide–ranging and interesting for this reason, many questions that regularly arise in class could be more easily resolved if we were careful with definitions and statements of results/theorems. The resources we had lacked clarity and consistent notation, including the homework assignments which sometimes contained consequential typos and had questions that we changed or recalled. Be prepared to reference other texts to better learn the material and formal justifications of results. To this end, even though some course staff/instructor(s) were wonderful and generous with their time, there was simply not enough time put into creating the assignments, the final, and course resources overall.This includes changes to the homework, office hour changes with last–minute notice, final project prompts which were not viable, etc. Some of these are matters of logistics, but overall, this course needed much more time and care to better represent a field that is ultimately interesting and important. The feedback we received on homework assignments was not very helpful for better understanding the material either. The feedback we (at least those I have spoken to) received largely overlooked significant subtleties which made the problems challenging and instead focused on minor details which were largely independent of the core concepts, to meet the assignment.All in all, the material of the course is very rewarding to study and it might be more interesting to those with a background in CS. But, ultimately this is not a course that necessarily rewards rigor and building a good foundation for understanding quantum information/computing for those not already studying/working in this field. You will get just as much out of this class as you put in, and it would be worth considering just self–studying this material using the text by Nielsen and Chuang.
worse_comment: I think course material depends heavily on who teaches it, since QIS combines both physics and computer science. I really wanted to learn the physics of QIS but learned the CS side instead because of Anurag's background. However, this perspective was really interesting and I'm still interested in learning more.  Background required: I felt that the prereqs for this class were misleading (which were know quantum mechanics at undergrad or grad level, linear algebra at level of 21b, and how to write proofs). I wouldn't say you even need to take quantum mechanics or know physics for this version of QIS. Instead, you need to know some TCS, information theory, and the math of tensors –– none of which was covered. We did have a section 0 that might have covered some material, but most of us didn't know about it because it was announced on Ed as a post (so none of us got notifications about it) 10 minutes before it took place. There was no announcement about it during lecture, which relates to my following comments about the course structure/staff etc. There were a lot of things that made taking this class frustrating. Anurag is a kind professor and knows his stuff. However, lectures were hard to follow (handwriting hard to follow; order of writing on blackboard was not left–to–right/top–to–bottom but more circular) and this made it difficult for doing scribe notes. Homework was only 3 problems and 15 points, and grading was inconsistent. You could make a computational error and lose one point. Or you could do half a problem but lose only one point. Or you could handwave an entire problem, not have your solution be correct, and still get full points. The inconsistent grading wouldn't have been a big deal if each homework wasn't worth only 15 points. Additionally, we used Ed for course announcements. But some important announcements (like section 0, office hour time changes, etc) were announced as posts, so you never got email notifications about them. A lot of times, you would retroactively find out about something. Finally, we were given a very short timeframe to do the final project. Discussing the final project was pushed back by several lectures, until there was basically no time left in the semester: introduce project and then the project proposal due 2 lectures later, draft presentation the next week, final presentation the second week. Overall, I felt this course has a lot of interesting material and promise, but would benefit from restructuring things like course timeline and grading. I do not regret taking it and did learn quite a bit.

best_comment: This course doesn't seem to spend enough time on fundamentals and the foundations of quantum information/computing. Though the topics and scope are wide–ranging and interesting for this reason, many questions that regularly arise in class could be more easily resolved if we were careful with definitions and statements of results/theorems. The resources we had lacked clarity and consistent notation, including the homework assignments which sometimes contained consequential typos and had questions that we changed or recalled. Be prepared to reference other texts to better learn the material and formal justifications of results. To this end, even though some course staff/instructor(s) were wonderful and generous with their time, there was simply not enough time put into creating the assignments, the final, and course resources overall.This includes changes to the homework, office hour changes with last–minute notice, final project prompts which were not viable, etc. Some of these are matters of logistics, but overall, this course needed much more time and care to better represent a field that is ultimately interesting and important. The feedback we received on homework assignments was not very helpful for better understanding the material either. The feedback we (at least those I have spoken to) received largely overlooked significant subtleties which made the problems challenging and instead focused on minor details which were largely independent of the core concepts, to meet the assignment.All in all, the material of the course is very rewarding to study and it might be more interesting to those with a background in CS. But, ultimately this is not a course that necessarily rewards rigor and building a good foundation for understanding quantum information/computing for those not already studying/working in this field. You will get just as much out of this class as you put in, and it would be worth considering just self–studying this material using the text by Nielsen and Chuang.
worse_comment: I think course material depends heavily on who teaches it, since QIS combines both physics and computer science. I really wanted to learn the physics of QIS but learned the CS side instead because of Anurag's background. However, this perspective was really interesting and I'm still interested in learning more.  Background required: I felt that the prereqs for this class were misleading (which were know quantum mechanics at undergrad or grad level, linear algebra at level of 21b, and how to write proofs). I wouldn't say you even need to take quantum mechanics or know physics for this version of QIS. Instead, you need to know some TCS, information theory, and the math of tensors –– none of which was covered. We did have a section 0 that might have covered some material, but most of us didn't know about it because it was announced on Ed as a post (so none of us got notifications about it) 10 minutes before it took place. There was no announcement about it during lecture, which relates to my following comments about the course structure/staff etc. There were a lot of things that made taking this class frustrating. Anurag is a kind professor and knows his stuff. However, lectures were hard to follow (handwriting hard to follow; order of writing on blackboard was not left–to–right/top–to–bottom but more circular) and this made it difficult for doing scribe notes. Homework was only 3 problems and 15 points, and grading was inconsistent. You could make a computational error and lose one point. Or you could do half a problem but lose only one point. Or you could handwave an entire problem, not have your solution be correct, and still get full points. The inconsistent grading wouldn't have been a big deal if each homework wasn't worth only 15 points. Additionally, we used Ed for course announcements. But some important announcements (like section 0, office hour time changes, etc) were announced as posts, so you never got email notifications about them. A lot of times, you would retroactively find out about something. Finally, we were given a very short timeframe to do the final project. Discussing the final project was pushed back by several lectures, until there was basically no time left in the semester: introduce project and then the project proposal due 2 lectures later, draft presentation the next week, final presentation the second week. Overall, I felt this course has a lot of interesting material and promise, but would benefit from restructuring things like course timeline and grading. I do not regret taking it and did learn quite a bit.

best_comment: This course was very challenging but was also very rewarding at the same time. I am very convinced that you can learn a lot out of this course, regardless of your research interest within physics.

course_title: Statistical Mechanics of Spin Glasses and Neural Networks 001
best_comment: One of the coolest (but more difficult) classes I've taken! The course moves very quickly, and you need to review the notes / do some extra reading to get everything. The course builds a lot of theoretical machinery, which all comes together very beautifully in the study of neural networks at the end of the course. On the problem sets you get a lot of practice with replica calculations in different random systems, and I think I got a lot faster and more confident over the course of the semester. Haim is a great professor and it's always fun to go to lecture.
worse_comment: This class has proven to be quite difficult. the course expects students to already know a lot of materials and familiarity with math and the content. Would definitely prepare a lot before entering the class.

best_comment: Great course! It covers a lot of important topics in condensed matter / many body physics, and Subir is a great lecturer. He motivates the physics well, even if he skips a lot of steps in the derivations ("when the dust settles, you get ..."). The final project — a 30 min presentation — takes a lot of time, but I thought it was a valuable experience. I feel more confident reading papers and attending talks after taking the course.
worse_comment: Consider whether the class is relevant to either your research or future class interests. The prerequisite knowledge should be taken seriously, as it may be difficult to grasp the physical intuition behind some of these concepts without them.

best_comment: You will really benefit from taking the time to choose a subjects for practice teaching carefully and thoughtfully and prepare multiple drafts of teaching notes. It will help you with a multitude of essential scientific communication skills.
subject: Physics

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II 001
best_comment: This class is excellent! You will be challenged to step outside your comfort zone because of the cross–disciplinary nature of this portion of the PHS2000 coursework, in particular, but it will make you a better researcher as a result. I genuinely learned so much that I never would have come across in my own field of study through this course. Furthermore, the teaching team is fantastic. Jarvis is so dedicated to helping students learn, and he is such an excellent and kind professor. The teaching fellows are likewise amazing and are also so passionate about helping students learn. This is definitely one of the best classes at HSPH.
subject: Population Health Sciences

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences II 001
best_comment: This class is excellent! You will be challenged to step outside your comfort zone because of the cross–disciplinary nature of this portion of the PHS2000 coursework, in particular, but it will make you a better researcher as a result. I genuinely learned so much that I never would have come across in my own field of study through this course. Furthermore, the teaching team is fantastic. This is definitely one of the best classes at HSPH.
subject: Population Health Sciences

best_comment: Took this class pass/fail –– probably could have gotten an A if I cared enough to put in the effort into creating perfect notes or overly studying lecture slides, but tbh I just wanted to learn about the content in the most relaxed manner possible and I think pass/fail did a good job with that. Pinker is definitely an interesting guy with controversial opinions (many of which I do not agree with), so it was interesting attending his lectures, especially since I have read his book in high school. Some of the weeks had particularly interesting content too (illusions, 3D, Emotions lectures), and Pinker does a great job with making lectures engaging with class wide activities. This class does overly focus on memorizing content rather than learning it, and I wish the questions asked on exams were not so specific to the direct facts mentioned on each lecture slide group. I would recommend taking this class pass/fail if you are interested in the content but don't want to overly focus on rote memorization and forcing very specific facts down your throat.
worse_comment: This was my biggest regret at Harvard. If I would go back, I would not have taken this class. I thought it wasn't going to be too bad because I already had a bit of a Psychology background, but I was completely wrong. It was actually one of my hardest classes and the class that gave me the most stress over the semester. You can find Steven Pinker's lectures online and he says the same things in lectures that he did now and lectures that he's done in previous years, it's all very memorized and doesn't seem that genuine. I would recommend taking Psych 1 in another semester and with a different professor.
subject: Psychology

subject: Psychology

best_comment: I definitely recommend taking this course. Especially for psych concentrators. Fiery is a beast and he gives lectures that are very engaging and very interesting. There might have been like 3–4 lectures that felt a bit slower, but the rest did justice to his name: they were fire! There are such relevant, interesting, and thought–provoking questions raised. I came out of almost every lecture saying that I loved the course. Section is also very interesting and helps consolidate topics covered in class in an interesting way, it just depends on your TF. But great course overall!
worse_comment: Do the assignments and review with your TF before submitting. Even if you fail the exams/barely pass, the assignments weigh so much that you can still pass.

best_comment: Assignments are fairly written and graded reasonably. A lot of students will say exams are too hard but if you have an understanding of the lecture material you will be fine. Just don't expect to be told what is going to appear on the exam or to receive a study guide. Section was super fun and Brian was the best part of the course.
worse_comment: This class was a pretty interesting introduction to developmental psych, but I just think that midterms and exams in general just feel a bit unclear. Not even the section TF knew what was going to be on the midterm (the section labeled as "midterm review" on the syllabus had next to NO review) and the materials are a bit dense. I only really realized how I should be studying for the midterm AFTER I took it, which was personally not the best. Great class to take for interest, but I would say expect more work than you think there will be!
subject: Psychology

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses 001
best_comment: This course definitely isn't easy, but I found it really helpful and rewarding! I found it pretty manageable overall, and I learned a lot about psychological writing. I would definitely recommend reaching out to your instructor with any questions you have and writing about a subject you actually enjoy for the final paper, though.
worse_comment: STAY ORGANIZED WITH YOUR PAPER!! You'll be working on this thing for AGES so if you're just saving citations and pdfs and tabs willy nilly, you'll have NO IDEA where to pick back up again in a month when it's time to write your first draft. Use Zotero, take notes about all your sources *in* Zotero with the little notes feature so you don't have to literally re–read every single one of your sources when it comes time to work on your draft like I did.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses for Cognitive Neuroscience and Evo 001
best_comment: I actually really enjoyed this course. It's a requirement for all psych concentrators so you don't have a choice, but the small class size is really nice, and it builds towards the final paper really well. There are a bunch of assignments but not an overwhelming amount, and they build on each other and prepare you for the final paper really well. I feel like my writing improved in this course, and it was a helpful course. Very TF dependent, but I loved mine. Feedback provided is also so helpful and detailed.

course_title: Contemporary Issues in Psychology: Intensive Cross-level Analyses for Cognitive Neuroscience and Evo 001
best_comment: I actually really enjoyed this course. It's a requirement for all psych concentrators so you don't have a choice, but the small class size is really nice, and it builds towards the final paper really well. There are a bunch of assignments but not an overwhelming amount, and they build on each other and prepare you for the final paper really well. I feel like my writing improved in this course, and it was a helpful course. Very TF dependent, but I loved mine. Feedback provided is also so helpful and detailed.

This course was one of the best courses I've taken during my 4 years at Harvard. EXTREMELY interesting materials, and great discussions. I highly recommend this course if you even the slightest bit interested in cults and why someone might join one. The structure of the course is set up so that each week we study a different cult, and each one is extremely fascinating. There is not a boring week. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!

This course was one of the best courses I've taken during my 4 years at Harvard. EXTREMELY interesting materials, and great discussions. I highly recommend this course if you even the slightest bit interested in cults and why someone might join one. The structure of the course is set up so that each week we study a different cult, and each one is extremely fascinating. There is not a boring week. TAKE THIS CLASS!!!

Take this class!! I want to go into law, and this class changed the way that I think about so many important issues within the criminal justice domain. It also showed me how I might be able to integrate psychology into the work that I do. The field of law always benefits from having more people who understand psychology (as we discuss in class!), so if you want to go into law, this is a great opportunity to learn things that will help you make a positive impact. That said, ANYONE and everyone can benefit from and enjoy this class – regardless of what you have studied in the past, and regardless of where you want to go moving forward.
worse_comment: I recommend! I got to see another side of Psychology that I had not otherwise been exposed to. Learning about psychology in a professional, legal setting was incredibly fascinating, even if I don't see myself going into law in the future. **Content warning: violence, trauma, SA, school shootings. These topics were not too difficult for me to handle, but I think it's worth mentioning in case any of them may be upsetting for you.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This class was truly the best one I have taken in all my years at Harvard. Professor Maksimovskiy exuted  a great deal of enthusiasm about the subject. Each day of class I learn something new that I have not before when I feel as though many of my other classes are recaps of previous knowledge. I am grateful to have had taken this class as it truly has opened up a new perspective on how I look at life.  DO take this class before graduation, it was the best decision of my life.***

I honestly think every single person would benefit from taking this course – it was so interesting – you learn so much about various clinical psych approaches and treatments and different disorders and I think it really pushes you to open your mind to different ideas and perspectives. I loved it so much and would highly recommend. Lauren is such a great instructor and cultivates a great class environment as well. Readings are super manageable, assignments are also super manageable and interesting – definitely take this!!

best_comment: This is a great class! It only meets once a week, and the discussions are super interesting. The professor is very knowledgeable, and the class is tailored so you can study what most peaks your interest for the culminating project! It's a great class! Highly recommend taking it!
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This is a great class! It only meets once a week, and the discussions are super interesting. The professor is very knowledgeable, and the class is tailored so you can study what most peaks your interest for the culminating project! It's a great class! Highly recommend taking it!

course_title: How Hidden Incentives Shape the Mind: The Origins of Our Beliefs and Ideologies 001
best_comment: This is SUCH A GOOD CLASS. Bethany is awesome –– so smart, so kind, so engaging, and makes everyone's opinions welcome. The readings are so interesting and you can choose your own essay topics so you write about what you care about

course_title: How Hidden Incentives Shape the Mind: The Origins of Our Beliefs and Ideologies 001

course_title: Psychology of Social Connection and Belonging 001
best_comment: Dr. Perry is one of the most supportive, caring professors I have ever worked with. She cares about her students academic and personal wellbeing and goes above and beyond to be available for students and ensure they can execute their work in the best way possible while meeting her expectations. I would take ANY class she offered.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! I am praying that Professor Perry stays at Harvard and continues to teach this course. Such a phenomenal and insightful seminar, the material is not super hard but applicable to life!
subject: Psychology

I would take ANY class she offered.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! I am praying that Professor Perry stays at Harvard and continues to teach this course. Such a phenomenal and insightful seminar, the material is not super hard but applicable to life!
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This course was amazing! Especially if you have background and/or interest in eating/body concerns, Dr. Shingleton does a great job of creating an environment in which you can explore and discuss topics. She is so generous with her time (ex. loved the movie night she offered to watch a film related to coursework) and nurturing to her students!
worse_comment: Take this class! Not only did I learn a lot about eating disorder pathology and treatment, I also learned to be more cognisant of how my actions affect those who may be silent suffers or struggle with eating and body concerns.

best_comment: This is a fantastic course with a great professor! Dr. Noll is very understanding and flexible with assignments. If you feel like you haven't quite figured out how to bring your education to advocacy or even just the world in general, here's a great opportunity!
subject: Psychology

course_title: Fact or Fiction? Mythbusting Pseudoscience in Psychology 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS ! So interesting, exciting, and easy to understand. All of the assignments were actually fun to do. Great balance of group work and presentations as well as sitting and learning from lecture. One of the best psych classes I've taken at Harvard.
worse_comment: This class presents a lot of interesting information about misunderstood psychological phenomenon. There is not convincing evidence for many of the "myths" presented, though, so I'm still skeptical of what is actually myth or fact since all my other professors have provided extensive conflicting evidence for many "myths" discussed.  There is not much evidence provided for the anecdotal myths discussed in lecture.This class is participation–heavy at times, and there is not much accommodation for extenuating circumstances that affect your ability to turn in an assignment.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Absolutely loved this class! It was exciting to see an education class offered in the Psych department, and the class did not disappoint. You get to learn all about the science behind educational practices –– what really works, and what doesn't?  It was refreshing to be in a class full of students interested in education, with a few having actually taught before, or wanting to go into teaching, because I feel like that can be pretty rare at Harvard. Tanya is a great professor –– super approachable, cares a lot about her students, and gives great feedback.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This class is really great!!! You should engage as much as you can in the practicum challenges & sections which add to the class experience immensely. The readings are annoyingly long, but you do not need to read them in their entirety to succeed. You do need to attend lecture, pay attention, and take good notes in order to do well on the exams, which are fairly lecture–heavy and detail–oriented. Prof. Mitchell is awesome –– he's an engaging lecturer, includes his personal struggles/stories during lecture, and overall a really likable person which is always a plus. However, he is very committed to in–person lecture attendance so the lecture recordings are not distributed unless you are ill. This is made worse by the fact that, again, the exams are super lecture–heavy. Would hope he considers amending this policy in the future to make studying easier for students. Overall, though, I highly recommend this class to anyone; you learn so much about happiness and building a meaningful life, and it is one of those courses that I will remember for years after I graduate.
worse_comment: Be warned: Prof Mitchell does not accommodate emergencies and mental health crises. He is very firm about sticking to the syllabus. If you go through a major life crisis, make sure you keep up with this class. Also be warned that per the syllabus, even if your grade is passing, you automatically fail the course if you fail one of the exams or the final project (10–15pg paper). If you fail the midterm, final, or final project (or turn it in more than a few days late), you will fail the course.
best_gem_comment: Take this class! It was a great senior spring elective – not too challenging, but gives you lots of opportunities to grapple with big questions about happiness and how you can pursue it in your own life. Jason Mitchell is a gem and a great lecturer, and sections were fun and enjoyable.

course_title: Decisions Big and Small: The Cognitive Science of Making Up Your Mind 001
best_comment: PSY1322 was one of the most fascinating courses I've taken at Harvard for a multitude of reasons. For starters, Professor Ullman's insightful lectures and quirky humor made attending class a lot less painful, and I really enjoyed his frequent in–course activities. I got to win one of the dragons he gave out, as well as a toy robot from one of our class "intermission" exercises, both of which I still have and display on my desk. I was always interested in learning how people think, work, and decide, and this course was right up my alley! I'm glad to now have precise terms to describe concepts that I understood intuitively, but could just never name. One of the greatest things in the course that I personally enjoyed was the integration of personal reflection, particularly in the Final Thing. Not only did Professor Ullman give us freedom to do whatever we wanted for the final project, he also frequently made us think about decisions we've made and how its shaped us. I took the Final Thing as an opportunity to reflect on my personal growth and progress, and it was honestly one of the most insightful assignments I've ever had. I've also never had as much creative freedom in a course project, which is kind of sad that Harvard is so heavy on exams or writing assessments. Overall a phenomenal course, and you'll definitely regret not taking it!
worse_comment: This class moves very fast and is quite confusing. It is a minimal weekly workload but not easy material so I wouldn’t call it a GEM
subject: Psychology

course_title: Biological and Artificial Visual Systems: How Humans and Machines Represent the Visual World 001
best_comment: This course is amazing. The professors are fantastic, kind, and helpful. Seda, the TF is very knowledgeable and good at explaining concepts.  Preparing for class through videos is a relaxed way of being introduced to the content. The papers we must read for class are difficult to understand more often than not, but the study guide and the class discussion will prepare you for the quizzes. The group discussion format can be intimidating, but trying your best to prepare for class helps you feel more confident and classmates will help fill in gaps in knowledge. Class time is a great time to interact with the professors and TF and get questions answered. There are only quizzes which can be challenging, but there is a chance to redo them later to show how much you've learned and grown. The group project is quite fun. The final project is very opened ended and gives a chance to delve deep into a topic on bio/comp vision.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Biological and Artificial Visual Systems: How Humans and Machines Represent the Visual World 001
