subject: Psychology

best_comment: The professor is so kind and understanding! I genuinely felt as though she, along with the rest of the teaching staff, cared for my wellbeing and wanted to make sure that we focused on learning rather than raising our grades. The two hour lectures were a bit long, but she was able to give us little breaks in–between starting mid–semester so that it wouldn't feel like one 2–hour long block. The topics covered were also quite fascinating, and honestly pretty insightful given the dating culture at Harvard (or lack thereof). I showed up to as many lectures as possible, both because I was interested in what she had to say and also because I felt kind of bad that people weren't attending. A shame, because she had a lot of great things to teach us!
worse_comment: It's a low workload class. But I hate writing essays, so I spent a lot of time writing the essays. If you like essays, this is the class for you, You only have to write 3 essays and lecture is not mandatory (but you should def still go to lecture because the professor is so nice)
best_gem_comment: This course is an absolute GEM — Holly is the nicest person ever. You’ll learn actually interesting topics on super relevant topics and in section, you hear from peers present on super interesting topics as well (like how to navigate long distance)

course_title: Is Persistence a Panacea? Contextualizing Human Motivation 001
best_comment: *** Take it! Tim is a fantastic professor. He is always available to meet and he genuinely is passionate about the topic. He always will send readings if you wnt on any topic in motivation science. He is super knowledgeable. The weekly journals are great and the class is not stressful at all. Tim is very understanding. I cannot recommend this class enough!
Professor Botto is a great professor. One of the best I had! Easy to work with and makes the material engaging and fun to learn.

course_title: Family, School, and Society: Shaping the Developing Child 001
best_comment: This class is a really good discussion class if you want to talk about the many ways in which underprivileged and disadvantaged youth might be at psychological and developmental risk in the United States. There are many difficult topics that the class covers, but Dr. Lewin–Bizan handles them with grace and is a really good facilitator. She also has lots of good personal anecdotes and invites people to share their own thoughts and experiences often. It feels almost like more of a sociology class at times as opposed to a psych class, but overall is a very engaging discussion–based class.
worse_comment: This class really emphasizes how vulnerable children are to their environment and, personally, led me to reflect on the ways I plan to raise any future children I have. Course material isn't too difficult, especially with a background in psychology. The professor sometimes expresses personal views that I personally disagree with, and sometimes voicing opposition to those views can feel difficult.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Understanding Who We Are: Development of the Self 001
best_comment: This is a must take course! It is truly my favorite course at Harvard because of its approachability and accessibility. Dr. Botto is an amazing instructor who helps make this material easily digestible.

course_title: What Infants Know, How Children Learn 001
best_comment: Awesome class!! Professor Spelke is great. Would definitely recommend the course!

this has been my favorite class so far at Harvard. everything from the teaching style & organization of the class, down to the content itself, the types of assignments we had, and the professor, were amazing. personality psychology is one of the most interesting aspects of psychology, & as somebody who didn't come from a psychology background, I felt very well–oriented because of the class slides, and it encouraged me to participate more. there are weekly assignments that vary, from taking a personality quiz to making a video or writing a diary report, so every week is something new and fun. there are also weekly quizzes based on the content of the previous week's slides, so make sure to thoroughly review those lecture slides before the quizzes. the quizzes are low stress anyways, and will take at most 15 minutes. The professor was also amazing, very kind and always willing to walk through explanations several times. She had a very warm but calm spirit, and she was very open to feedback, even changing the class around a bit after mid–semester feedback. The content from this class was very applicable to real life, to the point where as I was learning, I was realizing that a lot of it explained different aspects of my personality. This class has made me more interested & confident in branching out from the STEM field towards social sciences.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Please take this class! Mayron has got to be one of the most enthusiastic, fun, amazing, helpful, supportive instructors around, and he really makes sure that you are enjoying the content and the course as you learn.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences 001
best_comment: very straightforward and easy class! will get an A if you just do the assignments. Grace is enthusiastic and makes it fun. it's flipped classroom, so going to lecture can be pointless but still need attendance for grade. video's not too long which is nice. weekly quizzes get 3 attempts so can do well. all take–home exams are not too bad and Grace gives extra credit/bonus options on every exam! Final project was also not too bad –– pay attention in section (where you learn R coding) and you'll be all set. Whether or not you need this for a concentration/secondary req, I'd take it! Easy and simple intro to coding and can do very well in class.
worse_comment: If you're taking this class, just know you get out what you put in. If you don't watch the videos on time, you're going to be confused and bored during "Lecture." It's a reverse learning format that is really frustrating for those who thrive off a traditional lecture format.
best_gem_comment: This was a gem! Loved this class. It was a great way to get through premed requirements in a low–stress environment while also learning about statistics and real–world applications.

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class! You learn so much about what good science looks like, and I feel much more confident to interpret papers and read results sections effectively in future psychology courses. BUT, PLEASE TAKE PSY 1900 FIRST I promise it will make your experience so much better. Also, try to get Kevin as your TF—he is the absolute best person, teacher, and is so supportive. His feedback is so useful and I feel like I have genuinely learned so much from him!
worse_comment: This class was interesting, but it did feel a bit like we were thrown out into the wild with projects, both in terms of preparation as well as guidance given. In addition, I think for me it was not the best that a lot of things were groupwork and groups were decided kind of randomly –– if you don't luck out with your group then your experience is not great.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This is a great class, sometimes it will feel really tough and you may get stuck a few times on the homework assignments, but it is a great class! The professor and TF are so kind and always willing to answer questions. I highly recommend this class! and 1950
subject: Psychology

best_comment: It would be helpful to spread the debate preparation amongst each other across the semester. That's way less work than having everyone present something every week, and also makes coordination easier. People who aren't presenting can still contribute through brainstorming and providing ideas.

Professor McLaughlin and the SD Lab are some of the greatest people I've met so far, and I've truly had a great time as a Research Assistant at the lab. Most, if not all, of the lab meetings were spent going over current research conducted by some of the graduates/postdocs, and it was generally a supportive atmosphere. We also got snacks every once in a while, which was really nice to walk into! Professor McLaughlin is super kind, understanding, and passionate about her research, and the research that was presented every week was fascinating and covered topics I personally found insightful or interesting. It was also clear to me that everyone in the lab cared–their research was making a difference and they strived to improve their niche of Psychology. Overall, would highly recommend this lab and this course!

course_title: Laboratory for Clinical and Developmental Research 001
best_comment: Great opportunity to learn more about the research process in psychology! This lab is a safe and wonderful space for learning and everyone is so kind. I cannot stress enough how grateful I am to have joined this lab this semester.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: TAKE IT!!! this is a great class with a very light workload. I guess it would be different depending on your grad student and the point that they're at in their study, but I absolutely loved it. great to get to actually participate in research, I mostly ran participants and did preliminary research talking with the CEO of a software company, but the work was really rewarding and a nice break from school work.
This is an intellectual experience unlike others you could get at the college. Ask many questions and get to know all of the members — they have such divergent and compelling interests.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Information Science I 001
best_comment: This course doesn't seem to spend enough time on fundamentals and the foundations of quantum information/computing. Though the topics and scope are wide–ranging and interesting for this reason, many questions that regularly arise in class could be more easily resolved if we were careful with definitions and statements of results/theorems. The resources we had lacked clarity and consistent notation, including the homework assignments which sometimes contained consequential typos and had questions that we changed or recalled. Be prepared to reference other texts to better learn the material and formal justifications of results. To this end, even though some course staff/instructor(s) were wonderful and generous with their time, there was simply not enough time put into creating the assignments, the final, and course resources overall.This includes changes to the homework, office hour changes with last–minute notice, final project prompts which were not viable, etc. Some of these are matters of logistics, but overall, this course needed much more time and care to better represent a field that is ultimately interesting and important. The feedback we received on homework assignments was not very helpful for better understanding the material either. The feedback we (at least those I have spoken to) received largely overlooked significant subtleties which made the problems challenging and instead focused on minor details which were largely independent of the core concepts, to meet the assignment.All in all, the material of the course is very rewarding to study and it might be more interesting to those with a background in CS. But, ultimately this is not a course that necessarily rewards rigor and building a good foundation for understanding quantum information/computing for those not already studying/working in this field. You will get just as much out of this class as you put in, and it would be worth considering just self–studying this material using the text by Nielsen and Chuang.
worse_comment: I think course material depends heavily on who teaches it, since QIS combines both physics and computer science. I really wanted to learn the physics of QIS but learned the CS side instead because of Anurag's background. However, this perspective was really interesting and I'm still interested in learning more.  Background required: I felt that the prereqs for this class were misleading (which were know quantum mechanics at undergrad or grad level, linear algebra at level of 21b, and how to write proofs). I wouldn't say you even need to take quantum mechanics or know physics for this version of QIS. Instead, you need to know some TCS, information theory, and the math of tensors –– none of which was covered. We did have a section 0 that might have covered some material, but most of us didn't know about it because it was announced on Ed as a post (so none of us got notifications about it) 10 minutes before it took place. There was no announcement about it during lecture, which relates to my following comments about the course structure/staff etc. There were a lot of things that made taking this class frustrating. Anurag is a kind professor and knows his stuff. However, lectures were hard to follow (handwriting hard to follow; order of writing on blackboard was not left–to–right/top–to–bottom but more circular) and this made it difficult for doing scribe notes. Homework was only 3 problems and 15 points, and grading was inconsistent. You could make a computational error and lose one point. Or you could do half a problem but lose only one point. Or you could handwave an entire problem, not have your solution be correct, and still get full points. The inconsistent grading wouldn't have been a big deal if each homework wasn't worth only 15 points. Additionally, we used Ed for course announcements. But some important announcements (like section 0, office hour time changes, etc) were announced as posts, so you never got email notifications about them. A lot of times, you would retroactively find out about something. Finally, we were given a very short timeframe to do the final project. Discussing the final project was pushed back by several lectures, until there was basically no time left in the semester: introduce project and then the project proposal due 2 lectures later, draft presentation the next week, final presentation the second week. Overall, I felt this course has a lot of interesting material and promise, but would benefit from restructuring things like course timeline and grading. I do not regret taking it and did learn quite a bit.

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Information Science I 001
best_comment: This course doesn't seem to spend enough time on fundamentals and the foundations of quantum information/computing. Though the topics and scope are wide–ranging and interesting for this reason, many questions that regularly arise in class could be more easily resolved if we were careful with definitions and statements of results/theorems. best_comment: This is one of the best classes at Harvard. Professor Carrasco is one of the best lecturers at this school, and I have never been so interested and fascinated by the readings and the themes of the course. I learned so much about myself and how I see the world through this course. I would recommend this HIGHLY to anyone who has any interest in the ways that religion is seen in the world.
subject: Religion

best_comment: I highly recommend this class if you are looking for a space to learn more and have a space to discuss Christianity and important topics within Christian ethics like marriage and family, abortion, war and peace, feminism and gender, and the environment. This class is such a great opportunity to grow in your faith and speak openly about crucial issues that you rarely get the opportunity to speak about at Harvard. Everyone in the class is very kind and genuinely wants to learn more about Christian theology, morality, and ethics. Professor Lockwood is such a great moderator in the discussion and he always highlights key themes on the board. He is always willing to meet to discuss your papers and he  helps you grow as a writer with very thorough, clear feedback. There are only weekly discussion posts and 2 essays for the whole semester. The second essay can also be an extension of you first one if you are passionate about the topic. This is definitely my favorite class that I have ever taken at Harvard, please take it if you are interested!!
worse_comment: This is without a doubt the best course I have taken at Harvard

best_comment: This class is so great. The syllabus is enjoyable enough on its own, but Courtney really makes it.  Also just a note: the makeup of the class will REALLY shift the direction it goes. For one, Courtney shifts the syllabus a little (to my knolwedge at least) to accomodate interest, but also, for example, this year had a lot of social studies joints so there was a LOT of emphasis on the theory. Don't be intimidated, and contribute what only you can contribute. Fun class, COOL people, awesome experience overall! Would def reccomend to not only religion concentrators but anyone interested in religious thought more broadly!
worse_comment: This course is required for religion, so take it for that, but Courtney can be a very slow and unengaging lecturer, and the material is not super diverse, and 3 hours is a long time, especially at night
subject: Religion

course_title: The Conduct of Life in Western and Eastern Philosophy 001
best_comment: Take this class only if you have a strong interest in philosophy, religion, and its applications to, well, anything. The essay prompts are general enough that you can write about any topic in just about any form as long as you show that you’ve thought critically about it. Take the lectures as they are—long–winded and incomprehensible at times but occasionally resonant—and do the readings if you actually want to learn philosophy. Michael Puett is wonderful!!! He makes himself very available to students outside of class and generates significant enthusiasm for course material. You get out what you put in.

course_title: The Conduct of Life in Western and Eastern Philosophy 001
best_comment: Take this class only if you have a strong interest in philosophy, religion, and its applications to, well, anything. The essay prompts are general enough that you can write about any topic in just about any form as long as you show that you’ve thought critically about it. Take the lectures as they are—long–winded and incomprehensible at times but occasionally resonant—and do the readings if you actually want to learn philosophy. Michael Puett is wonderful!!! He makes himself very available to students outside of class and generates significant enthusiasm for course material. You get out what you put in.

course_title: Religion and Nationalism in the United States: A History 001
best_comment: Absolutely loved taking this class with Dr. Brekus. She makes religious history approachable for anyone, and everyone that I knew in the class felt engaged and excited about the material. The community in this class was also amazing, she does a great job of fostering relationships. Take it!!!
subject: Religion

best_comment: this class will teach you a lot, prof Dunning seems to have his own POV that he gets from Prof King, which may be contrary to what you have heard before, but it's good to hear many diff perspectives.
subject: Religion

course_title: Beginning French I: Cross-Cultural Encounters in French 001
best_comment: This course is a great intro to french. you learn a lot of french through fun applications and activities, but if you really wanna build your vocab, its kinda on you to memorize it on your own, as you won't learn every single word in class. the workload for this class is not bad at all. the homework is always due on the day of the quiz so you have about a week and a half to two weeks to finish the packet and it only takes a few hours to do and grade. the compositions are a good way to study for the quizzes because they have you practice the vocab and grammar that will be on the quiz, so I recommend finishing them before you take the quiz. This class is also fun and has a couple of different field trips within Harvard square that you go on. I'd also recommend that you go to the French table that they host once a week. besides getting a bonus point on the quiz, you also get to meet other people taking french and practice your listening skills (though it does  remind you how much you still have to learn in the language.) Overall, it's a good class that I am glad I took!
subject: French

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 001
best_comment: Amazing class!!! French has been one of my favorite classes at Harvard. The department does so much to make it fun and interesting. All the instructors are phenomenal and passionate about teaching.
worse_comment: The course is slightly easier and makes more sense than French 10 but is still extremely hard. I would not recommend taking this course if you don't have to.
subject: French

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 002
best_comment: If you want to learn French, I would absolutely recommend taking this class. You cover a lot of material in a very short period of time but it's taught so effectively that it doesn't feel overwhelming and is actually very effective. Also, getting to speak with a Parisien every few weeks and practice your French is actually unbelievably helpful.
subject: French

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 003
best_comment: French 11 is a very unique, engaging course with a reasonable workload and creative assignments. There are many portions of the class that seem scary on paper (class debates, Zoom conversations with a Parisian, essays) but are actually very manageable with the support you receive. Because of that, engagement and attendance in class is very important if you want to succeed. Overall though, I would say this class is extremely interesting and good to work into any schedule.
best_gem_comment: If you really want to take French I think this course is great, but it's also really dependent on your TF so it's not necessarily and guaranteed gem.
subject: French

course_title: Beginning French II: Paris in Virtual Reality 004
subject: French

course_title: Intensive Beginning French: Parisian Culture & Life 001
best_comment: I was really happy with the progress I made in my French during this course. Atim was a great instructor, and he did a wonderful job keeping us engaged despite the many classroom hours.
subject: French

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 002
best_comment: As long as you stay on top of the homework for each unit, you’ll be just fine. Keep in mind that if you push your comfort zone and try to use French in creative ways, you’ll get a better grade! Pick out sentences and conversations you have throughout the course of a normal day and then figure out how to say them in French—cannot stress how much this will help you.
worse_comment: Only take this course if you have to for the language requirement or you really want to learn French. If you're half in it you will not have a good time
subject: French

course_title: Intermediate French: Francophone Culture in Local Communities 003
best_comment: A solid class, keep up on the homework & study a bit and you will be just fine, cruising along.
subject: French

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 001
best_comment: This class is good if you're required to take if but you will not get much out of it if you're taking it out of interest in the topic. The curriculum is all over the place and really didn't touch on Francophone culture as much as I would have liked.
subject: French

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 002
best_comment: Great course, be sure to do the daily assigned readings and worksheets for maximum success. The french department is amazing and your section is guaranteed to be a blast.
subject: French

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 003
best_comment: My TF Atim was very flexible  with deadlines, which was really great and appreciated during a hard semester. While I enjoyed the flexibility this class gave me, I feel that I did not learn much beyond reviewing the passe composee, PQP, imparfait, and the subjunctif. The entire class surrounds social media and podcast making, and assignments are a mix of essays, podcasts, and a few tests. No vocab or grammar quizzes.
subject: French

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 004
best_comment: This class is great. The assignments are super manageable and by the end, you'll realize you've grown a lot in the language.**
worse_comment: This was the most disorganized class I've taken here by far. The canvas site still has all of the fall semester dates, my section was told that certain things would be on the test that didn't end up being on there, grading was unreasonably harsh, class always ended 30min early. The assignments were all busy work that didn't help me learn at all.
subject: French

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 005
best_comment: This course is a great way to continue your French education in a low stress environment that is perfect for learning a new language. I would try to take French 20 if at all possible first.
subject: French

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 001
best_comment: This class is a great way to improve your French listening skills. The movies are enjoyable, and the assignments are very helpful!
subject: French

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 002
best_comment: I honestly really enjoyed the film component of the class despite having no prior film background, and assignments were pretty easy and well–paced. However, it wasn't always clear what/when things were due, which I hope they improve in future iterations of the course.
worse_comment: The time management and class environment made this class unnecessarily stressful:The TF forgot that a quiz was coming up; they did not inform the class, so students only had two days to prepare. It had a notable impact on how well people did on the quiz; the Professor had to come in to offer people a chance to retake the quiz.At one point, some students were struggling to understand what was being said to them in French, and how the TF expected them to respond. After 15 minutes of trying to converse, the TF essentially threw their hands up in frustration and began speaking a bit harshly to the student struggling with the content. The rest of the class sat just watching the back–and–forth, with some people laughing; it was uncomfortable. Basically, it felt like there was a clear division between favorite students and ones that would either receive frustration or laughs (sometimes even from the TF) because they weren't speaking as fluently.Even the Professor and TF couldn't keep up with the schedule set in the syllabus, and this had a serious impact on grades and learning. The syllabus said that students would get a chance to turn in a second draft of their papers in order to work on what they struggled with and to receive some points back, but the class couldn't manage to get through everything that was originally scheduled; we didn't get a chance to write any second drafts (or work on what we struggled with, or receive points back...) The Professor had to drop an entire quiz because time was running out, which was nice because quizzes aren't fun, but it was still indicative of how poor the time management was.
subject: French

course_title: Advanced French I: The Contemporary Francophone World Through Cinema 003
best_comment: This class is phenomenal. Dr. Brisson is an amazing teacher, super nice (she literally cancelled our last test, gave us a chance to re–do at least one test throughout the semester and also gave us an opportunity to earn extra credit.) The writing assessments are super relaxed. The class is super educational, pretty  and genuinely so much fun. 10/10 would recommend.
best_gem_comment: I would highly recommend that you take this class. Dr. Brisson is an absolute gem, the sweetest lady, and very understanding and flexible if you need extensions on homework, projects, etc. The course load is not bad at all, and the final project (where you create a short French film in groups) is relatively low–pressure and super fun and creative. You’ll learn loads about Francophone cinema from a range of really interesting movies, which is not only a fun homework but also teaches you so much about Francophone culture – it’s really interesting. Definitely take this class – it was my favourite class this semester and you won’t regret it.
subject: French

course_title: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language 001
best_comment: This course was organized much better than previous French courses I took at Harvard. I personally liked the stress placed on learning vocab this semester, since most other classes focus on grammar instead. There is quite a bit of work but it isn't too difficult to complete and provides enough practice to actually improve. Would recommend taking if you need to fulfill a language req/finish a citation.
subject: French

course_title: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language 003
best_comment: This class is a fair amount of work (dossiers, exchange conversations, compositions) but as long as you start early/stay on top of everything, it's not too unmanageable. Prof. Gann was super nice and a great teacher and also great conversation facilitator. A lot of the topics the class goes into too are pretty interesting, and sometimes the class feels like a seminar which is cool. Best part of this class is definitely the lack of exams. I'd definitely recommend if you have the time or if you want to take an interesting French class.
subject: French

course_title: Feeling Modern: Introduction to 19th- through 21st-century French Literature 001
best_comment: Fantastic class! Super thought provoking readings. Assignments (response papers, one presentation, and essays) were manageable, enjoyable, and helpful in analyzing course material. Class discussions were great and Prof. Rodriguez is a a great instructor!

course_title: Staging Critique: French Theater and the Social Body 001
best_comment: It’s a very fun class that is a more untraditional option to typical French literature classes so I would highly recommend if you are someone who has creative interests!

course_title: Crimes of Passion: Balzac’s Short Stories 001
best_comment: This is an interesting class about Balzac and definitely not too much of heavy lift. Wonderful class if you just enjoy reading some interesting texts and chatting about them in French.
worse_comment: Take this course, but it is important to take those couple hours of class very seriously since you don’t get much out of it otherwise. Read read read every single text, they’re short but you get so much out of them.

course_title: "The Words to Say It": 20th-century Women Writing in French, From Colette to Satrapi 001
best_comment: Absolutely take this class if you have the chance. I took it in my senior spring and could not be happier that I took it. As someone who hasn't thought creatively since high school, I knew this class would challenge me in that way but it was definitely a fun challenge. The class won't stress you out workload wise it is super manageable, you read a total of four books over the course of the semester and you'll be glad to have read them!

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 001
best_comment: TLDR: TAKE THIS CLASS! It has been my favorite class at Harvard so far and it has been THE ONLY CLASS that I have genuinely enjoyed going to every day. If you've already taken Italian 10, Italian 11 is essentially the same class in a barely different font. I had Katie as my TF and she is AMAZING!! She was always so enthusiastic everyday in class, and that enthusiasm naturally passed onto me! The course itself is graded super reasonably––the class should rarely be overwhelming. In class quizzes are suuuuper reasonable, and its much easier to do well than poorly. THAs are very similar to the ones in Italian 10, these just involve some minor research and reading short articles/watching short videos. The online VHL assignments can get a bit tedious at times, but they're very doable, and a really great learning tool. The final project is SOOO reasonable, and is especially helpful when you're likely overwhelmed with other finals. It helped us end the class on a low–stress good note :) You will also probably form closer relationships with your classmates if you take Italian 11 since you would have taken Italian for almost a year together! I definitely recommend having Italian movie nights with your classmates towards the end of the semester when you have to watch the assigned film (La Meglio Gioventu)!
worse_comment: I would say that you need to study and make an effort to understand the material, since there are a lot of different tenses that will become really confusing really fast if you don't take the time to learn what each is and when to use them.
subject: Italian

course_title: Beginning Italian II - Parliamo Italiano! The Art & Craft of Italy 003
best_comment: You'll have a lot of homework, but it's necessary retaining the info you learn. Can feel really intense at times but worth it–– you'll learn a ton!
worse_comment: Italian 11 is not easy. It is entirely grammar focused and will require a large time commitment during the week. If you have to take this course for a language requirement, DO NOT take it with Elisa Maloney. She is unempathetic, unkind, and a horrible teacher.
subject: Italian

course_title: Intensive Beginning Italian: Gateway to Italy 001
best_comment: This is a great class, and if you'd like to learn a lot of Italian quickly, I'd highly recommend it. Be aware, it is a significant time commitment – but it is quite enjoyable.The class size is very small, so you are able (and need) to be very engaged. I found this very helpful for learning a language. There is homework every night, which is something to get used to versus a typical class with maybe weekly problem sets or the like. Prof Lieberman was great – very engaging, passionate, and kind. If you're debating between Italian 15 and Italian 10, I'd say, shop them both, and see how you feel. But if you want an intense Italian language experience, this class is hard to beat!
worse_comment: it is super easy to get behind in this course if you miss a few assignments or classes. you learn a lot in a very short period of time, which is nice, but having to make every class with no option to make them up asynchronously or anything was very difficult for me as a student with health issues/disabled student.
subject: Italian

course_title: Upper-Level Italian: Italiano in Verde: Sustainability Issues in the Italian Classroom 001
best_comment: This class is not only an effective Italian class and great follow–up to Italian 20, but it is a fascinating and engaging course in sustainability, environmental issues, and Italian culture. The class is much better than Italian 20, with less work, less demanding exams, more projects/group work, and globally relevant assignments that required creativity and were super interesting (such as visiting a farmer's marker!). Definitely take this class!!
subject: Italian

course_title: Advanced Italian II: Advanced Written Expression - Writing for Social Justice 001
best_comment: Take this class! Giulia is an expert in this area and makes the material interesting and worth while. I was initially a little apprehensive not to have Chiara as the prof, but Giulia offered a different lens on social justice in Italy that I found extremely compelling.
subject: Italian

best_comment: This class is an amazing class that helps you analyze present society through texts from the Renaissance. You get to learn SO much if you are engaged during class. This will not be hard since the professor is AMAZING!!

course_title: The Cosmos of the Divine Comedy 001
best_comment: Ambrogio is so, so sweet and will meet with you at least 5–6 times during the semester to get to know you but also to help with your final project. He is so kind and so smart and will be inspired by whatever you find interesting in the text. I'd say, take the class just to develop a relationship with this special man. Also because you will read the Divine Comedy, which is an incredible work. Don't be scared off by not knowing Italian –– I didn't know Italian, and it was never an issue. Also, the workload for this class is reallllyy minimal :)

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Marcia is soooo amazing and truly cares about your learning. Starting as a complete beginner, I have grown so much in my Portuguese skills because of the supportive environment Marcia has in her classroom. Through the 10/11 series, you will leave with a substantial understanding of the language and be able to hold conversations with speakers. This has been one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard so far and I hope to continue taking courses in the Portuguese language department. Highly recommend.
subject: Portuguese

course_title: Beginning Portuguese for Spanish Speakers II: More SAMBA, less Salsa! 001
best_comment: This class is awesome! Marcia is a really great instructor and cares so much about students. It's a fun and low–stress class, but your Portuguese skills will grow quickly and you'll absolutely love learning about the culture.
subject: Portuguese

course_title: Advanced Portuguese I: Images of Brazil through Contemporary Cinema 001
best_comment: This class is amazing. Cris is an amazing teacher and person. She is so caring and always has your best interest at heart. She is super passionate about this course and you will learn a lot about Brazilian history/ culture. Make sure you’re comfortable writing, speaking, and listening to Portuguese or else you’ll struggle.
subject: Portuguese

best_comment: This class is a mix of many students with all different approaches and needs. It can be difficult to then weave all conversations together (some students more interested in language pedagogy, other in pedagogy overall, and some other in cultural aspects of teaching a course). Professors Greene and Parra provided useful feedback in assignments. However, I wish the head courses take more leadership in the course, and give it shape and form to conversations more consistently. They rely quite heavily on their TFs, who were incredibly resourceful, but lack of leadership in the course was evident. Future versions of this course may become better, but it'd be hard to say now that Dr. Greene is retiring.
subject: Romance Languages

best_comment: This class is a mix of many students with all different approaches and needs. It can be difficult to then weave all conversations together (some students more interested in language pedagogy, other in pedagogy overall, and some other in cultural aspects of teaching a course). Professors Greene and Parra provided useful feedback in assignments. However, I wish the head courses take more leadership in the course, and give it shape and form to conversations more consistently. They rely quite heavily on their TFs, who were incredibly resourceful, but lack of leadership in the course was evident. Future versions of this course may become better, but it'd be hard to say now that Dr. Greene is retiring.
subject: Romance Languages

course_title: Sophomore Tutorial: Poetics, Practice, and Politics in Romance Societies 001
best_comment: This class was a great foundational course for RLL. It's really nice to be with all the concentrators across different languages and then have a section to be able to speak/read in your own language. The atmosphere is pretty laid back and it makes for a welcoming dynamic. Dr. Richman is great!
subject: Romance Studies

course_title: The Camera-Pen: The Essay Film from a Latin American Perspective 001
best_comment: This course was like a short story by Borges: self–referential, whimsical, analytical, and personal. I really enjoyed having the opportunity to create my own films based on our class work and received helpful feedback from the instructor, Andres DiTella. Andres is a very caring and respectful teacher who is incredibly knowledgeable about Latin American cinema, since he is a filmmaker himself. He picked out amazing films for us to watch during class, and I feel like I’ve grown as a person through this class as I have learned more about Latin America and learned more about my own creative process. I highly recommend this class.

If you are at all interested in the role that the humanities and art can play in the global field of migration, this is the course for you. Homi and Mariano are such great professors who lead you through a staggering range of fascinating materials. Some of the reading is quite challenging (stylistically, thematically, or emotionally) but the resulting discussions are always edifying and so much fun.

If you are at all interested in the role that the humanities and art can play in the global field of migration, this is the course for you. Homi and Mariano are such great professors who lead you through a staggering range of fascinating materials. Some of the reading is quite challenging (stylistically, thematically, or emotionally) but the resulting discussions are always edifying and so much fun.

Amazing! Kind of like a high school class in the best way possible: simple, 20 minute daily homework and review, daily class for one hour, small group discussion, timed writing assignments etc. Super chill and fun.
worse_comment: This course is not super fast–paced and emphasizes cultural knowledge over language learning. If you mainly want to learn Spanish this course may not be the best learning experience for the time spent in class. Iris is a super nice person and very enthusiastically teaching the class!
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This class is a great introduction to Spanish. I have never taken any Spanish classes before and learned so much! The work can be overwhelming sometimes, but overall I would recommend the class! Also, Iris is a great instructor.
worse_comment: This course moves VERY quickly in a short amount of time. A lot of information is given to students but not always reinforced after it is taught. This results in a necessary review outside of class. It is difficult if you do not have any Spanish background.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This is a good class if you would like to learn a basic amount of Spanish and is more interesting and enjoyable than typical foreign language courses.  If you put in a little bit of time outside of class on studying and preparing you can really learn a lot of Spanish quickly and it can be very fun to watch yourself progress in learning another language.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: Make sure to study the canvas modules pretty well because they will be the best way to make sure you have the necessary tools to succeed in the class. Paying full attention and studying them like class work will set you up very well.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: the course was easy for me because i took Spanish my whole life.  i noticed that the class moves fast though, especially for the students who had only taken 1 spanish class prior to this one. in high school, we would spend weeks on just one piece of grammar (preterite vs. imperfect, reflexive verb conjugations, present perfect conjugations).  in this class, we briefly went over them .  be prepared to do a lot of practice outside of class if you have not taken spanish before.
worse_comment: I would tell students that this course is hard. It is not an easy A unless you are super comfortable with your Spanish. You will learn a lot of Spanish, but the assignments feel largely unfair and are very harsh.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: I learned a lot of spanish. I learned more in this one semester than I did in 2 years of high school spanish. It was great. The instructor speaks really clearly and is very easy to understand. The class is organized and well run.
worse_comment: Keep on top of vocabulary spoken in class, they don't give you good vocabulary lists on canvas
subject: Spanish

best_comment: If you need to fulfill the Language Requirement and want to learn Spanish, take it! If you want to learn Spanish, I'd probably pursue an immersion program and then return to Harvard in a more advanced Spanish program. It is a fun course and fast–paced. As someone that struggles with foreign language, this was a perfect course for me. It was a manageable level of challenging that I think maximized how much I could learn in the academic year. The course structure needs some changes, but many of the TFs are incredible and caring. The course material is mostly interesting, the homework is not interesting but just–busywork, and the assessments are bizarre but a small portion of the grade.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: It's harder than Spanish 10, but still okay. The tenses are the hardest part. There are a lot of projects, but they aren't that hard and you gather a large amount of the information during the Talk Abroad conversations. Overall, I'd recommend it, especially over some other language classes that aren't as well organized or for which you have to pay for the textbook. Not an easy A, but not incredibly difficult either. If you're hoping to leave the class really having improved in speaking Spanish, rather than just reading or writing, try to sign up for a time with a smaller section. It's easier to skate by in larger sections, but much harder to actually get comfortable with the language and all the different tenses, since you won't be required to speak as often.
worse_comment: This class is great for learning a basic level of Spanish, but not fantastic for learning conversational spanish.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: Language classes at Harvard have genuinely been such a refreshing experience. For many, Spanish 11 fulfills the second part of their language requirement, but it has only strengthened my desire to keep going and progress further in Spanish.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This class is great! It is extremely well designed, engaging and fun!
subject: Spanish

best_comment: You will get out of this what you put into it. Either way the course is pretty good and you will definitely get much better writing and speaking Spanish.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: THE BEST CLASS AT HARVARD. I swear. This is my last semester and I promise you that this is the best out of all the 32 classes I have taken here. You will learn SO much. I would be confident going alone to anywhere Spanish speaking. The stuff you engage with is interesting too (lots of sustainability, migration etc.). Lastly, meeting every day at 9 with what will likely be a small group of people is such a great way to make new friends, and I'm really grateful for the people I met in this class. If you want to come out of the semester with a genuine tool that you can pick up and use, take this class. I literally could have written this whole thing in Spanish. That's how good the class is.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 001
best_comment: Definitely a difficult class and a step up from Spanish 11. A decent amount of work for sure that can pile up. However, super great way to grow and get a lot better at Spanish. Grades got a lot better as the year went on which was helpful.
worse_comment: This class is a lot of work––I'd reccomend avoiding Spanish 20 if possible. The assignments do not actually involve listening to the
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 002
best_comment: Make sure to do all the little assignments; they don’t take much time but they’re really helpful
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE IN ITS CURRENT FORM. The "flipped classroom" approach that Spanish 20 takes does NOT work. Honestly just ditch this course and do Duolingo or study on your own. You will save yourself so much time and so much hassle. Certainly do not take this course if you are looking to learn practical and useful Spanish for everyday interactions. The stories and vocabulary you read are great, but essentially useless in the real world and you will basically speak little to no Spanish in this class. Hands down one of the worst classes I have ever taken at Harvard.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: I strongly recommend taking this but from talking to friends, the PROFESSOR MATTERS.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: I think you will learn a lot in this class not just about Spanish, but the history and communities within Latin America. The course does require a lot of work, so make sure you have the capacity to devote your time to this class.
worse_comment: don't take Jose's section. he's a great person but an incredibly tough grader :(
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 005
best_comment: This is a good jumping off point if you are trying to become conversational in Spanish, but it will require some work on your end.  Fantastic literature selections, with a focus on learning a lot of the key tenses that you will use in everyday speech.  Highly recommend putting in time each week to learn the new vocabulary and review it as the course goes on because it will help tremendously with being able to express more complex thoughts.  Also highly recommend actively seeking out everyday situations in which to practice, which the course builds in to some degree but there is simply no replacement for the real thing.
worse_comment: This class is difficult. If you've only taken Spanish 10 and 11 with no other background, I'd heavily recommend speaking with your Spanish 11 teacher first.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 006
best_comment: Stay on top of all the grammar, it pikes up quickly
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 007
best_comment: This course is a wonderful language class at Harvard that works as not only a constructive review (if you have prior Spanish experience) but also as a course that comprehensively teaches grammar and relevant subjects (immigration, dictatorships, colonization) in an effective and efficient manner.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 008
best_comment: Spanish 20 is a good course. You learn a lot, and the instructors are amazing. I found that I had to spend a good amount of time teaching myself grammar concepts outside of class.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Intermediate Spanish: Language and Culture in the Hispanic World 009
best_comment: This course is VERY fast–paced but gives you an opportunity to learn so much. The course is not very practical to learning vocabulary necessary for everyday conversation, though. The course subjects are very specific such as human rights.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 001
best_comment: Spanish 30 can be a very difficult class, especially if you are hesitant about speaking Spanish clearer or if you have a professor like Daisy who can be a tough grader. But this class was an amazing experience that is a great way to expand your knowledge of Spanish culture and grow into a stronger speaker.
worse_comment: I would tell them to embrace mistakes! You're going to make them and it might be embarrassing. It's simply a part of learning a new language. As long as you take risks and fully engage yourself in the class your will not only obtain a good grade but you will also become proficient in spanish.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 002
best_comment: The workload consists of a reading (or analysis of a movie, song, painting, etc.) 3 times a week, commentary on current events 3 or four times a semester, creative compositions/essays, 2 oral exams, and one class presentation. While it seems like a lot, I think the course heads to a pretty decent job of spreading everything out, and it's truly not bad at all. Highly recommend!!
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 003
best_comment: This course is a review of Spanish 20 in terms of grammar, but AT A FASTER PACE for the sake of focusing on SPEAKING. Would TOTALLY recommend taking this after Spanish 20 because you TRULY solidify your skills in grammar while most importantly getting more comfortable speaking on the spot.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 004
best_comment: This is a great class to continue your spanish learning. Definitely more challenging than Spanish 20, but only as much so as is doable and appropriate. I was definitely expected to speak more (all cold calling), but this really helped to improve my comfort with speaking. The materials were mostly short stories which I enjoyed and generally found to be interesting. The Units focus on essentially reteaching you all the Spanish grammar from Spanish 20, but through texts and topics that make it a bit more interesting.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 005
best_comment: Spanish 30 is a great course. I took Spanish 20 the semester before and while I did like that course as well, Spanish 30 was defining more enjoyable. The workload is very manageable and I feel as though my ability to speak and write in Spanish has definitely improved.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 006
best_comment: This course is a wonderful introduction to the four countries that we examined throughout the semester. The instructors have taken the time to ensure that the course is accessible even for those that do not have any previous experience with the material. It is also a great opportunity to work on and learn the Spanish language and get comfortable with different colloquial expressions.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 007
best_comment: I love this class!! It was very manageable but I feel like I learned a lot, and I made good friends in the smaller section.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: You should definitely take this class. In all honesty, it was my favorite course I have taken at Harvard so far. My section was small, so I got to know everybody, and we always had fun in class. The final project was actually very fun to produce, and the workload throughout the semester is manageable.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 004
best_comment: THIS CLASS IS A MUST TAKE. I don't care if you've fulfilled your language requirement or if you are sick of the humanities. SPANSH 40 is an incredible class, and you should not miss out. If it's been a while since you've taken Spanish, please don't worry. I am an upperclassman who hadn't taken Spanish since high school. I was fine. You'll be fine, too. The class even covers the subjunctive, conditionals, etc., which levels the playing field and gives the people who need to brush up on their Spanish the opportunity to do so. Also, it's actually a good thing that the class meets three times a week because the class meetings are really fun and valuable to attend. Profe explained everything so clearly, and the in–class activities were highly interactive (a lot of small–group and full–group discussions and little icebreakers –– but not the awkward kind!). The discussions of the movies were quite rich. And I loved the grammar lessons; Profe used a lot of examples and gave us lots of opportunities to practice what we'd learned (through written exercises and through speaking), which I found SO helpful. Also, speaking of grammar lessons, Profe's slides organized the grammar we had to learn in a way that was very digestible.Moreover, the quizzes are not stressful to study for. If you do your homework and brush up on the grammar covered, you'll be more than fine.  And the oral exams are low stress as well. Just look at the prompts before going in. (I'd choose two, and Profe would have me discuss one of those two.)All of the composiciones were very interesting to write. I loved the prompts and was grateful that we had several to choose from. The short film was one of my three favorite final projects from my time at Harvard (and I say this as an upperclassman). It was so interactive, fun, and challenging. We wrote a script for a short film and brought it to life through acting, filming, and editing. (And yes, you can make yours funny. :))I loved the format of watching movies. Movies are so much more fun than readings. And the movies are REALLY GOOD. I was seriously absorbed in all of them. My favorites were Los colores de la montana, which explored war, corruption, and loss of innocence; Contracorriente, which explored identity, isolation, and loss; NO, which explored rhetoric and loss of innocence; and El secreto en sus ojos, which was filled with all sorts of crazy plot twists, explored the corruption in Argentina's government and police forces, and featured a fascinating scene in which a lawyer leveraged a suspect's fragile masculinity to get him to confess to a crime.The grammar discussed in the beginning of the class may seem familiar, but you'll get a lot better at using it. And for me, the grammar that was new entered the picture toward the middle and end of the course and was SO USEFUL. And you'll find a lovely community. :) You'll talk a lot with your classmates in class, and you'll learn a lot about them through participating in the aforementioned icebreakers.Some closing thoughts:–If a movie doesn't have closed captions, don't freak out. You'll understand more of it than you'd expect. :)–I had not taken a real humanities class in college before taking this one. Now, I want to take more.–The feedback you'll get on your work is SO VALUABLE.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 005
best_comment: It's a solid class. The movies are interesting but some of them are pretty gruesome while others are really really good. You can watch them at 2x speed and some of them have subtitles either in Spanish or English which is helpful. It's not that hard, but it is time–consuming, especially when you have an essay or project due. If you took AP Spanish in high school it honestly isn't that bad since not much new grammar is learned, so it's a lot of review of previous topics from that and Spanish 30, but it's useful with practicing speaking and listening
worse_comment: You get out what you put in. You won't get better at the language if you are not willing to make mistakes in order to learn.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 006
best_comment: I would highly recommend taking this class if you're interested in pursuing Spanish/improving your speaking and listening skills. I really liked the way this class was structured and how the assignments focused on improving your overall language skills. Also, if you have Xiomara as your instructor, you are super lucky—she is the best!!
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 001
best_comment: One of my favorite classes I've taken at Harvard! In Spanish 50, you get to read some really interesting plays, short stories, poems, etc., and then analyze them. I found it to be really helpful in strengthening my speaking and listening skills, in particular. You also review grammar content throughout the semester. There is some acting and public speaking involved for the class, so make sure you are comfortable for that before enrolling. Overall, an enjoyable class!
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 002
best_comment: This is such a fun class! I really loved all of my classmates and Natalie is a remarkable teacher. She always managed to keep up engaged and the texts we'd read for class were always rich and beautiful but also dark and complex. The best components though were performing and writing scenes and creating podcasts with my classmates. This has to be my favorite Spanish class I've taken to date!
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 003
best_comment: This class is an awesome one. As long as you genuinely try your hardest and do your best, you don't need to worry at all—you definitely get out what you put in, so while you could slack and get by, it is so worth it to actually try. I would say that if you are shy about speaking Spanish, either don't take this course or get over it, because it is so worthwhile to improve your Spanish in this class. The workload is very light, so it is good to take if you have other classes that are harder (and the homework is all completion–based). It is also a great class to take that fosters an excellent class environment, since we're all forced to get close and work together, which is nice. Just put yourself out there, and you will love this class!
worse_comment: Don’t be afraid to perform in from of the class! Everyone is in the same boat and no one is judgmental about acting skills. A step up in workload compared to Spanish 40, but it isn’t necessarily more difficult, just more work
subject: Spanish

course_title: Advanced Spanish II: Creative Writing and Performance 004
best_comment: This class is a fun, easy class. The readings are great and engaging, and they improved my Spanish reading comprehension quite a bit. The performance–based exams are a lot of fun, and added no pressure at all as someone with no drama or acting background. Overall, the course didn't improve my Spanish THAT much – so if you're looking to get as good as possible at Spanish as quickly as possible, consider skipping this class—but it was an easy way to stay on top of my Spanish by practicing every week while making progress towards a citation.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: Take this class! It is super rewarding and Sra. Quinonez is the best. The course work is very doable, but I will say, the three hours of volunteer work is not nothing! It is again, super rewarding, but definitely make sure you have time for the volunteering, Also, remember to look up where your volunteering is because mine was a 40 minute T commute which was definitely a bit challenging to fit in my schedule. All in all though, would highly recommend this class
subject: Spanish

course_title: Spanish for Latino Students II: Connecting with Communities 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is such a fun space to engage in important conversations about Latine identity and social justice issues while hanging out with some really cool people. This is a great class that relieved a bit of the stress from a more memorization and problem–set–based course load.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: Take this class if you want to simultaneously develop your Spanish skills at a really advanced level and gain an introduction to the field of public health. The readings are very difficult and will take a lot of time (took me entire afternoons sometimes), but if you put in the time, you will gain a very nuanced perspective on how different conditions like AIDS and diabetes have affected Latin America. In addition, Profesora Gutiérrez is very flexible and supportive.
best_gem_comment: Take this class, a gem! It is not very demanding and Gutierrez is such a supportive and knowledgeable professor. It was really fun to dedicate time during the week to speak in Spanish.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This class is amazing! It is really fun, completely manageable, and you talk about real–world stuff. Much of the reading and conversations are about viewing public health through a social and cultural lens, and the assignments and conversations really allow you to get creative. I'd recommend this class with enthusiasm –– it's not too challenging, really easy to balance, and so fun!
subject: Spanish

best_comment: I love this class!! Wilnomy is awesome, the texts are easy and not too long and the homework is minimal but rewarding! The class felt very comfortable and I improved my Spanish speaking and writing skills greatly while also becoming more informed on Public Health from a global perspective. The tests are nothing to stress about but do test your knowledge. Would definitely recommend this class! Structure, content, and teaching staff are all 10/10 :)
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This course is truly incredible. You discuss topics related to health in such an impactful and candid way, and your fluency improves immensely. The readings were amazingly curated and always were interesting reads. The course is also conducive to improving your Spanish and was just an incredible atmosphere. It truly was the highlight of my semester by a lot. I cannot express the excitement I had going to this class. Above all, Wilnomy is THE ABSOLUTE BEST!!! Like truly THE BEST!!! They have helped me improve immensely and has helped me grow both academically and personally (I can speak to my partner's parents in Spanish with such ease now). I speak for everyone when I say Wilnomy is a one of a kind educator. In short, TAKE THIS CLASS*** !!!
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS EVEN IF YOU ARE NOT PREMED!!!LOVE LOVE LOVE <3
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This is a super fun course with great readings.  The material is interesting, and the professor is SO wonderfully knowledgable and engaging.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This is a really fun class! It is all about food, which definitely makes learning Spanish more fun. You spend one class every other week in the kitchen, and then you get to eat it and discuss how well you liked it. I think I felt kind of overwhelmed in the beginning of the course because the essays come a little fast and it can just feel like a lot, but really it's a super chill course, the grading was not bad at all, and everyone's there for a good time.
worse_comment: In terms of speaking/communication, you should be comfortably proficient–– I took Spanish 50 last semester and did fine here. Overall, 81 is a great concept, and a lot of fun at times, but not quite as good as it looks on paper. You'll sometimes get hit with a sneakily hefty assignment that wasn't on the syllabus a few days before class... good example was a 5–minute presentation assigned on the Thursday before having class the following Tuesday, in addition to already–assigned reading. The teaching team is also pretty hot and cold... either very buddy–buddy or kind of confrontational / weirdly on your back if you mess something up. In keeping with the not–on–the–syllabus assignments, it's also just generally disorganized–– random assignments might come via email the day before, and you won't have any grades in Canvas the whole semester. However, the cooking component is almost too good to pass up (6 cooking classes throughout the semester–– you'll make great Spanish food), the material is interesting on net, and it's not a huge amount of work. So, overall, if you don't mind logistical inconveniences and some wacky moments here and there, it's a solid course.
best_gem_comment: This is an amazing class! Such a gem. Take it if you're able to get into it. I will never forget this class, and the speaking skills and vocabulary I learned from it will be invaluable!

course_title: Displacing Spain: Translating Transatlantic Poetry on 20th- and 21st-Century Spain 001
best_comment: Loved this course; highly recommend! I think the biggest strength of the course is that it is taught by Daniel who is a very knowledgeable professor who makes class engaging, encourages participation, and generates enthusiasm since he is very passionate for the subject matter. He really makes you excited to come to class and especially to be prepared with your thoughts on the poems since it is a very dynamic class where everyone gets the chance to speak and share comfortably. This was my first poetry class, and also my first poetry class in Spanish, and I believe that it was very accessible to me as I was provided with the necessary context and background required to read the anthology and formulate critical thoughts. There was a very interesting variety of authors and poems and I really enjoyed exposing myself to such works by choosing to take this class! I loved having the weekly freewheeling journal to be able to freely express my thoughts on the poems we read without worrying about a restricted format or structure. The final project (worked with a partner) is a translation exercise and it is similar to the freewheeling journal in that there is no restricted structure and you can focus on corroborating your choices effectively.

If you like film and are from Latin America, you should take this class. It is a little time consuming because you have to watch a movie for every class, which can sometimes be long, plus do a reading for each, so in the end it can add up. Also, some of the movies are a little boring and even difficult to understand, but they help you dissect them in class. Despite this, there aren’t too many assignments and the midterm and final are very manageable. And both the professor and TF are very nice! Overall, I recommend it, especially if you have some connection to Latin America.

course_title: Thinking Beyond the Human: Persons, Things and the Environment in Latin American Culture 001
best_comment: Katie is an awesome TF — take classes with her. Super fun and helpful. This is the kind of class that I would take in Spanish but maybe not in English because I think it being in my nom–native language helps all the discussions be more interesting/make people more friendly and have a sense of community. However, the lens we use in pretty specific, so I would only take the class is you are already interested in literature.

This class is a great way to get a background on Catalan culture and Spanish history in general. The course focused more than I was expecting on literature and art, but it was very interesting and I really enjoyed it. Aina is the best– she is so encouraging and enthusiastic, so she really makes the classroom feel like a welcoming, comfortable space. I took Spanish 40 before taking this course and feel like I was adequately prepared.

course_title: Queer, Trans*, and Feminism in the Americas 001

best_comment: Prosem is by far the nicest course I had. I really enjoyed seeing everybody 2–3 times a week, and Alexandra is probably one of the most knowledgeable people on campus. She provides resources, feedback,  and emotional support when needed.
subject: Russia, E Europe & Cntrl Asia

best_comment: Tatiana is such a wonderful teacher, I've learned so much from her! She is such a fantastic resource for the department as the only faculty member who has expertise in South Slavic languages and literatures.
subject: Bosnian, Croatian & Serbian

best_comment: This is an excellent, well–structured course in which your Polish skills will improve a lot. Iryna Kovalchuk is an excellent instructor who displays an admirable degree of patience and commitment to her students. If you have the chance to take Polish CR with her, I would highly recommend doing it. You will learn a lot about Polish grammar in this course, while also using Polish in 'real–world contexts' and academic settings. The fact that this course is tailored to students' individual needs is especially appealing, as it gave me the chance to deepen my understanding of the research themes in which I am interested while simultaneously bettering my Polish skills. I thought that this was a really good course and one of the most productive language courses that I have taken in recent years.
subject: Polish

best_comment: Stick with it. I was very frustrated during AA/AB due to the steep learning curve, but it has been so rewarding to continue with Russian. As one of the weaker performers in class during the first year, I can tell you from experience that the teaching staff is unmatched in their compassion and commitment to your education and will work with you to achieve your goals with Russian.
subject: Russian

best_comment: Stick with it. I was very frustrated during AA/AB due to the steep learning curve, but it has been so rewarding to continue with Russian. As one of the weaker performers in class during the first year, I can tell you from experience that the teaching staff is unmatched in their compassion and commitment to your education and will work with you to achieve your goals with Russian.
subject: Russian

best_comment: Take this course! Yes, it is a lot of work, but you will learn so much! The teachers care so much about your success and they will go above and beyond to make sure you are successful!
subject: Russian

best_comment: Take this course! Yes, it is a lot of work, but you will learn so much! The teachers care so much about your success and they will go above and beyond to make sure you are successful!
subject: Russian

course_title: Fourth-Year Russian: Russian Media and Popular Culture 001
best_comment: This class was all about media, from YouTube interviews of Russian politicians to contemporary graphic novels in Russian. I enjoyed our honest discussions about the war in Ukraine and our weekly dissections of state and independent Russian news. I felt like this class was more about learning through media than learning through rote grammatical exercises. This is helpful in its own way, but even in 4th year Russian I wished for more grammatical emphasis, but this is my own opinion, since students had varying backgrounds and Russian levels in our class. The instructor is one of the best I have encountered at Harvard. He is kind, respectful, knowledge, and open minded about discussing the complications of modern Russian society.  He makes everyone feel comfortable and included in class, and I couldn’t ask for a better Russian teacher!
worse_comment: This course is absolutely incredible if you're looking for a better understanding of Russian culture or politics. Note that there is less emphasis on grammar, so if that's a weak point that you're hoping to work on, this may not be the best course for you. With that said, Russian students looking to bolster their listening comprehension, slang/pop–culture vocabulary, or exposure to Russian cultural staples should take this course.
subject: Russian

course_title: Fourth-Year Russian: Language, Ethnicity, and Diversity in Russia 1
best_comment: By the end of this course, your written and spoken Russian will be so much better. But it will take a lot of time and effort from you – even considering that this is a fourth–year Russian class, this was INTENSE. But it was also extremely rewarding. Take this course if you have the chance – Liya is an amazing instructor!
Take this course! It is a great way to learn about Slavic literature and Prof. Kremer is fantastic.
subject: Slavic

course_title: Squaring the Circle: Russia, Art, Revolution 001
best_comment: Art theory might feel unapproachable with many –isms of the day, but this is a class that really teaches you something more about the general knowledge of the world, and makes art something approachable (and it's fun to be able to recognise what we are learning when going through galleries, and realise we aren't as lost as we thought in the face of art)

This course is lovely! It gave me an amazing first overview into 20th century modern literature, and has gotten me excited about reading more works by these authors in the future. Professor Buckler is great, and it's a really collaborative format in that the students can suggest readings and guide where discussions go/what sorts of assignments we do. I had a lot of fun.

course_title: Russia’s Golden Age: Literature, Arts, and Culture 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in Slavic literature/culture or even just reading/literature in general, this is a great course for you. You'll read some masterpieces and also spend time with ballet and opera. It's a great mix of classics from Russian culture. The reading load per week is very manageable, and you'll find it interesting. There are no essays, unless that's what you choose to do as your final project. There are only a mix of weekly discussion posts and other more creative assignments like video annotations, scrollytelling, and video essays. It's a good mix of different media based assignments that gives you the chance to be creative and approach the material in a different way. Prof. Buckler and Joanna are excellent, and if you have any knowledge of Russian, Prof. Buckler also does an optional Russian section where you check out the original Russian versions of the week's reading, which I loved. I highly recommend overall.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to do more English but maybe feel scared about the discipline

best_comment: You will love it. Daria is the best.

course_title: The Other Russia: Twenty-First Century Films, Fictions, States of Mind 1
best_comment: Take this course! Even if you have only an inkling of an interest in contemporary Russian culture/media, this is an amazingly fruitful class. Professor Sandler is wonderful and will help you gain a ton from the material, even if you don't understand anything the first time you read it. The class covers some sensitive topics (especially given the ongoing war in Ukraine), but framed by that war you get to cover a lot of really powerful and interesting material by Russian dissidents and intellectuals. Loved this class, was an amazing way to close out my senior year.
worse_comment: Take this class if you want to find out how Russian literature fights back against the neo–imperialist society that faces Russia today.

best_comment: Professor Dibrova is amazing, and I want to sincerely thank him for making this class so engaging and fun. it was one of the classes which I awaited every week.

I loved this course, and I will miss it next year. While I did not love every text, I enjoyed the ability to gain a new perspective from history every single week that changed the way I approached/understood the world around me. It was great to read thinkers I had heard of before but had never personally engaged with. I also really think my writing benefitted from the course. I had a great tutorial leader who gave me really helpful and detailed feedback that I have implemented into my writing style moving forward. The highlight of the course is the tutorial system for sure. I loved working through different ideas with my peers every week, and I feel like it is such an unique and special system that works so well for this subject
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: I loved this course, and I will miss it next year.
