course_title: Legitimacy and Resistance in an Unjust World 001
best_comment: It's easy to feel daunted by the syllabus of this course — biweekly discussion posts, a final term paper, lectures, and sections — but nobody does it quite like Arthur and Matt. Arthur talks about the material with infectious enthusiasm, and devotes considerable time to hearing what students have to say, inside and outside of the classroom. The 2–hour, 45–minute lecture flies by, and you'll have the most fun in the course (and succeed) if you show up having at least done the readings. Your lingering questions and clarifications will be covered during lecture, section, and office hours. Matt is also incredible and helped us break down complicated concepts and readings on the board. Similar to Arthur, he encourages people to be active participants and respects what all of us have to say. Although the questions we were discussing are fundamental to our understanding of government and our relationship to it, classes felt like an extremely inviting place to take academic risks.The course is also a great introduction to what Social Studies will be like in terms of the questions asked and historical ground covered. Overall, it made me more confident in wanting to take Social Studies 10 next year.

course_title: Making Sense of Methods for Theoretical and Historical Research 001
best_comment: Give yourself a lot of time with the readings. The more I engaged with the texts, the more I got out of the week. That is the case for most classes of course, but it is especially true for this one.
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: This course is great if you have an interest in the legal field and want to start connecting the law with academia. You get a lot of freedom with your projects so pace them well! Terry is a great facilitator and person, get to know him!
subject: Social Studies

course_title: Art, Political Culture, and Civic Life 001
best_comment: This course really did transform how I look at art and, more broadly, the gorgeously rich cultural heritage we hold in common. It showed me the value of public art as a site for social imagination, memory, protest, change — hugely important ideals uncapturable in the quantified 'language' of costs and benefits. Professor Adatto is really wonderful: kind, understanding, closely attendant to all details of the course. Her support in the process of coming up with and then refining ideas for the paper was really valuable, and she did a wonderful job creating an environment where students really were raring to share ideas and engage deeply and thoughtfully. Take. this. course.
worse_comment: Take this course if you can. Incredible subject matter with an incredible professor, and, in my case, an incredible group of other students. This course will change the way you think about public art and its relationship to public life and discourse. You will engage with and discuss complicated dilemmas that perhaps do not have true answers, but it will be fulfilling and transformative. I could not recommend this course enough to other students.

best_comment: Nicolas is great. The course content could have been more focused, but the class does what it promises. It gives you the resources and support to write a meaningful semester–long paper on a topic of interest related to globalization and the nation state.

course_title: Critical Theory of Knowledge, Technology and Power 001
best_comment: Highly recommend this course! It's a super fascinating topic and great reading list. Bo–Mi is a fantastic tutorial leader and great at facilitating discussion. She encourages everyone to speak and knows to intervene when the conversation goes off the rails. An excellent junior tutorial.

course_title: Empire, Capitalism, and Global Economic Development 001
best_comment: One key aspect to note is that the value you derive from this course largely depends on the extent to which you engage with the assigned readings. While your final paper may not necessarily be directly linked to the readings, they provide a valuable foundation for deeper insights and understanding. This course offers a great deal of freedom, allowing you to shape your learning experience based on the effort and dedication you put into it.

course_title: The Foundations of Democracy and Dictatorship 001
best_comment: I loved this class. Levitsky is amazing and I loved writing the final paper. This is a class where you actually have to do the readings because of its small class size and the seminar being structured where Levitsky walks through the concepts in each reading one by one. I loved that it forced you to do the readings. However, I thought that the seminar part of the course could have connected concepts from reading slightly more and made you build upon concepts. Therefore, I did not get much out of the seminar portion when I did the readings in depth because it was just reviewing the concepts of the readings which felt a little elementary. But the reading list was spectacular, and I really enjoyed the topic. Also Levitsky is a character with so much knowledge. His expertise cannot be understated. Go to his office hours; he's a great guy to talk to.
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: Prof. Swindle is very caring and involved, but this year there were some kinks to work out because it was the first time the course was offered. It wasn't a difficult class at all, and the final paper was a nice capstone and it was pretty satisfying to do completely in R. Certainly not as time consuming as other AM courses
It’s a great opportunity!
subject: Sociology

best_comment: Honestly, I was scared of taking this class and thought it would be excruciating, however it ended up being my favorite class this semester.  Don't get me wrong, this class is definitely challenging. There's a lot of readings and it can be dense at times but there are so many resources out there to make the concepts and topics easier to understand. Also, Shai and the TFs are always available and would be happy to clear up any tough topics. The class is super rewarding and you'll with such a great understanding of sociological theory, both from the fathers of sociology and previously ignored theorists, such as POC and women. The second half focused on the forgotten theorists so I really appreciate the amount of time we dedicated to these individuals. Also, the midterm and final paper allow for much freedom, you can write about anything which makes the process so much better. Also, the sections are super engaging which was great. Zehra was an amazing TF and if you are lucky enough to get her you are set. She cares so much about our success and will go above and beyond to help us. Shai is also an amazing prof and cares so much too, he has a good sense of humor which I appreciate. Overall this class was great but make sure you have a lighter workload to make room for this class.
worse_comment: Be prepared to take care of your mental, when discussing serious issues trigger warnings are not provided which can be extremely damaging at times.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: I loved this class I was so nervous going into it about doing a research project but the course structure really holds ur hand through it and makes it not hard at all. Rachel is so so awesome and creates the best learning environment where its okay to make mistakes.
worse_comment: Professor Meyer is incredible, and this course is a well oiled machine!! She has so much experience teaching this class, and it really does show. I learned so much and my only regret is not taking it sooner (even though I suppose that wouldn't have been an option anyways)

best_comment: Please consider another sociology course first before enrolling in this one. I had taken an advanced sociology course before taking this one and I did better overall, learned more and enjoyed the course more.Unfortunately the course is just a lot of work for a singular intro class. Every single week there are at least 3–4 readings that are mandatory because they are discussed in the mandatory section. The entire course revolves around the readings and because of this there is a quiz at the end of every class, making up 25% of your overall grade. These quizzes are insanely frustrating because they are meant to trick you, and even if you completely understand the overall meaning of a reading, you can still do poorly on the readings. A good thing about this course is the teaching team, they are all so nice and put so much effort into the workings of this class and caring for the well–being of students. Danilo is honestly so passionate about sociology that makes his lectures really engaging.
worse_comment: This class is very theory–based and focuses heavily on very specific situations written by the authors. For example, in the gender week, you don't learn about general gender in sociology but read specific readings about women in guerilla camps or women taking sick days off from work. If you take this class expecting to learn general sociology topics and talk about the modern world, then this class would not be good for you.

best_comment: The course is an introduction to Sociology, and I would recommend it to people interested in the discipline. I would not recommend it as an elective, because it is a lot of work and there are other Sociology classes that are more engaging and fun that push the bounds a little bit more. This course inspired me to think deeply about inequality, where it comes from, and how it is sustained. Especially gender inequality/ family gender roles.
worse_comment: This is a decent introductory course for Sociology concentrators and you will read many texts that you can take with you to other courses – that being said, expect the discussions to be relatively uncomfortable.

best_comment: This course is truly amazing. I actually read basically all of the readings for this course; some were a little dense and I'd skim, but they were genuinely all so fascinating and pressing. Jason and Rachel are the most caring individuals, and I really felt encouraged to explore difficult topics like the ones discussed in class in a safe + nurturing environment. I took this course to count for the recommended premed sociology + as a foundational GHHP requirement, and I 10000% recommend this to anyone considering it! The readings aren't too bad to get through, and the weekly reading responses force you to stay accountable for getting through everything; section is the best time with Rachel's fun icebreakers + open discussion, and I really loved coming to lecture every week. The only thing is that the lecture hall is really comfortable and around noon nap time, so I would get a little sleepy in lecture, so would recommend bringing snacks!The exams are a little scary at first, all short answer and do require that you actually do the readings + pay attention in lecture/section, so don't let it creep up on you. Definitely go to office hours to get to know Jason, he's the coolest + a great conversationalist, you'll never run out of things to say!
worse_comment: Not a very good intro class to sociology or a good class on health, in my opinion. Does not cover a wide range of topics. In fact, lectures and readings are very repetitive. They all say some variation of SES, environment, racism, institutions, etc affect health. When we get to more interesting topics, professor does not go into depth. Rachel, however is a good TF, and I enjoyed section a lot more than lecture.
best_gem_comment: This class is an incredible introduction to sociology, especially if you are already set on concentrating. I felt like I learned so much and will enter each interaction from now on with a new level of empathy. A gem! TAKE THIS COURSE :)
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This was such an amazing course. Truthfully, I was a little bit hesitant about this course because the syllabus mentioned that we'd read one book a week, and I'm a very slow reader. But I loved each and every ethnography so much, and I genuinely took so much away from the course. This course honestly inspired me to pursue ethnographic research.  Tom is such an amazing instructor, and he's super chill and comfortable to talk to—which I appreciate a lot! Also, the discussions in this class were so productive, and I learned so much from everyone.

course_title: The Internet, Social Media, and Society 001
best_comment: I would tell future students that this class is great because of the people in it. But, the structure of the course was not definite, which is great for some people and not great for others.
worse_comment: Don't take this course. The professor is incredibly unorganized, there is no thought put into the material. It felt like a waste of my time, don't be fooled by the course description.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This class does have a bit of work which is definitely something that happened more recently, but it' very manageable. There's weekly readings which help to better understand the material though missing a few weeks is not the end of the world. There are also weekly lab assignments which usually take an hour or so and are not too time consuming. This class is especially great if you want to do social studies research in the future.
worse_comment: this class is honestly so unhelpful and a complete waste of time. not sure why, but there was an insane amount of assignments this year (a lab every week, an essay, a midterm, and a final). in past years it was a few labs and a midterm. this amount of work is objectively not too bad, but given that this class is a course on how to conduct research, it genuinely doesn't make any sense. all the exams ended up being memorization on niche details of readings and having to be overly specific with terms. they also were written by hand and had not only definition questions, short answer questions, but also an essay question. the ethics essay also did not make sense and was disconnected from so much of the course along with the other assignments. obviously, no knowledge of any of the information related to the assignments is actually required to conduct good research. honestly, any and all information from this class would be something you would cover in the types of trainings youd need to get a certificate for research (which i have done). the majority of people in the class also have no interest in conducting research so making them take this is unhelpful as well. the lectures are required but add no substance whatsoever and are a waste of everyones time. the sections are also unhelpful since the material youre going over is pretty intuitive and doesnt require a whole extra hour to review/clarify. while dr. fairchild did hold study sessions before exams, they were basically useless bc she would just end up asking us how we would answer the questions we gave her. the ENTIRE reason we are going to the study session is bc we dont know the material, like please, do your job. she would also just always continuously talk around the subject and never give a clear answer or feedback in general. obviously, this is a required class so you have to take it, but it is terrible and i hated every minute of it. also according to many classmates of mine, my TF (minjin) was a super harsh grader for no reason and took off points for really small things. i had a good experience with her but i do know that wasnt the usual experience. she was also just often confused and would even give us incorrect information during the section which made it even more useless and a waste of time.
subject: Sociology

course_title: Student Leadership and Service in Higher Education 001
best_comment: This course is AMAZING!!!! Seriously one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard (if not the absolute best). It didn't even feel like going to class, just that I was going to chat about why I love my extracurriculars and hear from other student leaders about why they love their clubs. Manja is the absolute best and is so so so nice and supportive and caring and just wonderful. It is so cool to apply your extracurricular passions to an academic setting in a way that we really don't get to do often. The class really gives you a whole new appreciation for whatever organizations you're involved in, as well as the general scope of extracurricular life at Harvard and the amazing level of student leadership happening. Please take this class if you have the chance – it is truly so worth it and I could not say enough good things!!!

This class is really fascinating. The teaching staff is great, and the content will seriously push you to explore new concepts in and around the public/private/non–profit spheres. There is so much to find interesting, and you have the freedom to explore your own interest in the research paper. Also, make sure to do the readings to really get the most out of this class. It will really make a difference.
worse_comment: DROP THIS CLASS IF YOU DON'T LIKE YOU'RE GROUP. You will have to meet with them weekly, text them almost everyday, and have to reach out and work with nonprofits on your own schedule. Without my group I would not have survived the class.

best_comment: This class is really fascinating. The teaching staff is great, and the content will seriously push you to explore new concepts in and around the public/private/non–profit spheres. There is so much to find interesting, and you have the freedom to explore your own interest in the research paper. Also, make sure to do the readings to really get the most out of this class. It will really make a difference.
worse_comment: DROP THIS CLASS IF YOU DON'T LIKE YOU'RE GROUP. You will have to meet with them weekly, text them almost everyday, and have to reach out and work with nonprofits on your own schedule. Without my group I would not have survived the class.

best_comment: Take this class if you're at all interested in understanding Chinese society! Professor Lei is super knowledgeable and kind to students, and also makes her lectures interesting by incorporating anecdotes from her own fieldwork experiences in China. Each lecture is packed with interesting content — I never regretted going to lecture — and the final project allows you to explore any topic related to Chinese society of interest, so it's not restrictive at all. 10/10 recommend
subject: Sociology

best_comment: Don’t take this class if you want to engage deeply with sociology, economics, or network theory. The class may be easy, but it’s mind bogglingly annoying; you’ll find yourself working on trivial assignments like making slides, filling out surveys and google forms, diagramming, and filling out collaborative documents that, while changing up the pace of the course, doesn’t really further your understanding and just takes a lot of time. I find myself held back by the sheer number of small asssignments that are due throughout the week, and it’s hard to find the energy to do so many of these tasks that make the class overall feel like a nitpicky gened. I spent more time keeping track of assignments and being asked obvious questions than actually learning new things. The concepts discussed in class have potentially, and the sociological and economic theory discussed in class can be interesting. Dr Leah is also an enthusiastic and kind professor who truly has a deep understanding of the field and is very engaging to talk to and get to know. The size of the class, however, likely made this class feel too impersonal and trying to make this class accessible to everyone likely made this class more intro than is needed to actually explore the material in depth. The staff overall are kind and the class is made with good intentions, but other classes may be a better option if you want something substantive.
worse_comment: Unless it gets completely revamped, it is not worth taking this class. Unbelievably boring and unimportant. It barely even had any content. And the content that was there was completely not engaging. Shocking that this is an actual class at Harvard
best_gem_comment: I would tell students this class is a gem and be prepared to participate during lecture and be creative in your writing responses!
subject: Sociology

best_comment: **This is an amazing class period. Professor Jijon is such a good teacher and cares a lot about her students. She goes above and beyond to provide support and I really appreciate that. She provides good feedback, answers emails in a timely fashion, and wants us to succeed. The discussion posts were really low stress, just submitting 2 questions on the readings. Also, the readings are super interesting and fair in terms of page number (3 readings between 10–20 pages each a week). The questions are shared in class and are used for discussion which is amazing and engaging. Also, all of the assignments all lead towards the final paper, so even though it might seem like a lot of work and demanding to write a 15–20 page paper, most of the work is done by the end of the semester which is great. If you are lucky enough to take one of her classes I promise you won't be disappointed!!

** i personally really enjoyed this class!! i do know i come from more of a stem background so the concepts were familiar and made sense to me, but i still feel the general format of this class is amazing. lectures and sections are also optional plus there are only 4 assignments and 3 exams (2 'midterms' and a final). the final assignment is the longest but involves mostly work you did on the last 3 so everything builds on each other, which is so helpful. dr killewald is also a great lecturer and if youre unsure about anything, going to lecture or speaking with her easily clears it up. i had ohjae as my tf and he was one of the nicest tfs i ever had. he was always there for support, super friendly, and helpful as well! i asked him to look over my assignments before i would submit them and each time he was so patient and would go over them really meticulously. i do know many people had trouble with this class and it can involve a lot of self teaching especially if you dont go to lecture. still though, i ended up having a great time with it and think its completely manageable/possible!
worse_comment: Do not take this class. Take a class in the Statistics Department. This class does not teach you about sociology in the slightest. Class time felt like a waste because lectures are a horrible and ineffective way to teach math. There was no in–class assistance in what was being taught, so you couldn't practice in real time what you were supposed to be learning. There was also a stupid extension rule where you can only use an extension once in the entire semester and it was a 48–hour one; it completely disregards what students actually needs since students can't control when they may need an extension since busyness or mental health or any other difficulty can happen at whatever point in a semester. This class has made me completely hate statistics and has ensured that I never use quantitative methods as a sociologist. I absolutely hated this class and I'm not the only one. The lecture slides as well were awful as they were completely full of words making reading them difficult, yet they somehow consistently lacked the proper words that were needed to understand the concepts when studying. This class needs a complete revolution with a new class materials, teaching actual sociology, revamping the curriculum, getting rid of the lecture format, and including time in class to practice the math that taught. I do not think I can properly express how angry this class made me over the semester and how utterly useless this class is in the larger scope of my sociological career. I literally learned nothing in this class. And I went to every class and section.

best_comment: This class is absolutely amazing. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to take a genuinely interesting class and may have a bit of a fuller schedule. It's the perfect balance of learning a lot, making friends in class, and also not having a lot of stress for no reason about a class. Professor Swindle is a great professor and is truly interested in the material and is always willing to listen to other's opinions and validate the perspective they give to the discussion.

course_title: K-12 Education in the United States 001
best_comment: Awesome course! Dr. Handsman is wonderful. She is so kind, and she thoughtfully crafted the syllabus. You will learn so much about K–12 education.
Take this course! Emily is super accessible and accommodating, works with you, and makes the class engaging. No reservations about recommending the course to anyone!

course_title: Food Choice, Health, and Inequality SEM
best_comment: If you are at all interested in food, I very highly recommend this course. It was transformative and eye–opening. Caitlin (Professor Daniel) is incredible and creates such wonderful and fruitful class discussions. This course is definitely a good amount of work (weekly readings and required memos on the readings) but it is very rewarding. The selected readings are interesting and very enjoyable to read. I am so happy that I took this course.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: Amazing class

course_title: Cultural Processes in the Production of Inequality SEM
best_comment: USE ZOTERO. Make sure to take good notes week–to–week! (There are many readings so it's easy for them to become blurred together.) Appreciate how fun the readings are. Be ready to engage deeply with readings/discussion––you and your peers co–create the class with the professor. Throughout the semester, think about how each week's themes/readings may apply/not apply to your final project.

PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE do yourself a favor and take this course. Richard ji is literally the best teacher ever and he makes the class super fun, engaging, and inclusive. He is very patient and great and explaining the grammar behind a completely foreign language. The structure of the class (completely discussion–based) allows for great peer learning and connections.
worse_comment: It's harder than you think –– I really struggled with Hindi. It should not be taken lightly, and what you get out is exactly proportional to what you put in.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: Relatively intense but very rewarding. If you put in time and energy, you will probably be surprised by how much you learn in just one semester or one year.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

course_title: Bollywood and Beyond: Commercial Cinema, Language and Culture in South Asia 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class that offers a wide breadth of perspectives on Hindi cinema. Richard ji's instruction is excellent, the readings he assigns are compelling (though sometimes long), and his feedback on assignments is unmatched. The kinds of movies you watch vary so widely, from gangster movies to comedies to period pieces set in a precolonial courtesan's world. I learned enormously from the course, and the TF Akhil was incredibly friendly, insightful, and helpful throughout the semester.
worse_comment: Take this class. If you are at all interested in Bollywood, take it.The class was extremely unique –– coming into the class, I wasn't sure what to expect. I thought we'd be watching Bollywood movies and doing a bit of "analysis" of them. Boy, did I underestimate what "analysis" really meant. We REALLY dived into the films, dissecting particular scenes and characters within the films, as well as events and situations outside of the film. The class was extremely engaging. Richard ji asks really intriguing questions, which at first seem ridiculous. As the course of the semester went on though, we realized just how deep we can look into these films.I learned a lot about film analysis, but also about Indian history. This class takes "killing two birds with one stone" to a whole new level. The class literally kills like six birds with half a stone.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: Since Nell is no longer teaching, it will be hard to give any feedback for future students. Sanskrit is a beautiful subject, and regardless of who is teaching, I'd recommend giving it a shot.
worse_comment: Work hard. Don't fall behind. Be patience with yourself. You got this!
subject: Sanskrit

best_comment: This course is great for students with an interest in philosophical Sanskrit and poetical and linguistic theories.
worse_comment: The cliché response of "don't be afraid to ask questions" is extremely relevant to this course. We're working with difficult material and no one has a complete hold of the language yet, so it's important to remember that we're all in it together with establishing our readings skills.

best_comment: While this course's mission was all about receiving feedback and iterating on progress to improve at researching and presenting topics in statistics, the sheer lack of feedback in the 9 person class made this mission impossible. We did not receive feedback on many of the assignments and presentations we gave, and that made it difficult to know how to improve or continue developing skills. The class provided a good amount of freedom in exploring topics in statistics that are interesting to you, but the quick turnarounds and 9pm due dates often made this experience less enjoyable. It was somewhat frustrating that the course was flexible most of the time, but then had incredibly quick deadlines expecting us to make a lot of progress. The final project does help with thesising/deciding if you want to, but it is just 1 of the 3 projects during the semester (so not recommended you take the course just for the sake of finding a thesis idea).
worse_comment: This class provides a lot of practice in statistical writing and presenting. The feedback is a little slow though and there is a lack of grade transparency. You definitely have the opportunity to explore a range of statistical topics, but this class does not help with the process of finding an advisor to work with.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: This class is awesome. There are so many levels of support and it does not assume that you know anything about code or stats. They teach you from the ground up. Admittedly, it's confusing at times, especially in the beginning, but you get the hang of it and there are so many ways to get help. Professor McConville is super helpful and approachable, the CAs are so great, and the head TF Julie is awesome. If you struggle and you need help, you can get help easily in this class. By the end I overcame some fear about coding and math–y looking concepts. It's truly a great class.
worse_comment: I really did not get anything out of this course. One of the worst courses I have ever taken at Harvard. The Powerpoints were disorganized without dates/weird formatting so you could not see all slides at once. Professor also did not do a good job explaining how to use r. Please do not take this class. This class cost be so much sleep and made me so stressed. You will not be prepared for the midterm/final, cause she quizzes you on stuff that was only vaguely covered.
best_gem_comment: STAT 100 is not necessarily a gem, but it is definitely not too bad for a coding/statistics course! I definitely recommend taking this for a statistic requirement, or if you're interested in R or statistics. Khalila is the best TF, hands down, so try to join her section or take her oral exams with her if she's free. The problem sets are more so lengthy than hard, so definitely start early. R can be intimidating at first (and trust me, I hated coding so much), but you will get the hang of it!
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001

Admittedly, it's confusing at times, especially in the beginning, but you get the hang of it and there are so many ways to get help. subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: A background in basic stats could be helpful, but the class isn't really orientated around pure statistics, it's more about applying statistical concepts to R. You do very little computations by hand, you learn to code them in R instead. Office hours are extremely helpful for the psets (I think some of the psets would have been impossible to do without going to office hours). But overall, this was an extremely fun class, and I don't usually describe classes as being "fun".  Professor Marie Bind is very nice and good at explaining concepts. I recommend taking this class as long as you understand that you'll have to put some work in to be successful, but it's nothing ridiculous. I'd say it was similar in effort to math 1a, but the psets and exams were much less difficult.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for Life Sciences 001
best_comment: A background in basic stats could be helpful, but the class isn't really orientated around pure statistics, it's more about applying statistical concepts to R. You do very little computations by hand, you learn to code them in R instead. I'd say it was similar in effort to math 1a, but the psets and exams were much less difficult.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics 001
best_comment: I was a little nervous coming into this course because of previously bad Q–reviews (with different professors), but Kevin has honestly been amazing and this course is really well–run! Lectures are engaging and interesting – I loved doing the lecture handouts because it really helps you understand what you are learning. The weekly psets are very manageable – not easy, but there's a lot of support provided in terms of study breaks/section/OH, and you have a lot of time to do them. Exams are hard, but if you prepare well it's not impossible to do well, just make sure to do the practice exams. I honestly really liked this course, Kevin is a great prof and super supportive, the TFs are also really great. You definitely have to put in effort to do well, but it was one of my favorite classes this semester, and I'd highly recommend taking this especially for the Econ stats requirement!!
worse_comment: This class is pretty doable if you pay attention. The psets always take you longer than you think, and the LaTeX is a pain. Midterms are lowkey terrible. If you have any extenuating circumstances or disability accommodations, you have to get official documentations. Professor Rader doesn’t give accommodations easily, and is very letter–of–the–law in general, so follow the syllabus to the letter (except the part about “we can't guarantee your accommodation will be accepted after week 3 of the class” because they legally have to accommodate you no matter when you get the paperwork in).
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Statistical Computing with R 001
best_comment: To future students considering taking this class, I would highly recommend it. Not only will you learn a great deal about R programming and its applications in data analysis, but you will also gain practical experience in working with real datasets. The class is well–structured and the course materials are well–designed, with plenty of examples and exercises to reinforce your learning. Dr. Kelly McConville is knowledgeable and approachable and provides useful feedback on your work. In addition to the technical skills you will learn, the class also emphasizes the importance of effective communication and presentation skills, which are valuable in any field. Overall, this class is an excellent opportunity to develop your skills in data analysis and R programming, and I would encourage anyone with an interest in these areas to take advantage of it

course_title: Introduction to Statistical Computing with R 001
best_comment: To future students considering taking this class, I would highly recommend it. Not only will you learn a great deal about R programming and its applications in data analysis, but you will also gain practical experience in working with real datasets. The class is well–structured and the course materials are well–designed, with plenty of examples and exercises to reinforce your learning. Dr. Kelly McConville is knowledgeable and approachable and provides useful feedback on your work. In addition to the technical skills you will learn, the class also emphasizes the importance of effective communication and presentation skills, which are valuable in any field. Overall, this class is an excellent opportunity to develop your skills in data analysis and R programming, and I would encourage anyone with an interest in these areas to take advantage of it

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001
best_comment: A bit harder than 209a/109a but still easy. lecture note material is very clear, lectures are great, homeworks are very practical, and exams are very easy. overall an extremely useful course with a great staff.  the final project is horrible if you have a bad group though but I guess all group projects are like that.  Usually one person ends up doing way more work than the others and its super unfair so really try to find a good final project group
worse_comment: If you simply want ‘data science’ on your resume, then this class is for you. But if you actually want to LEARN about data science, then I would suggest looking elsewhere. By far the most disappointing class I’ve taken at Harvard. Chris is fantastic, but the rest of the TFs are not very helpful and often make mistakes. Beyond this, they make condescending comments regarding how simple the mathematical computations are, but pressed to implement those computations are just as lost as the students. As a rule of thumb, if the teaching fellows cannot solve the problem, it probably should not be assigned to students. Skip the advanced section too unless you absolutely need to take it — again, an enormous amount of work for little payoff. Simply put, this class is an absurd waste of time. That’s not to say that there’s not useful insights provided in this class, but the cost is far greater than the payoff.  On top of the homework and midterms expect: pre class reading, post–class readings, post class quizzes, post class exercises (that are sometimes broken and simply do not work), labs, sections, and a final project! Overall, the teaching staff has little to no respect or consideration for enrolled students — making this class incredibly stressful when it doesn’t need to be. Reaching out to the teaching staff results in dismissive replies. Classes like this exemplify why a code of conduct/expectations for professors and TF should be a standard aspect of an academic curriculum. Finally, and perhaps most alarmingly, homework was assigned overlapping with reading week, but no TAs offered availability to help with that homework.  This is notable because that means this class violated  official guidelines from the FAS by assigning homework during reading week. If I could report a class somewhere for crossing boundaries, this class would be it.  In conclusion, take another course because this class is a waste of time & effort.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Data Science 2: Advanced Topics in Data Science 001

subject: Statistics

best_comment: I did not take Stat 110 before taking this class. I went through the 110 edX a week before the semester starts, and it was inadequate preparation. But you can pick up the necessary concepts on the go throughout the semester and you will realize which concepts are recurrent (conditionals, Adam, Eve, LLN, CLT, and most importantly all the different distributions and their relationship with each other). Although it is pretty manageable, I would highly recommend taking stat 110 beforehand. To be clear, I do not recommend taking stat 111 without stat 110 unless you absolutely have to. If so, go through the textbook, do the exercises, do the midterms and finals, and make sure you score >90 in the 110 practice finals if you ever decide to take 111 without 110.The course is also not really pedagogical, at least to me, in the sense that the structure does not let me learn as effectively as I could. I would recommend going to sections where the TFs cover the essentials of what you need to know. Then watch the lectures on 2X speed. Joe is a very enthusiastic and entertaining lecturer, and his lectures can be a good review of what you learn in the sections. The textbook is very theoretical and you might not need it unless you are curious about the proofs.Absolutely try to spend time on your own doing the psets before consulting OH or your friends. Most of my consolidation of 111 knowledge comes from doing them.Make sure to be able to explain everything on the Exam handouts (Joe will post these a couple of weeks before the exams). Sometimes obscure examples noted in these handouts but not in section notes can appear.Also utilize Ed. An amazing platform and the CAs and Joe are very kind to answer your questions.Stat 111 can be a very fun and rewarding course. Enjoy!
worse_comment: This is a difficult class. Joe takes no prisoners. However, it is very informative and if you engage you will learn a lot. go to section and read the textbook.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: A great stats class, especially senior spring. Low total workload, but also very little busywork so you can get a lot out of it if you put in enough work. As a senior who has taken a lot of stats classes + compbio research, I felt like I didn't learn a ton in terms of raw content from the class (i.e. new models or estimators) but learned more about how to defend your work, describe it to people, and debate pluses and minuses of different modeling choices. If you need any other reason to take this class, it should be because of Giovanni. He is energetic, kind, and an excellent teacher who is very well–connected in the research community if you are looking for opportunities for senior thesis research (and beyond). Overall a wonderful experience!
subject: Statistics

best_comment: The course is amazing! Tracy taught almost everything you want to know about time series model. For example, in the course, we have learnt ARMA, ARIMA, GARCH, HMM and so on. They are all really useful in academic research and practical applications(e.g. stock returns prediction). Besides, this course makes a great balance between the math(theoretical) and practical using. You can enjoy both the beauty of the math behind the models, and you can also learn how to actual use them! Moreover, for the students who major in finance,  this course may help you understand better about Capital Market related models(CAPM,FF3,FF5). And for the students who major in economics, this course may be an extension of econometrics. Time Series will be really helpful for research and practical applications.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Take this course! One of the better 'upper–level' statistics courses for undergraduates. Alex is excellent: organized and communicative, effective lectures, clearly cares about his students. David (TF) was great also, although I think he is graduating.If you really enjoyed the probability stuff you learned in 110, this is a great opportunity to apply it in another field (you'll go a lot deeper with Poisson processes). I enjoyed 171 because it gave the 'time' component of probability; 141 gives the 'space' component.The course structure is very pleasing as a student. Homeworks are 50% of the grade and, while some of the theory can be challenging, there's plenty of support. The final is a week–long take home, so you never feel the pressure of having to cram / study. The R toolset is pretty cool as well. All in all, take this course and any other that Alex is offering!

Take this course! Mark is great: nice, funny, an engaging lecturer, extremely organized and passionate about this class. The material is very relevant, and you cover a ton in just a few months. You'll be challenged the perfect amount: it's not totally trivial, but you won't be pulling all–nighters studying and doing homework. The problem sets are long, but you have two weeks and can usually get through them ok with the course notes + questions on Ed.The one comment I'll make: when I was reading course evaluations before taking this course, they all emphasized how strict the grading can be on homeworks and exams, and to make sure not to forget to "hold other variables constant" lest you lose a few points. This was at the top of my mind all semester, and it should be for you if you take this class!But seriously, awesome class, every Stat concentrator should take it. You might have a bad subconscious association because of Stat 139, but this is way, way better.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Find friends to work on problem sets with, and start early. Go to lecture; Natesh welcomes questions. An interesting STAT class to take that will certainly require a substantial amount of time, but very interesting! Would recommend if you're even remotely interested in the world of finance – I took it as a skeptical STAT concentrator who honestly didn't want to trade, and I've come out of it still not really wanting to trade, but definitely gained a lot of valuable insight + new perspectives!
worse_comment: As a more theory–inclined person I regret taking this instead of 171

best_comment: This is honestly a great class. Prof. Sen is a clear lecturer who writes great notes, and is an all–round nice guy. Material is interesting and new, very strong stat class overall.
worse_comment: This class was very difficult, and got more difficult as the semester went on. Important to go to office hours for the sets. Start studying early for the midterms.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Statistics and Data Science of Networks 001
best_comment: Great class. It was a bit chaotic this year since its the first year its being run, but I assume next year will be a little more structured. Morgane is a super super super nice professor, who is very willing to spend time outside of class to go through material, or to give academic/professional advice. The material is also super interesting, and is presented in a very logical way. Start from metrics on graphs, different graph models, and go all the way to embedding–based methods for graphs (based on random walks), an exploration of node2vec, deepwalk, to finish up with Graph Neural Networks which are explained super well by Morgane. Overall I highly recommend the course.

I absolutely loved 212. I found the course content really interesting, problem sets were helpful for understanding the course content better, lectures were very clear, section was super helpful, and it's clear that Prof. Austern knows the content really well and cares a lot about her students. I'd highly recommend going to section, doing the practice problems for exams, and reviewing your notes before the next lecture; especially during the first half of the semester, the course is fairly unforgiving if you fall behind on content.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: I would like to comment on the Course TF: RitwikRitwik is a legend, a maestro, of undying proportions. When you enter section and see the Ritwik wielding the chalk, you know that he will set straight the indifferent, cruel currents of the unsolicited game of life. Going to the RITwik's section was a RITual of seemingly unbounded possibilities, a nirvana... a sheer utopia perhaps, of learning. When the Ritwik was in the room, Classroom 705 turned into a Citadel of higher thought, a true intellectual haven. Each section was a symphony in its own right. Each lemma, example, and proposition was a separate element that combined and complemented each other in ways initially unclear, perhaps even contradictory to the senses. But only as time progressed, with the mystery of local asymptotics and "Bayesian Statistics" slowly unravelling, did one finally understand the true genius of Ritwik. Like a composer, or perhaps the coy mystery novelist, the Ritwik dangled the plot's conclusion forth of the student in a display of agonizing suspense. Only approaching the ringing of the bell did Ritwik reveal the connections and relations of each separate lemma and proposition, allowing the coalescence of each component to fuse into a glorious creation whose value is truly worth more than the sum of its parts. In this sense, the Ritwik's sections can only be compared to the greatest of human artforms: Rachmaninoff's 2nd, the Mona Lisa perhaps, and surely the myriad remakes of John WIcK movies.If the sections were the orchestra hall, then the office hours were the place of salvation. The "homework" assigned were tasks of Herculean proportions, but Ritwik was Hercules. The problems fell under his glance and cowered amid a swift slash of chalk. Their only remainder being the gentle sprinkling of chalkdust that fell gently to the ground, like the lingering mist after a summer storm. He was the beacon guiding us through the fog of ignorance towards truth; without his light, perhaps we would never have made it out of the mist, doomed to drift forever amidst the waves of unintellectualism.Here concludes the telling of the tales of Ritwik. But alas, why do I try? Try as I may, my words are but a loathsome depiction of the glorious truth. After all, how can the words of a man describe the musings of a God?
worse_comment: The 24 hour exams are brutal
subject: Statistics

course_title:
Topics in high-dimensional statistics: methods
from statistical physics 001
best_comment: I knew replicas and other stat phys techniques, but this course helps me deeply understand what they are doing, with a specific concentration on spiked SK model (or MLE or Bayesian estimator in stat view point) for a long time in this class. Now I am confident in reading many replica–related machine–learning papers in recent days, which is a great gain for me. Also, as an advanced course, the workload after class is not too much. Thanks the course staffs for this wonderful course!
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Professor Liu is a strict but amazing teacher. I will highly recommend everyone to take the class; I have learnt so much from it! I think the biggest takeaway to succeed in the class is to actually go to office hours and not be afraid to raise questions or suggestions. Professor Liu is one of the most open–minded professors I have met in the school, and I am extremely grateful to get to learn more from him. The course materials are not extremely difficult, but it requires dedication and effort to understand. I realize some students might complain about the difficulties etc, but most of the time, these students never attend lectures, nor do they go to office hours, and come on, this is a graduate class.  All in all, I think Professor Liu is an amazing lecturer, and I have personally learnt a lot from this course, and sincerely think the materials taught in the class is extremely useful.
worse_comment: As someone who has taken many stat courses and enjoyed almost every one of them, Harvard truly has an amazing stat department. Jun Liu is really nice, but unfortunately, this course is the exception. If you need a Bayesian course, this is perhaps the only statistics topic where I would highly encourage you to look down the road to MIT. Note that my response may be somewhat biased to discovering I do not like Bayesian inference (though I did believe I would enjoy Bayesian inference before this course!). Pros of this course:1. You get simulation and modeling practiceCons of this course:1. Lectures are unengaging2. The course is disorganized3. Problem sets consist of problems taken straight from the BDA book. These problems are (1) vague and hard to approach without office hours, (2) often not pedagogical, and (3) often computational and felt like it was a waste of time. 4. Weekly problem sets with varying length5. Problem set feedback comes so late and then you’re surprised you were deducted for random points (that were not clear needed to be addressed) on a problem set you did a month ago (and which you might have lost points for multiple times because of vagueness).6. The pacing is really off. We spend over a month reviewing 110 and 111 (in a graduate course...) before moving on to other topics (which then are unfortunately not taught well).tldr; this class is a lot of pain for not much gain. Take at your own risk.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Deep Statistics: AI and Earth Observations for Sustainable Development 001
best_comment: The class is very free–flowing in the best of ways. Many topics that you may never have considered in data science are studied through real–world publications, and the homework assignments are designed to effectively test your interpretations of these topics. After taking the course, I really feel I understand a lot more about "how the sausage is made" when it comes to data science
subject: Statistics

course_title: Design of Experimental and Non-experimental Studies 001
best_comment: Amazing experience. In the top 2 courses I've taken in the stats department. Most weeks, you'll have very little work (just reading). For the two weeks that you are a presenter, you'll put in many hours, but probably get a lot out of it. Jose creates a wonderful seminar atmosphere. He will also provide direct feedback about your presentations, which is helpful (and unfortunately rare). I ended the course with a paper that I'm excited to continue working on.

course_title: The Art and Practice of Teaching Statistics 001
subject: Statistics

course_title: The Art and Practice of Teaching Statistics 001
subject: Statistics

course_title: Building a Human Body: From Gene to Cell to Organism 001
best_comment: If you took SCRB10, this is the natural next step and rightfully so, and I can say that as someone who tookSCRB10. The class is a very easygoing as long as you set time to watch the pre–lecture videos (and I mean actually watch them… don’t just let them play in the background) and start the take home tests in advance. Starting the tests early is very helpful since it gives you time to attend office hours, and the work can easily pile up on the weekend if you delay it. Office hours/asking questions are really big determinants of your success in this course.One somewhat cheesy note: please take the time to enjoy this class. Amie and her team put so much effort into making the class fun, but what that means is that you may feel tempted to blow off lecture and just complete your assignments without giving much thought to the material. Don’t. This class is designed to inspire you and push you towards advancing the field of biology—if you come into lecture with a thirst to learn and ask questions (especially HSCI faculty are speaking), you’ll get more than just a good grade—you’ll gain inspiration and a desire to achieve a high–level of excellence in biology. Don’t pass up on the many opportunities you have to find your passion in this class.
worse_comment: Take LS2. Previous q scores might have said this class is better, but they have changed it. It is not. The assessments are ridiculously hard, even though they are take home. CAs are inaccessible and TFs want nothing to do with you or your questions. Grading is very hard even when the whole class does poorly, there is no curve. Labs are so boring but relatively easy. the research proposal final is also very hard and you have little to no guidance. Amy is nice but is constantly angry that we are doing poorly in the class and that attendance is low (lectures are so boring). take it if you have to i suppose.
best_gem_comment: If you don't like microbio and are not interested in lab stuff around microbio but need a premed req filled, take ls2. I appreciated what i learned, but originally took scrb50 bc it was supposed to be a gem. That wasn't the case, and i wished i took ls2 because it's hard but at least you learn anatomy. If you end up taking the class, start the assessments early and work with a lot of people. Check the slides because they help with answering questions.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: Great course! Super interesting material for anyone remotely interested in biotech, healthcare, and medicine! I learned so much from this class.
worse_comment: Very participation heavy. If you don’t like to speak in lecture, don’t take this course. If you do, this is for you. Little to no assignments but heavy participation. Would not really recommend overall.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: this is an amazing class! the subject matter is really interesting and unique– you won't find any other class at Harvard that's teaching reproductive biology. The teaching staff id also great, you can tell they really care about the well being and thoughts of their students. The assignments weren't bad at all either, and were mainly used as a learning opportunity or us. I liked how we didn't have lecture every class, and instead how sometimes we had guest speakers come and speak about interesting topics.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

course_title: A World of RNA: An RNA-centric view of life 01
best_comment: Take the class if you're interested in RNA research, Prof. Flynn is super nice and responsive. It's simply an invaluable experience to just chat about random research questions and ideas with him.
worse_comment: The expectations are unclear for the final projectDisparity in undergrad vs grad participation
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

course_title: Stem Cell Therapeutics: Exploring the science and the patient experience 01
best_comment: Hands down, the BEST course at Harvard. Every week during lecture, a new physician provides an overview of our weekly topic/disease (which just so happens to be their specialty) along with a discussion of how stem cells can be leveraged to treat this disease. Afterwards, a patient with that particular disease shares their experiences living with the disease and how the treatment process is like for them (we also have ample time to ask the patient questions). In this way, this course covers a broad range of specialities within medicine and stem cell therapeutics in addition to the BEST THING THAT THIS COURSE HAS TO OFFER, which of course, is its weekly patient perspectives. As a result, class is SUPER exciting and you'll never want to skip lecture!
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: It's not a terribly difficult class, just get through it.
worse_comment: Do not let your PQE topic be restricted to the topics taught in this class, and do not delay coming up with a PQE idea based on this class schedule–– do your own external learning, because 1) having more time to hone your idea (not work on it necessarily, but think about it in depth) will be very useful2) the class doesn't go over all quantitative methods that might be relevant for it3) the class won't go into enough detail about the topic for it to be enough of a primer to use the method (won't help you implement it, except potentially ODEs)Be your own judge for how much energy is worth putting into this class versus your PQE and your rotations–– personally, I put my rotations before this class because rotations/choosing a lab impacts the next 5 years more. Only near the end did it conflict with my PQE, so that was not a big issue, but I did once struggle to balance PQE final submission with the final problemset.

best_comment: If you are serious about building a venture and want the support of Harvard behind you, then please take this class. I learned so so much and met wonderful students and guest lecturers. This was a wonderful class to end my undergraduate career!
worse_comment: Great course to have time to work on your starutp, but 9 am to 11:45 am schedule is a little brutal.
subject: Creativity and Entrepreneurshi

course_title: Bodies and the Metaverse: Performing "The Singularity Play" 001
best_comment: This course was amazing for me. Jay and Keenan were just incredible and the play itself was just beautiful. I loved my cast mates and I really enjoyed every rehearsal and performance. I'll miss it greatly! I know this course changes instructors and play each year, so for future students I can only say I hope you get lucky enough to have as wonderful instructors and content as this year's course. The class itself is a large time commitment, not so much in the beginning of the semester but it ramps up a lot by the end. But hey, that's theater! That's tech week! I loved this play and the chance to work on something professionally produced as a non–professional actor was just incredible.
worse_comment: One if not the best production studio at Harvard! Keenan and Jay are incredible instructors and collaborators, don't ever miss a chance to work with them!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Bodies and the Metaverse: Performing "The Singularity Play" 001

worse_comment: One if not the best production studio at Harvard! Keenan and Jay are incredible instructors and collaborators, don't ever miss a chance to work with them!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: LROD is the absolute best, kindest, most supportive, inspiring dance teacher i've ever had. take anything with them. this class changed how i think about movement and my body. it was so incredible to do a production, tech week was one of my favorite weeks of the semester, it took a bit for us dancers to get close but when tech week came we all got really tight. lovely and i love them. so so cool to have a real production team–– a world renowned costume designer, lighting, stage design, everything. i'm so grateful! LROD has so much knowledge as a dancer and teacher and is one of my favorite people i've ever met
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Foundational Concepts in Theater, Dance & Media 001
best_comment: Make friends with everyone in the class to maximize your fun. New York is a great time to do this!Also be sure to actually do the readings. Section gets very in–depth on them! And make sure to put effort and thought into your blog posts ahead of time. There is no such thing as a throwaway assignment in this class. Best of luck!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Foundational Concepts in Theater, Dance & Media 001
best_comment: Make friends with everyone in the class to maximize your fun. New York is a great time to do this!Also be sure to actually do the readings. Section gets very in–depth on them! And make sure to put effort and thought into your blog posts ahead of time. There is no such thing as a throwaway assignment in this class. Best of luck!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: Take this course!! It is an incredible opportunity to be able to work on projects that align with the productions being staged at the A.R.T. and Ryan is so supportive! If you have any interest in theater, you will love this class!

I learned so much not only about the craft of acting in this class but about how I personally relate to characters and how I express myself onstage. The teachers, Johnny and Wes, were easily the best teachers I've had at Harvard. They care, they're funny and playful and direct. They are focused. They play off of each other so well. Every minute of our 2 hours and 45 min was milked for all the info they could give us!
worse_comment: Be open minded.Be willing to explore.This class can deeply change you.It’s not a lot of work, and you only get one “workshop” a week.Don’t miss it.

best_comment: Take this course if you are at all interested in improving your acting! You will get out of this class exactly what you put in. I spent a lot of time and effort in finding material, memorizing it, and practicing it, which meant this was actually one of my more stressful classes but it meant that I got so much out of this class and feel like I have really grown as an actor. Getting constant feedback on your acting and getting to use interesting techniques was so meaningful to me and the community of the class was so supportive and great. Couldn't recommend this class enough if you are at all interested in acting and getting constant opportunities to work on acting!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: REMO IS REMARKABLE! Truly one of the best professor's I've had at this institution. You'd be remiss not to take his classes, most especially this one. Each day, I managed to learn so so much not only from Remo and James (our incredible TF), but also from my wonderfully talented classmates. I felt my own understandings of the texts strengthen as we explored them deeply in class, (especially with my minimal knowledge of Shakespeare outside of English classrooms) and the scanning and acting techniques I learned truly improved my own capabilities as an actor. I'm so sad that we're finished now, but it was truly so wonderful to be able to grow and learn with such an incredible group of students <3 Please please please TAKE THIS CLASS if you have the opportunity to!! You won't regret it!! I didn't :)

Take this class!!!! It is super interesting and super useful no matter your concentration! Erika is an amazing professor, and all of the in class activities are a lot of fun! You will learn a lot about how to be more effective when speaking text!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: This class is great. Kate is a great professor, and the time commitment outside of class is pretty low. We even got to see Hamilton as a class for free, and think about how physical theater manifests in big productions like that. No prior acting experience required, and it's just a really fun time. Also definitely easy to take as an extra just–for–fun 5th class!

Take this class!!! I had never directed before, but this class really got me out of my comfort zone in a way that felt supported and safe. It is definitely a significant amount of work, but I felt like it was worth it to get the experience of directing multiple projects. It is a lot of fun!

Syllabus gets pretty fuzzy, so I'll just say exactly what this version of the class was. The structure seems like it might change if the class is offered again, so take with a grain of salt:–– First few weeks of the class were half English, half TDM. We read/watched The Exorcist and did presentations on certain aspects of it, and we would also have a speaker come most weeks to teach us something about theater, usually in a hands–on way. –– Last few weeks of the class were based around performances. We were put in small groups to make mini theatrical pieces that related to the exorcist in some way.  After the first one,  groups were shuffled and we made a new piece.  Over the last month, we would perform this new piece, get comments for how to improve it, and make those improvements for the following week until the final class.For people thinking about taking this class, I'd say that the first half is generally very good. Second half is much more of a toss–up, depending on how OK you are with making a theatrical piece with varying levels of guidance and then performing it several times and working with the same small group of people over the course of a month.
worse_comment: Take this class if you like horror, but not just horror movies – the history of performing horror and performance theory are discussed and can be difficult to understand to beginners. It's not just for people who like the movie...!

course_title: Uncovering Form: Uncovering bodily forms through the modular lenses of flesh, memory, site, history 001
best_comment: Take this class if you're interested in dance or movement at all! It's really interesting, and getting to work with Sidra is wonderful.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE Jeffrey is amazing. He is a bold personality when we are actually dancing and warming up in class––he will get you hyped and yell at you (with lots of tough love).  Aside from the big energy when we are dancing, he is very gentle and kind and amazing to talk to. I had never done any dance class prior to this and could not have had a more fun, enthusiastic, and welcoming introduction. I feel more flexible and aware of my own body after this class. Learning about the history and meaning of koteba and the traditions of the region enriched the class and meaning of the dance greatly. We started each class with a discussion recapping that weeks discussion post which was nice. I still do the warm ups I learned in class throughout the week and in the gym. Jeffrey really encourages you to learn how to pick back up where you fell off and never be defeated when you cannot get a dance. You will get out what you put into this class and Jeffrey puts his all as well. The final project allowed us to put together what we learned and just have fun dancing with others in a group.
best_gem_comment: This class is a lot of physical work, but truly a gem besides the soreness and sweat.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: Jeff and Amanda are super fun. It feels less like a class and more like a fun learning club with fantastic mentors. Go ahead and try something new! They'll be happy to help you.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: This course is so much fun! Even if you're not a designer of any kind, this course makes costume design fun and approachable. If you're willing to dedicate the time it takes to design, and are even remotely interested in the beauty of costume design, this class is for you!
This is a wonderful course that truly helps expand your idea of art–making. If I had the chance to take it again I would. Highly recommend!

This class is very fun without being too much work. You get a lot of freedom when it comes to what your final podcast looks like, and it's mainly just up to you to put into this class what you aim to get out of it.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! tania is one of the absolute best professors at harvard and one of the most exciting artists today. it's CRAZY that i had the opportunity to take a class with her, i feel so grateful to know her and she is so kind and helpful to students. one of my favorite people. the assignments are fun and difficult because you have to get so into it to get anything out of the course. BUY IN. rachel is wonderful, so organized, the best tf. take anything you can with tania but especially this class.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! No questions asked. Don't even ask "what's the difference between performance and performance art?" because you'll figure that part out – and in my opinion, it's better that you don't know the difference, so your world can be torn apart, and then you can rebuild it.

course_title: Intersections: Theater, Democracy and Civic Practice 1
best_comment: Honestly, you NEED this course. I’ve never taken a TDM class or explored the arts before, and this class was my first entry point. Leah and Dayton are so so good at building honest community through check ins and encouraging everyone’s reactions to be grounded in their experiences. They also are TOP TIER at hyping you up so that you feel like you’re really into something unique and new. I’ve loved this class so much and would take it again 100x over.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Collective Freedom Dreaming: Engaged Pedagogy and Radical Love as Praxis 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Pour into it and engage with your classmates and Dr. Bell. You will not regret it.

course_title: The Ritual of Breath is the Rite to Resist Social Impact 001
best_comment: Definitely take it! It's challenging work, but super rewarding. Your work will directly impact the community, and it's an opportunity you truly won't get anywhere else!
TAKE THIS CLASS. Dr. Light and Kirin are the BEST! Study WGS!
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Tutorial - Junior Year: Research and Methods 001
best_comment: Take this class if you are at all considering thesis–ing in WGS or if you want a supportive mentor in doing an independent WGS research project! I am leaving the semester with the conclusion that I will likely not thesis (just because I want more breadth not depth from my senior year, and a thesis will take away from that experience of exploring more), but I am not AT ALL regretful of completing the WGS junior tutorial because it helped me learn 1) how to conduct independent WGS work 2) was an opportunity to just read a lot about a topic i really care so much about 3) Learned that I don't want to thesis in the meantime. Even if I don't thesis this was a chance to do like a mini thesis (think like one chapter's worth of work) and if that's all you want but don't want to commit to a thesis, this was still a solid v chill way to experience that process!
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Worlds of Wonder?: Social Constructions of Childhood through Children’s Literature 001
best_comment: Loved this course! Very interesting material and conversations throughout the semester, especially with the student–led presentations. Definitely reading–heavy some weeks though. The workload was manageable, but most importantly, I felt like they were all relevant and engaging; it was really nice going to the Children's Museum and doing my own archival work in Schlesinger. Professor Bronski and Kirin were both extremely kind, knowledgeable, and accessible. I loved learning from them and being in this class this semester.

I really hope that this class is as amazing with the next professor as it was with this one. The reading list was carefully designed, and we had rich conversation right up to the bell during every single week. I truly learned SO much in this class and found myself looking forward to our Tuesday 'book club sessions.' This class is chill in the sense that there isn't a lot of required work, but time–consuming in the sense that this is the class you'll WANT to spend more time on. Please take this class. It's also great if you're thesising soon because you'll learn more about what makes a strong thesis.

course_title: Women's Voices in Asian and Asian American Literature 001
best_comment: This has been my FAVORITE class that I've taken at Harvard!!! Professor Choi is an AMAZING teacher, and you can tell that she really, really, really cares about her students. I've never met an educator who is as invested in her students' success as she is. She meets with you one–on–one multiple times throughout the semester to check–in on your progress in the class — but also just to get to know you more as a student and as a person. She creates a really welcoming, safe environment for her students that allows us to engage in fruitful conversations. Through this class, I got to interact with texts I would have never had the chance to read otherwise. Professor Choi chooses our readings meticulously, and I feel like I learned something valuable from every assignment. The midterm and final projects were also rewarding in how personal we could make them. This class also helped me develop a deeper understanding of my own identity.If you're thinking about taking this class, DO IT! You won't regret it.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Leaning In, Hooking Up: Visions of Feminism and Femininity in the 21st Century 001
best_comment: Take this class!!!!!! The professor is absolutely amazing and cares so much about the students. Not only will you learn so much, but you'll get to interact with concepts/topics that you never really have to chance to encounter in your other classes. This class has truly felt like a safe space. I had never felt so stimulated and intrigued by lectures in a Harvard course before having taken this class. If you're a WGS concentrator or secondary, definitely take this class. Grades are very very reasonable ;) Even if you have no connection to WGS, but still want to take a really dope class to get some credits and feel super engaged, still take this class!
worse_comment: If your boyfriend says "I don't think you should be taking the feminism class. It's just making you unnecessarily anxious," you should take that as a RED FLAG and SCRAM because it shows he does not actually understand feminism and it would mean an exhausting lifetime of educating him if you stayed. This class covers a wide range of topics to give a thorough introduction to feminism, but it can seem a little surface–level to people who are already connected to this content, whether through other classes or social media.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Gender, Race, and Poverty in the United States 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! As a person living in the US, it is everyone's responsibility to learn about poverty– how it affects different people, how prevalent it is, and how to reduce it. The intersectional lens of gender and race added a necessary and wonderful element to this class, and it humanized the readings in a great way. We also listened to lots of podcasts! Dr. Mtshali is a brilliant, intelligent, wonderful lecturer and sociologist. Sara is the best TF and so so knowledgeable about social issues. The workload is reasonable and the content is very interesting.
worse_comment: You should take this class no matter what your lived experience or understanding of poverty is! Especially if have never experienced poverty, you will be exposed to a lot of eye–opening knowledge.

best_comment: This class was wonderful! I am a WGS concentrator, but had never taken a writing class before. I was nervous about the workshop structure and sharing my work with my classmates, but it was such a supportive and constructive environment. I learned so much about myself as a writer and really enjoyed seeing other people's work too. Would definitely recommend! Zero reservations!

course_title: Live Theory (and Practice): A Graduate Proseminar in WGS Studies 001
best_comment: Take it as early as you can, it will provide you with valuable tools and a great overview.
